All academic policies and registration deadlines apply. Directed Independent Study courses cannot substitute for General University Requirements and are not eligible for tuition waiver.

A/HI 301.course_description: Survey and critical analysis of modernist, theory and criticism.

A/HI 302.course_description: Assist faculty in the classroom and with activities such as lecture preparation, class website upkeep, classroom discussion, research, and reviews for exams. Duties vary by course and instructor, but the time commitment will be 3-9 hours/week.

A/HI 305.course_description: Emphasis on art preparation/installation methods, gallery/collections management, and museum education/public programming. Students must commit to registering for this class for fall, winter and spring quarter. Repeatable to a maximum of 9 credits, including original course. Intended as a resume building class. Credits may not be used for the Art History major or minor.

A/HI 306.course_description: Internship at museum, educational or public arts organization under the direction of a designated art history faculty member, in consultation with a staff member of the host institution. Intended as a resume building class. Credits may not be used for the art history major or minor. Repeatable to a maximum of 9 credits, including original course.

A/HI 308.course_description: A hands-on class designed to give students a practical experience in promotion of visual culture in the community.

A/HI 310.course_name: Indigenous Arts of the Pacific Northwest
A/HI 310.course_description: Selected topics in the arts of the Pacific Northwest. Includes discussion of contemporary artists.

A/HI 313.course_description: Critical approaches to the study of artistic practices based on visual technology. Topics may include: photography, film, video, computer-generated art and electronic media.

A/HI 315.course_name: Early Modern Civic Identity: Special Topics
A/HI 315.course_description: Civic identity explored through ritual structures, urban society, and lay cultures. Repeatable with different topics. Can be repeated once as an elective with different topics.

A/HI 316.course_description: Studies of landscape and ideology in painting and garden design; issues of environment in the production of visual culture; relationships of land and architecture.

A/HI 330.course_name: Art and Texts of the Sacred
A/HI 330.course_description: The ideological basis of painting, sculpture and manuscript illumination as tools of communication. The interdependence of textual and visual traditions and their subversion or alteration.

A/HI 335.course_name: Visual Arts in the Age of Contact, Exploration, and Colonization
A/HI 335.course_description: This course explores artistic responses to the unprecedented clash and integration of cultures resulting from exploration and the consequent expansion of European empires throughout the world in its earliestphase, ca. 1492 to 1700.

A/HI 336.course_name: Visual Arts of Medieval Iberia and Early Modern Spain
A/HI 336.course_description: This upper-lever lecture course explores the arts produced in the Iberian Peninsula and the domains of the Spanish Empire at large. Topics may include: Visigothic and Islamic conquests, Medieval architecture and painting, the rise and fall of the Spanish Empire in Europe and abroad during El Siglo de Oro, and the artistic impact of the Enlightenment.

A/HI 348.course_description: This cross-disciplinary course examines how our natural environment is conceptualized in art, science and media. Through lectures, collaborative projects and experiential learning, students engage with historic debates associated with discoveries in natural science and current controversies on climate change, ecology and biodiversity.

A/HI 358.course_description: Examines postwar American culture, from 1950 to 1970, and critically assesses the relationships between art, popular media and the social upheavals of the postwar era.

A/HI 360.course_name: Nationalism and Cultural Identity, 19th and 20th Centuries
A/HI 360.course_description: Studies in the relationship between ideas of nation and the formation of cultural identity.

A/HI 368.course_description: Art of Melanesia, Polynesia, Micronesia. Includes study of contemporary Pacific arts.

A/HI 370.course_description: Topics addressing historical and contemporary Islamic visual cultures in the Middle East, Africa, and Asia.

A/HI 371.course_name: Transforming Traditions: Art and Visual Culture in Japan
A/HI 371.course_description: Study of visual cultures in Japan from 5000 BCE to present. Analysis of cultural influx and assimilation from Asia and Europe as well as indigenous and individual visual expressions. Also offered as EAST 371.

A/HI 372.course_description: This course will examine film practice in one or more Asian countries with an emphasis on narrative construction and stylistic techniques. Repeatable to a maximum of 10 credits under different topics, including original course.

A/HI 375.course_description: Methodological approaches to the study of Art History and further development of writing skills and visual analysis.

A/HI 381.course_description: This course explores the ways in which African art confirms, legitimizes, and challenges authority on a local, national, and global level.

A/HI 383.course_name: Contemporary Art of the African Diaspora (WWII to present)
A/HI 383.course_description: This course explores the creative practices of artists of African descent who live and work beyond the continent, from World War II to the present.

A/HI 385.course_description: This course explores the creative practices and primary themes of African film directors, both on the continent and in the diaspora.

A/HI 388.course_description: This course will address the history and theory of museums, while simultaneously introducing students to contemporary museum practices and various aspects of museum work. In addition to critically examining the development of the institution of the museum in the United States, the course will also consider the ways societies have collected, classified, and displayed knowledge and material culture throughout time. Through readings, discussions and sessions with museum professionals, students will gain knowledge and understanding of the nature of museums, the work that they do, and the dynamics at play, both within the institution and within their larger communities.

A/HI 391.course_description: Advanced lecture course focused on specialized topics in the history of art. Repeatable with different topics to a maximum of 15 credits, including the original course.

A/HI 396.course_name: Summer Art History Program in Japan
A/HI 396.course_description: Study traditional and contemporary culture in Japan.  Activities include: visiting historical sites, galleries, museums and artist studios.  Experience a tea ceremony, papermaking, weaving, natural dyeing and more.  Students will write a paper following the trip. Offered summer quarter only.

A/HI 400.course_description: An individualized course of study not available through or replacing existing curriculum, to be arranged between one matriculating student and sponsoring faculty member. All academic policies and registration deadlines apply. Directed Independent Study courses cannot substitute for General University Requirements and are not eligible for tuition waiver.

A/HI 401.course_description: Theoretical analysis of late twentieth century postmodernist art and culture, and critical discussion of the expansion of visual media during the contemporary era.

A/HI 411.course_description: Examines Japanese artistic forms and visual culture from Post-World War II until the present. Explores connections between Japanese socioeconomic and artistic developments, as well as visual manifestations of contemporary Japanese youth culture. Topics include anime, manga, Harajuku fashion and art movements such as Gutai and Superflat. Also offered as EAST 411.

A/HI 413.course_description: Theoretical and cultural analysis of the history of representing space within Western art and architecture, from Gothic cathedrals and Renaissance perspective to cubist fractured surfaces and contemporary heterogeneous space.

A/HI 415.course_description: Topics in urban organization, urban/rural dynamics, regionalism, spaces and social production in the built environment and the arts.

A/HI 416.course_name: Topics in Global Borders and Contested Terrains
A/HI 416.course_description: Mapping artistic domains; implications of geographic borders; defining places and margins in cultural production.

A/HI 430.course_name: European Sacred Art and Theological Aesthetics
A/HI 430.course_description: This seminar focuses on Western sacred artworks and theological aesthetic theories. Topics may include, amongst others: devotional images, popular images, the educational role of images in liturgy, pilgrimage churches, reliquiaries, the performativity of icons, or the effects of the Protestand reformation and subsequent Catholic reformation.

A/HI 431.course_description: Studies in topics such as collecting, pilgrimage, touring and acquisition of the authentic.

A/HI 434.course_description: This seminar presents a study of Rococo art and culture, giving gravity to the period’s aesthetic levity and taking seriously its playfulness. Topics explored will include Rococo painting, the sociopolitical status of women, the new male archetype and its critics, libertine and erotic literature, philosophies of freedom, identity as performance, and utopian visions on the brink of the French Revolution.

A/HI 438.course_description: Studies past and present visual practices, and how they engage with cultural representations of gender, sex, and sexuality, along with their interconnections to class and race. Course topics may include self-fashioning and performativity, portraiture and identity, patronage and matronage, the body as political, intersectionality, women painters in the Academy, feminism and femininity, nuns as divine artists, queer theory, and/or transgender and gender non-conforming artists. Specific geographic areas and time periods covered in the course may vary.

A/HI 440.course_description: Theoretical and critical approaches to the development of cyberspace and its relationship to new media, electronic art, virtual reality, videogames, and biotech art.

A/HI 446.course_description: A seminar on aesthetics and art theory. Possible topics may include: definitions of art; Renaissance theories of perspective; Romanticism and the sublime; theories of viewership; phenomenology; post-structuralism; critical theory.

A/HI 447.course_name: Art in the Public Sphere: Laws, Markets, Policy
A/HI 447.course_description: This course presents a study of core questions framing the encounter between artists and the public sphere, exploring the moral, civic, and legal status and responsibilities of artists in relationship to political authorities, legal systems, and the art market.

A/HI 450.course_description: Analysis of how visual culture has been colonized and, increasingly, decolonized, with a focus on how power dynamics operate through visual forms. Readings focus on specific examples, with postcolonial theory, critical race theory, and queer theory providing frameworks for students to build their own analyses.

A/HI 451.course_name: African Textiles: Shaping Culture through Cloth
A/HI 451.course_description: This course focuses on the textiles arts of the African continent and its diaspora, which have been historically overlooked and underappreciated in Western academia. In this course we will give the textile arts careful and detailed study not just for their formal properties and technical achievements, but for the economic, social, political, religious, performative, and other roles they play in the communities that make and use them.

A/HI 475.course_description: Final course for art history majors. May be a research project aimed toward the pursuit of an advanced degree or a practicum in one of several careers in arts advocacy, administration, community outreach, and other fields.

A/HI 489.course_description: Examines museum architecture and the exhibition of architecture in museums in Europe and America from the eighteenth century to the present.

A/HI 490.course_description: Seminar on issues such as the display of visual experience and the configuration of public culture and community identities by artists, institutions and audiences. Repeatable to a maximum of 10 credits, including original course.

A/HI 491.course_description: In-depth seminar course on a specific topic.  Repeatable with different topics to a maximum of 15 credits, including the original course.

AUAP 001.course_description: Development of communicative English through the practice of listening, speaking, reading, and writing skills.

AUAP 002.course_name: Test of English for International Communication (TOEIC) Exam Preparation
AUAP 002.course_description: Development of English language skills and test taking strategies to prepare for the TOEIC.

AUAP 009.course_description: Introduction and analysis of topics related to English language learning. Repeatable with various topics with no maximum.

AUAP 010.course_description: Investigation of social, political, and cultural developments in American society.

AUAP 011.course_description: Discussion of social, political, and cultural developments in American society.

AUAP 019.course_description: Introduction and analysis of topics related to cultural studies. Repeatable with various topics with no maximum.

AUAP 020.course_description: Development of communication skills in English for a variety of social, survival, and intercultural settings. Students learn functional English language patterns and vocabulary through presentation, practice, and application.

AUAP 021.course_description: Investigation of global issues including sustainability related to population, consumption, and the environment; poverty and equity; and conflict.

AUAP 029.course_description: Introduction and analysis of topics related to issues of communication. Repeatable with various topics with no maximum.

AUAP 031.course_description: Introduction to resources, services, and activities for living and studying abroad.

AUAP 032.course_description: Exploration of career exploration process. Overview of workplace and business English.

AUAP 039.course_description: Introduction, analysis, and application related to issues of experiential learning. Repeatable with various topics with no maximum.

ASTR 103.course_description: A survey of astronomy including stars, galactic structure and cosmology. Not recommended for science, math or computer science majors.

ASTR 113.course_description: Introduction to the Solar System. Topics include the motion of objects in the sky, seasons, phases of the Moon and eclipses, and the properties of the Sun, planets, and moons with discussion of recent results from space missions. Some class sessions will be held in the planetarium. Open to all students.

ASTR 300.course_description: An individualized course of study not available through or replacing existing curriculum, to be arranged between one matriculating student and sponsoring faculty member. All academic policies and registration deadlines apply. Directed Independent Study courses cannot substitute for General University Requirements and are not eligible for tuition waiver.

ASTR 315.course_description: Introduction to the modern physical understanding of the Solar System. Topics include gravity, orbits, the formation of stars and planets, planetary atmospheres and surfaces, physical processes in the Solar System.

ASTR 316.course_description: Observational evidence of the nature of stars; star formation and star death; structure and kinematics of the Milky Way and other galaxies.

ASTR 320.course_description: Large-scale structure of the universe; black holes and active galaxies; curved spacetime; evolution of the expanding universe; the Big Bang and the early universe.

ASTR 400.course_description: An individualized course of study not available through or replacing existing curriculum, to be arranged between one matriculating student and sponsoring faculty member. All academic policies and registration deadlines apply. Directed Independent Study courses cannot substitute for General University Requirements and are not eligible for tuition waiver.

ASTR 416.course_description: Application of physics to stars, nebulae and galaxies. Radiation; atomic spectra and chemical abundances in stellar atmospheres and gaseous nebulae; nuclear synthesis in stars; stellar evolution.

BNS 194.course_description: A course for College Quest students only. Emphasizes the relationship between brain structure/function and behavior through lecture and lab. S/U grading.

BNS 195.course_description: An introduction to the role of the nervous system in normal and abnormal behavior, thought, and emotion. S/U grading.

BNS 300.course_description: An individualized course of study not available through or replacing existing curriculum, to be arranged between one matriculating student and sponsoring faculty member. All academic policies and registration deadlines apply. Directed Independent Study courses cannot substitute for General University Requirements and are not eligible for tuition waiver.

BNS 301.course_description: An introduction to experimental design in neuroscience and coverage of the appropriate statistics analysis of neuroscience data.

BNS 302.course_description: Experimental design and writing in behavioral neuroscience.

BNS 305.course_description: This class provides a cellular and molecular understanding of central nervous system function. The physiology of neural cells will be stressed, from the ionic basis of membrane currents and synaptic physiology, to the unique challenges of neuronal cell biology. The genetic basis of normal and abnormal neurophysiology will be discussed.

BNS 306.course_description: Theoretical and empirical exploration of how different neural structures interact with one another to form functional circuits that transduce, analyze and integrate sensory information, assess that information with the context of current need and past experience, and then generate the neural activity that underlies learning and memory, attention, reward, decision-making, reasoning, executive functions, and emotions.

BNS 327.course_description: Introduction to laboratory methods and techniques used in cognitive neuroscience. Concentration will be on large scale brain imaging of cognition using EEG. Students will collect and analyze data from participants undergoing a broad range of cognitive paradigms.

BNS 328.course_description: Introduction to laboratory methods and techniques used in behavioral neuroscience. Two hours lecture and four hours lab each week; students will be introduced to basic techniques in histology, neurophysiology, neurochemistry, molecular biology, or behavioral analyses. May require live animal research. Repeatable to a maximum of 8 credits, including the original course.

BNS 400.course_description: An individualized course of study not available through or replacing existing curriculum, to be arranged between one matriculating student and sponsoring faculty member. All academic policies and registration deadlines apply. Directed Independent Study courses cannot substitute for General University Requirements and are not eligible for tuition waiver.

BNS 401.course_description: A detailed examination of how behavior emerges from the function of the brain with a focus on neurophysiological mechanisms. Learning is based upon review and discussion of current literature in the field of behavioral neuroscience. The specific topic under investigation may vary depending on who teaches the class.

BNS 428.course_description: Laboratory based study of integrated neural systems underlying behavior, based on advanced techniques in histology, neurophysiology, neurochemistry, molecular biology, or behavioral analyses. Two hours lecture and four hours lab each week; may require live animal research. Repeatable to a maximum of 8 credits, including the original course.

BIOL 101.course_description: Major ideas and processes of modern biological science at molecular, cellular, organismic and community levels; stressing qualitative and quantitative dimensions of the discipline in lecture, laboratory, field and discussion settings. Lab included. Intended for non-science majors.

BIOL 102.course_description: A consideration of biodiversity; adaptations and life cycles of plants and animals; organismal biology; science as a way of knowing; the relevance of the above-mentioned topics for the educated citizen. Lecture, discussion, field and lab included.

BIOL 140.course_name: The Ecology and Economics of Salmon Recovery
BIOL 140.course_description: Focus on the 4 causes of salmon decline (Habitat, Hydropower, Harvest, and Hatcheries) to investigate the interactions between ecology and economics through lectures, reading and independent projects. Also offered as ECON 140.

BIOL 194.course_name: Ecology of Local Marine Habitats (College Quest)
BIOL 194.course_description: An examination of environmental and biological factors that affect the distribution, abundance, and diversity of marine organisms, using local marine habitats to examine ecological patterns. Open to College Quest students. S/U grading.

BIOL 195.course_description: A field-based introduction to marine biology for entering first-year students. S/U grading.

BIOL 204.course_name: Introduction to Evolution, Ecology and Biodiversity w/lab
BIOL 204.course_description: Introduction to evolutionary and ecological processes involved in the generation of our planet’s biodiversity, including review of patterns and processes that influence the origin, evolution, distribution, and abundance of living things. Lab included.

BIOL 205.course_name: Introduction to Cellular and Molecular Biology w/lab
BIOL 205.course_description: Structure and function of biomolecules and cells, membrane structure and function, photosynthesis and respiration, molecular origin of life, phylogenetic and metabolic diversity of prokaryotes, molecular genetics and genomics. Lab included.

BIOL 206.course_description: Study of the many ways that eukaryotic organisms perform basic functions and cope with varying environmental conditions. Phylogenetic organismal diversity and organ system structural and functional diversity will be studied in lecture and laboratory. Lab included.

BIOL 245.course_description: General microbiology with an emphasis on health related issues. Students will learn aseptic technique in lab and the characteristics of microbes that affect human health. Credits earned in this course cannot be applied towards a Biology degree. Lab included.

BIOL 300.course_description: An individualized course of study not available through or replacing existing curriculum, to be arranged between one matriculating student and sponsoring faculty member. All academic policies and registration deadlines apply. Directed Independent Study courses cannot substitute for General University Requirements and are not eligible for tuition waiver.

BIOL 321.course_description: Survey of classical genetics, molecular genetics and genomics in prokaryotic and eukaryotic organisms.

BIOL 322.course_description: Uses prokaryotic and eukaryotic model organisms to explore the fundamentals of genetics and the use of genetics as a tool for basic research. Includes lecture. Lab included.

BIOL 323.course_description: Cell structure and function.  Topics include:  protein structure and function, gene regulation, cell cycle, signal transduction, and organelle assembly and function.

BIOL 324.course_description: An introduction to widely used molecular biology techniques and laboratory skills. Lab included.

BIOL 325.course_description: Interactions between organisms and their environment, focusing on fundamental concepts in physiological, population, community, and ecosystem ecology.

BIOL 326.course_description: Introduction to ecological research, culminating in student-designed research projects. Written and oral presentation of projects. Lab included.

BIOL 327.course_description: This course covers the molecular flow of genetic information, including transcription, translation, DNA replication and repair, chromatin structure, and regulation of gene expression.

BIOL 328.course_description: This course covers eukaryotic cell structure and function; topics include protein sorting in organelles, cellular organization, cell signaling, growth regulation and mass and energy exchange across biomembranes.

BIOL 340.course_description: The design of biological experiments and appropriate statistical analysis of experimental data.

BIOL 345.course_description: Cell structure, metabolism, evolution and ecology of prokaryotes.

BIOL 346.course_description: Techniques of general microbiology, including isolation, culture, enumeration and identification of prokaryotes. Includes lecture. Lab included.

BIOL 348.course_description: Macroscopic and histological examination of human anatomical systems, and study of general neuromuscular and cardiopulmonary functions. Includes lab. Credits earned in this course cannot be applied towards a BA or BS in Biology, except for the BA and BS in Biology/Anthropology. Lab included.

BIOL 349.course_description: A comprehensive introduction to the study of integrated functions of cells, organs and organ systems in humans. Lab included.

BIOL 395.course_description: Participation in biology research under the direction of a biology professor. The experience may include assisting in the maintenance of experimental setup, data collection, data entry, literature searches, and developing graphics. Repeatable up to 6 credits, including original course.

BIOL 400.course_description: An individualized course of study not available through or replacing existing curriculum, to be arranged between one matriculating student and sponsoring faculty member. All academic policies and registration deadlines apply. Directed Independent Study courses cannot substitute for General University Requirements and are not eligible for tuition waiver.

BIOL 401.course_description: This course will explore some molecular mechanisms underlying the disease pathology of neurodegeneration, to give insight into how age, genes and risk factors may contribute to common cellular pathologies and diverse disease presentations.

BIOL 402.course_description: This course introduces materials and methods used to identify and delineate jurisdictional wetlands under the Army Corps of Engineers (Corps) 1987 Wetlands Delineation Manual and Corps Regional Supplements and is intended for anyone who is interested in wetland delineation such as biology or environmental science majors, land use planners, civil and environmental engineers, and biological/environmental consultants.  Students learn how to identify and delineate jurisdictional wetlands and understand and identify field indicators of hydrophytic vegetation, hydric soils, and wetland hydrology, as well as methods for disturbed and atypical wetlands, and recognizing difficult wetland situations as defined by the Corps, through lectures and “hands-on” field instruction. Skills learned in this course are applicable nationwide and satisfy requirements for basic wetland training as specified by the Corps. Lab included.

BIOL 403.course_description: Physiological and biochemical adaptations of animals to environmental factors. Marine environments are emphasized, but adaptations to fresh water and terrestrial conditions also are considered. Laboratories introduce research techniques which are then applied in student-designed independent research projects. Lab included.

BIOL 404.course_description: This course will explore the intrinsic connections between changes in development and the evolution of complex organisms. We will examine how aspects of development can promote or constrain evolutionary potential and explore why multicellular species are composed of groups of traits that develop and evolve together. We will also study the development of Evo-Devo as a field of study.

BIOL 405.course_description: Study of microbial communities in aquatic and terrestrial environments, with emphasis on the functional role of microbes in energy flow, nutrient cycling and element transformation. Overview of microbial interactions with eukaryotic hosts. Discussion of structure, genetics, and community on microbial communities. Offered in alternate years.

BIOL 406.course_description: Biological oceanography is the study of how organisms affect and are affected by the physics, chemistry, and geology of the oceanographic system. This course will provide a process-oriented view of marine pelagic ecosystems. Oceanographic processes covered in this course will include ocean circulation, biogeography, energetics, food webs, biogeochemical cycles, benthic-pelagic coupling, and plankton ecology.

BIOL 407.course_description: The structure and function of marine ecosystems with an emphasis on processes in shallow-water and benthic habitats. Investigative field and laboratory studies of local marine and estuarine systems. Lab included.

BIOL 408.course_description: Students will learn instrumentation and methodology for field research, and practice it in a field setting. Specifically, students will perform comparative investigations of three meso-habitats by measuring ecologically relevant parameters, such as spatiotemporal variation in microclimate or vegetation, and terrestrial invertebrate abundance and diversity. Lab included.

BIOL 409.course_description: Field research will focus on developing knowledge and understanding of the population, behavioral, and physiological ecology of reptiles.  Observational-comparative and experimental methods will be learned. Data collected in BIOL 408 will be analyzed, interpreted, and prepared for publication. Lab included.

BIOL 410.course_description: Investigation of the component processes and adaptive functions of animal behavior in an ecological and evolutionary context, and an introduction to the questions asked, hypotheses proposed and methods used in the study of animal behavior. Offered in alternate years.

BIOL 416.course_description: Investigation of the factors controlling whole ecosystem processes such as productivity, decomposition, and nutrient cycling. Application of these concepts to current issues in global change, including the carbon cycle and global warming, land use change, nitrogen-loading, and biodiversity and ecosystem function. Lectures and textbook reading are integrated with discussion of papers from the primary literature.

BIOL 423.course_description: An introduction to the fields of computational biology and bioinformatics for the purposes of analyzing environmental genomic data. Students will gain a conceptual understanding of the state of the fields, power and limitation of analytical tools, a practical understanding of the data analysis, and an experience posing and testing hypothesis on existing large data sets. Lab included.

BIOL 424.course_description: This class provides a practical introduction to how genetic methods can be used to address problems in ecology and evolution. As an applied course this class will stress general concepts of population genetics, phylogenetics, and comparative genomics via the use of quantitative tools in practical exercises while putting less emphasis on the theoretical details underlying these tools.

BIOL 425.course_description: Students will explore basic concepts in population and quantitative genetics, and focus on approaches to dissecting genetic variation in ecologically important traits across multiple scales. These concepts and approaches are broadly applicable to many areas of biology; thus readings range in topic from microbes to plants and animals.

BIOL 432.course_description: Principles, patterns, processes and mechanisms of evolution.

BIOL 437.course_description: This study abroad course is led by a faculty member to provide students with international, experiential learning. Students will participate in both classroom and applied learning opportunities that may include: pre-travel orientation and class meetings at Western, group instruction, reading, writing, and critical reflection assignments, learning from the host community, cultural excursions, field work, post-travel debriefing, and culminating projects.

BIOL 444.course_description: The Biology Department Seminar Series provides opportunities for undergraduate students to learn about the latest developments in key fields of biological research. Students will be required to attend seminars and provide a written synopsis of each presentation.

BIOL 445.course_description: This literature-based course will cover the role of bacteria and fungi in symbioses ranging from mutualistic to pathogenic with eukaryotic hosts (including humans and their microbiomes). We will discuss the ecology, evolution, biochemistry, and cellular biology of symbiotic interactions. We will focus on the most current experimental approaches for investigating host-microbe interactions at the molecular and cellular level.

BIOL 446.course_description: Cellular and molecular components of innate and adaptive immune responses, cellular and humoral immunity, and discussion of immunological diseases and therapies.

BIOL 451.course_description: An examination of the molecular basis of plant development and the applied uses of recent discoveries on crop improvement strategies. Emphasis on discussion of primary literature. Offered alternate years.

BIOL 452.course_description: Taxonomy of higher plants with emphasis on the characteristics and phylogeny of flowering plant families; collection and identification of local species. Lab included.

BIOL 453.course_description: This course examines the biology of the true fungi, including systematics, life history traits, ecology, physiology, and evolutionary biology. The course includes field components. Lab included.

BIOL 456.course_description: Physiology and ecology of macroalgae and phytoplankton including identification, collection and culture of major algal groups. Laboratory focuses on research techniques which are then applied in student independent projects. Lab included.

BIOL 460.course_description: Evolutionary relationships of invertebrate animals, including anatomy, physiology, classification, development and ecology. Lab included.

BIOL 462.course_description: The biology of insects, emphasizing their ecology and evolution, as well as comparative anatomy, physiology, and development. Laboratory exercises will focus on community studies and insect identification. Lab included.

BIOL 464.course_description: Examination of the evolution, physiology, ecology and conservation of marine mammals through critical thinking and discussion of the primary literature. Offered in alternate years.

BIOL 465.course_description: Investigations of vertebrate phylogenies; analyses of the biogeographic and ecological patterns of spatiotemporal distribution of many vertebrate taxa; examinations of the principal adaptive features that uniquely define each major vertebrate taxon. Offered alternate years. Lab included.

BIOL 467.course_description: Examination of the physiological functions of organ systems in each of the major vertebrate classes, with systems of taxa compared in evolutionary and ecological contexts.

BIOL 468.course_description: Design and implement laboratory research on some aspect of whole-animal performance physiology. Lab included.

BIOL 470.course_description: Examines the development and application of genome-based experimental approaches in biology.

BIOL 473.course_description: A seminar course examining the structure, replication and expression of genetic information that focuses on recent advances in gene expression.

BIOL 475.course_description: This seminar course explores scientific research on the cellular and molecular mechanisms by which naturally occurring variation in genes results in medically, agriculturally, and evolutionarily important trait variation.

BIOL 476.course_name: Structure and Physiology of Membrane Transport Proteins
BIOL 476.course_description: Examination of the structure of membrane transport proteins and their role in physiological processes through presentation and critical discussion of primary literature. Offered in alternate years.

BIOL 477.course_description: Introduction to the design and analysis of genomic research experiments. Genomics is the application of high-throughput molecular biology and bioinformatic techniques to questions in biology. Focus topics include genome assembly, differential gene expression, and genome-wide association studies. Primarily a computer lab course aimed at developing practical bioinformatics skills. Lab included.

BIOL 479.course_description: Basic principles of physiology including cell structure and function, plant-soil-water relationships, absorption and translocation of materials, transpiration, photosynthesis, respiration, mineral nutrition, growth and development, hormonal regulation. Lab included.

BIOL 480.course_description: An in-depth introduction to the analysis of sequence data at the gene level that combines concepts and theory in bioinformatics, molecular biology, and molecular evolution with applied skills development via computer-based exercises. Lab included.

BIOL 482.course_description: An examination of the molecular, cellular and genetic aspects of developmental biology in invertebrate and vertebrate model systems: fruit flies, nematodes, sea urchins, frogs and mammals.

BIOL 484.course_description: Laboratory investigations of cellular and developmental processes. Tissue culture methods and microscopy techniques, including immunofluorescence. Lectures will focus on optics and image processing. Lab included.

BIOL 486.course_name: Topics in Molecular Mechanisms of Neurodevelopment
BIOL 486.course_description: Molecular analysis of developmental processes controlling the formation of functional neural circuits. Emphasis placed on critical evaluation and discussion of primary literature.

BIOL 487.course_description: Research into the molecular basis of cell biology using molecular biological and biochemical methods, such as PCR genotyping and Western blotting. Lectures will focus on cell biology and gene regulation. Lab included.

BIOL 490.course_name: Human Anatomy and Physiology Teaching Internship
BIOL 490.course_description: Students will strengthen their understanding of human anatomy and physiology (A/P) by assisting the instructor(s) as a Teaching Intern in BIOL 348 Human Anatomy and Physiology laboratories. Serving as a Teaching Intern also represents a third academic quarter in which students are actively applying their knowledge in Human A/P, which will satisfy the requirement by some graduate programs for a full year of Human A/P. Repeatability to a maximum of 4 credits, including original course.

BIOL 494.course_description: Individual or collaborative research, including design and implementation of a research project, working under the tutelage of a biology professor. Repeatable to a maximum of 8 credits including original course.

BIOL 495.course_description: Analysis and written and/or oral presentation of results of individual scientific research. Communication can be in the form of a full scientific paper, a poster, or an oral presentation. Number of credits is dependent on the form of communication. Repeatable to a maximum of 6 credits including original course.

BIOL 496.course_description: Full- or part-time work with a cooperating agency or firm. Written reports required. Repeatable to a maximum of 8 cr. S/U grading.

BIOL 498.course_description: Classroom experience in biology teaching. Students will assist faculty in the laboratory and lecture settings. Repeatable to a maximum of 4 cr. S/U grading.

BIOL 500.course_description: An individualized course of study not available through or replacing existing curriculum, to be arranged between one matriculating student and sponsoring faculty member. All academic policies and registration deadlines apply.

BIOL 501.course_description: This course will explore some molecular mechanisms underlying the disease pathology of neurodegeneration, to give insight into how age, genes and risk factors may contribute to common cellular pathologies and diverse disease presentations.

BIOL 504.course_description: This course will explore the intrinsic connections between changes in development and the evolution of complex organisms. We will examine how aspects of development can promote or constrain evolutionary potential and explore why multicellular species are composed of groups of traits that develop and evolve together. We will also study the development of Evo-Devo as a field of study.

BIOL 506.course_description: Biological oceanography is the study of how organisms affect and are affected by the physics, chemistry, and geology of the oceanographic system. This course will provide a process-oriented view of marine pelagic ecosystems. Oceanographic processes covered in this course will include ocean circulation, biogeography, energetics, food webs, biogeochemical cycles, benthic-pelagic coupling, and plankton ecology.

BIOL 508.course_description: Analysis and discussion of current literature on selected topics in marine and estuarine biology. Examples of topics include symbiosis, intertidal community dynamics and marine microbiology. Repeatable with different topics.

BIOL 509.course_description: Study of microbial communities in aquatic, terrestrial and extreme environments, with emphasis on the functional role of microbes in terms of energy flow, nutrient cycling and biogeochemical transformations. Discussions of community structure and diversity, evolutionary history, and phylogenetic relationships will be covered. All students will be asked to put together a literature review on a topic of interest within the broad umbrella of microbial ecology.

BIOL 513.course_description: Physiological and biochemical adaptations of animals to environmental factors.  Emphasizes marine environments, but adaptations to freshwater and terrestrial environments conditions are also considered.  Labs introduce research techniques which are applied in student-designed independent research projects.

BIOL 516.course_name: Advanced Ecosystem Ecology and Global Change
BIOL 516.course_description: Investigates the factors controlling whole ecosystem processes.  Application of these concepts to current issues in global change, including the carbon cycle and global warming, land-use change, nitrogen load, and biodiversity and ecosystem functioning.

BIOL 520.course_description: Part of the core curriculum for all Biology MS students. This course is an overview of departmental resources and guidelines for navigating the Biology MS in a timely fashion, with workshops for developing skills in research and teaching (including developing an inclusive learning environment in the classroom) in the biological sciences.

BIOL 521.course_description: Part of the core curriculum for all Biology MS students. This course helps students learn about the research expertise of University faculty participating in science graduate programs, and potential equipment and resources available for research projects.

BIOL 522.course_description: Part of the core curriculum for all Biology MS students. This course is an introduction to developing and writing research proposals and obtaining funding in the Biological Sciences.

BIOL 523.course_description: Part of the core curriculum for all Biology MS students. This course helps students develop critical thinking skills related to their thesis research and biology research in general. Repeatable to a maximum of 4 credits, including original course.

BIOL 524.course_description: This class provides a practical introduction to how genetic methods can be used to address problems in ecology and evolution. As an applied course this class will stress general concepts of population genetics, phylogenetics, and comparative genomics via the use of qualitative tools in practical exercises while putting less emphasis on the theoretical details underlying these tools.

BIOL 525.course_description: Students will explore basic concepts in population and quantitative genetics, and focus on approaches to dissecting genetic variation in ecologically important traits across multiple scales. The topics covered in this course are broadly applicable to many areas of biology, ranging from microbes to plants and animals.

BIOL 526.course_description: A discussion-based course that uses on-line Collaborative Institutional Training Initiative training modules and supplemental readings to understand common ethical issues encountered in scientific research. S/U grading.

BIOL 545.course_description: This literature-based course will cover the role of bacteria and fungi in symbioses ranging from mutualistic to pathogenic with eukaryotic hosts (including humans and their microbiomes). We will discuss the ecology, evolution, biochemistry, and cellular biology of symbiotic interactions. We will focus on the most current experimental approaches for investigating host-microbe interactions at the molecular and cellular level.

BIOL 551.course_description: An examination of the molecular basis of plant development and the applied uses of recent discoveries on crop improvement strategies. Emphasis on discussion of primary literature. Offered alternate years.

BIOL 575.course_description: This seminar course explores scientific research on the cellular and molecular mechanisms by which naturally occurring variation in genes results in medically, agriculturally, and evolutionarily important trait variation.

BIOL 576.course_name: Structural Basis of Membrane Transport Proteins
BIOL 576.course_description: This course will examine the general structural basis of membrane transport proteins; studying their mechanistic information, examining the actual body plans and structure of these proteins and evaluating the structure-function relationship that permits them to perform their task. The overall goal of this course is to acquire a unifying view of membrane transport mechanisms. Offered in alternate years.

BIOL 577.course_description: Introduction to the design and analysis of genomic research experiments. Genomics is the application of high-throughput molecular biology and bioinformatic techniques to questions in biology. Focus topics include genome assembly, differential gene expression, and genome-wide association studies. Primarily a computer lab course aimed at developing practical bioinformatics skills.

BIOL 580.course_description: An in-depth introduction to the analysis of sequence data at the gene level that combines concepts and theory in bioinformatics, molecular biology, and molecular evolution with applied skills development via computer-based exercises. Lab included.

BIOL 586.course_name: Topics in Molecular Mechanisms of Neurodevelopment
BIOL 586.course_description: Molecular analysis of developmental processes controlling the formation of functional neural circuits. Emphasis placed on critical evaluation and discussion of primary literature.

BIOL 594.course_description: Laboratory investigations of cellular processes. Tissue culture methods and microscopy techniques, including immunofluorescence. Lectures will focus on optics and image processing.

BIOL 595.course_description: An examination of the molecular, cellular and genetic aspects of developmental biology in invertebrate and vertebrate model systems: fruit flies, nematodes, sea urchins, frogs and mammals.

BIOL 690.course_description: Research contributing to a graduate degree program.  Graded ‘K’ until thesis completed. Repeatable up to 36 credits. S/U grading.

BUS 310.course_description: Exploring career options related to individual student interests will take place in the context of both general career-related information and customized feedback. Professional workshops on topics such as professionalism, networking, interviewing, and etiquette provide a foundation for each student’s pursuit of their own career aspirations and goals.

BUS 410.course_name: Professional & Career Readiness as a College Graduate
BUS 410.course_description: This class provides students with opportunities to document and reflect on all of their professional and career readiness activities completed as part of their CBE program. Students will engage in career planning and preparation as well as reflect on program-specific activities.

C/AM 200.course_description: A broad interdisciplinary survey course which introduces students to the study of the territory presently known as Canada. Topics include human-environment relationships; Indigenous peoples and settler colonialism; the development of present-day cultural, political, and economic systems; and the impact of US-Canada relations. An understanding of Canada is valuable not only to provide a better understanding of a nearby neighbor, but also to gain a better understanding of the U.S. itself.

C/AM 277.course_description: Canadian history from aboriginal occupation to the present. Also offered as HIST 277.

C/AM 300.course_description: An individualized course of study not available through or replacing existing curriculum, to be arranged between one matriculating student and sponsoring faculty member. All academic policies and registration deadlines apply. Directed Independent Study courses cannot substitute for General University Requirements and are not eligible for tuition waiver.

C/AM 305.course_description: Topics in Canadian-American Studies. Variable topics. Repeatable with different topics to a maximum of 10 credits, including original course, but only 5 credits can count towards major requirements.

C/AM 325.course_description: This course offers an introduction to Québec politics and Québec-U.S. Relations. Part I uses a historical-institutionalist approach to present the main conceptual and theoretical elements on Québec politics and offers an overview of recent evolution in Quebec’s political life. Part II discusses three crucial themes in contemporary Québec politics: the evolution of Québec’s identity; the future of Québec’s independence movement; and the road ahead for Québec’s international relations. Part III shows how Québec and the United States are integrated and offers an overview of the actors and issues in Québec-U.S. relations. Also offered as PLSC 325.

C/AM 331.course_description: This course explores the production of Canada as both a territory and a geographical idea. Topics include physical geographies, Indigenous geographies, geographies of settler colonialism, resource extraction, urban development, and de-colonial spaces. Also offered as ENVS 331.

C/AM 355.course_name: Canadian-American Media Systems: News, Culture, and Diplomacy
C/AM 355.course_description: This course examines how news institutions, governments, and other media actors in the region — Indigenous nations, non-governmental organizations, and multinational corporations — produce their own media that renders cross-border regions such as Cascadia, the Great Lakes, and the Arctic as politically and culturally dynamic geographies. The course provides students with an understanding of cross-border media flows and their impact on the relationship between Canada and the United States. Students in this class will acquire an introduction to Canadian news media in the context of their relationship to U.S. counterparts — and vice-versa. Also offered as JOUR 355.

C/AM 365.course_description: This course introduces students to the history of Canada’s economic development and contemporary issues in the Canadian economy. It will especially examine Canada’s international economic relations, and interactions with its largest trading partner, the United States. Also offered as ECON 365.

C/AM 366.course_description: This course will examine in detail different features of Canada’s business environment. Topics could include trade relations, energy and resource policy, immigration and the competition for talent. The emphasis is on Canada-U.S. comparisons and on features of the Canadian business environment that are of greatest relevance for the United States. Also offered as ECON 366.

C/AM 368.course_name: Decolonization across the Medicine Line: Comparative Indigenous politics in Canada and the U.S.
C/AM 368.course_description: This course explores the tangled colonial histories of the U.S. and Canada, paying particular attention to Indigenous-settler relations. This course engages with Indigenous scholars in order to understand the Indigenous critique of the two settler states. In addition, we will interrogate the roots of colonialism and what it means for all people to work towards transforming the colonial relationships that are embedded within state structures. Also offered as FAIR 368.

C/AM 369.course_description: Settler Cities represent settler futures, settler ideals, and settler fantasies while attempting to erase Indigenous presence and Indigenous futures. Many North American cities were built upon Indigenous villages, actively removing Indigenous peoples to create settler spaces. As this class will demonstrate, the ongoing project of settler urbanization has not been successful, highlighting the resurgence of Indigenous communities across Turtle Island and the geopolitical extents of the North American settler-state. The course provides a cross-border assessment of Settler Cities between Canada and the United States demonstrating the pervasive systems of settler colonialism and the shared project of Indigenous Futures. Also offered as UEPP 369.

C/AM 375.course_name: Indigenous Placemaking: Decolonizing Space and Place
C/AM 375.course_description: Spatial Knowledge encompasses the production of knowledge through land-based practices. Through the course we will investigate the impacts of colonization on spatial practices and the current dominance of settler-colonialism on Indigenous communities and the continuity of Indigenous knowledge systems. We will explore both spatial knowledge across multiple scales of the Land from macro, meso and micro to the rural - urban divide. Also offered as UEPP 375.

C/AM 379.course_description: Examination and impacts of significant developments in the political, diplomatic, economic, social and cultural relations between Canada and the United States. Also offered as HIST 379.

C/AM 400.course_description: An individualized course of study not available through or replacing existing curriculum, to be arranged between one matriculating student and sponsoring faculty member. All academic policies and registration deadlines apply. Directed Independent Study courses cannot substitute for General University Requirements and are not eligible for tuition waiver.

C/AM 401.course_description: Directed research on a problem or in an area of interest. Required for all students enrolled in the major.

C/AM 402.course_description: Analysis and writing on the research findings in C/AM 401. A writing proficiency course. Required for all students enrolled in the major.

C/AM 405.course_description: Advanced Topics in Canadian-American Studies. Variable topics presented in seminar style. Involves theoretical discussions with a strong emphasis on student research. Repeatable with different topics to a maximum of 10 credits, including original course, but only 5 credits can count towards major requirements.

C/AM 406.course_description: Canadian political institutions and process, relations with U.S., current topics including regional tensions, the environment, and First Nations. Also offered as PLSC 406.

C/AM 410.course_description: Intensive survey course featuring expert instruction from WWU faculty and distinguished speakers from Canada and the U.S. Topics include: Canadian history, geography, government, culture, free trade and environmental issues, First Nations and Canada-U.S. relations. Participants are introduced to a variety of curriculum materials, visit Canada, experience its culture, and develop a curriculum project that meets national standards and expands their personal teaching portfolios. Repeatable to a maximum of 9 credits.

C/AM 430.course_description: Geographic investigation of cross-border resource management and other issues associated with the growing importance of the United States’ cross-border regions, especially our northern border with Canada; selected trans-border environmental, resource management, sustainability, economic, and urban topics. Also offered as ENVS 430.

C/AM 441.course_description: This course explores geographies of resource extractivism in North America. It is based upon the idea that, at root, natural resources and attendant spaces are produced through political-economic and cultural systems; they are not pre-existing things. The course is designed to enable students to identify how these systems have shaped natural resource geographies at a variety of scales in both the United States and Canada. Also offered as ENVS 441.

C/AM 442.course_name: Geography, Colonialism, and the Pacific Northwest
C/AM 442.course_description: Colonialism is not merely a period of time but rather a set of patterns, processes and conditions which have shifted through time and space yet continue to be constitutive of the present. In this course, we will explore key geographical arrangements which have produced and perpetuated colonial structures, particularly in the Pacific Northwest region. Equally importantly, we will consider Indigenous peoples’ refusal of these structures and highlight enactments of de-colonized geographies. Also offered as ENVS 444.

C/AM 444.course_description: Work as research and/or management assistant with a local, state or federal government body, private organization, or university unit. No more than 10 credits in internship may be counted towards the major without permission of the chair. Repeatable up to 15 credits, including original course.

C/AM 450.course_description: This course studies selected works of Canadian literature important for their artistic, cultural, or historical content and contexts. Like Canada itself, its literature represents a “contact zone” between Indigenous peoples, French and British settlers, and immigrants all over the world. Students will engage in close readings of one work of contemporary Canadian fiction with additional material drawn from Canadian history, geography and culture, including films and media to provide context. The course outline will look different each session, with new themes, readings, and learning activities.

C/AM 489.course_description: A research seminar that examines how economic, environmental, social and political agendas affect the shared international ecosystem - Georgia Basin/Puget Sound. Course focuses on the interests of various stakeholders and the efforts taken to manage the cross-border environmental issues. The course involves cross-border travel and field work and thus participants require a passport. In some years, the course will involve collaborations with students and faculty from Canadian Universities. Also offered as PLSC 489.

CHEM 100.course_description: An introductory course in chemistry designed for freshmen students intending to enroll in the General Chemistry sequence (CHEM 161, 162, 163).  Instruction in dimensional analysis, atomic structure, basic laboratory technique, and chemical bonding.  Includes lab.  S/U grading.

CHEM 101.course_description: A course for non-science students.  Emphasizes the process of building scientific models for how matter behaves through the collection and interpretation of evidence. Applications to important societal issues will also be discussed.  Lab included.

CHEM 161.course_description: Matter, measurement, dimensional analysis, stoichiometry, atomic and molecular structure, periodic trends, and molecular interactions. Lab included.

CHEM 162.course_description: Solutions, types of chemical reactions, gas laws, thermochemistry, thermodynamics, and kinetics. Lab included.

CHEM 163.course_description: Equilibrium, acids and bases, solubility equilibria, and electrochemistry. Lab included.

CHEM 175.course_description: An accelerated survey of fundamental chemical principles, including atomic and molecular structure, bonding, solution chemistry, and gas laws. Lab included.

CHEM 176.course_description: An accelerated survey of chemical thermodynamics, equilibria, kinetics, and solution chemistry. Lab included.

CHEM 201.course_description: Undergraduate research under supervision. Written report required. Repeatable up to 9 credits over three quarters, including original course. S/U grading.

CHEM 225.course_description: An accelerated survey of fundamental chemical principles, including atomic and molecular structure, bonding, chemical thermodynamics, equilibria, kinetics, solution chemistry, nuclear chemistry, and analytical  methods.  Lab included.

CHEM 251.course_description: Reactions, nomenclature and uses of carbon compounds; an abbreviated course in organic chemistry primarily for persons not requiring the CHEM 351-354 series.

CHEM 300.course_description: An individualized course of study not available through or replacing existing curriculum, to be arranged between one matriculating student and sponsoring faculty member. All academic policies and registration deadlines apply. Directed Independent Study courses cannot substitute for General University Requirements and are not eligible for tuition waiver.

CHEM 301.course_description: Undergraduate research under supervision. Written report required. Repeatable to a maximum of 9 cr over three quarters. S/U grading.

CHEM 308.course_description: Types of polymers, methods of polymerization, and preparation of important commercial thermoplastic and thermosetting plastics. Addition and condensation polymers are prepared in the laboratory.

CHEM 333.course_description: Theory and practice of gravimetric, volumetric, potentiometric and spectrophotometric methods of analysis. Selected analytical topics such as ion exchange resins, non-aqueous solvents, chelates, extractions, chromatography.

CHEM 351.course_description: Chemistry of carbon compounds with emphasis on structural theory, reactions and mechanisms.

CHEM 352.course_description: Chemistry of carbon compounds with emphasis on structural theory, reactions and mechanisms.

CHEM 353.course_description: Chemistry of carbon compounds with emphasis on structural theory, reactions and mechanisms.

CHEM 354.course_description: Techniques of organic chemistry: reactions, separations and syntheses of organic compounds.

CHEM 355.course_description: Techniques of organic chemistry: reactions, separations; multi-step syntheses and introduction to practical spectroscopy. Includes online and hardcopy literature searching, use of chemical drawing software, and writing journal-style reports. This course is intended for students planning to major in Chemistry.

CHEM 356.course_name: Organic Chemistry Laboratory II for Life Sciences
CHEM 356.course_description: Techniques of organic chemistry:  reactions, separations; syntheses and introduction to practical spectroscopy.  This course is specifically designed to meet the requirements of students in Life Sciences, Biochemistry, and/or Pre-Healthcare Professions programs.

CHEM 375.course_description: Introduction to the structure and function of proteins, nucleic acid, lipids, and carbohydrates. Enzyme chemistry. Replication, transcription, and translation of genetic information. Metabolism of carbohydrates, the citric acid cycle, electron transport, and oxidation phosphorylation. This course is not intended for students in the bachelor of science-biochemistry program.

CHEM 381.course_description: An examination of current and emerging biofuel technologies including an understanding of the processes for biomass conversion to fuel and other factors associated with commercial biofuel production. Also offered as ENRG 381.

CHEM 400.course_description: An individualized course of study not available through or replacing existing curriculum, to be arranged between one matriculating student and sponsoring faculty member. All academic policies and registration deadlines apply. Directed Independent Study courses cannot substitute for General University Requirements and are not eligible for tuition waiver.

CHEM 401.course_description: Undergraduate research under supervision. Written report required. Repeatable to a maximum of 9 cr over three quarters. S/U grading.

CHEM 405.course_name: Intensive Writing in Chemistry or Biochemistry
CHEM 405.course_description: Concentrated study of a topic associated with chemistry or biochemistry. Students are required to write a substantial expository paper. Writing proficiency course.

CHEM 425A.course_description: Isolation, structure, synthesis, biosynthesis and photochemistry of selected classes of natural products.

CHEM 425B.course_description: Organic chemical reactions as applied to problems in organic synthesis.

CHEM 425C.course_description: The chemistry of drug discovery, design, development, and action.

CHEM 425D.course_description: Correlation of mathematical group theory with molecular symmetry and application of symmetry groups to the interpretation of molecular spectra. Principle applications will be to infrared and Raman vibrational spectra.

CHEM 425H.course_description: Structural and quantitative study of enzyme mechanisms, enzyme inhibition, structure-based inhibitor design, high-throughput screens for enzyme inhibitors, advanced experimental techniques, enzyme engineering, gene-specific reagent studies, biopharmaceuticals, review and analysis of current literature regarding enzyme studies.

CHEM 425K.course_description: The analysis of biomolecules, substances of significant biological interest, and substances in biological matrices using advanced instrumental methods.

CHEM 425M.course_description: Classes of organometallic compounds; structure, bonding, general patterns of reactivity; reactions; industrial homogeneous catalysis.

CHEM 425R.course_description: Physical chemistry of solid surfaces. Examples drawn from heterogeneous catalysis and environmental chemistry.

CHEM 425S.course_description: Analysis of protein structure and protein-ligand interactions, protein design considerations, and design of small molecule and protein-based therapeutic agents.

CHEM 425U.course_description: Examining binding sites and reactivity of biologically important metal ions, and the physical methods used to probe these sites.

CHEM 425V.course_description: The role of chemistry in energy production, distribution, storage and usage, with a focus on chemical, photochemical, and electrochemical transformations. Applications to existing and emerging energy technologies.

CHEM 426.course_description: This course will cover basic macromolecule and polymer structure and processing techniques. Emphasis will be placed on modern synthetic methods for producing and characterizing these materials. The design, synthesis and use of polymers in specialty applications will also be discussed.

CHEM 427.course_description: This course will cover the chemical reactions and processes affecting the distribution and cycling of chemical species in natural water systems like lakes and oceans. Topics include aqueous geochemistry, kinetics and thermodynamics, acids and bases, metal complexes, redox reactions, dissolution, sorption and precipitation, nutrient cycles, photochemistry, natural organic matter and organic pollutants.

CHEM 434.course_description: Theory or modern optical, electrical and other physical measurements applied to chemical analysis.

CHEM 436.course_description: Application of modern instrumental methods of chemical analysis including optical, electrical and other physical measurements.

CHEM 441.course_description: Bonding, structure and reactivity of inorganic molecules; transition metal and organometallic chemistry; chemistry of the nonmetallic elements.

CHEM 454.course_description: Identification of organic compounds by spectroscopic methods: infrared, nuclear magnetic resonance, ultraviolet and mass spectroscopy. Laboratory work includes application of spectroscopy in identifying unknowns with confirmation by chemical methods.

CHEM 455.course_description: A lecture/lab course in advanced techniques in nuclear magnetic resonance, including Fourier transformation, multiple pulse sequences, relaxation time measurements, gated decoupling, polarization transfer, pulse sequences and two-dimensional NMR experiments.

CHEM 461.course_description: Atomic and molecular structure, states of matter, solutions, chemical thermodynamics and equilibria, chemical kinetics and electrochemistry.

CHEM 462.course_description: Atomic and molecular structure, states of matter, solutions, chemical thermodynamics and equilibria, chemical kinetics and electrochemistry.

CHEM 463.course_description: Atomic and molecular structure, states of matter, solutions, chemical thermodynamics and equilibria, chemical kinetics and electrochemistry.

CHEM 464.course_description: An integrated approach to inorganic synthesis and physical measurement. Includes formal report writing.

CHEM 465.course_description: An integrated approach to inorganic synthesis and physical measurement. Includes formal report writing.

CHEM 466.course_description: Biophysical experimental methods and theory, including classical and quantum mechanics, bonding, spectroscopy, crystallography, ligand binding, protein/enzyme function, structural biophysics.

CHEM 467.course_description: Biophysical experimental methods and theory, including classical and statistical thermodynamics, bonding, ligand binding, spectroscopy, transport processes, enzyme kinetics, and X-ray diffraction.

CHEM 468.course_description: Biophysical experimental methods and theory, including classical and statistical thermodynamics, bonding, ligand binding, spectroscopy, transport processes, enzyme kinetics, and X-ray diffraction.

CHEM 471.course_description: A consideration of the structure and function of biological macromolecules; intermediary metabolism; membrane structure and function; bioenergetics.

CHEM 472.course_description: A consideration of the structure and function of biological macromolecules; intermediary metabolism; membrane structure and function; bioenergetics.

CHEM 473.course_description: An examination of the structure, replication and expression of genetic information.

CHEM 474.course_description: Modern methods of isolation and characterization of biological macromolecules, especially enzymes and other proteins.

CHEM 476.course_description: A review of the “hallmarks of cancer”; a detailed look at factors affecting genome integrity, immune system evasion, metastasis; current methods in cancer therapy; the design of engineered proteins to be used in cancer research and treatment; a brief introduction to some of the social/ethical/political issues associated with the costs of cancer treatments.

CHEM 486.course_description: A hands-on introduction to computational models employed in contemporary chemical research. Topics will include energy landscapes, geometry optimization, and molecular dynamics; classical force fields, ab initio quantum chemistry, semi-empirical methods, density functional theory; critical assessment of assumptions and approximations in computational chemistry.

CHEM 494.course_description: Academic credit awarded for chemical employment in industry or government in areas such as research, development or quality control. Written report and an oral or poster presentation describing the work are required. Repeatable up to 9 credits, including original course.

CHEM 498.course_description: Oral presentation and honors thesis required.

CHEM 500.course_description: An individualized course of study not available through or replacing existing curriculum, to be arranged between one matriculating student and sponsoring faculty member. All academic policies and registration deadlines apply.

CHEM 501.course_description: Advanced individual laboratory projects under supervision. Repeatable to a maximum of 15 credits including original course.

CHEM 502.course_description: Curriculum and instructional support for teaching the general chemistry laboratory sequence. Repeatable to a maximum of 3 cr. S/U grading.

CHEM 505.course_description: This course is designed to assist graduate students in beginning to write their MS thesis. Students are required to write at least one complete, peer reviewed chapter of their thesis for satisfactory completion. In addition to writing drafts of a thesis chapter, topics including thesis structure, writing style, and figure preparation will be covered.

CHEM 510.course_description: Specialized lectures on a conference basis for a particular area of interest. Repeatable to a maximum of 12 credits including original course.

CHEM 511.course_description: Specialized laboratory on a conference basis for a particular area of interest. Repeatable to a maximum of 12 credits including original course.

CHEM 526.course_description: This course will cover basic macromolecule and polymer structure and processing techniques. Emphasis will be placed on modern synthetic methods for producing and characterizing these materials. The design, synthesis and use of polymers in specialty applications will also be discussed.

CHEM 527.course_description: This course will cover the chemical reactions and processes affecting the distribution and cycling of chemical species in natural water systems like lakes and oceans. Topics include aqueous geochemistry, kinetics and thermodynamics, acids and bases, metal complexes, redox reactions, dissolution, sorption and precipitation, nutrient cycles, photochemistry, natural organic matter and organic pollutants.

CHEM 534.course_description: Principles of chromatographic, spectrochemical and electrochemical methods of analysis.

CHEM 535.course_description: The analysis of biomolecules, substances of significant biological interest, and substances in biological matrices using advanced instrumental methods.

CHEM 536.course_description: Advanced techniques of modern instrumental analysis including optical, electrical, and other physical measurements, including analysis of materials.

CHEM 539.course_description: Examining binding sites and reactivity of biologically important metal ions, and the physical methods used to probe these sites.

CHEM 540.course_description: Classes of organometallic compounds; structure, bonding, general patterns of reactivity; reactions; industrial homogeneous catalysis.

CHEM 552.course_description: Isolation, structure, synthesis, biosynthesis and photochemistry of selected classes of natural products.

CHEM 553.course_description: Organic chemical reactions as applied to problems in organic synthesis.

CHEM 554.course_description: Identification of organic compounds by spectroscopic methods: infrared, nuclear magnetic resonance, ultraviolet and mass spectroscopy. Lab included.

CHEM 555.course_description: A lecture/lab course in advanced techniques in nuclear magnetic resonance, including Fourier transformation, multiple pulse sequences, relaxation time measurements, gated decoupling, polarization transfer and two-dimensional NMR experiments.

CHEM 556.course_description: The chemistry of drug discovery, design, development, and action.

CHEM 562.course_description: Correlation of mathematical group theory with molecular symmetry and application of symmetry groups to the interpretation of molecular spectra. Principle applications will be to infrared and Raman vibrational spectra.

CHEM 565.course_description: Physical chemistry of solid surfaces. Examples drawn from heterogeneous catalysis and environmental chemistry.

CHEM 573.course_description: Structural and quantitative study of enzyme mechanisms, enzyme inhibition, structure-based inhibitor design, high-throughput screens for enzyme inhibitors, advanced experimental techniques, enzyme engineering, gene-specific reagent studies, biopharmaceuticals, review and analysis of current literature regarding enzyme studies.

CHEM 576.course_description: A review of the “hallmarks of cancer”; a detailed look at factors affecting genome integrity, immune system evasion, metastasis; current methods in cancer therapy; the design of engineered proteins to be used in cancer research and treatment; a brief introduction to some of the social/ethical/political issues associated with the costs of cancer treatments. S/U grading.

CHEM 578.course_description: Analysis of protein structure and protein-ligand interactions, protein design considerations, and design of small molecule and protein-based therapeutic agents.

CHEM 586.course_description: A hands-on introduction to computational models employed in contemporary chemical research. Topics will include energy landscapes, geometry optimization, and molecular dynamics; classical force fields, ab initio quantum chemistry, semi-empirical methods, density functional theory; critical assessment of assumptions and approximations in computational chemistry.

CHEM 595.course_description: Presentation of contemporary subjects in chemistry. Repeatable to a maximum of 2 cr. S/U grading.

CHEM 596.course_name: Seminar in Current Chemistry and Biochemistry
CHEM 596.course_description: Introduction to current research problems in chemistry and biochemistry.  Repeatable to a maximum of 6 cr. S/U grading.

CHEM 690.course_description: Research in chemistry under faculty direction terminating in a master’s thesis. Repeatable to a maximum of 12 cr. S/U grading.

CHEM 694.course_description: A supervised technical field experience in chemical laboratory practice. The experience may be in an industrial or government laboratory setting in such areas as research and development, chemical sales, manufacturing, process development, clinical chemistry, analytical chemistry, quality control or environmental control. A project report following an approved format is required. Repeatable to a maximum of 12 cr. S/U grading.

CHIN 101.course_description: To be taken in sequence. Fundamentals of the modern standard language (Mandarin): pronunciation, grammar, aural comprehension, reading and speaking.

CHIN 102.course_description: To be taken in sequence. Fundamentals of the modern standard language (Mandarin): pronunciation, grammar, aural comprehension, reading and speaking.

CHIN 103.course_description: To be taken in sequence. Fundamentals of the modern standard language (Mandarin): pronunciation, grammar, aural comprehension, reading and speaking.

CHIN 104.course_description: Designed for students with two years high school Chinese or equivalent to prepare them for the intermediate level through review and development of basic listening, speaking, reading and writing skills in Chinese. Also for students needing a review of the first year.

CHIN 201.course_description: To be taken in sequence. Review of the fundamentals of the modern standard language (Mandarin); emphasis on acquisition of oral and written vocabulary; intensive reading and discussion in Chinese of graded materials in modern Chinese (Mandarin).
