CHIN 202.course_description: To be taken in sequence. Review of the fundamentals of the modern standard language (Mandarin); emphasis on acquisition of oral and written vocabulary; intensive reading and discussion in Chinese of graded materials in modern Chinese (Mandarin).

CHIN 203.course_description: To be taken in sequence. Review of the fundamentals of the modern standard language (Mandarin); emphasis on acquisition of oral and written vocabulary; intensive reading and discussion in Chinese of graded materials in modern Chinese (Mandarin).

CHIN 280.course_description: An introduction to the principles used in the formation and history of Chinese characters and their relations to Chinese culture. The components of the characters are analyzed and compared with the new, simplified forms. Reading materials and class discussion provide practice in reading and writing characters. Calligraphy sessions provide opportunity to learn theories and principles of writing characters in 4 different styles (seal script, clerical script, cursive script and regular script).

CHIN 300.course_description: An individualized course of study not available through or replacing existing curriculum, to be arranged between one matriculating student and sponsoring faculty member. All academic policies and registration deadlines apply. Directed Independent Study courses cannot substitute for General University Requirements and are not eligible for tuition waiver.

CHIN 301.course_description: Designed to help students achieve the third-year (intermediate-high) Chinese proficiency in listening, speaking, reading, and writing, It focuses on students’ Chinese skills in communication with expressions of abstract ideas, and in comprehension of multiple-paragraph texts of complicated grammatical structures and broader vocabulary. After a successful completion of the 300 sequence, students will be able to converse with native or near-native Chinese speakers on every-day topics in a variety of settings using tonally accurate, syntactically complex, and lexically appropriate language. Students will also be able to understand linguistic variety of regional/national usages within Chinese cultures. Taught in Chinese.

CHIN 302.course_description: Designed for students to achieve the third-year (intermediate-high) Chinese proficiency in listening, speaking, reading, and writing, this course focuses on developing students’ Chinese skills in communication with expressions of abstract ideas, and in comprehension of multiple-paragraph texts of complicated grammatical structures and broader vocabulary. After a successful completion of the 300 level Chinese series, students will be able to converse with native or near-native Chinese speakers on every-day topics in a variety of settings using tonally accurate, syntactically complex, and lexically appropriate language. Students will also be able to understand linguistic variety of regional/national usages within Chinese cultures.

CHIN 303.course_description: Designed to develop abilities to speak, understand, read, write and translate typical Chinese in business and economic settings from both linguistic and cultural perspectives. While focusing on the Chinese language that is used in the business world, this course will also introduce related business and economic climates, practices and customs of Chinese-speaking communities.

CHIN 304.course_description: This course is designed to acquaint students with values and viewpoints of Chinese cultures and societies through review and discussion of major grammatical elements and genre types in Chinese. Students will also compare Chinese and English grammar and cultures and compose essays to reflect their interlingua and intercultural communicative competence.

CHIN 314.course_description: This course introduces phonetics (the study of how speech sounds are produced) and phonology (the study of the sound system) of modern standard Chinese. The primary goal of the course is to help students learn how Chinese sounds are produced, so that they can describe them in articulatory terms, write them out in Pinyin and the International Phonetic Alphabet, and produce them accurately. Other topics include an introduction to higher-level units of Chinese speech including words, intonation phrases, and Peking accent; the relation between tone and intonation; and comparison between Chinese and English sounds. The course should prove useful to students desiring a better understanding and acquisition of Chinese pronunciation.

CHIN 330.course_description: Designed to introduce students to different aspects of Chinese culture through film, this course focuses on how an informed understanding of China's cultural heritage can help students make better sense of China's present in the global context as well as give students some clues of where China may be headed in the future. Through class discussion, presentations and group projects, students explore major issues in contemporary Chinese culture, such as philosophy, religion, political power, authority, economy, customs, family bond, friendship, lifestyles, arts, literature, martial arts, etc. Repeatable with different topics up to 10 credits including the original course.

CHIN 400.course_description: An individualized course of study not available through or replacing existing curriculum, to be arranged between one matriculating student and sponsoring faculty member. All academic policies and registration deadlines apply. Directed Independent Study courses cannot substitute for General University Requirements and are not eligible for tuition waiver.

CHIN 401.course_description: This course is designed to serve as a capstone course for students who major in Chinese Language and Culture. It provides students with the opportunity to apply and integrate both linguistic and cultural knowledge that they have acquired from each course in their program of Chinese study at Western. It is also intended to develop students’ consciousness as a global citizen and their communicative ability to compete successfully in the global workforce.

CHIN 402.course_description: This course is designed for students to gain a comprehensive understanding of the structure and usage of Mandarin (Modern standard) Chinese. Through class discussion, reading materials, and a research project, students explore all core areas of Chinese language and linguistics: phonology, morphology, semantics, syntax, as well as dialect variations. Students will be guided step by step to conduct research on aspects of Chinese language and linguistics effectively.

CHIN 403.course_description: This topic course is designed for students to acquire a deeper understanding of modern Chinese society and culture. Through an examination of cultural unities and diversities and comparison between tradition and globalization, it helps students develop abilities to think critically about major developments in Chinese society and culture from the 20th to the 21st centuries. Repeatable to 10 credits.

CHIN 425.course_description: Students selected for tutoring must dedicate four hours per week to provide help to other students primarily those enrolled in 100-200 levels of Chinese courses. Permission may also be given to assist with other Chinese courses completed with outstanding achievement. Students may be requested to lead group sessions or work with students individually. Expertise in Chinese grammar or linguistics is desirable. S/U grading.

CLST 117.course_description: An introduction to the contributions made by Greece and Rome to the European cultural tradition.  Five thematic questions and the answers offered by the ancients are to be examined:  God or Mortal; Citizen and State; the Great Individual; the life of philosophy and the life of political activity; the Burden of Immortality.

CLST 300.course_description: An individualized course of study not available through or replacing existing curriculum, to be arranged between one matriculating student and sponsoring faculty member. All academic policies and registration deadlines apply. Directed Independent Study courses cannot substitute for General University Requirements and are not eligible for tuition waiver.

CLST 350.course_description: A study of Greek myths as a vital and evolving feature of Greek religious and intellectual life from Homer through Hesiod and Aeschylus to Euripides.

CLST 360.course_description: Survey of the major Greek texts - epic, dramatic and narrative - in translation with emphasis on those works which have shaped the classical tradition.

CLST 370.course_name: Literature of Rome and Her Empire
CLST 370.course_description: A survey of highly influential works of Latin literature which serve to define the Roman character and Empire along with discussion of major lines of interpretation of these works and the continuous influence they exercised on the literature of the next two millennia.

CLST 400.course_description: An individualized course of study not available through or replacing existing curriculum, to be arranged between one matriculating student and sponsoring faculty member. All academic policies and registration deadlines apply. Directed Independent Study courses cannot substitute for General University Requirements and are not eligible for tuition waiver.

CLST 401.course_description: Fundamentals of the classical language:  pronunciation; reading and writing of devanagari script; grammar.

CLST 425.course_description: Practicum in preparation, implementation and evaluation of instructional materials. Repeatable up to 3 times to a maximum of 10 credits, including original course. S/U grading.

CLST 450.course_description: Varying topics, such as individual genres (e.g., epic, tragedy) or eras (fifth-century B.C. Athens, the Mediterranean World in the first century A.D.), will be treated from quarter to quarter. Repeatable with different topics up to 10 credits, including original course.

CD 280.course_description: A practical application of principles and techniques used in sport coaching, including program organization and administration, team building, teaching sports strategies, leadership principles related to sport performance, sport-related motor skill acquisition and performance principles, and the evaluation of coaching strategies and methods.

CD 281.course_description: A practical application of principles and techniques used in sport coaching, including program organization and administration, team building, teaching sports strategies, leadership principles related to sport performance, sport-related motor skill acquisition and performance principles, and the evaluation of coaching strategies and methods.

CD 300.course_description: An individualized course of study not available through or replacing existing curriculum, to be arranged between one matriculating student and sponsoring faculty member. All academic policies and registration deadlines apply. Directed Independent Study courses cannot substitute for General University Requirements and are not eligible for tuition waiver.

CD 381.course_description: Practical and theoretical aspects of coaching the sport with special emphasis on advanced skill development and current methodology and resource material being utilized.

CD 383.course_description: Practical and theoretical aspects of coaching the sport with special emphasis on advanced skill development and current methodology and resource material being utilized.

CD 400.course_description: An individualized course of study not available through or replacing existing curriculum, to be arranged between one matriculating student and sponsoring faculty member. All academic policies and registration deadlines apply. Directed Independent Study courses cannot substitute for General University Requirements and are not eligible for tuition waiver.

CD 500.course_description: An individualized course of study not available through or replacing existing curriculum, to be arranged between one matriculating student and sponsoring faculty member. All academic policies and registration deadlines apply.

CSD 210.course_description: This course will provide a basic overview of our knowledge of language and what it can tell us about the nature of the mind, and vice versa. It will explore relevant theories of cognitive and language development. Students will view pre-recorded lectures about the structure of sentences (syntax), words (morphology), and sound shape (phonetics, phonology), and how these are typically acquired, mentally represented, and processed by humans. Lectures will cover the relationships between early social interactions, social cognition (theory of mind), language, and social competence (“inter-subjectivity model” of language and executive functioning). Lectures will also include discussion of communication disorders and differences, and the social cognitive effects of communication disorders on children and adults at a national and global scale. This course will include readings, video analyses of typical and clinical populations, online demonstration activities, a final paper, and on-line discussion board activities and reflections.

CSD 251.course_description: An introduction to communication sciences and disorders. This course provides a basic overview of our knowledge and understanding about language, speech, hearing, and cognitive processes underlying communication. The course also includes discussion about communication disorders and differences, and highlights how neurodiversity, disorders, and differences impact social and cultural interactions across the lifespan.

CSD 253.course_name: Speech and Hearing Sciences for the Liberal Arts
CSD 253.course_description: Basic concepts of speech production, speech acoustics, hearing and speech perception. Includes lab.

CSD 300.course_description: An individualized course of study not available through or replacing existing curriculum, to be arranged between one matriculating student and sponsoring faculty member. All academic policies and registration deadlines apply. Directed Independent Study courses cannot substitute for General University Requirements and are not eligible for tuition waiver.

CSD 301.course_description: Instruction and practice in writing; includes opportunities for multi-drafting, revision, and reflection. Repeatable up to 2 credits.

CSD 352.course_name: Anatomy and Physiology of Speech Mechanisms
CSD 352.course_description: Structure and function of the nervous, respiratory, phonatory, and articulatory systems for speech production.

CSD 353.course_description: Instrumental measurement of respiration, phonation, and articulation. Lab required.

CSD 354.course_name: Speech and Language Development in Children
CSD 354.course_description: Typical speech and language acquisition; its impact on the developing child; origins and growth of symbolic processes, developmental norms; factors influencing learning of language and speech.

CSD 356.course_description: Training in recognition and production of sounds of spoken English through use of the International Phonetic Alphabet. Explanation of phonology and phonological processes and clinical analysis of phonological processing errors.

CSD 361.course_description: Etiologies of language learning disabilities in children from birth through school age; diagnosis and treatment procedures for children with language-learning impairments.

CSD 370.course_name: Adolescence and Young Adulthood in People with Autism
CSD 370.course_description: This course explores adolescence and young adulthood in people with autism. It will be primarily a lecture format with contributions from current college students with autism. Too often, ‘experts’ in the field of autism dispense information about people with autism reflecting a neurotypical perspective focused on deficits. Although identifying deficits can be helpful initially to receive a diagnosis and early intervention services, there should be a conscious shift during later childhood that builds on areas of strength and emphasizes the gifts that people with autism bring to society. In order to understand how autism more accurately affects people, we will be reading books and articles that were either written by people with autism, have a person with autism as the narrator, or contrast the largely negative historical view of autism with a current, positive neurodiverse approach.

CSD 371.course_description: Introduction to the nature of sound and its measurement. The structure and function of the auditory mechanism.

CSD 372.course_name: Anatomy, Physiology, and Disorders of Hearing and Balance
CSD 372.course_description: Structure, function, and disorders of auditory and balance mechanisms.

CSD 380.course_name: Peer Mentorship for College Students with Autism
CSD 380.course_description: Service learning project designed to teach upper level neurotypical college students how to support and coach college students with autism. Areas of mentorship may include, but are not limited to: developing interpersonal relationships, understanding and coping with feelings of anxiety and stress, prioritizing academic coursework and assignments, navigating and accessing campus programs, support and advocacy on campus across academic, social and living environments. Mentors will generally meet once per week with mentees, as well as once per week with Director. A one-year academic commitment is required in order to develop a solid relationship with your assigned mentee and minimize transitions and disruptions to service. Repeatable up to 12 credits including original course.

CSD 381.course_name: Physiological and Psychological Bases of Hearing
CSD 381.course_description: The study of the structure and function of the auditory system. Analysis of significant theories in speech acoustics and speech perception. Examination of the effects of hearing impairment on speech perception.

CSD 400.course_description: An individualized course of study not available through or replacing existing curriculum, to be arranged between one matriculating student and sponsoring faculty member. All academic policies and registration deadlines apply. Directed Independent Study courses cannot substitute for General University Requirements and are not eligible for tuition waiver.

CSD 440.course_name: Augmentative and Alternative Communication for CSD and Related Disciplines
CSD 440.course_description: Introduction to collaborative assessment and intervention in augmentative and alternative communication techniques with individuals with severe communication disorders.

CSD 450.course_name: Neuroanatomy for Speech Pathology and Audiology
CSD 450.course_description: Normal and abnormal structures of the human nervous system as they pertain to speech, language and hearing. Particular emphasis on sensory and motor pathways, localization and lateralization.

CSD 453.course_description: An introduction to the nature, assessment, and treatment of select speech disorders.

CSD 457.course_description: Current principles, methods and materials used in the assessment and treatment of a variety of communication disorders. Directed observation. Writing proficiency course.

CSD 460.course_description: Current principles, methods, and application of research-based theories to a dynamic clinical process which includes identification, prevention, assessment, and intervention for communication disorders. Lab required.

CSD 462.course_description: Introduction to the theory and application of pure tone, immittance and speech audiometry to the assessment of hearing function; implications for rehabilitation.

CSD 463.course_description: Listening training, speech reading, orientation to amplification devices, and coping skills for the aurally handicapped.

CSD 464.course_description: Supervised clinical practice in the (re)habilitation of the deaf and hard of hearing. Repeatable to a maximum of 6 credits. S/U grading.

CSD 466.course_description: Pathologies of the hearing mechanism and their auditory manifestations. Discussion with physicians regarding diagnosis, referrals and report writing.

CSD 468.course_description: Supervised clinical practice in audiological evaluation. Repeatable to a maximum of 6 cr. S/U grading.

CSD 470.course_name: Acquired Disorders of Language and Cognition in Adults
CSD 470.course_description: An overview of acquired disorders of language and cognition in adult and geriatric populations. The course will introduce students to basic language and cognitive processes; etiology, characteristics, and neuropathology of aphasia, TBI, right hemisphere disorder, and dementia; and principles of evidence-based practice.

CSD 482.course_description: Study of history, development, and use of emerging technologies and special clinical instrumentation for the evaluation of hearing, auditory function, and balance.

CSD 483.course_description: Study of history, development, and use of amplification and other sensory devices for treatment of hearing loss and auditory processing deficits.

CSD 485.course_name: Children With Hearing Loss in School
CSD 485.course_description: This course will introduce the student to the needs of the hearing impaired child in the public school environment, the public school laws affecting the placement of such children, and the types of remediation that occur in this setting.

CSD 486.course_name: Infants and Children With Hearing Loss
CSD 486.course_description: Developmental milestones of auditory functions, implications of childhood hearing loss, and observation of pediatric assessment utilizing current evaluation techniques.

CSD 487.course_description: Noise as a public health hazard.  The effect of noise on hearing.  Noise abatement, control and protection.  Federal and state noise regulations and compensation for noise induced hearing loss (NIHL).

CSD 488.course_description: Study of the nature and implications of hearing loss across the adult age spectrum.  Anatomic and physiologic influences of aging on the auditory system and how these changes influence auditory function and communication will be highlighted.

CSD 490.course_name: Social, Political, Cultural Aspects of Communication Disorders
CSD 490.course_description: Introduction to social, political, and cultural forces impacting communication  and communication disorders.  Overview of theories and research tools that guide our observations of these forces.  Emphasis on becoming culturally competent in providing educational and health care services to diverse client population.

CSD 491.course_description: Research-based writing or field project under direction of faculty advisor. Must be taken Fall, Winter and Spring quarters of senior year for 2 credits each quarter. Repeatable to a maximum of 6 credits.

CSD 499.course_name: Field Placement/Observation in Speech-Language Pathology or Audiology
CSD 499.course_description: Off-campus field experience in an approved setting designed to introduce students to management of communication disorders. Subject to availability of suitable site. Repeatable up to 6 credits. S/U grading.

CSD 500.course_description: An individualized course of study not available through or replacing existing curriculum, to be arranged between one matriculating student and sponsoring faculty member. All academic policies and registration deadlines apply.

CSD 501.course_name: Counseling in Communication Sciences and Disorders
CSD 501.course_description: Contemporary theories and techniques for counseling individuals with communication disorders.

CSD 502.course_name: Evidence-Based Practice in Communication Sciences and Disorders
CSD 502.course_description: This course focuses on the processes used in research and the integration of research principles into evidence-based clinical practice. Topics include constructing clinical research questions, accessing sources of research information, understanding and critically evaluating research methods and designs, and appraising treatment, diagnostic, and patient/practice evidence to inform clinical practice.

CSD 503.course_description: This course provides conference-based opportunities for practicing professionals to engage in learning about current research and treatment strategies on a variety of special education issues, including communication disorders.  The courses are intended for the professional development of the conference attendee.  The WWU credits may not be used as elective credits in a graduate degree program.

CSD 504.course_description: Student presentations of patient cases and clinical topics in audiology. Repeatable up to 10 credits including original course. S/U grading.

CSD 505.course_description: Clinical competency assessment at each of four successive clinical levels. Repeatable up to a maximum of 4 credits, including original course. S/U grading.

CSD 506.course_description: Current and future audiology practice models and related professional issues. The course will be taught in seminar format and across multiple quarters.  Different professional issues and practice patterns will be addressed each quarter. Repeatable to a maximum of 12 credits including original course.

CSD 507.course_description: Research-based project or non-research project (i.e. treatise on clinical procedures relative to diagnosis or remediation, informational materials relevant for community workshops, instructional videos, interactive software, etc.). Repeatable to a maximum of 6 credits, including the original course.

CSD 508.course_description: Introduction to research in the field of Audiology. Topics include the scientific method, research strategies and designs, data collection and analysis, and interpretation of results.

CSD 509.course_description: Topics include the scientific method, research strategies and designs, data collection and analysis, and interpretation of results.

CSD 510.course_name: Assessment and Treatment of Resonance Disorders
CSD 510.course_description: A review of the etiologies and nature of cleft lip and palate and communication disorders associated with cleft lip and palate; and diagnostic and intervention approaches for treating cleft and non-cleft resonance disorders.

CSD 515.course_description: Current topics and issues related to evidence-based assessment and treatment of speech sound disorders (SSDs).

CSD 540.course_name: Essential Audiology for Speech Language Pathologists
CSD 540.course_description: Essential knowledge and skills required of speech-language pathologists in providing optimal clinical services to clients with hearing loss and auditory processing issues.

CSD 542.course_description: Pathophysiology and evaluation of swallowing disorders; diagnostic evaluation and management/rehabilitation in adults, infants, and children.

CSD 543.course_description: This seminar introduces students to current topics related to professional practice in speech-language pathology.

CSD 550.course_description: Examines the biological, functional, and psychological contributors to changes in vocal quality, pitch, loudness, and resonance. Introduces instrumental, perceptual, and survey methods to measure the voice. Introduces orientations to voice therapy, treatment approaches, and cancer of the larynx and post laryngectomy rehabilitation. Lab required.

CSD 551.course_description: Graduate level seminar focused on the application of evidence-based assessment and therapeutic supports for children with developmental language disabilities in varying contexts (e.g., homes, preschools, elementary/high schools). It is the third in a three-course series.

CSD 552.course_description: This class is an on-campus practicum using specialized methods, tests and instruments used in the assessment and evaluation of a variety of communication disorders.

CSD 553.course_description: Graduate level seminar on the nature, diagnosis, and therapeutic support of developmental language disabilities. Content will include foundational theories, and principles and methods of assessment and therapeutic support of foundational language components supporting oral language. It is the first in a three-course series.

CSD 554.course_description: Analysis of current models and recent research on stuttering and cluttering disorders; chief rationale for therapy and evaluation of therapy procedures and results. Review and practice of clinical assessment and intervention.

CSD 555.course_description: Graduate level seminar on the nature, diagnosis, and therapeutic support of developmental language disabilities. Content will include evidenced-based methods of assessment and support of advanced language components supporting oral as well as literate language. It is the second in a three-course series.

CSD 556.course_name: Assessment and Treatment of Aphasia & Related Acquired Language Disorders
CSD 556.course_description: Facilitation of student knowledge and skill with multimodal acquired language impairments, including etiology, characteristics, neuroanatomical, psychological, linguistic, and cultural correlates. Includes differential diagnosis, assessment, and treatment methods. Focus on adult populations.

CSD 558.course_name: Graduate Clinical Practice in Speech-Language Pathology
CSD 558.course_description: The purpose of this course is to apply clinical processes and to provide information that will help students embark on clinical assignments with confidence and knowledge. Clinical problem-solving will be highlighted through weekly class meetings and clinical team discussions. The course will include a variety of clinically related discussions, presentations, simulations, and demonstrations of various treatment techniques. This is a course for students in their first and second year of graduate school. Students are assigned clients to serve in the Western Washington University Speech-Language Clinic. Repeatable to a maximum of 25 credits and 9 times, including original course.

CSD 559.course_description: Must be completed with a grade of B- or better.

CSD 561.course_description: Study of basic auditory correlates and advanced diagnostic audiometric procedures.

CSD 563.course_description: This course provides an overview of the psychosocial impact of auditory disorders on adults and children and their families, rehabilitation available for adults and children who are deaf or hard of hearing, and the effects of technology on therapy and teaching.

CSD 564.course_name: Advanced Clinical Practice in Aural Rehabilitation
CSD 564.course_description: Supervised practice in rehabilitation of individuals who are deaf or hard of hearing. Students must demonstrate clinical competence across domains to earn a grade of Satisfactory in this course. Repeatable to a maximum of 16 credits, including original course.

CSD 565.course_description: Application of standard psychophysical techniques and theory of signal detection to audiologic research.

CSD 566.course_description: The ear as a transducer and analyzer; electrophysiological and mechanical properties of the ear.

CSD 568.course_description: To be taken in sequence; must have a minimum of 25 hours of documented speech-language pathology/audiology and rehabilitation observations. Clinical practicum designed to advance skills in audiology. Students must demonstrate clinical competence across domains to earn a grade of Satisfactory in this course. Repeatable to a maximum of 16 credits, including original course.

CSD 569.course_name: Advanced Clinical Practice in Aural Rehabilitation
CSD 569.course_description: Supervised clinical practicum. S/U grading. Offered summer only. Repeatable to 4 credits.

CSD 570.course_description: Pathologies of the hearing mechanism and their auditory manifestations. Discussion with physicians regarding diagnosis, referrals and report writing.

CSD 571.course_description: This course is designed to provide students with a foundation in fundamental amplification principles and technology used in the hearing aid industry. The course will focus on both hardware and software technology used in modern air and bone conduction hearing aids and hearing assistive technology systems (HATS) as well as the principles that underlie those technologies. While some attention will be given to specific hearing aid products currently available, rapidly changing product lines demand that the main focus be on underlying principles. The course is intended for students who desire to learn more about amplification for the hearing impaired. Students who successfully complete the course will have a working knowledge of modern hearing aids, their design and function, measurement and modification of the hearing aid response, and earmold acoustics.

CSD 572.course_description: This course is designed to build upon fundamentals learned in Hearing Aids I (CSD 571), by providing information and training related to the assessment, selection, fitting, verification, and validation processes associated with modern air and bone conduction hearing aids and other hearing assistive technology systems (HATS). While current hearing aid products will be discussed, students’ training will focus on fundamental knowledge of the devices as technology is rapidly changes.

CSD 573.course_description: In-depth study of the acoustic speech signal. Analysis of significant theories in speech production/acoustics. Application of relevant acoustic principles in the evaluation and remediation of communicative disabilities.

CSD 574.course_description: Critical analysis of current issues in speech perception. Examination of the effects of communication disabilities on speech perception.

CSD 575.course_description: Contemporary theories and techniques of counseling individuals with communication disorders and their families.

CSD 576.course_description: Processes and theories of cognitive functions; assessment and management of cognitive disorders associated with acquired brain injury.

CSD 577.course_description: Developmental milestones of auditory function, implications of childhood hearing loss and supervised testing of pediatric patients utilizing basic and advanced testing techniques.

CSD 578.course_description: Current topics and issues in specialized areas of averaged electro-encephalic audiometry and otoacoustic emissions; research trends and problems. Lab required.

CSD 579.course_description: Anatomical and physiological influences of aging on the auditory mechanism and how these changes influence overall auditory function and communication.

CSD 580.course_name: Communication Disorders in the Public Schools
CSD 580.course_description: Role of the professional in organizing and directing a speech-language therapy or audiology program in the public school setting. Required for public school certification.

CSD 581.course_description: Assessment of the auditory system via early, middle, late, and cognitive auditory evoked potentials.

CSD 582.course_description: Current topics and issues related to the practice of speech pathology in a medical/clinical setting.

CSD 583.course_description: Focus on advanced level audiologic protocols for diagnosis and management of congenital and acquired disorders of the auditory and vestibular systems.

CSD 585.course_description: Current literature review and discussion of the nature of neurologically based speech disorders (dysarthrias and apraxia). Examination and practice of clinical intervention methods.

CSD 587.course_description: Focus on the cochlear implant, including technology, patient candidacy, medical process, post-implantation aural (re)habilitation, and controversial issues surrounding cochlear implantation.

CSD 588.course_name: Seminar in Augmentative and Alternative Communication
CSD 588.course_description: Focus on evaluation and intervention for children, adolescence and adults with moderate to severe congenital or acquired disorders in speech and language who require augmentative and alternative models for oral or written communication.

CSD 590.course_description: This course will focus on the role of the audiologist in the school system, audiologic services, and service delivery models to assist school-aged children who are deaf or hard of hearing, and children who have auditory processing difficulties.

CSD 591.course_description: Course will focus on the provision of auditory rehabilitation services to infants and young children who are deaf or hard of hearing.

CSD 592.course_name: Seminar in Autism for Speech-Language Pathologists
CSD 592.course_description: This course focuses on special topics related to the roles and responsibilities of Speech-Language Pathologists serving Autistic individuals. Topics include diagnosis/evaluation, intervention and contemporary discourse on autism and neurodiversity.

CSD 593.course_description: Current technology and procedures involved in the clinical assessment of balance disorders.

CSD 595.course_description: Clinical assessment and treatment of tinnitus and other sound tolerance conditions.

CSD 596.course_description: Supervised, part-time off-campus practice experience. Repeatable to a maximum of 12 credits, including original course. S/U grading.

CSD 598.course_name: Internship in Speech-Language Pathology or Audiology
CSD 598.course_description: Supervised, part-time experience providing opportunities to develop and demonstrate clinical competence in an approved setting. Placement is dependent on a suitable site. S/U grading. Repeatable up to 8 credits.

CSD 599.course_description: Supervised, full-time, off-campus experience providing opportunities to develop and demonstrate clinical competence in an approved setting. Placement is dependent on a suitable site. S/U grading. Repeatable up to 16 credits.

CSD 691.course_description: Writing based on research or clinical projects.

CSD 692.course_description: Full time year long clinical externship placement will allow students to develop their skills as an audiologist. An externship may consist of placement at one site or simultaneous or sequential rotations at multiple sites. Repeatable to a maximum of 32 credits, including original course. S/U grading.

COMM 100.course_description: This course will teach students the process of creating speeches, from the beginning to end. We will discuss the basic principles and strategies of public speaking. Students will apply each principle as the speaker and listener. Students will have the opportunity to select a current diverse issue that is related to social justice, equity, and inclusion. In addition, students will learn how to build their self-concept in preparation for their speeches. The class will consist of fun role playing, discussions, observations, reflections, skills-rehearsals, and lectures.

COMM 101.course_description: Functional approach to effective communication. Emphasizes the application of principles to practical problems in speech for persons with little or no previous public speaking experience.

COMM 220.course_description: Survey of human communication focuses on communication theories, concepts and principles ranging from intrapersonal to interpersonal, group, organizational, rhetorical, intercultural, international and mass communication.

COMM 224.course_description: Exploration of the dynamics of human interaction in small group settings. Group tasks include the development of problem-solving skills, utilizing topics of current interest.

COMM 225.course_description: This course is designed to foster the skills necessary for civil engagement and effective dialogue on controversial issues. Students will learn to appreciate, integrate, and effectively challenge diverse perspectives on a number of traditionally divisive topics.

COMM 228.course_description: Survey of research and theories in organizational communication. Introduces students to communication theories and concepts relating to workplace practices and processes.

COMM 230.course_description: Students are introduced to  rhetorical theories and modes of criticism that inform the study and pursuit of social change. Emphasis is placed on the important role rhetoric plays in contemporary public discourse and democratic citizenship.

COMM 235.course_description: Students are introduced to the principles of persuasive argumentation and advocacy. Students gain practical experience through applied debate, research, and presentation exercises. This course also teaches students core library skills related to research at the college level, information literacy, and critical thinking.

COMM 236.course_description: Applied Practice course that requires participation in at least 2 weekend competitions throughout the quarter on a designated topic for debate. Students gain introductory applied knowledge in argument construction and refutation, research, critical thinking, and oral communication. Offered Fall and Winter only. Repeatable to a maximum of 6 credits, including original course. S/U grading.

COMM 240.course_description: This course develops students’ ability to think critically about mass media. Media messages and images are examined, as well as the social, political, and historical significance of media.

COMM 244.course_description: Introduction to nonprofit information campaigns, social issues marketing and other forms of advocacy through contemporary mass media. Students will learn basic theories and engage in applied exercises.

COMM 260.course_description: This course introduces students to communication theories that explore the ways discourses produce, reinforce, and challenge our understandings of identity — as well as how these identities interact with discourses of difference. By critically engaging the politics of representation, intersectionality, materialism, and power, this course questions identity and difference from hybrid perspectives rather than taking up isolated categories (such as race, gender, sexuality, disAbility, and class) as distinct particulars. The course will particularly emphasize debates within Communication Studies that problematize contemporary discourses and practices of multiculturalism. Students will be encouraged to understand how communication works to oppress certain populations while privileging others.

COMM 300.course_description: An individualized course of study not available through or replacing existing curriculum, to be arranged between one matriculating student and sponsoring faculty member. All academic policies and registration deadlines apply. Directed Independent Study courses cannot substitute for General University Requirements and are not eligible for tuition waiver.

COMM 303.course_description: This course examines the role of communication in conflict. Students will examine the nature and causes of conflict and will explore practical methods as well as theoretical models for dealing with conflict in diverse relational contexts.

COMM 306.course_description: Coursework examines the skills and techniques of event planning by emphasizing communication and organizational skills and theories that contribute to developing and managing successful events. Students work primarily in groups throughout the course, planning hypothetical events as well as actual events as part of service-learning based assignments.

COMM 308.course_description: Students will learn verbal and nonverbal communication skills regarding the donor-centered approach to fundraising, fundraising program research, and fundraising budgets. Students will be required to conduct a group fundraising event during the quarter.

COMM 318.course_description: This course integrates business writing, presentations, collaborative problem-solving, and diversity training in a professional development context. Theoretical application and skill development are emphasized. Students may be guided to collaborate with organizations on or off campus.

COMM 319.course_description: Survey of health communication theory and research. Introduces students to theories, research, practices, and skills related to health communication across interpersonal, intercultural, group, and various media platforms. Students will examine current issues related to healthcare practices, such as health literacy, access and equity, communication-based education, outreach, and research in health and risk communication.

COMM 325.course_description: Introduction to intercultural communication. Principles, concepts and various topics in this rapidly growing, important field. Covers the needed knowledge and skills in communicating effectively with people of diverse cultural backgrounds.

COMM 327.course_description: Focuses on theory and practice in work, family, and social settings. Emphasizes observation, analysis, and skills training in relationship development. Topics include language use, listening, nonverbal behavior and conflict management.

COMM 330.course_description: This class is an exploration of the way the environment is represented rhetorically and the implications this has for public policy and personal action.

COMM 331.course_description: Theory and practice in the art of public discourse.

COMM 339.course_description: Students function in a variety of directed studies and contexts in which they apply their communication skills. Covers putting theory into practice in such areas as small group communication, interpersonal communication, organizational communication, intercultural communication and applied public information strategies. Repeatable to a maximum of 6 credits including the original course. S/U grading.

COMM 342.course_description: Course includes practical application of techniques used in video production. Utilizes digital technology, graphic materials, design and staging. Students will learn the role of producer and director. S/U grading.

COMM 350.course_description: Primary course objective is technological literacy - gaining skills and experience for working with emerging communication technologies. Students will engage in a range of experiential and service-learning assignments using various emerging technologies. Secondary objective is technology critique and the study of theories of technology.

COMM 365.course_description: Students will study the evolving theory and practice of nonviolent social change in historical context. Emphasis will be placed on the central role of symbolic actions, issue framing, social movement learning and training, media coverage, social media use, and other communicative dimensions. Empirical evidence regarding the relative efficacy of nonviolent movements will also be examined, along with their ethical and philosophical underpinnings.

COMM 398.course_description: Course should be taken as soon as possible after admission to the major as it is prerequisite for most 400-level communication courses. Survey of qualitative and quantitative research methods utilized in the field of communication.

COMM 400.course_description: An individualized course of study not available through or replacing existing curriculum, to be arranged between one matriculating student and sponsoring faculty member. All academic policies and registration deadlines apply. Directed Independent Study courses cannot substitute for General University Requirements and are not eligible for tuition waiver.

COMM 416.course_description: In-depth coverage of special topics in communication, rhetoric and mass media. The subject of each individual course may differ. Repeatable with different topics to a maximum of 12 credits.

COMM 420.course_description: In-depth examination of advanced theories in human communication. Emphasis on theory development.

COMM 425.course_description: Introduction to dynamic forces that enhance effective communication between persons with various cultural backgrounds. Covers topics such as differences, similarities, values, pride and prejudice, cultural barriers in communication settings, and effectiveness of intercultural communication.

COMM 427.course_description: Senior seminar that offers an in-depth examination of theories and practices in interpersonal communication.

COMM 428.course_description: Reviews current theory and research on topics such as communication and organizational decision making, organizational culture, gender relations, and power and control in organizations.

COMM 430.course_description: This course aims to interrogate the relationship between rhetoric and the image. Devoting attention to theories that explore the symbolic and performative dimensions of visual culture, this course introduces advanced students to theories of perception and visual interpretation as they relate to visual communication, media and film studies, cultural studies, art, literature, memory, and the public spectacle.

CSCI 578.course_description: Selected topics from number theory; simple, homophonic, polyalphabetic substitution ciphers; product ciphers, DES; exponentiation ciphers; knapsack ciphers; key management.

CSCI 579.course_description: Introduction to the automatic processing of spoken language. Fundamental theory and algorithms in speech processing, including speech analysis, recognition and synthesis, as well as the linguistic and mathematical theory on which spoken language processing systems rely. Implementation of spoken language processing systems is required.

CSCI 580.course_description: An introduction to computer graphics with a focus on 3D rendering. Topics include representation and manipulation of 3D geometry, modeling, and rendering using both ray tracing and rasterization.

CSCI 581.course_description: Covers the fundamentals of deep learning, including important models, such as deep feedforward, recurrent, convolutional and transformer neural networks, and algorithms and considerations for training them. The application of deep learning to domains such as natural language, speech and vision will also be discussed.

CSCI 584.course_description: Introduction to the computer display of scientific datasets. Topics include visualizing 2D and 3D scalar and vector fields, visualizing nonlinear relationships, and user interface design.

CSCI 585.course_description: Digital image fundamentals, image transforms, image enhancements, image restoration, image encoding, representation and description, color image processing, morphological operations.

CSCI 590.course_description: Students will discuss state-of-the-art computer science research papers in various topics. External speakers may be invited. The objectives are to expose students to a wide range of state-of-the-art research topics and to provide opportunities for students to share research experiences. Repeatable to a maximum of 3 credits.

CSCI 591.course_description: Students will discuss state-of-the-art computer science research papers in various topics. External speakers may be invited. The objectives are to expose students to a wide range of state-of-the-art research topics and to provide opportunities for students to share research experiences. Each student will read and give a presentation on a Computer Science research paper to other students in CSCI 590 and CSCI 591. Repeatable to a maximum of 8 credits, including original course. S/U grading.

CSCI 601.course_name: Area of Specialization Research Experience I
CSCI 601.course_description: Work on ongoing research project. Credit given when CS 601, 602 and 603 completed. S/U grading.

CSCI 602.course_name: Area of Specialization Research Experience II
CSCI 602.course_description: Work on ongoing research project. Credit given when CS 601, 602 and 603 completed. S/U grading.

CSCI 603.course_name: Area of Specialization Research Experience III
CSCI 603.course_description: Work on ongoing research project.  S/U grading.

CSCI 692.course_description: The course provides research experience for students through project work under the guidance of a research advisor. Students learn about a computer science topic in depth and apply their computer science knowledge to address a research problem. The research experience involves both learning and experimentation. Students work in close collaboration with their research advisor on all aspects of the research project. Students are given access to appropriate facilities to work on their research project. The course may be repeated up to four times. Credit will be given when research is completed. Repeatable up to 20 credits including original course. S/U grading.

CISS 247.course_description: An overview of basic computer organization and design. Introduction to C programming. Topics covered include data representation, boolean algebra, machine language, instruction sets, processor architecture, multi-processors, system-level I/O, pipelining, and the memory hierarchy. Includes lab.

CISS 301.course_description: Introduction to discrete structures important to cyber security, including sets, trees, graphs, functions, relations, Boolean logic, and modular arithmetic. Introduction to the formal language classes and their corresponding automata, including regular languages and finite automata, context free languages and pushdown automata. Turing machines and computability will be introduced. Includes lab.

CISS 340.course_description: This course covers the design, implementation, and use of databases. Students learn to analyze and model data and data usage to create an efficient, normalized database, to implement a database in a relational database management system (RDBMS), and to manipulate the data and data format using SQL. Students study other forms of databases, and the security implications of different databases and database access techniques.

CISS 346.course_description: Techniques, methodologies and processes for development of robust, secure software. Security development process, threat modeling, common software vulnerabilities, web site vulnerabilities, defensive coding practices, security testing.

CISS 349.course_description: A study of the tasks, tools and techniques involved in the configuration and administration of heterogeneous networks of Windows and UNIX/Linux computers, with particular emphasis on system hardening, protection against attack, system monitoring and recovery.

CISS 350.course_description: The intent of this course is to provide students with basic understanding of how networks are built and operate, and to give students some experience in using tools to monitor and analyze a network. The course provides an understanding of common network protocols, how network components interact, and how networks evolve over time. Students will become familiar with common network vulnerabilities.

CISS 360.course_description: A study of the principles and techniques employed in modern computer operating systems.  The emphasis is on process and thread creation, management and scheduling; system calls; memory management, virtual memory and paging; file system implementation, input/output systems and device management.

CISS 361.course_description: A study of the fundamental concepts of cybersecurity, including assessing threats and vulnerabilities, applying countermeasures, the principles of cybersecurity, the role of cryptography, and cybersecurity policy implementation. The course will also examine cybersecurity related topics such as cyber warfare.

CISS 421.course_description: Computer security incident response.  Investigation of security breaches of computer network, identification of causes and vulnerabilities.  Recovery of data from memory dumps.  Recovery of damaged file systems.

CISS 422.course_description: Tools and techniques for the investigation of suspect software by running it and watching its effect.  Establishing a safe work environment, monitoring system behavior, network monitoring, file system monitoring, event reconstruction.

CISS 423.course_description: Tools and techniques for the static analysis of software by disassembly of executable code.  De-obfuscation and decoding techniques.

CISS 461.course_description: An overview of computer security and detailed study of the theoretical foundations and practical implementations of some aspects of security, including policy specification, the role of cryptography, policy implementation and assurance, security threats and counter-measures.

CISS 464.course_description: Tools and techniques for penetration testing of application software and computer systems, with the aim of identifying vulnerabilities for remedial action. Understanding common vulnerabilities, selection and trial of exploits, shellcode.  Wireless penetration techniques.

CISS 469.course_description: Discussion of current topics security aspects of industrial control, SCADA systems, cloud computing, mobile devices.

CISS 470.course_description: This course examines the policy, legal, regulatory, framework, and standards documents that provide requirements and guidance for cybersecurity, and the resulting compliance and audit requirements. The course covers risk-based techniques for assessing compliance and integrating compliance initiatives into cybersecurity strategy, planning, and projects.

CISS 471.course_description: This course investigates issues that arise in Privacy and Ethics in an Internet connected world, and how those issues intersect with cybersecurity. The course examines how privacy and ethical issues have been, or are currently being, addressed. In addition, the course covers topics in cybercrime, cyber-stalking, and other abusive behaviors in cyberspace.

CISS 473.course_description: Cyber Space has joined air, land, sea and space as the latest domain of warfare. This course examines warfare in the cyber domain beginning with an understanding of how it fits within the context of traditional theory of war. The course examines how countries prepare and apply capabilities and strategies, the impacts of non-state actors, and the future development of cyber warfare. Students are prepared to understand the impact of the extension of warfare into the cyber domain.

CISS 478.course_description: A study of the cryptographic techniques and tools commonly used in support of security for computer systems and networks.

CISS 491.course_description: The first of a three part team-based project to apply the skills and knowledge attained during the program to real, significant industry-based applications. In the course students research the project background, define the problem, develop a plan or design for a solution, create a project plan to achieve the solution in a timely manner, and create appropriate documentation.

CISS 492.course_description: The second of a three part team-based project to apply the skills and knowledge attained during the program to real, significant industry-based applications. In this course, students will implement and develop the project defined in the previous course.

CISS 493.course_description: The third of a three part team-based project to apply the skills and knowledge attained during the program to real, significant industry-based applications. In this course, students will complete assessment, testing, and evaluation of the project. The students will also create a report and presentation detailing their project and results.

CISS 495.course_description: A capstone team-based project to enable students to apply the skills and knowledge attained during the program to real, significant industry-based applications.

DISA 300.course_description: An individualized course of study not available through or replacing existing curriculum, to be arranged between one matriculating student and sponsoring faculty member. All academic policies and registration deadlines apply. Directed Independent Study courses cannot substitute for General University Requirements and are not eligible for tuition waiver.

DISA 330.course_description: This course provides an exploration of the field of critical disability studies. Students will learn about several central topics, including, disability rights and disability justice movements, cultural criticism of literature and popular media, and the principles of universal design in physical and digital spaces. Students will explore disability as an identity category that intersects with other identity categories such as race, gender, and sexuality. This is an interdisciplinary course designed for students from any major.

DISA 350.course_description: This course examines topics in the field of Critical Disability Studies such as representations of disability in art and culture, Universal Design in physical and digital environments, the political and legal aspects of disability, the values and histories of disability communities, disability rights and disability justice movements, and/or cultural criticism of literature and popular media. This is an interdisciplinary course designed for students from any major. It is a required component of the Critical Disability Studies minor. Repeatable with different topics to a maximum of 10 credits and 3 times, including original course. May be repeated once in the minor under different topics or instructors. Maximum of 10 credits from this course may count for the minor.

DISA 400.course_description: An individualized course of study not available through or replacing existing curriculum, to be arranged between one matriculating student and sponsoring faculty member. All academic policies and registration deadlines apply. Directed Independent Study courses cannot substitute for General University Requirements and are not eligible for tuition waiver.

DISA 450.course_description: This Capstone seminar in Critical Disability Studies provides students with an opportunity to research a topic of their choice. Students will write a capstone proposal, conduct a research project and present findings.

DNC 100.course_description: Entry level technique class that is a fusion of hip-hop and dance styles of popular culture. Emphasis on rhythm, conditioning, isolation and individuality. Repeatable to a maximum of 6 credits. S/U grading.

DNC 101.course_description: No dance experience required. Basic principles of ballet as an artistic and physical medium. Introduction to ballet terminology, basic barre exercises, simple combinations in adagio and allegro. Repeatable up to 6 credits including original course. S/U grading.

DNC 102.course_description: No dance experienced required. The study of the basic principles of movement: space, time and effort. Emphasis on alignment and range of motion, creative movement and an appreciation of dance as an art form. Open to non-minors. Repeatable to a maximum of 6 credits. S/U grading.

DNC 108.course_description: An introduction to the fine and performing arts. Through an exploration of art forms such as music, art, theatre and dance, students will develop a more personal relationship with the arts. Students will learn to describe and evaluate the arts and investigate ways in which they interrelate.

DNC 111.course_description: Introduction to the basic principles of ballet as an artistic and physical medium. Emphasis on French terminology, basic barre exercises, simple combinations in adagio and allegro. Open to non-majors. Repeatable to a maximum of 4 credits.

DNC 112.course_description: Builds on principles introduced in DNC 111, including the basic principle of ballet as an artistic and physical medium. Emphasis on French terminology, basic barre exercises, simple combinations in adagio and allegro. Open to non-majors. Repeatable to a maximum of 4 credits.

DNC 113.course_description: Builds on principles introduced in DNC 112, including the basic principles of ballet as an artistic and physical medium. Emphasis on French terminology, basic barre exercises, simple combinations in adagio and allegro. Open to non-majors. Repeatable to a maximum of 4 credits.

DNC 121.course_description: The study of the basic principles of movement: space, time, effort. Emphasis on alignment and range of motion, creative movement and an appreciation of dance as an art form. Repeatable to maximum of 6 credits.

DNC 122.course_description: The study of the basic principles of movement: space, time, effort. Emphasis on alignment and range of motion, creative movement and an appreciation of dance as an art form. Repeatable to a maximum of 6 credits.

DNC 123.course_description: The study of the basic principles of movement: space, time, effort. Emphasis on alignment and range of motion, creative movement and an appreciation of dance as an art form. Repeatable to a maximum of 6 credits.

DNC 200.course_description: Intermediate exploration of hip-hop and dance styles of popular culture. Emphasis on complex rhythm, phrasing and performance. Repeatable to a maximum of 6 credits.

DNC 203.course_description: This course focuses on the technical and expressive aspects of jazz dance and develops awareness of line, speed, balance and strength. Attention is placed on alignment, conditioning, musicality, and synthesis of combinations.

DNC 211.course_description: Further development in principles of ballet. Increased difficulty and terminology. Preparation for advanced levels. Repeatable to a maximum of 6 credits, including original course.

DNC 212.course_description: Further development in principles of ballet. Increased difficulty and terminology. Preparation for advanced levels. Repeatable to a maximum of 6 credits, including original course.

DNC 213.course_description: Further development in principles of ballet. Increased difficulty and terminology. Preparation for advanced levels. Repeatable to a maximum of 6 credits, including original course.

DNC 221.course_description: Further development in movement principles established in Contemporary Dance I. Repeatable to a maximum of 6 credits, including original course.

DNC 222.course_description: Continues with further development in movement principles established in Contemporary Dance I. Repeatable to a maximum of 6 credits, including original course.

DNC 223.course_description: Continues with further development in movement principles established in Contemporary Dance I. Repeatable to a maximum of 6 credits, including original course.

DNC 231.course_description: This writing course employs a historical and cultural introduction to dance.

DNC 232.course_description: An investigation of dance and performing arts as agents of change for accessibility, equity, diversity, and inclusion.

DNC 240.course_description: Provides in-depth study of a specific dance or somatic practice with a quarterly rotation. Repeatable with different topics to a maximum of 6 credits, including original course.

DNC 242.course_description: Introduction to basic principles of choreography: articulating a concept, finding movement vocabulary, and developing a structure. Prepares students to handle the rehearsal process from the point of view of a choreographer. Repeatable to a maximum of 6 credits.

DNC 243.course_description: Introduction to sound and video editing software and filming/framing techniques for use in the creation of Dances for Camera and other time based art. Repeatable up to a maximum of 6 credits.

DNC 257.course_description: Direct instruction and experience in performance work. Repeatable to a maximum of 8 credits. S/U grading.

DNC 300.course_description: An individualized course of study not available through or replacing existing curriculum, to be arranged between one matriculating student and sponsoring faculty member. All academic policies and registration deadlines apply. Directed Independent Study courses cannot substitute for General University Requirements and are not eligible for tuition waiver.

DNC 311.course_description: Comprehensive barre and center floor work with emphasis on strength, flexibility, stamina, musicality, and performance projection in all areas of the class enchainements. Variations from classical ballet repertoire may be included. Repeatable to a maximum of 12 credits, including the original course.

DNC 312.course_description: Comprehensive barre and center floor work with emphasis on strength, flexibility, stamina, musicality, and performance projection in all areas of the class enchainements. Variations from classical ballet repertoire may be included. Repeatable to a maximum of 12 credits, including the original course.

DNC 313.course_description: Comprehensive barre and center floor work with emphasis on strength, flexibility, stamina, musicality, and performance projection in all areas of the class enchainements. Variations from classical ballet repertoire may be included. Repeatable to a maximum of 12 credits, including the original course.

DNC 321.course_description: Advanced studies of movement principles established in Contemporary Dance II. Repeatable to a maximum of 12 credits, including original course.

DNC 322.course_description: Advanced studies of movement principles established in Contemporary Dance II. Repeatable to a maximum of 12 credits, including original course.

DNC 323.course_description: Advanced studies of movement principles established in Contemporary Dance II. Repeatable to a maximum of 12 credits, including original course.

DNC 332.course_description: A historical and cultural study of artistic and popular cultural depictions of dance in music videos, movies, fashion, video games, and social media analyzing the intersections of society, performer, choreographer, and viewer.

DNC 339.course_description: An internal exploration of functional alignment and its practical application towards movement and dancing. Experiential exercises that will enable the development and increased awareness of anatomical alignment and its relationship to range of motion, flexibility, strength, and movement potential. Introduction to proper anatomical and kinesiological terminology. Repeatable to a maximum of 6 credits.

DNC 340.course_description: An investigation of the human body and how it works. Through lectures, readings and laboratory experiences, students will analyze skeletal systems, individual differences, common dance injuries, and proper conditioning for dancers.

DNC 342.course_description: Further study of the principles of choreography. In addition to concepts, movement, vocabulary and structure this class involves experimentation with theme and development, use of music, as well as construction/deconstruction/reconstruction of choreographic forms and content. Training the thinking artist and the artistic thinker. Repeatable to a maximum of 8 cr.

DNC 343.course_description: Builds on skills learned in DNC 243 and applies an artistic process to the use of editing software and video equipment; combining visual design, choreographic skills and advanced filming and editing techniques to create Dances for the Camera and other time based art. Repeatable to a maximum of 6 credits.

DNC 345.course_description: Students explore elements of contemporary partnering including transfer of weight, momentum/leverage, counter balancing and moving in harmony. The class is not gender specific. The warm-up includes exercises to enhance kinesthetic awareness and to facilitate ease and comfort in lifting and being lifted. Repeatable to a maximum of 6 cr.

DNC 357.course_description: The process work, which leads to performance, involved in the creation and/or reconstruction of a major choreographic work. Repeatable to a maximum of 8 credits.

DNC 398.course_description: This arts education course provides future teachers with a foundation in the elements and principles of Visual Art, Dance, Music and Theatre and their applicability to the elementary classroom. Also offered as ART 398, MUS 398 and THTR 398.

DNC 400.course_description: An individualized course of study not available through or replacing existing curriculum, to be arranged between one matriculating student and sponsoring faculty member. All academic policies and registration deadlines apply. Directed Independent Study courses cannot substitute for General University Requirements and are not eligible for tuition waiver.

DNC 403.course_description: This course is designed for senior Dance majors to focus on skills and knowledge important for a successful transition to graduate school or professional employment in dance.

DNC 404.course_description: This course is designed to assist BFA candidates with their rehearsal processes, as performers and as choreographers, in preparation for and presentation of their culminating Capstone performances.

DNC 421.course_description: A performance approach to dance techniques - phrasing, musicality and clarity of intentions are emphasized at this level. Repeatable to a maximum of 12 credits, including original course.

DNC 422.course_description: A performance approach to dance techniques - phrasing, musicality and clarity of intentions are emphasized at this level. Repeatable to a maximum of 12 credits, including original course.

DNC 423.course_description: A performance approach to dance techniques - phrasing, musicality and clarity of intentions are emphasized at this level. Repeatable to a maximum of 12 credits, including original course.

DNC 431.course_description: Critical inquiry into historical movement practices and performance, with a focus on research of leading dance artists and their historical and cultural significance. This course explores effective writing in the discipline of Dance through reflection, critical analysis, and historical research.

DNC 433.course_name: Creative Movement for Educators With Lab
DNC 433.course_description: Methodologies of teaching creative movement to children. Exploration and integration of the elements of space, time, and effort as reflective of the Essential Academic Learning Requirements in the dance arts.

DNC 434.course_description: Critical inquiry of best practices in dance teaching methods. Includes theory and practice of principles, methods, and application of teaching dance technique.

DNC 442.course_description: Practical application of choreographic process in the performance setting. Experience in collaboration with costume and lighting designers to support and realize choreographic intention by means of the unity of supporting elements. Repeatable to a maximum of 8 credits.

DATA 311.course_description: Introduction to the fundamentals of data science, focusing on techniques for collecting, processing, visualizing and organizing data. Applied machine learning concepts will also be covered, including fundamentals of machine learning experimentation and the use of libraries to perform clustering, classification and regression. Includes lab.

DATA 471.course_description: Key machine learning theory, algorithms and experimentation techniques. Generalization, bias and variance. Classification, regression, and clustering. Linear models and nonlinear models, including neural networks. Ethical issues in machine learning.

DATA 490.course_description: Senior data science research project conducted under the supervision of a faculty member. Repeatable to a maximum of 6 credits, including original course.

DATA 491.course_description: Project initiation. Students work in teams on a data science project under the guidance of faculty and possibly industry sponsors. Work involves data acquisition, data management, data preparation and integration, data analysis, model development and deployment, and visualization. The emphasis of this course is on data acquisition, data management, data preparation, and formalizing project plans.

DATA 492.course_description: Project continuation. Students work in teams on a data science project under the guidance of faculty and possibly industry sponsors. Work involves data acquisition, data management, data preparation and integration, data analysis, model development and deployment, and visualization. The emphasis of this course is on data analysis, model development, and experimentation.

DATA 493.course_description: Project conclusion. Students work in teams on a data science project under the guidance of faculty and possibly industry sponsors. Work involves data acquisition, data management, data preparation and integration, data analysis, model development and deployment, and visualization. The emphasis of this course is on experimentation, results analysis, visualization, and communicating project findings.

DATA 571.course_description: Key machine learning theory, algorithms and experimentation techniques. Generalization, bias and variance. Classification, regression, and clustering. Linear models and nonlinear models, including neural networks. Ethical issues in machine learning.

DSCI 205.course_description: Statistical methods used in business research, analysis and decision making; preparation and presentation of data, frequency distributions, measures of central tendency and dispersion, statistical inference, regression and correlation.

DSCI 207.course_description: An introduction to the use of mathematical and statistical tools to analyze and understand data from sporting events.

DSCI 300.course_description: An individualized course of study not available through or replacing existing curriculum, to be arranged between one matriculating student and sponsoring faculty member. All academic policies and registration deadlines apply. Directed Independent Study courses cannot substitute for General University Requirements and are not eligible for tuition waiver.

DSCI 305.course_description: Examines the concepts and methods of extracting information from data for making decisions in business. Focuses on data visualization, statistical inference, and prediction (regression and classification) with emphasis on the use of computer software programs.

DSCI 400.course_description: An individualized course of study not available through or replacing existing curriculum, to be arranged between one matriculating student and sponsoring faculty member. All academic policies and registration deadlines apply. Directed Independent Study courses cannot substitute for General University Requirements and are not eligible for tuition waiver.

COMM 435.course_description: In-depth examination of advanced theories in rhetorical theory and criticism.

COMM 436.course_description: Applied Practice course that requires active and consistent participation with WWU intercollegiate debate program including participation in weekend competitions throughout the quarter. Students gain advanced applied knowledge in argument construction and refutation, research, critical thinking, and oral communication. Repeatable to a maximum of 6 credits, including original course. A combined total of 6 credits from COMM 236 and COMM 436 may be applied to the Communication Studies major. S/U grading.

COMM 440.course_description: Examination of advanced theories in mass communication and media literacy. Examines social, political, and economic forces that shape media; influences of media on society; and issues of media policy, media advocacy, and media reform.

COMM 450.course_description: Serve as undergraduate tutor for students taking communication courses. Learn instructional methods and gain further mastery of course content. Conduct supervised tutoring and feedback for students enrolled in communication courses. S/U grading

COMM 451.course_description: Help supervise teams of undergraduate tutors. Develop leadership, organizational and pedagogical skills. S/U grading.

COMM 452.course_description: Students enrolled in this course are the instructor assistants (IAs) returning to the COMM 101 program for the third time.
