Topics covered include the theory of economic integration, institutions of the EU, various current policy and agenda issues, and a look at EU economic relations with the U.S. and world economies.

ECON 389.course_description: The Pacific Rim treated as a distinct economic region. Topics include economic development patterns, interdependence, and economic achievements and problems. Specific emphasis on trade, development and policy relations involving the U.S., Japan and the so-called newly industrialized countries.

ECON 390.course_description: Eligibility outlined in departmental internship policy statement. Repeatable to a maximum of 10 cr.

ECON 400.course_description: An individualized course of study not available through or replacing existing curriculum, to be arranged between one matriculating student and sponsoring faculty member. All academic policies and registration deadlines apply. Directed Independent Study courses cannot substitute for General University Requirements and are not eligible for tuition waiver.

ECON 406.course_description: Application of quantitative and theoretical tools in key areas of microeconomics, with emphasis on quantitative models of the consumer, cost and production analysis of the firm, and market analysis. Special topics may include choice under uncertainty, capital markets, game theory, general equilibrium theory, and the economics of information.

ECON 407.course_description: Examination of current issues in macroeconomic theory and policy. Emphasis on recent U.S. experience, with particular attention given to inflation, unemployment, growth and the balance of payments. Includes extensive reading in current professional journals.

ECON 410.course_description: Benefit-cost analysis is an important tool for evaluating the economic impacts of public or private actions. Course provides students with a thorough understanding of the logical underpinnings of benefit-cost analysis and experience in applying benefit-cost analysis to ‘real-world’ problems.

ECON 411.course_description: Examines the theory and implementation of monetary policy. Topics may include the transmission mechanism of monetary policy, interest rate rules, the credibility of policymakers, and exchange rates. Special consideration is given to empirically measuring the impact of money on real economic variables and optimal monetary policy.

ECON 412.course_description: Positive and normative analysis of tax policy; topics include the taxation of savings, taxation of labor income, taxes on risk-taking and wealth, and optimal income and commodity taxation.

ECON 430.course_description: This course introduces experiments as a tool in economic analysis. The course will examine experimental methodology and provide a first exposure to various experimental results. The course will stress the interaction of theory and experiment, seeking to relate questions in the theory of markets, games, and decisions to issues in experimental design and the analysis and interpretation of those results.

ECON 435.course_description: This course studies the role of psychological processes in economic decision making. In contrast to much of economics, behavioral economics starts with observations of actual decision making and seeks to explain how and why individuals make the choices they do. Topics may include decision heuristics, decision making under uncertainty, time inconsistency, social preferences, and neuroeconomics.

ECON 442.course_description: A study of firms and the markets in which they operate. Considerable emphasis placed on strategic interaction among firms. Topics include mergers, predatory pricing, advertising, patents, vertical relationships and antitrust.

ECON 445.course_description: This course focuses on theoretical models exploring the quantity and quality of education. It then explores empirical evidence supporting or in opposition to these theories. Special emphasis will be placed upon models of signaling, human capital choice, externalities to education, and peer effects. The goal of this course is to provide students with enough theoretical and empirical insight to develop their own research paper in the economics of education field.

ECON 446.course_description: Presentation of basic microeconomic concepts including the operation and decision-making of households and businesses in a market economy. Special consideration is given to the development of classroom teaching strategies involving the use of games, simulations and audiovisual aids.

ECON 447.course_name: Methods for Teaching About the National Economy in the Public Schools
ECON 447.course_description: Forces affecting the overall levels of output, employment and prices in the U.S. economy. The economic effects of government policies involving taxes, spending and the money supply. Special consideration is given to the development of classroom teaching strategies involving the use of games, simulations and audiovisual aids.

ECON 448.course_name: Methods for Teaching Personal Finance in the Public Schools
ECON 448.course_description: This course is designed to provide educators with the background and training that they need to successfully integrate personal finance into their classes or to develop and present a new stand alone personal finance course.  The on-site portion, typically conducted in a conference setting, will be supplemented by research and a project to be completed after the classroom portion of the course.

ECON 462.course_description: The theory of international trade. Alternative approaches for explaining the pattern and terms of trade. An examination of the gains from trade and commercial policy. Includes issues of protectionism, economic integration and strategic trade policy.

ECON 463.course_description: Balance of payments, adjustment mechanisms, international monetary system and international interdependence. Topics include determinants of exchange rate policy, the relationship between domestic monetary and exchange rate policies, and international policy coordination.

ECON 465.course_description: This course will study the special problems faced by the less developed countries of the world and the economic mechanisms that must be taken into account in raising living standards. Topics considered may include population growth, the demographic transition, savings and capital accumulation, education and human capital, health and human capital, institutions and the development process, the role of history and multiple equilibria, the role of expectations and multiple equilibria, and economic integration.

ECON 470.course_description: Theory and techniques of forecasting economic trends at the macro, micro and regional levels. Application of regression and time-series methods using PC econometric/forecasting software.

ECON 475.course_description: Further topics in econometrics. Coverage may include systems of simultaneous equations, discrete-choice models, time series analysis, panel data, flexible functional forms, and nonparametric methods.

ECON 482.course_description: Examines an extended set of applications in environmental economics, with a focus on deepening the student’s understanding of the field. Applications involve current controversies in environmental policy and management, as well as methodological issues. Topics include climate change, solid waste management and recycling, water quality, and other issues of current interest.

ECON 483.course_description: Principles of efficient resource allocation over time, distributional equity and cost/benefit analysis. Examines minerals and other exhaustible resources; forests, fisheries and other renewable resources; and public goods such as water and wilderness.

ECON 484.course_description: Explores the economics of renewable energy and conservation. The economic history of renewable energy and the existing institutional framework are examined. Considers economic motivations for the expansion of renewable energy and conservation. Existing and prospective policies are analyzed. Examines the challenges associated with integrating renewable sources into existing energy systems. Various quantitative techniques are reviewed and practiced. Also offered as ENRG 484.

ECON 491.course_description: Discussion and analysis of selected issues of significant economic and political content. Also offered as PLSC 491.

ECON 493.course_name: Senior Seminar: Economics, the Environment and Natural Resources
ECON 493.course_description: Discussion and analysis of selected issues in the economics of the environment and natural resources.

ECON 495.course_description: This course involves the preparation of either an empirical research paper of publishable quality or an empirical professional consultant report, by each student. Topics vary depending on students’ projects. Advanced methods in Econometrics beyond those covered in ECON 375/ECON 475 will be addressed as needed for each of the research topics.

ECON 500.course_description: An individualized course of study not available through or replacing existing curriculum, to be arranged between one matriculating student and sponsoring faculty member. All academic policies and registration deadlines apply.

ESJ 411.course_description: Theoretical and practical foundation of education for social justice, exploring historical roots and the contemporary constructions of social justice issues and traditions as they play out in diverse educational contexts with emphasis on disruption of cultural reproduction of oppression through agency and activism.

ESJ 412.course_description: This course has been designed to develop a critical understanding of current issues of educational equity and social justice within the U.S. context. Through research based discussions and participation in symposia, workshops, seminars, and film viewings students will engage and grapple with their own development of critical consciousness and the implications for educators.

ESJ 416.course_name: Advanced Topics in Social Justice Education: Critical Race Theory in Education
ESJ 416.course_description: Specific issues in social justice education will be used as lenses for analyzing, evaluating and transforming interlocking systems of power, privilege, oppression and discriminatory institutional structures and cultural practice and social behavior.

EDAD 300.course_description: An individualized course of study not available through or replacing existing curriculum, to be arranged between one matriculating student and sponsoring faculty member. All academic policies and registration deadlines apply. Directed Independent Study courses cannot substitute for General University Requirements and are not eligible for tuition waiver.

EDAD 400.course_description: An individualized course of study not available through or replacing existing curriculum, to be arranged between one matriculating student and sponsoring faculty member. All academic policies and registration deadlines apply. Directed Independent Study courses cannot substitute for General University Requirements and are not eligible for tuition waiver.

EDAD 500.course_description: An individualized course of study not available through or replacing existing curriculum, to be arranged between one matriculating student and sponsoring faculty member. All academic policies and registration deadlines apply.

EDAD 501.course_name: Introduction to Educational Research and Evaluation
EDAD 501.course_description: Introduction to fundamental concepts and procedures of educational research and evaluation. Interpreting research and evaluation literature and assessing appropriateness of methodology and application of research and evaluation models; utilization of databases for K-12 application in curriculum and instruction decision making.

EDAD 502.course_description: Supervised study focusing on one or more selected topics.

EDAD 503.course_description: Studies to assist students in understanding school administration.

EDAD 512.course_name: Policy & Personnel Studies in Education Leadership
EDAD 512.course_description: Introduction to philosophical, ethical, moral and legal bases of education leadership, policy decision-making, and formulation and the relationship to successful personnel management. Study of selected personnel, policy development and implementation models in relation to above perspectives.

EDAD 518.course_description: Examination and discussion of several current and controversial issues in education. Repeatable with no maximum.

EDAD 536.course_name: Current Topics in Education Leadership and Finance
EDAD 536.course_description: Local-state fiscal arrangements; current school budgets; related educational finance procedures.

EDAD 540.course_name: Political and Economic Forces Shaping Education
EDAD 540.course_description: A study of major forces and groups at the federal, local and state level which impact education through political and economic means.

EDAD 541.course_description: The study of major administrative and leadership theories and the impact of management, leadership and decision making for school administrators.

EDAD 542.course_description: Problems and potentials of the principalship.

EDAD 543.course_description: Supervision as education leadership in continuous evaluation and improvement of school practice, misconduct, investigation, discipline and grievances.

EDAD 544.course_name: Collective Bargaining in the Public Schools
EDAD 544.course_description: Technical structure and protocol of collective bargaining as well as issues and practices.

EDAD 546.course_description: Identification, study and evaluation of research topics appropriate for building level administrators. Repeatable to a maximum of 6 credits.

EDAD 548.course_description: Legal principles underlying statutes and court decisions related to the schools including special education law and due process.

EDAD 550.course_description: Models for planning, implementing and evaluating professional development and school/community relations programs.

EDAD 551.course_description: The systems approach as related to educational project planning and management.

EDAD 552.course_description: Planning and decision-making process as related to development and administration of educational curriculum and innovations.

EDAD 553.course_description: Program articulation between elementary and secondary schools as well as unique aspects of these schools.

EDAD 554.course_description: An examination of the structure, organization and principles by which Western European schools are financed, staffed and administered. Repeatable to a maximum of 6 credits.

EDAD 555.course_description: Review and analysis of research findings related to effective school practices.

EDAD 556.course_description: Design, implementation and evaluation of a field project. Repeatable to a maximum of 6 credits, including original course.

EDAD 592.course_name: Field Experience in Administration for the Principal
EDAD 592.course_description: Applicants for the Washington State Administrative Certificate.  Repeatable with no maximum.  S/U grading.

EDAD 594.course_description: Field-based studies by entire school building staffs to resolve persistent and significant school problems. Course requirements include the development of an approved proposal for action research. May be repeated with different content. Repeatable to a maximum of 9 credits. S/U grading.

EDAD 640.course_description: Studies of current topics in educational administration, personnel administration, inter-program topics. Repeatable to a maximum of 10 credits, including original course.

EDAD 641.course_description: Systematic examination of curriculum and instruction policy development, implementation and maintenance of curriculum models, and development of guidelines for curriculum governance.

EDAD 642.course_description: Examination of important school system management theories and models.  Development of strategies for management models implementation, evaluation and maintenance.

EDAD 643.course_description: Examination of important leadership theories and governance styles as they relate to the role of the K-12 school superintendent.  Key focus upon the ethics and fairness of reasoned decision making as a leader.

EDAD 644.course_description: Exploration of research-based approaches to the development and implementation of public policy.  Examines successful approaches to implementation and dissemination.

EDAD 646.course_description: Repeatable to a maximum of 8 credits, including original course.

EDAD 647.course_description: Current problems and issues facing school administrators.

EDAD 650.course_description: This seminar experience is designed to make you aware of the support systems and resources available at WWU to begin to engage with qualitative research. You will complete this course with an understanding of resources in research. This course will include time to get to know your fellow learners and the instructors and staff who will be challenging and supporting you in your entire WWU learning experience.

EDAD 652.course_description: This course is an introduction to qualitative research in the social sciences and assumes no previous experience with conducting qualitative research.

EDAD 654.course_description: Quantitative Research is an introductory course for graduate students in applied statistics for the behavioral sciences. The course aims to provide a conceptual and practical basis to statistical literacy in the education disciplines. The course is designed to initiate statistical understanding in the graduate student from the ground up. Problems are taken from the fields of education and psychology, and include the computation, interpretation, and application of such statistical techniques as measures of central tendency, measures of variability, correlation, validity and reliability, standard scoring, probability, tests of significance, Chi-square and t-tests, regression, and analysis of variance.

EDAD 656.course_description: Equity and Values examines investigations into controversial ethical issues and dilemmas to prepare educational leaders as they think through potential situations that impact student and staff success. Leaders will consider the roles, stakeholders, issues and methods useful to apply ethical principals in school leadership settings. Discussions include the major ethical theories and principles.

EDAD 658.course_description: Research Institute II is to help each candidate with the structure of chapters one, two and three of the dissertation which includes the Introduction, Methodology and Review of Literature. Candidates are encouraged to come to this institute with a rough draft of all three chapters ready to share with classmates and with Chairs with the Seminar goal of refinement leading towards the initial defense.

EDAD 660.course_description: Organizational Theory is the study of human behavior within a variety of organizational settings, focusing specifically on K-12 schools. The course engages students in the study of major organization theories that inform education leadership research. Students will explore theory to help inform their own research and practice-based interests.

EDAD 662.course_description: Equity and Social Justice examines the critical components of achievement, fairness and access in educational settings and its impact on moral, ethical, and transformational leadership. Topics include cultural proficiency, responsive practices, gaps impacting advancement, courageous conversations and equity audits.

EDAD 664.course_description: Instructional Leadership is at the very core of improving both learner and teacher expertise.  This course will center on the skills that the educational leader must develop in order to meet the needs of all students. Students can expect to learn about the development  and nurturing of a shared vision, measurable strategic plan, targeted professional development strategies, data driven decision making, and the need for the development and monitoring of a n innovative curriculum designed to address equity, diversity and inclusion.

EDAD 670.course_description: This thesis course deals with both the theoretical practical aspects of designing dissertation research and successfully defending the design in a proposal hearing. The purpose of the course is to assist students through the proposal and dissertation writing processes. Repeatable to a maximum of 30 credits, including original course.

EDAD 690.course_description: Research study under the direction of a faculty committee. Repeatable to a maximum of 9 credits. S/U grading.

EDAD 691.course_description: Research study under the direction of a faculty committee. Repeatable to a maximum of 6 credits. S/U grading.

EDAD 692.course_name: Field Experience in Administration for the Superintendent
EDAD 692.course_description: Applicants for the Washington State Administrative Certificate. Repeatable with no maximum. S/U grading.

EECE 108.course_name: Introduction to Electrical and Computer Engineering Seminar
EECE 108.course_description: A general overview of the fields of Electrical and Computer Engineering (EECE) through weekly guest talks by industry professionals. Topics include curriculum introduction, careers in EECE industry, and fundamental skills to be successful in the EECE program and in one's future career. S/U grading.

EECE 109.course_name: Introduction to Electrical and Computer Engineering Lab
EECE 109.course_description: An introductory Electrical and Computer Engineering (EECE) class. Through a series of hands-on lab activities, students will get exposed to common EECE lab instruments and selected software tools, and work on micro-controller (MCU) based team projects. S/U grading.

EECE 111.course_description: Introduction to basic circuit analysis. Resistive circuits, RC and RL circuits, and network theorems.

EECE 210.course_description: Continuation of basic circuit analysis. AC circuits analysis, AC power, frequency response including Bode plots.

EECE 220.course_description: A first course in electronic devices and circuits. Fundamental properties of semiconductor devices and their behavior in electronic circuits.

EECE 233.course_description: Introductory digital electronics with emphasis on basic digital concepts, Boolean algebra, digital devices, interfacing, and the major functional units from building block approach. Laboratory with applications, constructing, testing and troubleshooting of digital circuits.

EECE 244.course_description: Introduction to microcomputers, microcontrollers, and programming concepts. Study of assembly instruction sets, structured programming using assembly language, and basic embedded debugging techniques.

EECE 300.course_description: An individualized course of study not available through or replacing existing curriculum, to be arranged between one matriculating student and sponsoring faculty member. All academic policies and registration deadlines apply. Directed Independent Study courses cannot substitute for General University Requirements and are not eligible for tuition waiver.

EECE 310.course_description: Introduction to continuous-time signals and systems. Analysis of linear time-invariant (LTI) systems. Laplace transforms, Fourier transforms, and their applications to LTI system analysis.

EECE 311.course_description: Introduction to discrete-time signals and systems. Z-transform, discrete Fourier transform, introduction to sampling theorem.

EECE 320.course_description: A course in the analysis and design of electronic systems including amplifier building blocks, frequency response, and an introduction to switch-mode power supply and control circuits.

EECE 321.course_description: Upper division treatment of active linear and nonlinear electronic circuits. Analysis, design and testing of electronic circuits and subsystems with primary emphasis on the application of integrated circuit components and modules including active filters, instrumentation amplifiers, oscillators and data convertors. Laboratory testing of designed circuits and formal report writing.

EECE 333.course_description: An upper-division course that covers the analysis and design of digital systems. Practical application of theory with an emphasis on writing HDL for design, simulation and testing of FPGA and SoC’s.

EECE 344.course_description: Upper-division study of analysis and design of electronic systems using embedded microcontrollers. This course focuses on using the C programming language for embedded microcontrollers, real-time programming techniques, and on-chip resources. Various hardware resources and interfacing techniques will be introduced and applied in laboratory design problems.

EECE 346.course_name: Probability and Statistics for Electrical and Computer Engineering
EECE 346.course_description: This course provides an introduction to probabilistic and statistical reasoning. Topics include probability models, combinatorics, axioms of probability, conditional probability and Bayes’ Theorem, random variables, functions of random variables, expectation, variance, independence, correlation, hypothesis testing, and confidence intervals. Emphasis on relevance of topics to real-world electrical and computer engineering applications such as communications, networking, circuit analysis, and computer engineering. Please note: No more than one of MATH 341, MATH 345, and EECE/MATH 346 can be counted for credit. Also offered as MATH 346.

EECE 360.course_description: This course introduces analog and digital communication systems with an emphasis on system level concepts. Fundamental principles underlying communication systems will be studied, including modulation and demodulation, radio architectures and receiver structures, bandwidth requirements, SNR, pulse shaping, and synchronization.

EECE 361.course_description: Signal transmission through both guided and unguided media. Distributed-circuit concepts, transmission line theory, and RF impedance matching. RF signal propagation, wireless channel modeling, and basic concepts in antenna theory. Emphasis on applications to communication systems.

EECE 362.course_description: This course introduces fundamental concepts of wireless networks. The course starts with the introduction of computer networking basics such as loss, delay, throughput at the network edge/core. Then it takes a top-down approach beginning at the application layer of a network and working its way down to the wireless physical layer. It also covers a broad range of wireless networking standards, and reviews important wireless network application areas (e.g., Network Security, Internet of Things and Connected Vehicles).

EECE 372.course_description: A study of electrical power concepts and electromechanical devices’ theory, operation, and analysis. Topics covered include electric and magnetic circuit analysis, three-phase power systems, power transformers, DC machines, synchronous machines, and induction machines. Also offered as ENRG 372.

EECE 374.course_description: A study of power electronics devices and circuits applied to power conditioning. Topics covered include switching characteristics of power semiconductor devices, power converter topologies, control techniques in power converters and practical applications of power electronics converters in energy systems. Also offered as ENRG 374.

EECE 378.course_name: Power System Analysis and the Smart Grid
EECE 378.course_description: A study of smart grid and renewable energy technologies. Topics covered include basics of power system analysis and operation, smart grid infrastructure, renewable energy technologies, and electricity markets. Also offered as ENRG 378.

EECE 383.course_description: Provides an introduction to machine learning with particular attention on real-world engineering applications. Theoretical foundation and application of supervised learning techniques such as regression and classification as well as unsupervised learning techniques such as clustering and dimensionality reduction. State-of-the-art deep learning algorithms as well as their implementation and use in solving engineering problems. Applications may include object detection and identification in images/videos, pattern recognition in speech/audio, and traffic prediction.

EECE 384.course_description: This course introduces the fundamental principles, techniques, and applications of artificial intelligence (AI) and reinforcement learning (RL). Topics include knowledge representation, heuristic and algorithmic search methods, reasoning and planning in uncertain environments, and algorithmic learning techniques in unknown environments. The course also includes a discussion of the ethical and societal implications of AI and RL. Students completing this course will have a working knowledge of the design and implementation of various algorithms that will allow an intelligent agent to accomplish tasks in complex environments. Applications of topics covered in this course may include robotics, autonomous driving, and computer games.

EECE 385.course_description: This course introduces the fundamental principles of modeling, analysis, and control of systems whose physical processes are informed by computation, sensing, and actuation. Such systems are termed cyber-physical systems (CPS) and examples include automobiles, power systems, and mobile phones. The course covers models of computation, qualitative and quantitative techniques to analyze and verify CPS behaviors, and an understanding of the working of CPS in real-world applications.

EECE 400.course_description: An individualized course of study not available through or replacing existing curriculum, to be arranged between one matriculating student and sponsoring faculty member. All academic policies and registration deadlines apply. Directed Independent Study courses cannot substitute for General University Requirements and are not eligible for tuition waiver.

EECE 401.course_description: This is the first of four courses in the culminating capstone project. Students are introduced to the engineering design process and project structure. By the end of the course they select and propose a project topic. S/U grading.

EECE 402.course_description: This course is the second part of the capstone project sequence for electrical and computer engineering students. The engineering design project selected in EECE 401 is defined through system requirements that include realistic constraints. A solution is produced and verified to determine the extent to which the requirements are met.

EECE 403.course_description: This course is the third part of the capstone project sequence for electrical and computer engineering students. The engineering design project selected in EECE 401 is defined through system requirements that include realistic constraints. A solution is produced and verified to determine the extent to which the requirements are met.

EECE 404.course_description: This course is the fourth and final part of the capstone project sequence for electrical and computer engineering students. The engineering design project selected in EECE 401 is defined through system requirements that include realistic constraints. A solution is produced and verified to determine the extent to which the requirements are met.

EECE 433.course_description: Introduction to the fundamentals of digital signal processing (DSP) and digital filtering. Topics include design and analysis of FIR filters and IIR filters, and practical applications of DSP. Students will gain both software simulation and hardware hands-on experience in implementing DSP algorithms.

EECE 444.course_description: The advanced study of real-time embedded systems hardware and software analysis and design. Includes real-time kernels, kernel services, and a variety of hardware and software applications.

EECE 460.course_description: This course focuses on advanced digital communication system design, analysis, and implementation. Random processes will be used to model communication systems and analyze their performance in noise. Advanced communication techniques will be studied, such as: multicarrier systems, spread spectrum, equalization, channel coding, and modern wireless protocols and standards.

EECE 480.course_description: A study of analog control systems and techniques using operational mathematics, Laplace transforms, transfer functions, second-order systems, stability criteria, frequency response analysis, PID compensation. Laboratory investigation of control systems and computer modeling.

EECE 495.course_name: Directed Research in Electrical and Computer Engineering
EECE 495.course_description: Advanced study in problems chosen and conducted under supervision. Repeatable 3 times to a maximum 9 credits.

EECE 501.course_description: This course studies mathematical tools for analysis and control of deterministic engineering systems, with a focus on state space modeling of multivariable continuous-time and discrete-time systems. Topics include canonical forms, solution of state equations, stability, controllability, observability of linear systems, pole placement via state feedback, observer design, and Lyapunov stability analysis.

EECE 502.course_description: This course studies mathematical tools for designing and evaluating engineering systems that operate in uncertain environments. Topics include convergence of sequences of random variables; random vectors and minimum mean squared error estimation; stationarity and ergodicity; discrete-time and continuous-time Markov processes; correlation functions, spectral analysis and application to linear systems; Wiener filtering and the orthogonality principle.

EECE 503.course_description: This course studies data-driven tools for engineering, including modeling, predicting, classifying, and controlling complex systems. Topics include dimensionality reduction and transforms, such as singular value decomposition, principal component analysis, Fourier and wavelet transforms, sparsity and compressed sensing, machine learning and data analysis such as regression, clustering, and deep neural networks.

EECE 512.course_description: This course provides an introduction to optimization with a focus on designing algorithms for engineering systems. Topics include formulating an optimization problem to satisfy performance requirements, numerical solution techniques, gradient-based and gradient-free algorithms, solving optimization problems with multiple objectives, and developing robust solutions to optimization problems in the presence of uncertainty. Students will implement algorithms in a widely used programming language.

EECE 521.course_description: The goal of this course is to teach students some of the methods used in the design and analysis of custom analog integrated circuits, to illustrate how one approaches design problems in general, and to expose students to a broad cross-section of important analog circuit topologies. The course includes discussions that detail the trade-offs and considerations when designing at the transistor-level.

EECE 529.course_description: This course introduces fundamental theories, analysis techniques, and widely used devices in RF/microwave engineering as well as hands-on skills with commercial simulation tools used for designing RF/microwave circuits and components. Topics include transmission lines and waveguides, microwave network theory and analysis, impedance matching and tuning, microwave circuits and devices (power dividers and couplers, filters, amplifiers).

EECE 561.course_description: This course provides students with fundamental theories in antenna analysis, hands-on skills with commercial simulation tools used for antenna design, antenna measurement techniques, and applications. Topics include linear dipole antennas, loop antennas, microstrip antennas, slot antennas, aperture antennas, horn antennas, antenna arrays and phased arrays.This course provides students with fundamental theories in antenna analysis, hands-on skills with commercial simulation tools used for antenna design, antenna measurement techniques, and applications. Topics include linear dipole antennas, loop antennas, microstrip antennas, slot antennas, aperture antennas, horn antennas, antenna arrays and phased arrays.

EECE 562.course_name: Edge Computing and Analytics in IoT
EECE 562.course_description: This course covers Internet of Things (IoT) and edge computing architectures and systems, an overview of the underlying sensors, different edge computing hardware and software platforms, and associated resource constraints. The course studies various technologies such as cellular, LoRa and Wi-Fi that provide wireless connectivity to IoT devices, as well as machine learning algorithms that enable the devices to perform edge analytics to efficiently collect and analyze sensory data. Advanced topics such as IoT security and privacy challenges in real-world IoT applications are studied.

EECE 565.course_description: This course introduces the fundamental principles underlying the development and analysis of signal estimation and detection, which involve processing information-bearing signals to make inferences about the information that they contain. The course will apply this framework to problems in communications, radar, control, signal processing, and related areas. Topics include minimum variance unbiased estimators, the Cramer-Rao lower bound, maximum likelihood estimation, Bayesian estimation, dynamic parameter estimation and Kalman filtering, advanced hypothesis testing, generalized likelihood ratio testing.

EECE 573.course_name: Dynamics and Control of Power Converters
EECE 573.course_description: Modelling and control of three-phase high-power voltage source converters in stationary and rotating two-dimensional reference frame. Real and reactive power control of grid-connected power converters. Controlled DC port power converters. Autonomous operation of power converters. Applications such as wind generators, static synchronous compensators (STATCOMs), and high voltage DC systems.

EECE 585.course_description: This course provides an introduction to techniques to formally and rigorously verify whether a system meets a desired set of requirements using cyber-physical systems (engineered systems that integrate computation with physical components) as a foundation. Topics will include construction of models of physics and computation, identifying and proving correctness of system invariants, analyzing the reachability, stability, and progress of a system, and examining the role of data in the design of verification algorithms.

EECE 591.course_description: Definition of research project components and expected outcomes. Discussion of topics such as research integrity, ethics, copyrights, environmental impacts, and development of professional skills. Guidelines on preparing a successful research project report. External speakers may be invited. S/U grading.

EECE 592.course_description: Students discuss state-of-the-art electrical and computer engineering research papers on various topics. External speakers may be invited. The course exposes students to a wide range of research topics and provides opportunities for students to share research experiences. Repeatable to a maximum of 2 credits, including original course. S/U grading.

EECE 691.course_description: Under the guidance of a research advisor, students conduct research by studying an electrical and computer engineering topic in depth and applying their knowledge to complete a research project. Students work in close collaboration with their research advisor on all aspects of the research project. Credit will be given when research is completed, and after the student has met the requirements of a written report and presentation. Repeatable to a maximum of 18 credits, including original course.

ELED 300.course_description: An individualized course of study not available through or replacing existing curriculum, to be arranged between one matriculating student and sponsoring faculty member. All academic policies and registration deadlines apply. Directed Independent Study courses cannot substitute for General University Requirements and are not eligible for tuition waiver.

ELED 303.course_description: Course will explore principles of human development, individual differences, motivation, and learning as they relate to both academic and non-academic functioning. The course will emphasize the implications of these principles for early childhood and elementary settings.

ELED 305.course_name: Development and Learning in a Diverse Classroom
ELED 305.course_description: This course examines the principles of human development, individual differences, motivation, culturally responsive teaching and the brain, and conscious classroom management for equity. This course will emphasize the implications of these principles for primary and elementary settings. Students will explore thoughts and beliefs related to the student, the classroom environment, family and community and one’s own beliefs on classroom management, assessment, and teaching practices in a diverse classroom. Emphasis will be placed on the importance of building relationships with diverse students in a classroom setting. Students will be introduced to various types of assessments and use data to help guide instruction. Students will be encouraged to consider their motivation for teaching.

ELED 310.course_description: Issues of culture and social justice as they impact education, schools, and teaching. Includes a service learning component.

ELED 311.course_name: Understanding Washington State Tribal History, Culture, and Government: Since Time Immemorial Curriculum
ELED 311.course_description: This seminar is designed to provide teacher candidates with an understanding of “tribal sovereignty, history, culture, and treaty rights” through the Since Time Immemorial Tribal Sovereignty curriculum as mandated by Washington State law (RCW 28A.320.170 & SB 5028). Washington’s common schools are to use the Since Time Immemorial (STI) curriculum offered by the Superintendent of Public Instruction (OSPI) through the Office of Native Education (ONE) to support the understanding of tribal sovereignty and history of federal policy toward federally recognized tribes.

ELED 365.course_description: An introduction to Instructional design for inclusive classrooms. Includes the writing of instructional objectives, designing and delivering effective instruction and assessment of learning outcomes. An emphasis is placed on Universal Design for Learning, differentiated instruction and high leverage practices for diverse classrooms.

ELED 370.course_description: Exploring theoretical and practical approaches to culturally responsive teaching and planning for instruction which engages diverse students in substantive, worthwhile learning.  Includes practicum experiences in an elementary or middle school classroom.

ELED 372.course_description: Exploring theoretical and practical approaches to culturally responsive teaching and planning for instruction which engages diverse students in substantive, worthwhile learning. Not open to students who have received credit for ELED 370.

ELED 375.course_description: Strategies for creating affirmative, inclusive classroom environments with an emphasis on developing positive communities, utilizing effective management, applying engaging academics, and developmentally responsive teaching. Includes strategies for active engagement and the application of positive behavioral supports and systems.

ELED 380.course_description: Terminology and concept development of the language of literacy; introduction to assessment, curriculum, and instruction of literacy teaching and learning.

ELED 386.course_name: Practical Assessment in the Elementary Classroom I
ELED 386.course_description: Develop skills in using assessment methodology to enhance teaching. Topics include assessment models, basic premises, the value of sound assessment procedures, and an examination of the thought processes of educational evaluation.

ELED 387.course_name: Practical Assessment in the Elementary Classroom II
ELED 387.course_description: Refine skills in using assessment methodology to enhance teaching. Topics include application of assessment models and analysis of student performance using sound assessment procedures.

ELED 400.course_description: An individualized course of study not available through or replacing existing curriculum, to be arranged between one matriculating student and sponsoring faculty member. All academic policies and registration deadlines apply. Directed Independent Study courses cannot substitute for General University Requirements and are not eligible for tuition waiver.

ELED 401.course_name: Writing Instruction in the Elementary Classroom
ELED 401.course_description: Focus on writing development and processes. Methods for assessment and instruction for writing in the elementary school.

ELED 405.course_name: Culturally Relevant Materials for Diverse Learners
ELED 405.course_description: This course focuses on P-12 educators’ development of a critical eye when selecting and evaluating culturally relevant materials, including media and technology resources. The course includes a wide reading of culturally relevant resources, guidance in the selection and analysis of such materials, and instruction in how to use them in innovative ways. Correlation to current state and national standards is included.

ELED 412.course_description: Toward dismantling injustice, oppression, and unsettling settler-colonialism in U.S. schooling through community partnerships, pedagogy and action.

ELED 413.course_description: Course explores the barriers migrant students face in graduating from high school and going on to higher education. Course combines theoretical study with a service learning experience focused on supporting migrant youth to overcome the educational challenges they face. All students will take leadership roles in planning, implementing, and evaluating the effectiveness of the Migrant Youth Leadership Conference and outreach efforts with Migrant partner programs. Repeatable to a maximum of 8 credits, including original course. Also offered as ETHN 413.

ELED 424.course_name: Language Arts in the Elementary Curriculum
ELED 424.course_description: Functions and programs of language arts in the curriculum including reading, writing, speaking, listening.

ELED 425.course_name: Social Studies for the Elementary School
ELED 425.course_description: Social studies methods, resources, multicultural literature, curriculum, objectives, planning and exposure to contributions of social sciences. Includes practicum experiences in an elementary or middle school classroom.

ELED 426.course_description: Social studies methods, resources, multicultural literature, curriculum, objectives, planning and exposure to contributions of social sciences. No practicum experience is included in this course.

ELED 427.course_description: This course is designed to provide students with the content knowledge, classroom methods, materials and strategies for teaching Social Studies in elementary school settings. This course attends to the need for culturally responsive teaching by focusing on ways to teach inclusive social studies that honors diversity and inclusion.

ELED 455.course_name: Primary Literacy Instruction in Inclusive Classrooms
ELED 455.course_description: Topics include critical and theoretical perspectives on literacy development; influence of language and culture on literature development; and research-based literacy instruction and materials. Emphasis on assessment and instruction for early literacy development.

ELED 456.course_description: This course explores classroom-based literacy assessment, with a focus on reading, writing, and oral language. Students are expected to field test selected assessment procedures. Strategies for improving instruction will be presented.

ELED 460.course_description: Students will explore the elements, genres and applications of children’s literature as an integral part of the curriculum. Coursework involves reading widely across genres, considering professional research, designing instructional strategies to encourage reader response and utilizing criteria to evaluate, select and discuss texts in classroom settings.

ELED 464.course_description: Preparation for teaching in a multicultural society. Participants will learn how to design a curriculum that reflects diversity and an instructional methodology that promotes the learning of diverse students.

ELED 465.course_name: History of Native American Education and Policy Development
ELED 465.course_description: This course is a seminar designed to provide students with an understanding of the historical events surrounding the development of schools and schooling of American Indians/Alaska Native students. Students will explore the historical context of Indigenous education through the impact of federal and state policies affecting education programs and school systems that exist for Indigenous students today. This course has been designed to develop a critical understanding of current issues of Indigenous education through qualitative research-based discussions and participation in symposia, workshops, seminars, and film viewings. Students will engage and grapple with their own development of critical consciousness and the implications for educators working with Native communities and educating about Native communities.

ELED 466.course_name: Intermediate Literacy Instruction in Inclusive Classrooms
ELED 466.course_description: Supports a deeper understanding of a comprehensive literacy program by examining frameworks for addressing reading, writing, speaking and listening, and language in the elementary classroom. Students apply their knowledge of literacy learning by developing theoretically-sound and research-based instructional strategies appropriate for an inclusive learning environment. Part of Education for Inclusive Environments residency program.

ELED 470.course_description: Strengthening teaching understandings, skills, and dispositions with an emphasis on learners and learning in classroom contexts, subject matter knowledge and pedagogy, and developing and sustaining a productive and inclusive classroom culture and organization. Includes practicum experiences in an elementary or middle school classroom.

ELED 471.course_description: Capstone seminar in preparation for the full time internship that will demonstrate the candidate’s ability to design and implement standards-based instruction, assess student learning and reflect on the teaching and learning process.

ELED 472.course_description: Developing teaching understandings, skills, and dispositions with an emphasis on learners and learning in classroom contexts, subject matter knowledge and pedagogy, and developing and sustaining a productive and inclusive classroom culture and organization. Not open to students who have received credit for ELED 470.

ELED 473.course_description: Practicum experiences in an elementary or middle school classroom related to the content of ELED 472. Not open to students who have received credit for ELED 470. Students must also take ELED 472. S/U grading.

ELED 474.course_description: Instruction on the preparation of a final electronic portfolio documenting experiences in learning to teach and the ability to impact elementary student growth and learning.  Course will focus on classroom management.  Not open to students who have received credit for ELED 471. Students must also take ELED 475.

ELED 475.course_description: Practicum experiences in an elementary or middle school classroom related to the content of ELED 474 and participation in a collegial learning community. Not open to students who have received credit for ELED 471. Students must also take ELED 474. S/U grading.

ELED 478.course_description: Understanding the components and structure of a comprehensive literacy program for addressing reading, writing, listening, and speaking in the elementary classroom, with a particular focus on developing and supporting fluent communicators. Not open to students who have received credit for ELED 481. Students must also take ELED 479.

ELED 479.course_description: Practicum experiences in an elementary or middle school classroom related to the content of ELED 478. Not open to students who have received credit for ELED 481. Students must also take ELED 478. S/U grading.

ELED 480.course_description: Application of theoretical and research-based concepts of literacy.  Teaching and learning of emergent/beginning communicators in a pluralistic society.  Includes practicum experiences in an elementary school.

ELED 481.course_description: Understanding the components and structure of a comprehensive literacy program for addressing reading, writing, listening, and speaking in the elementary classroom, with a particular focus on developing and supporting fluent communicators. Includes practicum experiences in an elementary or middle school classroom.

ELED 483.course_name: Literacy Workshop: Reading, Writing, and Language Learners
ELED 483.course_description: Students will deepen and apply knowledge of literacy learning by developing and teaching theoretically-sound and research-based instructional strategies and units of study appropriate for a multilingual “mainstream” learning environment.

ELED 486.course_name: Supporting Struggling Readers in the K-12 Classroom
ELED 486.course_description: This course explores how educators can prevent and address reading challenges of students in their classroom. Students are expected to work with a small group of learners struggling in some aspect of reading.

ELED 490.course_description: Diagnosis of students, lesson preparation, videotaped peer teaching, analysis of teaching, lesson redesign. Repeatable up to 8 credits, including original course.

ELED 490A.course_description: Observation and participation in the opening of school. S/U grading.

ELED 491.course_description: Observation and participation in the opening of school. S/U grading.

ELED 492.course_description: In-school experience observing and teaching reading and language arts. S/U grading.

ELED 494.course_description: Supervised teaching experience to develop and demonstrate teaching competence at the primary and/or intermediate grades. Repeatable to 32 credits. S/U including IP grade.

ELED 496.course_description: Support school internship experience and students’ efforts to engage in ambitious teaching practices that support diverse learners.

ELED 500.course_description: An individualized course of study not available through or replacing existing curriculum, to be arranged between one matriculating student and sponsoring faculty member. All academic policies and registration deadlines apply.

ELED 501.course_description: Introduction to the concepts and procedures of contemporary education research. Locating and interpreting research literature; formulating research problems and hypotheses. Selecting research designs, including quantitative and qualitative approaches. Use of correlational, causal comparative, quasi-experimental, experimental, single subject, descriptive, case study, and various qualitative methodologies.

ELED 505.course_name: Books and Materials:  Use and Evaluation
ELED 505.course_description: Study and selection of children’s and adolescent literature (fiction and poetry). Literary criticism. Use of various media.

ELED 518.course_description: Examination and discussion of several current issues in Elementary Education. Repeatable to a maximum of 5 credits.

ELED 521.course_description: Advanced study of curriculum planning and development, including design, materials and problems in curriculum change. Independent research is expected.

ELED 530.course_description: Examination of the nature and role of play in the cognitive, affective, physical and social development of the child. Attention given to the educative functions of play and implications of those functions for curriculum and instruction.

ELED 531.course_description: In-depth exploration of programs, theories and significant recent research in early childhood education.

ELED 531A.course_name: Advanced Seminar in Early Childhood Education
ELED 531A.course_description: Specific problems are drawn from the field and content organized according to student need.

ELED 533.course_description: Advanced study of individual research topics in elementary education.

ELED 535.course_name: Research Analysis of Current Issues in Elementary Education
ELED 535.course_description: Examination and analysis of research underlying current issues and problems in elementary education.

ELED 538.course_name: Current Issues in Assessment and Evaluation in Elementary Literacy Education
ELED 538.course_description: Examines current theory, research, and practice in classroom-based literacy assessment and evaluation; includes supervised practicum.

ELED 539.course_description: Preparation and presentation of a seminar paper on a problem or issue in education.

ELED 555.course_name: Middle School Curriculum Designs and Instructional Strategies
ELED 555.course_description: Current trends in middle-level education; includes a review of developing curriculum ideas endorsed by the National Middle School Association. Physical, social and emotional growth of early adolescents; instructional strategies for middle-level schools; requires topical or action research project.

ELED 569A.course_description: Current issues and best practices in early childhood program design and implementation. Emphasis on family-centered, play-based interagency models that serve children of all abilities. Applied research focus.

ELED 569B.course_description: Issues and resources for accurate and appropriate assessment of young children. Current best practices in instructionally relevant assessment, monitoring child progress and evaluating overall program success. Alternative strategies for assessing the very young child, family needs and special populations. Emphasis on critical evaluation of instruments, psychometric adequacy and technical aspects of test development.

ELED 569C.course_description: Curriculum development and adaptation for infants, toddlers, and preschool children. Includes available resources, best practices with the developmentally young and play-based criteria. Focus on model program curricular approaches, the use of daily routines and parent-child interaction as a context and content for curriculum, and peer-mediated learning strategies. Emphasis on efficacy research and the impact of various curricular models.

ELED 583.course_description: Teaching basic reading skills through the use of children’s books; selection and analysis of children’s books in order to teach literacy, from beginning or pre-word recognition levels through junior/senior high level.

ELED 584.course_description: Teaching activities designed to foster continuing development of literacy, in part, through stressing interrelationships between the various forms of language.

ELED 585.course_description: Literacy education research and its application to classroom practices, to individual problems in the teaching of reading, to supervision and administration of reading programs.

ELED 586.course_description: Summary course in the Masters in Literacy, focuses on the role of the future literacy specialist in the analysis, correction, and prevention of literacy difficulties. Designed to refine the teacher leader’s knowledge of assessment, evaluation, planning, and teaching of readers, writers, and language users. Includes a 20 hour practicum.

ELED 587.course_description: Teaching developmental reading; methods, materials, theory.

ELED 589.course_description: Exploration of current theories in language acquisition, linguistics and psycholinguistics, and implications for early childhood education and literacy instruction.

ELED 594E.course_name: Practicum in Reading Diagnosis and Remediation
ELED 594E.course_description: Assessment and correction of reading difficulties: supervised practica in use of diagnostic reading tests.

ELED 594F.course_name: Practicum in Reading Diagnosis and Remediation
ELED 594F.course_description: Remedial instruction of children with reading problems: clinical practicum.

ELED 690.course_description: Research study under the direction of a faculty committee. Repeatable to a maximum of 9 cr. S/U grading

ELED 691.course_description: Graduate research under the direction of a program advisor/committee. Repeatable to a maximum of 5 credits, including original course. S/U grading.

ELED 692.course_description: The focus of this course (ELED 692) is to develop the capstone project proposal, including the determination of the inquiry strand, the focus topic, a draft review of literature, and an outline of the components related to the inquiry strand.

ELED 693.course_description: The focus of this course (ELED 693) is to revise the capstone project proposal, including the determination of the inquiry strand, the focus topic, a review of literature, and the outline of the components related to the inquiry strand. In addition, students will draft the components of their project.

ELED 694.course_description: The focus of this course (ELED 694) is to work with faculty mentors to revise and finalize components of the projects and prepare the master’s project presentation.

ENRG 101.course_description: Modern society is completely dependent on vast amounts of cheap energy, but the costs are high. Will we have enough usable energy for a planet of nine billion people? How do our choices in energy production impact the global and local environment? We will address these and other questions surrounding human energy use and try to understand the science, technology, and policy of energy use in the 21st century.

ENRG 140.course_description: Access to energy, especially low-carbon energy, impacts both the economic opportunities and environmental conditions of people around the world. The choices we make today have far reaching impacts on our children, children’s children, and potentially the entire human race. With energy markets that span continents, and an environmental problem (climate change) that requires a worldwide effort, understanding the policy options can be overwhelming. This course will provide a framework for thinking about energy usage decisions by learning about sources of energy, energy efficiency standards and economic instruments to control pollution such as cap-and-trade and carbon taxes. We will learn about these concepts in conjunction with a brief survey of the geography, energy needs/institutions, and opportunities of nations on six continents.

ENRG 284.course_description: Energy is an important sector in national and the world economies. This course will examine private and government-owned energy resource and service providers and will include a brief history of the energy business and differences in characteristics across a variety of energy markets: fossil fuels, nuclear, renewables, and efficiency measures. The impact of government regulatory and tax and subsidy policies on industry and corporate structure and behavior will be examined.

ENRG 300.course_description: An individualized course of study not available through or replacing existing curriculum, to be arranged between one matriculating student and sponsoring faculty member. All academic policies and registration deadlines apply. Directed Independent Study courses cannot substitute for General University Requirements and are not eligible for tuition waiver.

ENRG 310.course_description: This course introduces the scientific methods for analyzing energy flows in thermal systems, such as power plants, building energy systems, refrigeration and HVAC technology, and those found in production processes. Topics covered include first and second laws of thermodynamics, gas and steam power cycles, gas mixtures, refrigeration, humidification, fluid flow, heat transfer, and material considerations.

ENRG 320.course_description: Overview of energy resources and processes within a unified physical framework. Addresses traditional and renewable resources including fossil fuels, nuclear, wind, solar, hydroelectric, geothermal, and biofuels. Systems-level issues such as efficiency, transmission, and reliability are also covered.

ENRG 322.course_description: This class focuses on data analysis in the field of energy and the environment. In this course, you will develop skills necessary to gather, organize, analyze, and visualize energy data to gain understanding and insight. This class will also help you build competence with commonly used software in the energy field.

ENRG 330.course_description: This course covers the formation, development, extraction, limitations and technology associated with energy sources in the rocky part of Earth, particularly in the context of developing a sustainable energy mix for the future. Topics covered include a variety of fossil fuels, nuclear minerals and geothermal energy. Carbon sequestration techniques are also be discussed.

ENRG 340.course_name: Energy and Climate in Rural Development
ENRG 340.course_description: This course covers issues related to energy, agriculture, the environment, and social and economic development in rural areas of developing countries. Energy, climate change, and rural development are inextricably linked, and access to energy impacts the economic opportunities and environmental conditions of people around the world. As nations get wealthier, they use more energy, and the impacts of climate change will fall disproportionately on the poor and rural parts of the world. The course explores the complex linkages tying these issues together in the context of developing countries using principles from natural science, technology, and economics. Students also learn how to approach and understand the values and viewpoints of other cultures in a respectful manner.

ENRG 342.course_description: Mathematics as a tool for solving problems in environmental and energy sciences. Rates of change in time and space, integration, flux and box models, inference based on comparing orders of magnitude, and introductory numerical methods for both prediction and data analysis. Course is equivalent to ESCI 342.

ENRG 344.course_description: This course will examine the ways that North American communities can respond to the challenge of climate change at a local level. The problem has been amplified by 30 years of Federal inaction. Today, communities across the U.S. are committing to act on their own to accelerate the transition to clean energy and carbon emission reduction. We examine how public opinion influences policy and the future success of clean energy transition scenarios. We study potential for citizen advocacy to galvanize action, as well as the role of corporate leadership. We explore the need for a clean energy workforce and how to protect vulnerable communities from bearing the brunt of the transition. Also offered as ENVS 344.

ENRG 345.course_description: Energy has played a key role in the sociocultural and economic transformation of the Global South. This class examines the historical dimensions of these energy projects as a central component of modernization and national development. It also explores the impact on communities around the world of new or alternative energy technologies, infrastructures, politics, and political alliances, especially in light of the challenges presented by global climate change. Also offered as ANTH 345.

ENRG 350.course_description: This course will allow students to understand the history of energy policy and regulation within the US, with a focus on the interplay among energy science/technology, social justice, and policy. A specific focus will be placed on energy issues as they pertain to the Pacific Northwest. Also offered as UEPP 350.

ENRG 352.course_description: This course provides an introduction to some of the key challenges global climate change poses on current systems of governance, and what is at stake if such challenges are not addressed. The overarching aim of the course is to give students an understanding of the nature of the problem, an overview of the policy instruments used to address climate change, the basic design of greenhouse gas compliance regimes, the challenges with implementation, and the importance of political economy in understanding historical and current choices made in policy response and instrument design. Also offered as ENVS 352.

ENRG 354.course_description: An exploration of the uses and meanings of energy in American history. Topics include development of and transitions between different energy regimes; relations between energy producers and communities; energy and American foreign policy; and social, cultural, and environmental changes linked to changing patterns of energy production and consumption. Also offered as HIST 354.

ENRG 360.course_name: Energy Efficient and Carbon Neutral Design
ENRG 360.course_description: Introduction to energy use in buildings and the concept of energy efficiency as a resource.  Provides a quantitative but accessible approach to the analysis, design and evaluation of measures to improve energy efficiency and pursue net-zero and/or carbon neutral design. Topics covered include building heating and cooling loads, HVAC system efficiency, solar energy resources and sun angles, passive solar design and rooftop photovoltaic sizing, energy efficient and zero-carbon design for buildings, vehicles, appliances, hot water and HVAC. Also offered as ESCI 360.

ENRG 372.course_description: A study of electrical power concepts and electromechanical devices’ theory, operation, and analysis. Topics covered include electric and magnetic circuit analysis, three-phase power systems, power transformers, DC machines, synchronous machines, and induction machines. Also offered as EECE 372.

ENRG 378.course_name: Power System Analysis and the Smart Grid
ENRG 378.course_description: A study of smart grid and renewable energy technologies. Topics covered include basics of power system analysis and operation, smart grid infrastructure, renewable energy technologies, and electricity markets. Also offered as EECE 378.

ENRG 380.course_description: Saying that there is no such thing as a free lunch is a glib way of expressing the first law of thermodynamics and gets at the core of this class. How do our choices in energy use impact the global and local environment? What does the future hold in terms of human use of energy? This class emphasizes the physical principles behind energy and the effects of energy use on the environment. We will explore the interdependence of world economies and environment as well as look at individual opinions and choices on energy related issues. Also offered as ESCI 380.

ENRG 381.course_description: An examination of current and emerging biofuel technologies including an understanding of the processes for biomass conversion to fuel and other factors associated with commercial biofuel production. Also offered as CHEM 381.

ENRG 384.course_description: The role of energy in the economy and key aspects of energy supply and demand. Topics include the interrelationships among energy use, economic growth, and the environment; conservation; solar and ‘unconventional’ energy sources; world oil markets; regulation of gas and electric utilities; and U.S. energy policy. Also offered as ECON 384.

ENRG 386.course_description: Electricity markets have become more complex in recent years because of new energy production and usage technologies, regulatory changes, and increased environmental concerns. This course will look at demand and supply aspects of electricity markets, including the impact of government economic and environmental regulation. Emphasis will be on the U.S. electricity market. Also offered as ECON 386.

ENRG 388.course_description: Students will work with each other, faculty members, WWU Facilities Management engineers, and professionals in the energy field to analyze a real-world energy problem related to a WWU campus facility. Students will explore energy usage data, instrument measurements, design options, policy issues and business strategies related to the development of a clean energy project on or near the WWU campus. They will define and analyze a problem and craft one or more solutions, based on their degree of knowledge and skills from prior coursework in the energy program.

ENRG 391.course_description: The weekly IES speaker series informs WWU students and the Western community about a wide range of energy information, issues and perspectives. For the speakers, we will draw on experts from business, regulatory bodies, NGOs, and academia. Students and community members will have the opportunity to ask questions and engage in discussion with these experts. Repeatable up to 3 times for a maximum of 3 credits, including original course.

ENRG 392.course_description: This one-credit course prepares students for active and informed participation in the Institute for Energy Studies' Energy Symposium. Students, energy industry guests, and IES faculty will convene to discuss and propose solutions to a previously disclosed energy-related challenge. Students will conduct background research and summarize their findings and resources with the class in advance of the symposium. At the symposium, students will apply the insights they have gained to propose and defend solutions to the presented challenge. Repeatable to a maximum of 3 credits, including original course.

ENRG 400.course_description: An individualized course of study not available through or replacing existing curriculum, to be arranged between one matriculating student and sponsoring faculty member. All academic policies and registration deadlines apply. Directed Independent Study courses cannot substitute for General University Requirements and are not eligible for tuition waiver.

ENRG 420.course_description: Quantitative analysis of energy resources and processes within a unified physical framework. Covers traditional and renewable resources including fossil fuels, nuclear, wind, solar, hydroelectric, geothermal, and biofuels. Energy processes covered include electricity generation and energy storage in batteries and fuel cells. Systems-level issues such as efficiency, transmission, and reliability are also analyzed.

ENRG 421.course_description: This course explores energy resources and their utilization in contemporary energy services, including electricity and heating systems. Students will critically assess and compare energy resources within a unified physical framework. ENRG 421 applies energy resource and process concepts discussed in the energy science lecture courses through a series of hands-on laboratory experiments.

ENRG 430.course_name: Chemistry of Energy Materials and Waste
ENRG 430.course_description: This course introduces the scientific and engineering processes for managing energy materials and waste products related to the extraction and generation of energy. The first half of the course covers the scientific aspects of energy materials and waste, and the second half covers engineering and technological solutions for reusing/recycling waste materials, and for safer disposal.

ENRG 440.course_name: Public and Stakeholder Engagement in Energy, Climate, and Environmental Policymaking
ENRG 440.course_description: We examine different types of civic engagement in public policymaking about energy, climate, and environment through the lens of deliberative democracy. Students will learn to think critically and creatively about how the public, business, and organized interest groups can be effectively involved in policymaking. Also offered as UEPP 440.

ENRG 449.course_description: This course explores the technological, policy, and social changes underway to transition from a fossil fuel based energy system to a low-carbon system, including altering the ways in which we use energy, generate electricity, and fuel transportation systems. Emphasis will be on the Pacific Northwest and Columbia River basin. Also offered as ENVS 449.

ENRG 459.course_description: The goal of this course is to explore policy making and policy implementation in the context of energy technologies. Using case studies we will reveal the multidimensionality and tensions implicit in policy debates. We will assemble a toolbox that enables us to innovate, assess, and promote policy options. Focus will be placed on policy solutions such as common pool resource management, community-based social marketing, civic dialogue, and analytic-deliberation. Also offered as ENVS 459.

ENRG 461.course_name: Mechanical and Environmental Systems in Buildings
ENRG 461.course_description: Introduction to heating, ventilating and air-conditioning (HVAC) systems in large buildings, and the technical concepts of energy efficiency in the built environment, with an emphasis on existing buildings. Topics covered include indoor lighting systems, building heating and cooling loads, indoor air quality and ventilation, humidity and thermal comfort, HVAC system configurations and efficiency, economic analysis and metrics. The course includes a field/lab component in which students will measure energy use and analyze saving potential in an existing building. Also offered as ESCI 461.

ENRG 464.course_description: An advanced class for seniors and graduate students in building energy system analysis and energy efficient design. The course provides quantitative tools and methods to analyze, design, evaluate and communicate technology and design strategy to improve energy efficiency and occupant comfort in commercial and institutional buildings. Also offered as ESCI 464.

ENRG 466.course_description: Life cycle analysis (LCA) is a powerful tool for assessing the environmental impact associated with all the stages of a product’s life from cradle-to-grave (i.e from raw material extraction through materials processing, manufacture, distribution, use, repair and maintenance, and disposal or recycling).  This large picture view helps avoid a narrow outlook on environmental concerns and is an excellent method of comparing two potential products to see which has less impact on the environment. This course will focus on the energetic costs and carbon emissions associated with energy resources and technologies. Also offered as ESCI 466.

ENRG 475.course_description: Fundamentals of renewable and efficient electric power systems, including basics of electric generation, transmission and distribution as well as distributed generation and renewable sources on both sides of the meter, with an emphasis on solar photovoltaics and wind turbines. Topics include energy performance analysis, system sizing and financial metrics of renewable sources, as well as planning and operational impacts on electric utilities. Also offered as ESCI 475.

ENRG 480.course_description: This class is designed to bring students into contact with the industries where energy is produced. In this field-based class we will visit conventional and alternative energy facilities and learn how energy is produced and delivered to consumers. We will pay particular attention to the basic physics, chemistry and biology of energy systems as well as their impacts on the environment. Also offered as ESCI 480.
