Students will learn and practice the foundations of media literacy, visual analysis, and reception as we trace culturally specific historical, industrial, and aesthetic movements throughout the history of Japan’s film industries. Repeatable to a maximum of 10 credits, including original course.

JAPN 400.course_description: An individualized course of study not available through or replacing existing curriculum, to be arranged between one matriculating student and sponsoring faculty member. All academic policies and registration deadlines apply. Directed Independent Study courses cannot substitute for General University Requirements and are not eligible for tuition waiver.

JAPN 402.course_description: This seminar is required of students majoring in Japanese. It will be taught in Japanese but will include some readings and instruction in English when deemed appropriate. Advanced reading materials in Japanese literature are introduced according to the class discussion schedule. The topic of the seminar varies according to the instructor. Repeatable under different topics to a maximum of 10 credits, including original course under advisement.

JAPN 403.course_description: This seminar is required of students majoring in Japanese. It will be taught in Japanese but will include some readings and instruction in English when deemed appropriate. Students are introduced to advanced materials in Japanese thought according to the class discussion schedule. The topic of the seminar varies according to the instructor. This is a writing intensive course. Repeatable under different topics to a maximum of 10 credits, including original course under advisement.

JAPN 425.course_description: Practicum in course preparation, classroom materials, evaluation and counseling. Repeatable up to 4 credits. S/U grading.

JAPN 450.course_description: This is a survey course that covers a broad scope of Japanese history, culture and society. It will be taught in Japanese but will include some readings and instruction in English when deemed appropriate. It is a requirement for students pursuing a major in Japanese, but other interested students may enroll with the permission of the instructor if space permits. Specific course contents vary according to instructors.

JOUR 106.course_description: Analysis of and skill development in sentence structure, syntax, English grammar, mechanics, usage and punctuation as applied to journalistic writing.

JOUR 190.course_description: Introduction to basic issues and problems facing journalists and the public as recipients of mass media messages in national and international society; nature, theory and effects of communication; media systems, structure and support; world news flow; media controls; First Amendment rights; ethical considerations.

JOUR 195.course_name: Intro to Photo / Visual Journalism FYE
JOUR 195.course_description: Everyone’s a photographer, right? We can all take photos on our phones and post them to Instagram, Twitter, or Tumblr. Now, delve further into photo practice, history, creative meaning, and ethics through presentations, photo assignments, field trips, a visit to student publications, and in-class production in a design lab. To prepare you to do profile, stop motion, and self-expression projects, we will cover SLR cameras and do a tutorial on Photoshop. We will take two field trips—one to a local newspaper to meet with the photo editor and one to a local publisher to discuss editorial decision-making in publishing outdoor photos as narratives, as well as the career of freelancing. This course helps you build media literacy, as we will discuss design standards and visual creativity. The material covered is useful to prospective Journalism majors as well as any student who wants to learn how to produce photos with an understanding of the technical and creative aspects of photography, as well as the history and ethics of photo practice.

JOUR 207.course_description: Writing for news media; clarity in use of language, style and punctuation; sentence and paragraph structure and organization of stories; credibility of information and news judgment; basic methods of researching and writing.  Weekly news discussions based on a major national newspaper as one of the texts.

JOUR 214.course_description: Participation on the staff of the university newspaper. Write articles and take photographs for the university’s newspaper and online edition. Gather and edit audio and video, create multimedia packages for the newspaper’s Web site. Also includes lecture.

JOUR 300.course_description: An individualized course of study not available through or replacing existing curriculum, to be arranged between one matriculating student and sponsoring faculty member. All academic policies and registration deadlines apply. Directed Independent Study courses cannot substitute for General University Requirements and are not eligible for tuition waiver.

JOUR 305.course_description: Introduction to news photography and its application in print and online; composing effective new pictures; essentials of processing for print publication and multi-media projects; picture editing and layout; professional ethics and the law.

JOUR 307.course_description: Interviewing, news coverage of community news sources with emphasis on public affairs reporting. Introduction to computerized database reporting and investigative techniques. Writing for news media.

JOUR 309.course_description: News copy desk operations; editing; headline writing; dummying; page make-up and news graphics; and computerized editing.

JOUR 312.course_description: This introduction to environmental journalism and media explores the conceptual and professional foundations of the field. It highlights best writing and reporting practices, advocacy techniques, and real-world cases. Specific focus areas may include environmental reporting, historical media milestones, environmental feature writing, visual media, advocacy and strategic communication, ethics, and reporting on economic and natural resources issues. Students will write and revise as they develop their own media projects. Also offered as ENVS 312.

JOUR 314.course_description: Participation on the staff of the university newspaper. Write articles and take photographs for the university’s newspaper. Gather and edit audio and video, create multimedia packages for the newspaper’s Web site. Also includes lecture.

JOUR 321.course_description: Staff writers prepare and produce the quarterly university periodical and its online edition under the direction of the editor-in-chief and editorial management staff; learn and practice querying story ideas, researching, reporting, writing and then assisting with production of the written and visual elements of the magazine, including online elements for the website. Writers will manage their own time outside of class to report, write and revise manuscripts, investing time appropriate to their task and their goals and to meet deadline, and work with the editorial management team on production issues. Repeatable up to 8 credits including original course.

JOUR 330.course_description: Methods, tools and media used in planning and developing strategic public relations programs for all organizations. Practicing research methods, writing news releases, understanding effective communications strategies and integrated marketing communications, analyzing case studies, exploring relations with the press and developing creative public relations campaigns.

JOUR 340.course_description: An examination of how U.S. journalism has influenced U.S. history from the works that inspired the revolution to the coverage of 9/11. A poster presentation offers students the opportunity to research the role of the news media in shaping a specific event or issue in U.S. history.

JOUR 346.course_description: Critical and analytical exploration of the visual aspects of storytelling in print and online media; research on the cultural history and news media application of photography, infographics, typography, audio and video clips. Consideration of special properties, demands, and aspects of visuals as they are used to enhance and augment written news narratives. Application of these principles through projects that produce still and video photography, audio, informational graphics and typography to accompany written narrative.

JOUR 350.course_description: Rights and legal restrictions on freedom of the press; constitutional guarantees as interpreted through the courts; libel, privacy, access to information, censorship, contempt, agency regulations. Issues applying to various forms of mass media, including print, broadcast and online publishing.

JOUR 351.course_description: Introduction to ethical theories; examination of professional codes and standards; changing roles of the media that affect moral reasoning for the journalist; responsibilities of the media in a world of instant communication and reaction; historical perspectives through case studies; use of reporting editing and advocacy methods and formation of news in print, broadcast and online media. Research paper examines ethics topic.

JOUR 355.course_name: Canadian-American Media Systems: News, Culture, and Diplomacy
JOUR 355.course_description: Provides students with an understanding of cross-border media flows and their impact on the relationship between Canada and the United States. This course examines how news institutions, governments, and other media actors in the region — Indigenous nations, non-governmental organizations, and multinational corporations — produce their own media that renders cross. -border regions such as Cascadia, the Great Lakes, and the Arctic as politically and culturally dynamic geographies. Students in this class will acquire an introduction to Canadian news media in the context of their relationship to U.S. counterparts — and vice-versa. Also offered as C/AM 355.

JOUR 360.course_description: Reading and critiquing texts that use literary techniques to enhance journalism. Studying the history of literary journalism and its impact on the field.

JOUR 365.course_description: This course is designed for those who are interested in exploring magazines and who may be considering a career as a magazine writer, editor or designer. The course provides an introduction to magazine publishing, including a historical overview of the magazine industry, its evolution and its place in a consumer society. We will survey current consumer publications and will analyze what makes the best ones distinctive and valuable. The course will focus on how magazines are conceived, organized, edited, financed, produced and distributed. Based on this background, students will build a prospectus for a magazine of their own design which will answer the questions posed by backers: What is the editorial style, who is the audience, how will it be financed, who are the advertisers, what is the circulation, what is the character of its design, what makes it unique. The class also will address the growth of online publishing.

JOUR 370.course_description: Students will learn the basic steps to plan, produce and edit journalism that combines written components, audio, video and graphics to create compelling and engaging multimedia reports. Students will watch, analyze and provide written critiques of published multimedia projects. Students will examine the methods and techniques used by successful multimedia journalists. Students will produce, edit and review their own multimedia projects that combine written, audio and visual elements.

JOUR 375.course_name: Diversity, Mass Media and Social Change
JOUR 375.course_description: Uses an intersectional framework of race/ethnicity, gender, class and other demographic groups to examine how mass media cover social change and affect their audiences.

JOUR 380.course_name: Advanced Public Relations Writing and Techniques
JOUR 380.course_description: Intensive focus on the processes involved in writing for an organization’s diverse publics, including news releases, op-eds, broadcast material, speeches, organizational memos and proposals, employer publications, backgrounders, features and web sites.  Students gain hands-on experience by applying these skills and processes through service-learning by writing for community organizations.

JOUR 390.course_description: Critical examination of current news issues and decision-making processes through visiting news media professionals, readings and discussion. Repeatable to a maximum of 8 credits with various topics.

JOUR 400.course_description: An individualized course of study not available through or replacing existing curriculum, to be arranged between one matriculating student and sponsoring faculty member. All academic policies and registration deadlines apply. Directed Independent Study courses cannot substitute for General University Requirements and are not eligible for tuition waiver.

JOUR 404.course_description: In-depth article, column, and persuasive writing; development of ideas, gathering of materials and writing; special attention to individual interests; exploration of freelance writing markets.

JOUR 407.course_description: A study of the functions, processes and problems in the practice of public relations, paying particular attention to media relations, public relations theory and critical thinking. Students examine various genres of public relations, as well as exploring how theory, research, strategic objectives and evaluation contribute to successful campaigns. Students learn about creating successful public relations campaigns through critically analyzing case studies of both local companies and national programs and then applying what they learned to create a new proposal or campaign.

JOUR 414.course_description: Participation on the staff of the university newspaper. Writing articles and taking photographs for the university’s newspaper and online edition. Gathering and editing audio and video, creating multimedia packages for the newspaper’s Web site. Also includes lecture. Repeatable to a maximum of 16 credits, including original course.

JOUR 415.course_description: Publication editing and development; assigning and editing news stories, photographs and multimedia projects; creating content for the publication’s web site; creating and implementing budget and advising on budget decisions; acting as mentor to assigned staff members; holding office hours and meeting outside scheduled class time; preparing reports and presentations for class and instructor; assisting with and taking part in workshops; office management and security; learning personnel communication skills; using advanced publication software and technology; making self-evaluation and production reports for adviser. Repeatable to a maximum of 20 credits, including original course. This course may not be taken concurrently with a staff course.

JOUR 421.course_description: Staff writers prepare and produce the quarterly university periodical and its online edition under the direction of the editor-in-chief and editorial management staff; learn and practice querying story ideas, researching, reporting, writing and then assisting with production of the written and visual elements of the magazine, including online elements for the website. Writers will manage their own time outside of class to report, write and revise manuscripts, investing time appropriate to their task and their goals and to meet deadline, and work with the editorial management team on production issues. Repeatable up to 12 credits including original course.

JOUR 422.course_description: Print publication and online publication editing and development; hiring and supervising an editorial management team to produce the twice-quarterly university periodical and its online edition; acting as mentor to assigned staff members; holding office hours and meetings outside scheduled class time; preparing reports and presentations for class and instructor; assisting with and taking part in workshops;  managing the publication office; reviewing and staying within budget; learning personnel communication skills; using advanced publication software and technology; making self-evaluation and production reports for adviser. This course may not be taken concurrently with a periodical staff course. Repeatable up to 15 credits including original course.

JOUR 430.course_description: Supervised field work on newspapers, magazines, radio and TV stations, public relations and advertising agencies, or other appropriate professional situations. S/U grading.

JOUR 440.course_description: Study and practice in research methods, theory, implementation and evaluation of effective programs of communication. Students work in teams to establish a firm theoretical and research-based approach to planning an effective public relations campaign for a community organization.

JOUR 446.course_description: In depth exploration of concepts and practices explored in Journalism 346. Students work in teams to apply theories, conduct research, analyze data and apply design and software skills to produce visual and verbal elements for advanced projects.

JOUR 450.course_description: Survey and application of advanced reporting techniques, including computer-assisted reporting, and the use of the Internet, to produce news stories of depth, complexity and appeal.

JOUR 460.course_description: Students write about and photograph people who have ethnic, national, environmental or cultural backgrounds different from the dominant society; sensitivity to other cultural traditions; advanced reporting and writing skills.

JOUR 480.course_description: Examines research methods in and theories of mass communication in the context of the practice of journalism and public relations in a democratic society. A research paper provides students with practice applying specific methods and theories to explore contemporary issues in journalism and public relations.

KIN 300.course_description: An individualized course of study not available through or replacing existing curriculum, to be arranged between one matriculating student and sponsoring faculty member. All academic policies and registration deadlines apply. Directed Independent Study courses cannot substitute for General University Requirements and are not eligible for tuition waiver.

KIN 304.course_name: Prevention and Care of Athletic Injuries
KIN 304.course_description: Overview of current information on the care and prevention, and immediate care, of common sports injuries.

KIN 306.course_description: Application of the theory of measurement, evaluation and appropriate statistical processes to kinesiology programs; practical experiences involving test selection, administration and evaluation and interpretation of results in health and fitness settings.

KIN 307.course_description: Statistical techniques utilized in the exercise and sport science fields.

KIN 308.course_description: The study of postnatal growth, maturation, and physical activity, their interrelationship with cognitive and psychosocial development, with application to health promotion and physical activity programs for children and youth.

KIN 311.course_description: Application of basic mechanical principles to movement. Motion fundamentals, kinetics, kinematics, aerodynamics, hydrodynamics, equilibrium and external forces, rebound and spin, two-dimensional analysis, and the body as a machine; lab work is included.

KIN 312.course_description: Muscles of the body that contribute to providing motion; origin, insertion, and action; principles of human movement, including the fundamental contributors to the production of muscle force and the analysis of how muscle actions contribute to achieving motion; performance analysis of basic locomotor movement, daily living activities and sports skills; lab work included.

KIN 315.course_description: Instructional strategies, general progressions, pedagogical principles, teaching methods, class management, peer teaching, self-evaluation strategies, and supervision strategies for teaching in various health and fitness settings.

KIN 320.course_description: Psychological principles and states which are present in sporting activities, both at recreational and highly competitive levels.

KIN 321.course_description: This course examines the sociological implications of competitive sport in American society. Through analysis of race/ethnicity, gender, class, media, and youth sport issues, including discussions of both current events and sociological research, students explore the influence of broader social context on sport as well as the influence of competitive sport on society.

KIN 400.course_description: An individualized course of study not available through or replacing existing curriculum, to be arranged between one matriculating student and sponsoring faculty member. All academic policies and registration deadlines apply. Directed Independent Study courses cannot substitute for General University Requirements and are not eligible for tuition waiver.

KIN 409.course_description: This course will be a study of age-related physical and psychosocial changes which occur during the older adult years, their interrelationship with physical activity, with application to health promotion and disease prevention. Additionally, this course will examine the physical functional assessment methods commonly used with older adults, including those that are novel or in development. The research foundations and effectiveness of such assessments will be examined, and their appropriate utilization and interpretation will be practiced with community senior volunteers.

KIN 410.course_description: Principles of motor control and skill acquisition, as it relates to human movement.

KIN 412.course_description: This course will focus on independent dissection and preparation of the human cadavers for use in KIN 312 – Functional Anatomy by isolating and exposing the superficial and deep skeletal muscles. This course will allow students an incomparable experience to learn human anatomy through hands-on human body dissection. Students will be assigned a specific region of the body to dissect independently. Students will work in the cadaver lab 3 hours each week and spend 1 additional hour each week preparing dissection plans and completing assigned readings.

KIN 413.course_description: Nature of muscular, metabolic, cardiovascular and respiratory adjustments to acute and chronic exercise. The effect of training on fitness and health. Includes experimental laboratory sessions.

KIN 414.course_description: Current topics on exercise and nutrition; weight control, dietary supplementation and performance, fluid regulation, atherosclerosis and diabetes. Applications include metabolic balance, consumer issues such as marketing strategies, label analysis, food choices, attributes of food products such as natural, organic, fat-free, among others.

KIN 415.course_name: Physical Fitness Assessment and Exercise Prescription
KIN 415.course_description: Examine techniques of evaluation for physical fitness with an emphasis on aerobic capacity, flexibility, and body composition; case studies; develop appropriate exercise program and re-evaluation. Includes experimental laboratory sessions and practical laboratory skills analysis.

KIN 416.course_description: Theoretical and practical knowledge necessary to design safe and effective training programs for optimization of health, fitness and performance.

KIN 419.course_description: This course explores mental health concerns in sport, health, and exercise settings, including eating disorders, depression, recreational drug abuse, performance enhancing drug use, and burnout.

KIN 420.course_description: An interdisciplinary seminar (psychology/physical education) exploring core topics of sport psychology including: evaluation of athletes, research design and strategies, personality assessment, mental and physical preparation for competition, clinical applications.

KIN 421.course_description: This theory and application course will examine the relationship between personal, mental, and behavioral factors with exercise (bi-directional). Major topics will include, but are not limited to, the impact of exercise on mood states, mental health and immune function, exercise motivation, interventions and adherence.

KIN 422.course_name: Professional Issues in Health and Exercise Settings
KIN 422.course_description: The focus of this course is on professional issues relating to human resources, philosophy, finance and legal concerns with a focus on technical and professional writing.

KIN 435.course_description: Theoretical and practical aspects of developing and implementing worksite health promotion programs, including student team development and implementation of a community worksite based health promotion program.

KIN 472.course_description: Full-time supervised professional experience emphasizing functional proficiency under joint sponsorship of University and agency personnel. S/U grading.

KIN 491.course_description: Practical volunteer experience in agencies such as hospitals, physical therapy clinics, retirement or convalescent centers, worksite wellness programs, fitness facilitation, on-campus fitness programs and community sports organizations. S/U grading. Repeatable up to 6 credits including original course.

KIN 492.course_description: Practical volunteer experience in agencies such as hospitals, physical therapy clinics, retirement or convalescent centers, worksite wellness programs, fitness facilitation, on-campus fitness programs and community sports organizations. S/U grading. Repeatable up to 6 credits including original course.

KIN 493.course_description: Investigation of a problem conducted independently or as part of a group under faculty supervision. S/U grading.

KIN 494.course_description: Assist faculty in the classroom and lab instruction. Assist faculty with activities such as lab and lecture preparation and implementation, leading classroom discussions, assisting students with class materials. Duties vary by course and instructor but the time commitment will be 8 to 10 hours per week. Repeatable to a maximum of 6 credits. S/U grading.

KIN 500.course_description: An individualized course of study not available through or replacing existing curriculum, to be arranged between one matriculating student and sponsoring faculty member. All academic policies and registration deadlines apply.

KIN 502.course_name: Research Topics in Human Movement and Performance
KIN 502.course_description: Supervised research or study in topics related to sociology/ psychology of sport, biomechanics, exercise physiology, motor learning/control, human growth and motor development, and epidemiology of physical activity. Repeatable to a maximum of 10 credits including original course.

KIN 505.course_name: Proposal Preparation in Human Movement and Performance
KIN 505.course_description: Purpose and design of various research methods used in the analysis of human movement and performance problems; development of research proposals.

KIN 506.course_name: Research Statistical Analysis in Human Movement and Performance
KIN 506.course_description: Purpose and design of various research statistical methods used in the analysis of human movement and performance problems; survey of common statistical applications.

KIN 507.course_description: Examination of the structure and function of the human neuromuscular system, as it pertains to the production of movement.

KIN 510.course_description: Common laboratory techniques utilized in exercise science are presented with emphasis on body composition analysis, circulo-respiratory testing, phlebotomy/blood analysis, muscular strength and endurance, computer usage, force platform analysis, electromyography and motion capture techniques.

KIN 513.course_description: Design safe and effective physical activities for selected populations in rehabilitative, preventative, and competitive programs. Medico-legal aspects and administration of exercise prescription and programming. Case studies.

KIN 514.course_description: Current topics on physical activity and nutrition, with emphasis on athletes' types of diets and nutrients, weight control, dietary supplementation and performance, and fluid regulation. Applications include case studies, metabolic balance, nutrient excess and deficiency, and dietary attributes.

KIN 516.course_description: This course is designed to equip students with the theoretical and practical knowledge related to the most advanced and state-of-the-art methods used to maximize fitness and athletic performance.

KIN 520.course_name: Readings in Human Movement and Performance
KIN 520.course_description: Directed readings, analysis, discussion of current literature on human movement culminating in a written paper and discussion of chosen topic.

KIN 540.course_description: Selected topics in advanced exercise physiology: homeostasis, energy systems, metabolism, cardiorespiratory adjustments, hormonal control, neuromuscular physiology, nephrology, immunology, environmental responses and adaptations, by lecture and recitation.

KIN 541.course_description: Theoretical foundations and behavioral applications of sport psychology including: history, ethics and current status of sport psychology, individual differences in sport behavior, motivation in sport, exercise psychology, social influence and sport, and the dynamics of sport groups.

KIN 542.course_description: The study of sport as a microcosm of society with particular emphasis on the following topical areas: economics and sport, social mobility and sport, socialization, ethnic issues and sport, gender issues and sport, education and sport, sport and politics, and current social issues and sport.

I T 563.course_name: Techniques and Tools in Multimedia Development
I T 563.course_description: Create digital media (e.g., graphics, video, audio); identify properties, strengths and weaknesses of digital media in different learning contexts; analyze its use in a variety of settings including distance delivery.

I T 565.course_description: Design and develop web-based instruction and materials; study of various forms of web-based instruction with emphasis on online learning technologies.  Integrates appropriate methods, curricular resources, assessments, and Internet delivery systems.

I T 566.course_description: Techniques and procedures for authoring when developing multimedia. Scripting required in implementation of concepts.

I T 567.course_description: Design and develop technology-enhanced interactive learning objects for teaching and training.  Focus on using multimedia and instructional design for online learning.  Students explore concepts and findings identified in the multimedia and distance education literature.

I T 568.course_description: Advanced issues in the design and development of interactive multimedia instructional lessons. Covers design issues related to the use of multimedia for instruction and is organized around individual student projects. Repeatable to a maximum of 6 credits.

I T 571.course_description: Implement an instructional plan that integrates appropriate methods, curricular resources, assessments, and technology in a classroom setting; gather data to evaluate the plan’s effectiveness.  Develop a learning object; do usability testing and analysis.  Begin development of an electronic portfolio.

I T 572.course_name: Advanced Technology Tools and Classroom Applications
I T 572.course_description: Develop advanced skills in information and communication technologies, assistive technologies, and productive tools.  Employ one of these technologies in creating a prototype to be used for research.  Develop materials and methods for teaching of software applications.

I T 573.course_name: Emerging Issues:  the Social, Ethical, Legal and Human Implications of Technology
I T 573.course_description: Consideration of a wide range of human and social issues relating to the use of technology, including equitable access, social and cognitive effects of various technologies, appropriateness of technologies for students with diverse learning needs, gender and cultural bias, copyright, and health concerns.

I T 574.course_name: Educational Technology Research, Evaluation and Assessment
I T 574.course_description: Research the effectiveness of technology products and processes, selecting appropriate technology tools for assessment, and evaluating learner and program outcomes.

I T 575.course_name: Designing, Implementing and Evaluating Professional Development
I T 575.course_description: Identify research-based models for professional development, implement them effectively in particular settings, and evaluate participant outcomes.  Emphasis on diffusion of innovations and facilitating change.

I T 640.course_description: Studies of current topics in learning resources/library science or instructional technology. Repeatable with no maximum.

I T 690.course_description: Research study under the direction of a faculty committee. Repeatable to a maximum of 9 credits. S/U grading.

I T 691.course_description: Repeatable to a maximum of 6 credits. S/U grading.

IEP 001.course_description: Development of English grammar skills within the contexts of writing, reading, listening, and oral interpersonal communication skills at a basic level of proficiency.

IEP 002.course_description: Development of English reading competency at a basic level while integrating level-appropriate writing, grammar, listening, and oral interpersonal communication skills.

IEP 003.course_description: Development of English writing competency at a basic level while integrating level-appropriate reading, grammar, listening, and oral interpersonal communication skills.

IEP 004.course_description: Development of English listening and speaking competencies at a basic level while integrating level-appropriate reading, writing, grammar, and oral interpersonal communication skills.

IEP 009.course_description: Introduction and analysis of topics related to English language skills at the appropriate level. Repeatable with various topics with no maximum.

IEP 011.course_description: Development of English writing, reading, grammar, listening, and oral interpersonal communication skills at a Beginning level of competency.

IEP 012.course_description: Development of English reading competency at a Beginning level while integrating level-appropriate writing, grammar, listening, and oral interpersonal communication skills.

IEP 013.course_description: Development of English writing competency at a Beginning level while integrating level-appropriate reading, grammar, listening, and oral interpersonal communication skills.

IEP 014.course_description: Development of English listening competency at a Beginning level while integrating level-appropriate reading, writing, grammar, and oral interpersonal communication skills.

IEP 019.course_description: Introduction and analysis of topics related to English language skills at the appropriate level. Repeatable with various topics with no maximum.

IEP 021.course_description: Development of English writing, reading, grammar, listening, and oral interpersonal communication skills at an Early Intermediate level of proficiency.

IEP 022.course_description: Development of English reading competency at an Early Intermediate level while integrating writing, grammar, listening, and oral interpersonal communication skills.

IEP 023.course_description: Development of English writing competency at an Early Intermediate level while integrating level-appropriate reading, grammar, listening, and oral interpersonal communication skills.

IEP 024.course_description: Development of English listening competency at an Early Intermediate level while integrating level-appropriate reading, writing, grammar, and oral interpersonal communication skills.

IEP 029.course_description: Introduction and analysis of topics related to English language skills at the appropriate level. Repeatable with various topics with no maximum.

IEP 031.course_description: Development of English writing, reading, grammar, listening, and oral interpersonal communication skills at an Intermediate level of proficiency.

IEP 032.course_description: Development of English reading competency at an Intermediate level while integrating level-appropriate writing, grammar, listening, and oral interpersonal communication skills.

IEP 033.course_description: Development of English writing competency at an Intermediate level while integrating level-appropriate reading, grammar, listening, and oral interpersonal communication skills.

IEP 034.course_description: Development of English listening competency at an Intermediate level using level-appropriate reading, writing, grammar, and oral interpersonal skills.

IEP 039.course_description: Introduction and analysis of topics related to English language skills at the appropriate level. Repeatable with various topics with no maximum.

IEP 041.course_description: Development of English writing, reading, grammar, listening, and oral interpersonal communication skills at an Early Advanced level of proficiency.

IEP 042.course_description: Development of English reading competency at the Early Advanced level while integrating level-appropriate writing, grammar, listening, and oral interpersonal communication skills.

IEP 043.course_description: Development of English writing competency at an Early Advanced level while integrating reading, grammar, listening, and oral interpersonal communication skills.

IEP 044.course_description: Development of English listening competency at an early advanced level while integrating level appropriate reading, writing, grammar, and oral communication skills.

IEP 049.course_description: Introduction and analysis of topics related to English language skills at the appropriate level. Repeatable with various topics with no maximum.

IEP 051.course_description: Development of English writing, reading, grammar, listening, and oral interpersonal communication skills at an Advanced level of proficiency.

IEP 052.course_description: Development of English reading competency at an Advanced level while integrating level-appropriate writing, grammar, listening, and oral communication skills.

IEP 053.course_description: Development of English writing competency at an Advanced level while integrating level-appropriate reading, grammar, listening, and oral interpersonal communication skills.

IEP 055.course_description: Development of English aural and oral academic communication skills at an Advanced level while integrating level-appropriate reading, writing, and grammar skills.

IEP 059.course_description: Introduction and analysis of topics related to English language skills at the appropriate level. Repeatable with various topics with no maximum.

IEP 062.course_description: Development of English reading competency at an university prep level while integrating level-appropriate writing, grammar, listening, and oral communication skills.

IEP 063.course_description: Development of English writing competency at a university prep level while integrating level-appropriate reading, grammar, listening, and oral interpersonal communication skills.

IEP 065.course_description: Development of English aural and oral academic communication skills at a university prep level while integrating level-appropriate reading, writing, and grammar skills.

IEP 069.course_description: Introduction and analysis of topics related to English language skills at the appropriate level. Repeatable with various topics with no maximum.

IEP 103.course_description: Development of English writing competency while integrating level-appropriate reading, grammar, listening, and oral interpersonal communication skills. Students may include a maximum of 15 credits of 100-level IEP coursework towards undergraduate degrees at Western.

IEP 105.course_description: Development of English aural and oral academic communication skills while integrating level-appropriate reading, writing, and grammar skills. Students may include a maximum of 15 credits of 100-level IEP coursework towards undergraduate degrees at Western.

IEP 112.course_description: Development of English reading competency at an university prep level while integrating level-appropriate writing, grammar, listening, and oral communication skills. Students may include a maximum of 15 credits of 100-level IEP coursework towards undergraduate degrees at Western.

IEP 113.course_description: Development of English writing competency at a university prep level while integrating level-appropriate reading, grammar, listening, and oral interpersonal communication skills. Students may include a maximum of 15 credits of IEP 100-level coursework towards undergraduate degrees at Western.

IEP 115.course_description: Development of English aural and oral academic communication skills at a university prep level while integrating level-appropriate reading, writing, and grammar skills. Students may include a maximum of 15 credits of 100-level IEP coursework towards undergraduate degrees at Western. Repeatable to a maximum of 15 credits, including original course.

IBUS 337.course_description: This study abroad course is led by a faculty member to provide students with international, experiential learning. Students will participate in both classroom and applied learning opportunities that may include pre-travel orientation and class meetings at Western, group instruction, reading, writing, and critical reflection assignments, learning from the host community, cultural excursions, field work, post-travel debriefing, and culminating projects.

IBUS 370.course_description: Introduction to the environment and challenges of doing business abroad. Topics include country-market differences, trade and investment patterns, the international financial environment, issues in business-government relations and strategies for international business.

IBUS 372.course_description: This course is concerned with various perspectives on, and elements of, differences in national culture, the relevance of cultural differences to key management issues, and applied issues associated with management in cross-cultural contexts. This means that the course considers various disciplinary approaches to understanding national culture and relates them to key applied management topics such as motivation, leadership, decision making, and negotiations.

IBUS 400.course_description: An individualized course of study not available through or replacing existing curriculum, to be arranged between one matriculating student and sponsoring faculty member. All academic policies and registration deadlines apply. Directed Independent Study courses cannot substitute for General University Requirements and are not eligible for tuition waiver.

IBUS 470.course_description: Strategic and operational issues that firms face when they do business abroad. Themes include the competitiveness challenge, country-market analysis and entry strategies, negotiations and diplomacy, cooperative ventures, design and control of international operations, and various functional area issues.

IBUS 473.course_description: Operations of firms using exporting as a means to serve foreign markets. Focus on export operations (documentation, transport, support services, financing), practical aspects of contract negotiations, alternative methods of export business arrangements. In some terms, this class will be an export marketing research class with teams of students working with real companies to expand the company’s export opportunities. Repeatable to a maximum of 8 credits, including original course.

IBUS 474.course_description: Varying topics in international business. This could include courses on business in specific areas of the world, specific international business topics (e.g. negotiation), or currently important topics in the international business field. Repeatable with different topics up to 8 credits, including original course.

IBUS 475.course_description: The course discusses business and economic conditions in country systems. Students learn how both local and foreign country businesses and economic actors interact within the local market institutions and customs. The country mix may vary by term.

IBUS 490.course_description: Practical application of international business skills and theories learned in the classroom through work or special projects experience in private or public organizations. Repeatable to a maximum of 12 credits, including original course.

INTL 105.course_description: Credit through international exchanges, academic programs offered through universities or consortia, cosponsored programs. Repeatable. S/U including IP grade.

INTL 106.course_description: Credit through international exchanges. Direct Exchange 1 – Direct Exchange Two Semesters or Three Quarters. Repeatable. S/U including IP grade.

INTL 107.course_description: Credit through international exchanges. Direct Exchange 2 – Direct Exchange Semester. Repeatable. S/U including IP grade.

INTL 108.course_description: Credit through international exchanges. Direct Exchange Plan 3 – Direct Exchange Asia University. Repeatable. S/U including IP grade.

INTL 109.course_description: Credits earned through academic programs offered by faculty teaching for AHA International or a similar consortium. Repeatable to a maximum of 30 credits, including original course. S/U grading.

INTL 115.course_description: International internships, independent research projects, work experience approved by departments or colleges. Repeatable. S/U including IP grade.

KIN 543.course_description: Kinematic and kinetic analysis of human movement with focus on practical application of mechanical laws governing human motion; laboratory and computer applications.

KIN 544.course_description: Selected topics relating to biomechanics of the musculoskeletal system, muscular and skeletal system characteristics, biomechanics of the hip, knee, shoulder, foot, ankle and vertebral column.

KIN 545.course_description: The course provides students with a systematic introduction to gait analysis from a biomechanical perspective. The course specifically provides an introduction to fundamental gait terminology, data collection, and data interpretation methods used in gait analysis.

KIN 551.course_description: Provides comprehensive overview of applied educational strategies and techniques in sport and exercise psychology, including performance enhancement/intervention strategies and techniques, exercise psychology, psychosocial foundations of youth sport programs and psychology of coaching.

KIN 552.course_description: This is a sport and exercise psychology practicum course for graduate students enrolled in the Kinesiology master’s program in Sport and Exercise Psychology. While enrolled in this course, students will complete internship experiences that are focused on the application of sport and exercise psychology interventions for individual and/or groups of athletes, exercisers, or performers. Course instructors provide supervision to the students regarding their interactions with clients as well as provide training in specific applied sport and exercise psychology skills and ethics. Repeatable up to 10 credits including original course. S/U grading.

KIN 555.course_name: Professional Ethics in Sport and Exercise Psychology
KIN 555.course_description: This course is designed to provide students with a comprehensive overview of the ethical and legal issues relevant to sport, exercise, and performance psychology professionals. Ethical codes particular to applied mental performance consultants will be a featured component of the course along with ethical decision-making and moral reasoning models. Students will also be exposed to the application of ethical concepts and codes applied to teaching and research.

KIN 592.course_description: Supervised internship in schools, hospitals, clinics or corporation/industries as appropriate to complement the student’s area of interest. Repeatable to a maximum of 6 credits. S/U grading.

KIN 690.course_description: Repeatable to a maximum of 9 credits, including original course. S/U grading.

LAT 101.course_description: Fundamentals of grammar to provide a reading knowledge; selected readings from various Roman writers.

LAT 102.course_description: Fundamentals of grammar to provide a reading knowledge; selected readings from various Roman writers.

LAT 103.course_description: Fundamentals of grammar to provide a reading knowledge; selected readings from various Roman writers.

LAT 201.course_description: To be taken in sequence as the first in an intermediate language sequence. Review of fundamentals; selected readings from various Roman writers; introduction to Roman civilization.

LAT 202.course_description: To be taken in sequence as the second in an intermediate language sequence. Review of fundamentals; selected readings from various Roman writers; introduction to Roman civilization.

LAT 203.course_description: To be taken in sequence as the third in an intermediate language sequence. Review of fundamentals; selected readings from Roman writers with an emphasis on honing grammatical skills and understanding Roman literary and cultural achievements.

LAT 300.course_description: An individualized course of study not available through or replacing existing curriculum, to be arranged between one matriculating student and sponsoring faculty member. All academic policies and registration deadlines apply. Directed Independent Study courses cannot substitute for General University Requirements and are not eligible for tuition waiver.

LAT 340.course_description: Readings in major Roman authors of the late Republican and early Imperial periods; introduction to classical literary analysis.

LAT 341.course_description: Readings in the Christian Latin authors of the European Middle Ages.  Introduction to Latin paleography, Medieval literary genres and prosody.

LAT 342.course_description: Selections from authors of the European Renaissance, Reformation and modern periods; special attention given to the continuity of Classical literary traditions.

LAT 400.course_description: An individualized course of study not available through or replacing existing curriculum, to be arranged between one matriculating student and sponsoring faculty member. All academic policies and registration deadlines apply. Directed Independent Study courses cannot substitute for General University Requirements and are not eligible for tuition waiver.

LAT 425.course_description: Practicum in preparation, implementation and evaluation of instructional materials. Repeatable up to 3 times to a maximum of 10 credits, including original course. S/U grading.

LDST 100.course_description: Introduction to and critical examination of select virtues and character strengths associated with leading responsibly. Topics studied in class will be applied in a service learning experience.

LDST 101.course_description: This introductory leadership course delivers faculty-led interactive lectures where students participate to critically examine leadership theory and their own development as leaders and followers. Students also participate and coordinate in their Discussion Sections (led by more advanced leadership students) to participate in legacy-based community engagement projects. Each LDST 101 Discussion Section works on a different legacy project, which (depending on student choices and project details) can provide experience in areas like team development, video, project management, event planning, communication, interpersonal, outreach/advocacy, social media, and conflict management skills.

LDST 201.course_name: Introduction to Leading with Emotional and Social Intelligence
LDST 201.course_description: This class explores the foundations of emotionally and socially intelligent leadership. The course addresses how successful leaders generally display high degrees of emotional intelligence as they understand what they are feeling, what those emotions mean to them, and how these emotions affect other people. It also addresses how socially intelligent leaders are able to navigate social relationships and environments. Coursework also emphasizes students’ abilities to develop these core competencies in themselves.

LDST 240.course_description: This course provides a theoretical introduction and practical application of leadership competencies for students who serve in peer leadership capacities on campus. Students involved in clubs, student government, sports, or labwork settings may find this class helpful in terms of working with student peers.

LDST 300.course_description: An individualized course of study not available through or replacing existing curriculum, to be arranged between one matriculating student and sponsoring faculty member. All academic policies and registration deadlines apply. Directed Independent Study courses cannot substitute for General University Requirements and are not eligible for tuition waiver.

LDST 301.course_description: An in-depth examination of leadership theories, research, and practice. Students’ work will reflect theoretical application and personal skill development and may be accomplished through individual projects that may be tied to personal professional development, on or off campus advocacy, organizational support, or service-learning projects.

LDST 304.course_description: This course provides military veterans the opportunity to bridge their military and educational experiences in order to make the transition to professional civilian careers. Through online assignments, in-person meetings, lectures, guest speakers, and practical application, students will benefit from course content that addresses business and professional communication techniques and develop personal and professional understanding of themselves and their capabilities. Some class sessions may meet off campus in order to facilitate networking with professionals in the community.

LDST 340.course_description: This course provides an advanced exploration of the theoretical and practical applications of leadership competencies for students who serve in peer leadership capacities on campus. Students will engage in self-reflection and articulation of personal leadership capabilities to apply to and enhance their leadership roles. Students involved in clubs, student government, sports, or labwork settings may find this class helpful in terms of working with student peers.

LDST 341.course_description: Supervised work in leadership with an educational program or institution, public agency, private enterprise, or non-governmental organization. Meetings, written reports, and a paper related to the Practicum are required. Repeatable up to 6 credits including original course. A maximum of 4 credits may be applied to the LDST minor.

LDST 400.course_description: An individualized course of study not available through or replacing existing curriculum, to be arranged between one matriculating student and sponsoring faculty member. All academic policies and registration deadlines apply. Directed Independent Study courses cannot substitute for General University Requirements and are not eligible for tuition waiver.

LDST 408.course_description: Now, more than ever, we need leaders for sustainability. This course is designed for students who are curious about and eager to lead for a more sustainable and just world. This course will explore what kind of leadership is required to address sustainability and climate change. Together, we will examine how historical notions of leadership might offer lessons, and how we may need to think and act differently. Through the use of articles, case studies, personal reflection, and collaborative inquiry, you will learn key competencies for leading for sustainability. Also offered as SUST 408.

LDST 416.course_description: In-depth coverage of special topics in leadership. The subject of each individual course may differ. Repeatable with different topics up to 3 times for a maximum of 12 credits, including original course.

LDST 420.course_description: Introduces methodologies used in leadership research and facilitates student’s ability to conduct research in Leadership Studies.

LDST 450.course_description: Serve as discussion section leader for students taking Introduction to Leadership Studies. Learn instructional methods, gain further mastery of leadership course content and personal leadership skills. Lead discussions, and provide feedback for students enrolled in Introduction to Leadership Studies.

LDST 451.course_description: Serve as a discussion section leader for students taking Introduction to Leadership Studies and as peer mentor to one student enrolled in Leadership and Pedagogy. Continue to develop instructional methods and personal leadership skills by reflecting on prior (LDST 450) and learning new (LDST 451) course content.

LDST 452.course_description: Serve as a teaching assistant for students taking Leadership & Pedagogy. Lead discussions and activities, mentor, and help students reflect upon their leadership development. Gain further mastery in instructional methods, leadership course content, and personal communication skills. Develop skills associated with assessment, evaluation, and conflict management. Explore literature related to leading in complex and diverse cultural contexts.

LDST 453.course_description: Serve as a teaching assistant for students taking Leadership & Pedagogy. Gain further mastery in leading discussions and activities, mentoring, and assisting others in their reflective leadership development. Continue to develop instructional methods and personal leadership skills by reflecting on prior (LDST 452) and learning new (LDST 453) course content.

LDST 495.course_description: Integration and development of leadership skills through reflective practice.

LIBR 201.course_description: Introduction to the nature of research and the interpretation of information. Emphasizes information literacy, including: carrying out inquiry, locating both print and online resources, analyzing and interpreting a variety of sources for authority and authenticity, and incorporating material from sources into writing.

LIBR 205.course_description: This course examines the relationship between multiple academic literacies: research, writing, speaking, and listening. Together we will explore the value of dialogue as a form of research. The primary goal is to determine the connection between research on learning through sustained discourse.

LIBR 239.course_description: In support of their linked course and in preparation for future academic work, students in this Workshop course will learn strategies and skills necessary for engaging inquiry-based learning, efficient and ethical research, and communicating ideas in informal and formal writing assignments.

LIBR 300.course_description: An individualized course of study not available through or replacing existing curriculum, to be arranged between one matriculating student and sponsoring faculty member. All academic policies and registration deadlines apply. Directed Independent Study courses cannot substitute for General University Requirements and are not eligible for tuition waiver.

LIBR 320.course_description: Varying topics and information studies including emerging technologies and trends in scholarly research. Repeatable to a maximum of 6 credits.

LIBR 325.course_description: This course will introduce students to major topics in the history of books and printing. It will explore the complex process of producing a book at various times in history and consider the social and cultural impact of book production. Hands-on activities will improve student understanding of course readings and lectures. The course will meet in Special Collections in Wilson Library and involve extensive use of rare books and manuscripts from around the world.

LIBR 341.course_description: Through individualized learning plans developed in consultation with the instructor, students work with a peer mentor to gain and apply research, writing, reading, listening, speaking strategies. Repeatable to a maximum of 6 credits including the original course. S/U grading.

LIBR 400.course_description: An individualized course of study not available through or replacing existing curriculum, to be arranged between one matriculating student and sponsoring faculty member. All academic policies and registration deadlines apply. Directed Independent Study courses cannot substitute for General University Requirements and are not eligible for tuition waiver.

LIBR 402.course_description: Examines library resources, research processes, and scholarly discourse for upper-division students in a particular discipline. An upper-division library course intended to support advanced research methodologies for students in a particular major. Not repeatable. Letter graded. Equivalent to LIBR 403. Cannot take both LIBR 402 and 403 for credit.

LIBR 403.course_description: Examines library resources, research processes, and scholarly discourse for upper-division students in a particular discipline. An upper-division library course intended to support advanced research methodologies for students in a particular major. Not repeatable. S/U grading. Equivalent to LIBR 402. Cannot take both LIBR 402 and 403 for credit.

LING 101.course_description: Via a broad survey of non-Western languages of the world, this course explores how languages play a central role in colonization and nation-building processes, how language policies contribute to linguistic loss and revitalization, and how communities grapple with the interactions between language and culture. While exploring non-Indo-European languages and language families, students will examine historical and current issues of multilingualism to better understand the relationship between language, identity, and social mobility.

LING 201.course_description: Introduction to the scientific study of language and the various subfields of linguistics, including how language is acquired, how it varies across time and space, and how it is used in different social contexts.

LING 204.course_description: A thematic approach to the study of language use in society; topics might include language and social identity, dialect variation, language contact, endangered languages, language ideology and attitudes in education and the media.

LING 207.course_description: This course will address some of the fundamental topics underlying human language including: (1) how different components of language are processed by and represented in our brains; (2) how language is acquired and processed throughout the life span; (3) the relationship between language and thought; (4) the effects of music and multilingualism on language networks; and (5) how neuroimaging and computational modeling techniques are used to examine the processing, representation, and acquisition of language.

LING 300.course_description: An individualized course of study not available through or replacing existing curriculum, to be arranged between one matriculating student and sponsoring faculty member. All academic policies and registration deadlines apply. Directed Independent Study courses cannot substitute for General University Requirements and are not eligible for tuition waiver.

LING 301.course_description: Students taking this class will experience an introduction to how language is studied as a science. Core foci of the class will involve identifying and describing patterns in language, developing hypotheses to explain the observed patterns, and learning to test those hypotheses through experimentation.

LING 302.course_description: Topics in linguistics. Variable topics. Repeatable with different topics to a maximum of 10 credits, including original course, but only 5 credits can count towards major requirements.

LING 303.course_description: Analyzes how words are constructed by comparing English with many other languages. Investigates how and why languages create different grammatical forms of the same word (inflection). Understanding patterns of word formation cross-linguistically provides a solid understanding morphological theory.

LING 304.course_description: Exploration of the outcomes and mechanisms of language contact by surveying cases around the world from the past and the present.

LING 305.course_description: Introduction to experimental methods and data analysis techniques commonly used in linguistics and language sciences. Basics of experimental design and statistical inference for hypothesis testing, as well as practical training on experimental paradigms used in various academic, research, and corporate fields.

LING 310.course_description: Focused introduction to linguistic analysis in phonetics, phonology, morphology, syntax and semantics in English and other languages, in preparation for more in-depth courses in theory and analysis in the linguistics major.

LING 311.course_description: Exploration of the mechanisms of speech and on the production, perception and transcription of speech sounds used in various languages.

LING 312.course_description: Exploration of the sound systems of the world’s languages; development of an understanding of and ability to do phonological analysis within the framework of generative grammar.

LING 315.course_description: An introduction to the science of the mind via exploration of language, as well as visual perception, attention, memory, learning, problem solving, and consciousness.

LING 321.course_description: Exploration of basic morphological and syntactic structures and operations across languages and the theoretical principles proposed to explain them.

LING 331.course_description: Exploration of semantics and pragmatics across languages and the theoretical principles proposed to explain them.

LING 332.course_description: Introduces students to the formal tools of semantics, including set theory, logic, and lambda calculus.

LING 336.course_description: Introduction to English sentence structure. Topics include clause structure, modification, complementation, and syntactic principles such as movement, coordinating and pronominalization.

LING 370.course_description: Exploration of systemic discriminatory practices in education based on language: what they are, how they came to be, and why they continue. Investigation of a diverse range of research and practice on enacting change in teaching about language to promote equity and inclusion.

LING 400.course_description: An individualized course of study not available through or replacing existing curriculum, to be arranged between one matriculating student and sponsoring faculty member. All academic policies and registration deadlines apply. Directed Independent Study courses cannot substitute for General University Requirements and are not eligible for tuition waiver.

LING 402.course_description: Advanced topics in linguistics. Repeatable with different topics up to a maximum of 15 credits, including original course.

LING 403.course_description: Investigates how phonology, morphology, syntax, and semantics evolve over time, revealing universal tendencies in language change as well as unique features in the history of individual families. Surveys the currently accepted genealogical classification of languages and explores how natural processes of linguistic change reflect the inborn human language ability.

LING 404.course_description: This course provides practical instruction in the methods employed in sociolinguistic research and the theoretical background associated with specific approaches. Possible topics for discussion include language variation and change, bi-/multilingualism, language attitudes and ideologies, age, social class, and gender.

LING 411.course_description: Advanced exploration of phonetic and/or phonological phenomena across languages. Repeatable with different topics up to a maximum of 10 credits, including original course.

LING 415.course_description: Provides students with the structural components and organization of the central and peripheral nervous systems and their conduction pathways and functions, with specific emphasis on those structures that subserve normal speech, language and hearing processes.

LING 421.course_description: Advanced exploration of morphological and/or syntactic phenomena across languages. Repeatable with different topics up to a maximum of 10 credits, including original course.

LING 425.course_description: Students collaborate with a faculty member to gain knowledge of pedagogical practices. Tasks may include leading group discussions, working with students individually, or presenting on topics of interest, under the guidance of faculty. Repeatable up to a maximum of 4 credits, including original course. Does not count towards major requirements. S/U grading.

LING 431.course_description: Advanced exploration of semantics and pragmatics across languages. Repeatable with different topics up to a maximum of 10 credits, including original course.

LING 435.course_description: Students will either work with faculty members on research, assisting in labs and/or with research projects. Repeatable to a maximum of 6 credits, including original course. S/U grading.

LING 441.course_description: Development of skills in linguistic fieldwork, including eliciting, recording, transcribing and analyzing data by working with a native speaker of a language unfamiliar to the students.

LING 445.course_description: Application of linguistic theory and principles in the second language learning, teaching, and research classroom.

MGMT 195.course_description: A comprehensive introduction to Accounting, Decision Sciences, Finance and Marketing, Economics and Management. The course will include a field trip to local businesses. S/U grading.

MGMT 201.course_description: A survey of the field. Introduction to the major functional areas comprising business or organizations. Recommended for students not intending to major in the College of Business and Economics.

MGMT 202.course_description: An introduction to perspectives on the nature of business in society, the development of the firm and how organizations function.

MGMT 271.course_description: Historical development of legal institutions, the judicial process, and impact of the law upon individual and business decision making.

MGMT 300.course_description: An individualized course of study not available through or replacing existing curriculum, to be arranged between one matriculating student and sponsoring faculty member. All academic policies and registration deadlines apply. Directed Independent Study courses cannot substitute for General University Requirements and are not eligible for tuition waiver.

MGMT 311.course_name: Introduction to Management and Organizational Behavior
MGMT 311.course_description: Introduction to organization theory, behavior and interpersonal communication; concepts of power, authority and influence; the role of philosophy and values in organizations.

MGMT 313.course_description: An introduction to teamwork concepts and skills. Covers structural and process attributes of teams with the objective of enhancing team leader or member effectiveness.

MGMT 315.course_description: This course helps students identify goals and the personalized steps needed to successfully transition from Western after graduation. Through practical and hands-on experiences, students will prepare for the job and internship search process and gain essential skills necessary to succeed in their future career. This course is open to students interested or declared in any major. S/U grading.

MGMT 319.course_description: The ability to communicate ideas accurately and persuasively is essential as a manager.  Effective communication can foster cooperation, productivity, and teamwork within diverse teams and organizations. This class provides a framework for students to learn, develop, and practice essential interpersonal, written, digital, and verbal communication skills.

MGMT 337.course_description: Management elective credit for upper-division courses taken at a WWU-approved study abroad program. Students must present sufficient documentation to show the material was successfully completed with a letter grade and the content is appropriate for upper-division elective credit in management.  Repeatable up to 12 credits.  S/U grading.

MGMT 359.course_name: Business and Sustainability Principles and Practice
MGMT 359.course_description: This course will provide both a survey and applications of principles and practices in business using environmental ethics, resources conservation, and sustainability frameworks. Also offered as UEPP 359.

MGMT 380.course_name: Business History of the United States
MGMT 380.course_description: Business history of the United States. Review and analysis of the organizational methods, performance, climate and entrepreneurship of American business from 1780 to the present.

MGMT 382.course_description: A study of the business decision-making process as these decisions interact with the social, technological, political/legal and economic environments. The causes and effects of the regulation of business are developed and explored.

MGMT 400.course_description: An individualized course of study not available through or replacing existing curriculum, to be arranged between one matriculating student and sponsoring faculty member. All academic policies and registration deadlines apply. Directed Independent Study courses cannot substitute for General University Requirements and are not eligible for tuition waiver.

MGMT 401.course_description: Examination of the theory and practice of interpersonal conflict management and negotiations in organizations. Uses cases and simulations to develop negotiation skills. Topics include conflict resolution, distributive and integrative negotiation techniques and outcomes, mediations, and collaboration.

MGMT 405.course_description: This course explores the positive potential of everyday interactions in the context of professional relationships. Emphasis is placed on the “how” of building and maintaining authentic, enlivening, fulfilling relationships. Organizational conditions that support or inhibit the cultivation of high-quality relationships are also considered. Significant attention is given to personal reflection, discussion, and skill development.

MGMT 413.course_description: This hands-on, project-based course focuses on learning and applying business consulting skills using strategic thinking and problem-solving methods, in partnership with a local non-profit organization. Students work in consulting teams to address an identified organizational need or business issue, resulting in the delivery of concrete products or recommendations for business improvement.

MGMT 414.course_description: A problem-based leadership course with emphasis on leading teams, leading organizational change, and self-leadership.

MGMT 415.course_description: Creativity and innovation are the future. Leaders who can inspire creativity and innovation in others throughout their organization will be successful in any role, industry, or location. Leaders who can themselves build teams to solve problems creatively will thrive in the organizations of the future. In this class, students will have an opportunity to build skills related to inspiring creativity and innovation in both themselves and others. Upon completing this course, students will have the skills to work with others in creative endeavors in many organizational contexts. Be prepared to get messy and creative!

MGMT 417.course_description: This course is about using entrepreneurial skills to craft innovative responses to social problems. Entrepreneurs are particularly good at recognizing opportunities, exploring innovative approaches, mobilizing resources, managing risks, and building viable enterprises. These skills are just as valuable in the social sector as they are in business. Social entrepreneurship applies to both profit and non-profit firms who have programs designed to create social value.

MGMT 437.course_description: This course is an interdisciplinary faculty-led study abroad and service learning experience. Students will participate in both classroom and applied learning opportunities that include pre-trip orientation, group instruction, reading, writing and critical reflection assignments, learning from and with indigenous knowledge sources, cross-cultural service and immersion activities, post-trip reorientation, and culminating projects for positive social change. Students will be guided in their academic areas of interest by faculty, staff and Rwandan partners, and are expected to be active participants in their own learning. This course is designed to enable students to get the most out of their international experience by developing their knowledge, skills and values and their application in an intercultural context.

MGMT 466.course_description: This course is an experiential capstone combining faculty and student teams from the College of Business and Economics and College of the Environment. Student groups prepare a Green Business Assessment for a community or campus organization and compile, distribute, and present a final report to the campus and the client organizations. Also offered as ENVS 466.

MGMT 474.course_description: Varying topics in management. Courses cover current issues and trends in the management field. Repeatable with different topics up to 8 credits, including original course.

MGMT 481.course_description: Examines dynamics of diversity, equity, and inclusion and implications for leaders, employees, organizations, and the society. Considers issues of race, ethnicity, gender, sexual orientation, and other categories in organizations using social science and other perspectives. Explores the nature, role and treatment of differences and the creation of inclusion in the workplace.

MGMT 483.course_description: An investigation of ethical theories and their application to issues faced by managers. An analysis of the morality of capitalism as a social system, and the ethical issues involved in international business operations.

MGMT 490.course_description: This hands-on, project-based course allows students to apply classroom skills and theories in work settings. Students gain practical experience while working for nonprofit, for-profit, and public agencies. Repeatable to a maximum of 12 credits, including original course. Variable credit available.

MGMT 491.course_description: Planning, marketing, financial, legal, control and human elements associated with the startup, acquisition and operation of a small business from the entrepreneurial point of view.

MGMT 492.course_description: Field consulting work and study under faculty supervision with small business entrepreneurs in the local business community, directed towards solving varied real-life small business problems.

MGMT 495.course_description: Case study of policy making and administration from a general management point of view.  Emphasis on problem analysis, the decision-making process, administration and control, and development of policies and objectives.
