MATH 381.course_description: Investigations of mathematics topics that focus on logical reasoning, number concepts, and number operations. Emphasis on problem solving, the use of manipulatives and computing technologies, remediation and resource materials, and optimal pedagogical techniques that help students learn quality mathematics.

MATH 382.course_description: Investigations of mathematics topics that focus on proportional thinking, rational numbers, and probability. Emphasis on problem solving, the use of manipulatives and computing technologies, remediation and resource materials, and optimal pedagogical techniques that help students learn quality mathematics.

MATH 383.course_description: Investigations of mathematics topics that focus on geometry, algebraic reasoning, measurement and statistics. Emphasis on problem solving, the use of manipulatives and computing technologies, remediation, assessment and resource materials, and optimal pedagogical techniques that help students learn quality mathematics. Not acceptable for any departmental major except BA/Ed, Elementary.

MATH 400.course_description: An individualized course of study not available through or replacing existing curriculum, to be arranged between one matriculating student and sponsoring faculty member. All academic policies and registration deadlines apply. Directed Independent Study courses cannot substitute for General University Requirements and are not eligible for tuition waiver.

MATH 401.course_description: Introduction to groups, Lagrange’s Theorem, isomorphisms and homomorphisms, normal subgroups and factor groups, the fundamental theorem of finite abelian groups.

MATH 402.course_description: Introduction to rings and fields, ideals, polynomial rings, unique factorization domains, field extensions, finite fields.

MATH 405.course_description: An overview of algorithms and techniques inspired by geometry and used to solve systems of polynomial equations. Topics include affine varieties, polynomials, the division algorithm, Groebner bases, elimination theory, Hilbert’s Nullstellensatz, the ideal-variety correspondence and basic projective geometry.

MATH 409.course_description: Preparation for participation in the annual Putnam Exam. This exam involves mathematical concepts beyond those typically found in standard courses. Questions cut across the bounds of disciplines and are hard. This course covers the basics of the relevant mathematical content, particularly in discrete mathematics, and emphasizes advanced problem-solving techniques. S/U grading.

MATH 410.course_description: The construction and solution of mathematical models, using optimization, stability analysis, eigenvalue methods, probability and simulation.

MATH 412.course_description: Preparation for participation in the national mathematics modeling competition. Repeatable with no maximum.

MATH 415.course_description: An introduction to mathematical models in biology. Population models, Michaelis-Menten kinetics, models for neuron functioning, pattern formation. Mathematical topics: difference equations, dynamical systems, conservation equations, stochastic models.

MATH 419.course_description: History and development of mathematical thought from ancient to modern times. Philosophical, sociological and biographical perspectives.

MATH 420.course_name: Topics in the History and Philosophy of Mathematics
MATH 420.course_description: Concentrated study of a topic or a closely connected group of topics associated with the history and philosophy of mathematics. Students are required to write a substantial expository paper.

MATH 421.course_description: Introduction to metric spaces, properties of functions on metric spaces, compactness and continuity. The student is expected to develop competence in proving basic theorems involving these concepts.

MATH 422.course_description: Analysis on the real line, including uniform convergence of series, using metric space notions. The student is expected to develop competence in proving theorems involving these concepts.

MATH 424.course_description: Topics such as pointwise convergence of Fourier series, Gibbs phenomenon, Poisson summability, Dirichlet problem for the disc, Weierstrass approximation theorem. Repeatable to a maximum of 8 credits with various topics.

MATH 430.course_name: Fourier Series and Applications to Partial Differential Equations
MATH 430.course_description: An introduction to Fourier series and the Fourier transform; applications to boundary value problems including the wave and heat equations.

MATH 431.course_description: Solutions for general first order and linear second order partial differential equations.  Topics from  characteristics; propagation of singularities; hyperbolic, and elliptic equations;  Cauchy problem; Dirichlet problem; Green’s function; Poisson formula; maximum principle.

MATH 432.course_description: Forced second order equations, systems of nonlinear differential equations, applications.

MATH 438.course_description: Differentiation and integration of complex-valued functions; Cauchy integral theorem; calculations of residues.

MATH 441.course_description: Discrete and continuous random variables, moment generating functions, multivariate distributions, survey of widely used distributions such as normal, chi-square, gamma, t and F distributions. Emphasis on the theoretical aspects of probability.

MATH 442.course_description: Limiting distributions, the Central Limit Theorem, statistical inferences such as confidence intervals, hypothesis testing and chi-square tests, maximum likelihood methods, sufficiency.

MATH 443.course_description: Matrix algebra for linear models, multivariate normal distribution, quadratic forms, Gauss-Markov Theorem, estimation in full-rank and less-than-full-rank models, hypothesis testing in full-rank models.

MATH 444.course_description: Statistical models and methods for categorical responses. Topics include chi-square and likelihood-ratio tests for the analysis of contingency tables, as well as a treatment of generalized linear models including logistic, cumulative logit, and Poisson regression. Extensive use of a computer statistical package.

MATH 445.course_description: Generation of random variables, Monte Carlo simulation and variance reduction techniques, resampling methods including bootstrap, jackknife, and permutation, Markov chain Monte Carlo. Extensive use of a computer statistical package.

MATH 446.course_description: Statistical models in nonparametric settings; nonparametric point and interval estimation; centrality inference for single samples; nonparametric methods for one-sample, paired-sample, two-sample, and k-sample cases; statistical inferences based on ranks, runs tests, and median test; correlation; regression models; comparisons between independent and paired samples.

MATH 447.course_description: Basics of statistical learning, cross-validation, penalized least squares, principal component analysis, classification algorithms, decision trees, and clustering algorithms. Extensive use of a computer statistical package.

MATH 451.course_description: An overview of elementary number theory beyond MATH 302, including such topics as multiplicative functions, quadratic residues and reciprocity, primitive roots, nonlinear Diophantine equations, continued fractions, and cryptology.

MATH 456.course_description: Exploratory analysis of trend and seasonality, stationary and non-stationary processes including ARIMA, model estimation, selection, diagnostics, and forecasting.

MATH 457.course_description: Introduction to Bayesian inference; prior and posterior distributions; conjugate priors; statistical inference, including summarizing posterior information and making predictions; hierachical and linear regression models. Monte Carlo methods including Gibbs sampling.

MATH 458.course_description: Selected topics in the area of stochastic processes including Random Walks, Markov Chains, Poisson Processes and Brownian Motion.

MATH 463.course_description: An overview of methods in geometric topology focused on understanding knots and surfaces. Topics include basic graph theory, including the classification of Platonic solids; simplicial and polygonal descriptions of knots and surfaces; classification of surfaces; and diagrammatic, combinatorial, and geometric techniques in knot theory.

MATH 465.course_description: Selections and arrangements, inclusion-exclusion, partitions, binomial identities, ordinary and exponential generating functions, bijective proofs of combinatorial identities.

MATH 473.course_description: Norms; fundamental matrix types, transformations and factorizations; linear equations, linear least squares; rounding error, condition and stability; the algebraic eigenvalue problem (QR method).

MATH 483.course_description: Topics include pre-algebra, algebra, geometry, problem solving and resource materials.

MATH 490.course_description: Intensive study of an advanced topic in mathematics.

MATH 491.course_description: Focus on issues and practices related to teaching K-8 mathematics, coordinated with the year-long K-8 classroom internship. Includes the use of ideas, theory, and lesson plans from the Mathematics 381-383 sequence in actual classroom settings, plus opportunity to assess and work with K-8 students on an individual, small group, and whole class basis. Not acceptable for any departmental major except BA/Ed, Elementary.  S/U grading.

MATH 500.course_description: An individualized course of study not available through or replacing existing curriculum, to be arranged between one matriculating student and sponsoring faculty member. All academic policies and registration deadlines apply.

MATH 502.course_description: Introduction to rings and fields, ideals, polynomial rings, unique factorization domains, field extensions, finite fields.

MATH 503.course_description: Topics such as Galois theory, number theory, group representation theory, algebraic geometry, Lie algebras. Repeatable with various topics.

MATH 504.course_description: Abstract vector spaces, linear transformations, spectral theory.

MATH 505.course_description: An overview of algorithms and techniques inspired by geometry and used to solve systems of polynomial equations.  Topics include affine varieties, polynomials, the division algorithm, Groebner bases, elimination theory, Hilbert’s Nullstellensatz, the ideal-variety correspondence and basic projective geometry.

MATH 510.course_description: The construction and solution of mathematical models, using optimization, stability analysis, eigenvalue methods, probability and simulation.

MATH 511.course_description: Exact and numerical techniques for the development and analysis of models of dynamic processes, including the construction and validation of models.

MATH 515.course_description: An introduction to mathematical models in biology. Population models, Michaelis-Menten kinetics, models for neuron functioning, pattern formation. Mathematical topics: difference equations, dynamical systems, conservation equations, stochastic models.

MATH 521.course_description: Introduction to metric spaces, properties of functions on metric spaces, compactness and continuity.

MATH 522.course_description: Analysis on the real line, including uniform convergence of series, using metric space notions.

MATH 523.course_description: Parameterization, integration and changes of variables in Euclidean spaces.

MATH 524.course_description: Topics such as pointwise convergence of Fourier series, Gibbs phenomenon, Poisson summability, Dirichlet problem for the disc, Weierstrass approximation theorem. Repeatable to a maximum of 8 credits with various topics.

MATH 525.course_description: Topological spaces, connectedness, compactness, product and quotient spaces, homotopy.

MATH 527.course_description: Theory of Lebesgue measure and integration.

MATH 528.course_description: Spaces of functions, linear functionals and their representation, applications.

MATH 530.course_name: Fourier Series and Applications to Partial Differential Equations
MATH 530.course_description: An introduction to Fourier series and the Fourier transform; applications to boundary value problems including the wave and heat equations.

MATH 531.course_description: Solutions for general first order and linear second order partial differential equations emphasizing geometric properties and integral representations.  Topics include characteristics; propagation of singularities; hyperbolic, elliptic, and parabolic equations; Cauchy problem; Dirichlet problem; Green’s function; Poisson formula; maximum principle.

MATH 533.course_description: Existence and uniqueness of solutions, stability theory for nonlinear equations, bifurcation.

MATH 535.course_description: Nonlinear programming with emphasis on basic theory (including Lagrange multipliers and the Kuhn-Tucker conditions), algorithms for numerical solution of problems, and applications. Introductory dynamic programming, with emphasis on applications and algorithms.

MATH 538.course_description: Differentiation and integration of complex-valued functions, Cauchy integral theorem, residues.

MATH 539.course_description: Topics such as normal families, mapping properties of analytic functions, conformal mappings, fluid flow, Dirichlet and Neumann problems, Julia sets. Repeatable with various topics.

MATH 540.course_description: Topics from Markov and sequential decision processes, renewal theory, inventory theory, stochastic control, random arrival and service processes, waiting time, number in queue, bulk arrivals, networks, balking. Repeatable with different topics up to 12 credits, including original course.

MATH 541.course_description: Discrete and continuous random variables, moment generating functions, multivariate distributions, survey of widely used distributions such as normal, chi-square, gamma, t and F distributions. Emphasis on the theoretical aspects of probability.

MATH 542.course_description: Limiting distributions, the Central Limit Theorem, statistical inferences such as confidence intervals, hypothesis testing and chi-square tests, maximum likelihood methods, sufficiency.

MATH 543.course_description: Matrix algebra for linear models, multivariate normal distribution, quadratic forms, Gauss-Markov Theorem, estimation in full-rank and less-than-full-rank models, hypothesis testing in full-rank models.

MATH 551.course_description: An overview of topics in elementary number theory, including multiplicative functions, quadratic residues and reciprocity, nonlinear Diophantine equations, continued fractions, primality testing and cryptology.

MATH 556.course_description: Exploratory analysis of trend and seasonality, stationary and non-stationary processes including ARIMA, model estimation, selection, diagnostics, and forecasting.

MATH 557.course_description: Introduction to Bayesian inference; prior and posterior distributions; conjugate priors; statistical inference, including summarizing posterior information and making predictions; hierachical and linear regression models. Monte Carlo methods including Gibbs sampling.

MATH 558.course_description: Selected topics in the area of stochastic processes including Random Walks, Markov Chains, Poisson Processes and Brownian Motion.

MATH 560.course_description: A study of one or more topics in geometry such as convex sets, polytopes, tilings, integral geometry or combinatorial geometry. Repeatable with various topics.

MATH 562.course_description: Geometry of curves, surfaces and manifolds.

MATH 563.course_description: An overview of methods in geometric topology focused on understanding knots and surfaces. Topics include basic graph theory, including the classification of Platonic solids; simplicial and polygonal descriptions of knots and surfaces; classification of surfaces; and diagrammatic, combinatorial, and geometric techniques in knot theory.

MATH 564.course_description: Basic properties of graphs, trees, Eulerian and Hamiltonian circuits, genera of graphs, algorithms, applications.

MATH 566.course_description: Counting techniques, generating functions, coding, coloring and relations with probability theory. Repeatable with various topics.

MATH 570.course_description: Topics taken from nonlinear programming, calculus of variations or the theory of optimal control. Repeatable with various topics.

MATH 573.course_description: Norms; fundamental matrix types, transformations and factorizations; linear equations, linear least squares; rounding error, condition and stability; the algebraic eigenvalue problem (QR method).

MATH 575.course_description: Polynomial interpolation including splines, orthogonal systems of functions and least squares approximation; numerical differentiation and integration; solution of systems of nonlinear equations and unconstrained optimization.

MATH 577.course_description: Topics from numerical optimization, approximation, linear algebra, quadrature, and the solution of algebraic and differential equations. Repeatable with various topics.

MATH 582.course_description: Teaching content presentation and problem solving skills in the context of core college math classes at the level of calculus and above.

MATH 595.course_description: Curriculum and instructional support for teaching the algebra and precalculus sequence. S/U grading.

MATH 599.course_description: Repeatable to a maximum of 4 cr.

MATH 680.course_description: An internship in industry, government, or other organizations during which participants will work with people in the host organization on problems of a quantitative nature.  Number of credits depends on time spent at the host organization. S/U grading.

MATH 690.course_description: Repeatable to a maximum of 4 cr. S/U grading.

MATH 691.course_description: Repeatable to a maximum of 2 cr. S/U grading.

M/CS 300.course_description: An individualized course of study not available through or replacing existing curriculum, to be arranged between one matriculating student and sponsoring faculty member. All academic policies and registration deadlines apply. Directed Independent Study courses cannot substitute for General University Requirements and are not eligible for tuition waiver.

M/CS 335.course_description: The optimization of linear functions subject to linear constraints. Linear programming, duality theory, sensitivity analysis, applications.

M/CS 375.course_description: Computer arithmetic, solution of nonlinear equations and optimization in a single variable; matrix factorization; matrix iterative techniques.

M/CS 400.course_description: An individualized course of study not available through or replacing existing curriculum, to be arranged between one matriculating student and sponsoring faculty member. All academic policies and registration deadlines apply. Directed Independent Study courses cannot substitute for General University Requirements and are not eligible for tuition waiver.

M/CS 435.course_description: Nonlinear optimization with emphasis on basic theory (including Lagrange multipliers and the Kuhn-Tucker conditions), algorithms for numerical solution of problems, and applications. Introductory dynamic programming, with emphasis on applications and algorithms.

M/CS 475.course_description: Polynomial interpolation including splines, orthogonal systems of functions and least squares approximation; numerical differentiation and integration; solution of systems of nonlinear equations and unconstrained optimization.

M/CS 478.course_description: Construction and analysis of classical cryptosystems, Diffie-Hellman key exchange, ElGamal cryptosystem, RSA, cryptographic attacks, introduction to information and complexity theory, introduction to lattices and applications to cryptography, digital signature schemes related to RSA and ElGamal, modern symmetric key cryptography including AES.

LANG 300.course_description: An individualized course of study not available through or replacing existing curriculum, to be arranged between one matriculating student and sponsoring faculty member. All academic policies and registration deadlines apply. Directed Independent Study courses cannot substitute for General University Requirements and are not eligible for tuition waiver.

LANG 400.course_description: An individualized course of study not available through or replacing existing curriculum, to be arranged between one matriculating student and sponsoring faculty member. All academic policies and registration deadlines apply. Directed Independent Study courses cannot substitute for General University Requirements and are not eligible for tuition waiver.

LANG 410.course_name: World Language Instruction: Theory and Method I
LANG 410.course_description: To be taken prior to field experience. Theory of world language instruction. Topics include contrastive analysis of English with target language; comparative first and second language acquisition; cognitive, attitudinal and political dimensions.

LANG 420.course_name: World Language Instruction: Theory and Method II
LANG 420.course_description: To be taken prior to field experience. Methods of world language instruction. Demonstration of and practice with techniques appropriate to a variety of levels.  Use, analysis and critique of technology, grammar and translation, audiolingual techniques, and direct methods. Professional development is discussed and analyzed.

LANG 500.course_description: An individualized course of study not available through or replacing existing curriculum, to be arranged between one matriculating student and sponsoring faculty member. All academic policies and registration deadlines apply.

MDS 300.course_description: An individualized course of study not available through or replacing existing curriculum, to be arranged between one matriculating student and sponsoring faculty member. All academic policies and registration deadlines apply. Directed Independent Study courses cannot substitute for General University Requirements and are not eligible for tuition waiver.

MDS 310.course_name: Work and Leisure through the Ages
MDS 310.course_description: From a multidisciplinary studies approach using a variety of media (e.g., literature, video, speakers, discussion, and projects), an historical exploration of work and leisure and their relevance for individuals and society today. Students will understand the historical background of work and leisure in relation to present conditions and future possibilities.

MDS 400.course_description: An individualized course of study not available through or replacing existing curriculum, to be arranged between one matriculating student and sponsoring faculty member. All academic policies and registration deadlines apply. Directed Independent Study courses cannot substitute for General University Requirements and are not eligible for tuition waiver.

MDS 410.course_name: The Capstone Experience: Past, Present, and Future
MDS 410.course_description: The purpose of this course is for students to reflect on, examine, and evaluate their Multidisciplinary Studies major in terms of their futures. Using a variety of media and methods (readings, videos, speakers), students will use a narrative approach to explore their pasts, assess themselves in the present, and imagine their futures. Assignments include homework, in-class activities and writing sessions, a written self-narrative, and a presentation.  Online version will include real-time Zoom class sessions every other week. Self-Paced version will include one-on-one consultations with instructor but otherwise will be asynchronous.

MDS 471.course_description: Supervised professional experience emphasizing functional proficiency under joint sponsorship of University and agency personnel. All students participate at the work site for at least 12 hours per week in the type of activities specified in the internship contract. S/U grading. Repeatable up to 10 credits including original course.

MLE 300.course_description: An individualized course of study not available through or replacing existing curriculum, to be arranged between one matriculating student and sponsoring faculty member. All academic policies and registration deadlines apply. Directed Independent Study courses cannot substitute for General University Requirements and are not eligible for tuition waiver.

MLE 400.course_description: An individualized course of study not available through or replacing existing curriculum, to be arranged between one matriculating student and sponsoring faculty member. All academic policies and registration deadlines apply. Directed Independent Study courses cannot substitute for General University Requirements and are not eligible for tuition waiver.

MLE 431.course_description: The first in a sequence of courses designed to prepare individuals to work with culturally and linguistically diverse (CLD) students in the US P-12 school context, this course introduces students to foundational concepts in second language acquisition, linguistics, and the historical, legal, theoretical and policy contexts of CLD students. We will explore theory and research on second language acquisition and learning drawn from sociocultural and cognitive traditions that inform current practice. The course also includes an outline of basic linguistic aspects of language (phonology, morphology, syntax, semantics, and pragmatics) and their historical, geographical, and social variation. Students will consider how language and policy intersect, including an examination of the language development standards across domains of reading, writing, listening and speaking.

MLE 432.course_name: Academic Language and Grammar for P-12 Teachers
MLE 432.course_description: Students are introduced to academic language overall and grammar specifically, including the structure, history and use of English with an emphasis on their application to the teaching of P-12 level language learners within the P-12 school system. The theory of English grammar, including parts of speech, syntactic structure, coordination, subordination, and discourse patterns will be covered. Systemic functional linguistics is also introduced.

MLE 433.course_name: Culture, Equity, and Advocacy for Bilingual Students
MLE 433.course_description: This course provides a foundation for teachers to understand and address the relevant cultural and equity issues that linguistically diverse students face in US public schools. This includes being able to identify bias across assessment, curriculum, and pedagogy.  There is also an emphasis on culturally and linguistically sustaining approaches to programming for students identified as language learners.  A service learning experience allows teacher candidates to connect theory to context.

MLE 434.course_description: This class is an expansion on theoretical and practical concerns in teaching English as an additional language/bilingual education to students in grades P-8 of all proficiency levels. Emphasis is on innovative approaches to the teaching of language and literacy within a communicative framework and academic register. This class provides guidance in the evaluation, development, and use of creative materials, including media-based materials. We will build on the techniques introduced in the Secondary Methods course but shift the emphasis to content and developmentally appropriate for younger students specifically vocabulary, form, function, and fluency of language across domains of reading, writing, listening and speaking. Requires participation in an embedded practicum experience with English language learners.

MLE 435.course_description: An introduction to the theoretical and practical concerns in teaching English as an additional language/bilingual education to students in grades 6-12 with different levels of proficiency in English. Emphasis is on innovative approaches to the teaching of language and literacy within a communicative framework and academic register. Provides guidance in the evaluation, development, and use of creative materials, including media-based materials. This course will offer teachers methods and strategies to refine students’ communication abilities across different content areas in the secondary school setting. The course will focus primarily on academic language; specifically vocabulary, form, function, and fluency of language across domains of reading, writing, listening and speaking. Requires participation in guided interactions with language learners.

MLE 436.course_name: Seminar and Practicum for ELL or Bilingual P-12 Teachers
MLE 436.course_description: MLE 436 Provides a forum for reflection and sharing of the teaching of ELLs in P-12 schools. Includes research-based lesson planning and advocacy, linking to WA state and Federal laws. Provides practice working collaboratively with colleagues and the community. Repeatable to a maximum of 6 credits, including original course. S/U grading.

MLE 438.course_name: Methods and Programming for P-12 Bilingual Classrooms
MLE 438.course_description: In this course, candidates will extend their knowledge of language development, assessment & instructional practices, with an emphasis on bilingual education settings. Students will focus on methods for instruction that support Multilingual Learners (MLLs) in Dual Language settings and other bilingual settings. We will build on techniques already introduced in previous classes on literacy and deepen learning around effective approaches to bilingualism & biliteracy across domains of reading, writing, listening & speaking.

MLE 441.course_name: Language, Culture, and Equity: From Global to Local
MLE 441.course_description: This is the first in a sequence of courses designed to prepare individuals to work with emergent bi/multilingual students in the USA’s P-12 school context. Educational equity and cultural and linguistic sustainability are core commitments that run throughout this course and across the program. This course introduces students to foundational concepts in language acquisition for multilingual students, and the historical, legal, theoretical and policy contexts of culturally and linguistically diverse (CLD) students. Students will examine their own cultural and linguistic identity and understand how beliefs and perspectives influence teaching. We will explore theory and research on bilingual and biliteracy acquisition and development drawn from critical, sociocultural, cognitive, and sociolinguistic traditions that inform current practice. Students will consider how language and policy intersect, including an introduction to the WIDA language development standards across domains of reading, writing, listening, and speaking.

MLE 442.course_name: Language, Culture, and Equity in the Classroom
MLE 442.course_description: The second in a sequence of courses designed to prepare individuals to work with emergent bi/multilingual students in the USA’s P-12 school context. Educational equity and cultural and linguistic sustainability are core commitments that run throughout this course and across the program. This course expands on foundational concepts introduced in MLE 441: Language, Culture, and Equity: Global to Local and contextualizes the lives of multilingual students in their families, schools, and communities–both broad and local. We will consider the intersection of language, culture, and identity in learning and explore implications for teaching. We will also examine the translation of national and state-level policies into the classroom context (including various program models), looking at implications for schools, teachers, students, and families and identifying routes for advocacy. Students will gain practice in identifying linguistically and culturally appropriate classroom materials that build on student and community assets, as well as design principles grounded in contemporary understandings of second language acquisition. In this class we will also begin exploring bias in assessment, curriculum, and pedagogy. A 10-hour minimum required service learning experience will support these goals by providing opportunities to bring theory and practice into conversation

MLE 443.course_name: Methods for Teaching Entering and Emerging Multilingual Learners
MLE 443.course_description: An introduction to the theoretical and practical concerns in teaching English as an additional language/bilingual education to students at entering & emerging levels of language proficiency across P-12. The course is framed by a culturally and linguistically sustaining pedagogical approach, including strategic uses of translanguaging. The focus is on building oral language as a bridge to early literacy (to include phonemic and phonological awareness, morphological knowledge), with emphasis on applying theories of second language acquisition to task design. The course provides guided practice in material selection and development, with a specific focus on students new to the US school system. Students will engage in task, lesson, and unit design that integrates interpretive and expressive modes of language. Students will also examine a variety of formative and summative assessment strategies, as well as be introduced to language proficiency assessments. Students will examine the intersection of special education/highly capable programs and ELL/Bilingual programs for dual identified multilingual students. This course requires participation in guided interactions with English language learners.

MLE 444.course_description: In this course, students will explore a functional approach to language, examine second language acquisition theories to teaching, study the state language development standards, and begin to bring language, SLA, and standards together to create meaningful educational experiences for their students in P-12 in a culturally and linguistically sustaining classroom.  As we learn about different ways we use language to make meaning, we will also discuss how we can assess students in their language development.

MLE 445.course_name: Methods for Teaching Developing, Expanding, and Bridging Multilingual Learners
MLE 445.course_description: An introduction to the theoretical and practical concerns in teaching English as an additional language/bilingual education to students at developing, expanding, & bridging levels of language proficiency across P-12 grades. The course is framed by a culturally and linguistically sustaining pedagogical approach, including strategic uses of translanguaging. It builds on the functional approach to language established in MLE444 by providing guided practice in material selection and development, with a specific focus on building students’ disciplinary literacy. Students engage in task and lesson design that integrates interpretive and expressive modes of language. We also examine a variety of formative assessment strategies. This course requires participation in an embedded practicum with language learners.

MLE 500.course_description: An individualized course of study not available through or replacing existing curriculum, to be arranged between one matriculating student and sponsoring faculty member. All academic policies and registration deadlines apply. Directed Independent Study courses cannot substitute for General University Requirements and are not eligible for tuition waiver.

MLE 531.course_name: Second Language Acquisition, Linguistics, and Policy
MLE 531.course_description: The first in a sequence of courses designed to prepare individuals to work with culturally and linguistically diverse (CLD) students in the US P-12 school context, this course introduces students to foundational concepts in second language acquisition, linguistics, and the historical, legal, theoretical and policy contexts of CLD students. We will explore theory and research on second language acquisition and learning drawn from sociocultural and cognitive traditions that inform current practice. The course also includes an outline of basic linguistic aspects of language (phonology, morphology, syntax, semantics, and pragmatics) and their historical, geographical, and social variation. Students will consider how language and policy intersect, including an examination of the language development standards across domains of reading, writing, listening and speaking. Individual research and course presentation are expected of graduate students.

MLE 532.course_name: Academic Language and Grammar to Support P-12 ELs
MLE 532.course_description: Experienced teachers reinforce their understanding of the structure, history and use of English with emphasis on their application to the teaching of P-12 language learners within the P-12 school system. Includes the theory of English grammar, including parts of speech, syntactic structure, coordination, subordination, and discourse patterns. Academic language and Systemic Functional Linguistics are emphasized. Individual research and course presentation are expected of graduate students.

MLE 533.course_name: Culture, Equity, and Advocacy for Bilingual Students in P-12
MLE 533.course_description: This course provides a foundation for teachers to understand and address the relevant cultural and equity issues that linguistically diverse students face in US public schools. This includes being able to identify bias across assessment, curriculum, and pedagogy. There is also an emphasis on culturally and linguistically sustaining approaches to programming for students identified as language learners. A service learning experience allows teacher candidates to connect theory to context. Individual research and course presentation are expected of graduate students.

MLE 534.course_name: Elementary ELL and Bilingual Methods for P-12 Teachers
MLE 534.course_description: This class is an expansion on theoretical and practical concerns in teaching English as an additional language/bilingual education to students in grades P-8 of all proficiency levels. Emphasis is on innovative approaches to the teaching of language and literacy within a communicative framework and academic register. This class provides guidance in the evaluation, development, and use of creative materials, including media-based materials. We will build on the techniques introduced in the Secondary Methods course but shift the emphasis to content and developmentally appropriate for younger students specifically vocabulary, form, function, and fluency of language across domains of reading, writing, listening and speaking. Requires participation in a practicum experience with English language learners. Individual research and course presentation are expected of graduate students.

MLE 535.course_description: An introduction to the theoretical and practical concerns in teaching English as an additional language/bilingual education to students in grades 6-12 with different levels of proficiency in English. Emphasis is on innovative approaches to the teaching of language and literacy within a communicative framework and academic register. Provides guidance in the evaluation, development, and use of creative materials, including media-based materials. Requires participation in guided interactions with language learners. Individual research and course presentation are expected of graduate students.

MLE 536.course_name: Seminar and Practicum for ELL or Bilingual P-12 Teachers
MLE 536.course_description: Provides a forum for reflection and sharing of the teaching of ELL’s in P-12 schools. Includes research-based lesson planning and advocacy, linking to WA state and Federal laws. Provides practice working collaboratively with colleagues and the community. 4+ ELLs are required in the classroom where the practicum takes place or permission of the director. Individual research and course presentation are expected of graduate students. S/U grading.

MLE 538.course_name: Methods and Programming for P-12 Bilingual Classrooms
MLE 538.course_description: In this course, candidates will extend their knowledge of language development, assessment & instructional practices, with an emphasis on bilingual education settings. Students will focus on methods for instruction that support Multilingual Learners (MLLs) in Dual Language settings and other bilingual settings. We will build on techniques already introduced in previous classes on literacy and deepen learning around effective approaches to bilingualism & biliteracy across domains of reading, writing, listening & speaking.

This course requires participation in guided interactions with English language learners.

MLE 544.course_description: In this course, students will explore a functional approach to language, examine second language acquisition theories to teaching, study the state language development standards, and begin to bring language, SLA, and standards together to create meaningful educational experiences for their students in P-12 in a culturally and linguistically sustaining classroom. As we learn about different ways we use language to make meaning, we will also discuss how we can assess students in their language development.

MLE 545.course_name: Methods for Teaching Developing, Expanding, and Bridging Multilingual Learners
MLE 545.course_description: An introduction to the theoretical and practical concerns in teaching English as an additional language/bilingual education to students at developing, expanding, & bridging levels of language proficiency across P-12 grades. The course is framed by a culturally and linguistically sustaining pedagogical approach, including strategic uses of translanguaging.  It builds on the functional approach to language established in MLE 544 by providing guided practice in material selection and development, with a specific focus on building students’ disciplinary literacy. Students engage in task and lesson design that integrates interpretive and expressive modes of language. We also examine a variety of formative assessment strategies. This course requires participation in an embedded practicum with language learners.

MLE 546.course_name: Methods in Multilingual Disciplinary and Critical Literacies
MLE 546.course_description: This course focuses on principles and methods for building students’ disciplinary and critical literacies, with special attention given to work with students at developing, expanding, & bridging levels of language proficiency across P-12 grades. The course is framed by a culturally and linguistically sustaining pedagogical approach, holding central the notion that literacy instruction involves a dynamic interaction of readers, texts, and contexts. It builds on the functional approach to language established in MLE 444 by providing guided practice in material selection and development, the integration of language, literacy, culture, and content learning, to include strategic uses of translanguaging. Students engage in task and lesson design that integrates interpretive and expressive modes of language. This course requires participation in an embedded practicum with language learners.

MUS 100.course_description: A combined theory, composition, and music literature class keyed to the works students will perform during the Marrowstone Music Festival. Students will gain insight into these works and have the opportunity to develop their own compositional skills. S/U grading.

MUS 101.course_description: The study of musical construction for those unfamiliar with the fundamentals of notation (pitch and rhythm), major and minor scales, intervals, triads and keys, with particular attention to their practical application.

MUS 102.course_name: Introduction to Music Theory and Ear Training
MUS 102.course_description: Courses designed to strengthen the prospective music major’s knowledge of fundamental theoretical principles and to introduce the basic aural/reading skills needed to begin the musicianship sequence.

MUS 103.course_name: Introduction to Music Theory and Ear Training
MUS 103.course_description: Courses designed to strengthen the prospective music major’s knowledge of fundamental theoretical principles and to introduce the basic aural/reading skills needed to begin the musicianship sequence.

MUS 104.course_name: The Art of Listening to Music
MUS 104.course_description: Open to all students. Non-technical basis for enjoyable listening to music; performance practices relating to symphony orchestras, instrumental ensembles, opera, choral groups and solo performance.

MUS 105.course_name: Survey of Popular and Rock Music
MUS 105.course_description: Open to all students. An introduction to the genres, forms and composers of popular music within the framework of a study of its historical and cultural context.

MUS 106.course_description: Study of the major works of Hip-Hop, including the history, culture, and influence of the art form from its onset in the 70’s to its place in the popular music of the 21st century.

MUS 107.course_description: Explore the country music genre, including major performers, songwriters, songs and impact on culture from the early times on the radio to the twenty-first century.

MUS 108.course_description: A critical overview of the history, development, and current state of music & audio in video games & interactive media and surrounding issues.

MUS 109.course_description: Case studies of iconic film scores, and their impact on the overall cinematic experience. This course explores a select variety of soundtracks throughout the history of films, including Planet of the Apes, Psycho, Star Wars, Lord of the Rings, and others. Foreign films that use folk influenced scores will also be explored.

MUS 110.course_description: An introduction to analog and digital audio recording/editing, MIDI, analog and digital synthesis, and the history of electronic music.

MUS 111.course_description: Music majors entering with piano as their major instrument of study are expected to be proficient sight readers and to accompany instrumentalists and vocalists as part of their training. Pianists must be able to pass a sight-reading proficiency exam; if they cannot, this course provides the necessary tools to gain this critical strength. A student will repeat this class until the sight-reading exam is passed. Repeatable to a maximum of 6 credits, including original course.

MUS 116.course_description: This course serves as an introduction to the guitar. Techniques include both basics of plectrum and finger-style technique. Also covered are chords, strumming and finger-style applications for arpeggio playing, leading to basic accompaniment. S/U grading.

MUS 121A.course_description: The development of aural and visual competence in music, including the Western diatonic major and minor system. Singing with solfege, dictation, error detection, accuracy of rhythm and intonation. Although the emphasis is Western art music, relevant examples from other musical styles and traditions will be drawn upon as well.

MUS 121B.course_description: The development of competence in and familiarity with the piano keyboard, reading and playing in the diatonic major and minor systems. Exercises and drill in scales, harmonization, accompaniment, prepared and sight reading.

MUS 122.course_description: Study and practice of basic materials of musical construction including notation, melody, harmony, rhythm, and form. Although the emphasis is Western art music, relevant examples from other musical styles and traditions will be drawn upon as well.

MUS 123A.course_description: The development of aural and visual competence in music, including the Western diatonic major and minor system. Singing with solfege, dictation, error detection, accuracy of rhythm and intonation. Although the emphasis is Western art music, relevant examples from other musical styles and traditions will be drawn upon as well.

MUS 123B.course_description: The development of competence in and familiarity with the piano keyboard, reading and playing in the diatonic major and minor systems. Exercises and drill in scales, harmonization, accompaniment, prepared and sight reading.

MUS 124.course_description: Study and practice of basic materials of musical construction including notation, melody, harmony, rhythm, and form. Although the emphasis is Western art music, relevant examples from other musical styles and traditions will be drawn upon as well.

MUS 125A.course_description: The development of aural and visual competence in music, including the Western diatonic major and minor system. Singing with solfege, dictation, error detection, accuracy of rhythm and intonation. Although the emphasis is Western art music, relevant examples from other musical styles and traditions will be drawn upon as well.

MUS 125B.course_description: The development of competence in and familiarity with the piano keyboard, reading and playing in the diatonic major and minor systems. Exercises and drill in scales, harmonization, accompaniment, prepared and sight reading.

MUS 126.course_description: Study and practice of basic materials of musical construction including notation, melody, harmony, rhythm, and form. Although the emphasis is Western art music, relevant examples from other musical styles and traditions will be drawn upon as well.

MUS 160.course_description: Designed for students with no keyboard experience. Basic reading skills and technique.

MUS 163.course_description: Study of basic vocal production skills and repertoire preparation.

MUS 166A.course_description: This course will prepare the student for success in solo and choral voice performance at the university level.  The student will be exposed to linguistic and musical resources for the preparation and performance of vocal music in various languages.  Efficient practice and research techniques are also integral to the course.

MUS 166B.course_description: A continuation of MUS 166A with added emphasis on skills necessary for success as a vocal soloist.  The student will be exposed to more in-depth linguistic and musical resources such as:  recital preparation, performance anxiety, and a general survey of the solo vocal repertoire.

MUS 168.course_name: Exploring the World of Teaching Music
MUS 168.course_description: Overview of strategies for effective teaching, rehearsal techniques and strategies, motivational tools, appropriate body language, assertive classroom management. S/U grading.

MUS 173.course_description: Study, rehearsal and performance of orchestra literature appropriate to students participating in the Marrowstone Music Festival. S/U grading.

MUS 181.course_description: Study, rehearsal and performance of chamber music appropriate to students participating in the Marrowstone Music Festival. S/U grading.

MUS 202.course_description: Open to all students. Personalities, styles and social/cultural influences in Jazz from its beginning to the present day with focus on Art as Impetus for Social Change, Jazz and Race, and the Importance of Black American Music.

MUS 205.course_description: Open to all students. A general introduction to the musical styles of major world cultures, including those of Africa, India, Asia, Indonesia and Eastern Europe. Focus on the role played by music in each society.

MUS 211.course_description: Repeatable to a maximum of 66 credits, including original course.

MUS 212.course_description: Repeatable to a maximum of 66 credits, including original course.

MUS 221A.course_description: The development of aural and visual competence in the Western chromatic major and minor system; diatonic modes and other scales; introduction to extended tertian and non-tertian harmony. Singing with solfege, dictation, error detection, accuracy of rhythm, and intonation. Although the emphasis is Western art music, relevant examples from other musical styles and traditions will be drawn upon as well.

MUS 221B.course_description: The development of competence in and familiarity with the piano keyboard, reading and playing in the chromatic major and minor system; introduction to extended tertian harmony. Exercises and drill in scales, harmonization, accompaniment, prepared and sight reading.

MUS 221C.course_description: This course builds on the student’s solo piano skills by learning accompanying, harmonization, service playing, score reading, and lead sheet playing. There will be an organ and accompanying lab each week.

MUS 222.course_description: Advanced study of and practical experience in using the materials of musical construction including extended, chromatic, and non-tertian harmonic structures and complex musical forms. Although the emphasis is Western art music, relevant examples from other musical styles and traditions will be drawn upon as well.

MUS 223A.course_description: The development of aural and visual competence in the Western chromatic major and minor system; diatonic modes and other scales; introduction to extended tertian and non-tertian harmony. Singing with solfege, dictation, error detection, accuracy of rhythm, and intonation. Although the emphasis is Western art music, relevant examples from other musical styles and traditions will be drawn upon as well.

MUS 223B.course_description: The development of competence in and familiarity with the piano keyboard, reading and playing in the chromatic major and minor system; introduction to extended tertian harmony. Exercises and drill in scales, harmonization, accompaniment, prepared and sight reading.

MUS 223C.course_description: This course is designed to build on the student’s solo piano skills by learning accompanying, harmonization, score reading, lead sheet playing, jazz chord progressions, and expanded skills in reading clefs beyond treble and bass. There will be weekly labs on playing the pipe organ and accompanying performance.

MUS 224.course_description: Advanced study of and practical experience in using the materials of musical construction including extended, chromatic, and non-tertian harmonic structures and complex musical forms. Although the emphasis is Western art music, relevant examples from other musical styles and traditions will be drawn upon as well.

MUS 225A.course_description: The development of aural and visual competence in the Western chromatic major and minor system; diatonic modes and other scales; introduction to extended tertian and non-tertian harmony. Singing with solfege, dictation, error detection, accuracy of rhythm, and intonation. Although the emphasis is Western art music, relevant examples from other musical styles and traditions will be drawn upon as well.

MUS 225B.course_description: The development of competence in and familiarity with the piano keyboard, reading and playing in the chromatic major and minor system; introduction to extended tertian harmony. Exercises and drill in scales, harmonization, accompaniment, prepared and sight reading.

MUS 225C.course_description: This course is the final in the series of courses designed to build on the student’s solo piano skills by accompanying for specific instrumentation, harmonization including secondary dominants, score reading with choral and orchestral scores, and lead sheet playing. There will be weekly labs on playing the pipe organ and accompanying performance, as well as building experience on the harpsichord.

MUS 226.course_description: Advanced study of and practical experience in using the materials of musical construction including extended, chromatic, and non-tertian harmonic structures and complex musical forms. Although the emphasis is Western art music, relevant examples from other musical styles and traditions will be drawn upon as well.

MUS 230.course_description: Instruction in audio processing and synthesis with computer software; history of electroacoustic music.

MUS 231.course_description: Elementary craft of melody, counterpoint, harmony, instrumentation, texture, rhythm, and notation; participation in weekly composition seminars.  Repeatable for credit under advisement.

MUS 232.course_description: Instruction in musical programming with Max or CSound. Topics include sound synthesis, signal processing, and algorithmic composition.

MUS 260.course_description: Concentration on specific areas of the Keyboard Competency Exam based on individual needs. Repeatable for credit.

MUS 261.course_description: Intermediate piano repertoire, sight-reading skills, technique and accompanying. Repeatable to a maximum of 6 credits.

MUS 262.course_description: Playing and accompanying skills on ukulele, guitar, and keyboard, appropriate for classroom music making, K-12.

MUS 263.course_description: Basics of vocal pedagogy and performance: vocal anatomy, physics, and health with the instrumental music teacher in mind.

MUS 264K.course_description: Pedagogy of and performance on the flute; developing teaching strategies with this instrument in mind.

MUS 264L.course_description: Pedagogy of and performance on clarinet and saxophone; developing teaching strategies with these instruments in mind.

MUS 264M.course_description: Pedagogy of and performance on oboe and bassoon; developing teaching strategies with these instruments in mind.

MUS 264N.course_description: Pedagogy of and performance on French horn or trumpet (students select one section); developing teaching strategies with those instruments in mind.

MUS 264O.course_description: Pedagogy of and performance on trombone or tuba (students choose one section); developing teaching strategies with these instruments in mind.

MUS 264P.course_description: Instruction for future music educators in performance techniques and teaching methods for standard percussion used in concert band, orchestra, and percussion ensemble.

MUS 264Q.course_description: Instruction in performance techniques and teaching methods for the contemporary marching percussion ensemble. Classes will include hands-on instruction and drills on a variety of marching techniques to build both individual as well as ensemble technique. The course will also provide essential information covering basic instrument care and maintenance, drum tuning, stick and mallet selection, instrumentation, and rehearsal strategies.

MUS 264R.course_description: This course provides instruction for future music educators in performance techniques and teaching methods for drumset. Students will develop stick technique on the snare drum and four-way coordination at the drumset while developing a basic understanding of drumming in a variety of musical styles including: rock, jazz/swing, and Latin grooves.

MUS 264W.course_description: This course will introduce percussion instruments and rhythms used in West African, Afro Cuban, and other global music styles through the study of playing techniques, written documents, and audio and video recordings. Future music educators will learn basic information concerning teaching methods and performance techniques for a broad range of hand percussion instruments.

MUS 265C.course_description: Pedagogy of and performance on violin and viola; developing teaching strategies with these instruments in mind.

MUS 265D.course_description: Pedagogy of and performance on cello and string bass; developing teaching strategies with these instruments in mind.

MUS 266.course_description: For instrumental music education majors. Topics include jazz instruments, groups and set-up, articulations, notation, chords and chord symbols, improvisation, and jazz ensemble conducting.

MUS 268.course_description: This course is designed to introduce philosophical issues and pedagogical practices in the teaching of music in elementary and secondary schools.  Through discussion, reading, presentation, and observation, students will explore the career realities of full-time public-school music teaching. Students will be introduced to a variety of frameworks for effective instruction and will examine content and strategies for organizing and presenting lessons in classroom and rehearsal settings.

MUS 269.course_description: Observation, assisting and/or micro-teaching experience in K-12 music classroom environments. Repeatable for credit.

MUS 271.course_description: Preparation and performance of major choral works and part-songs. Open to all students having the ability to sing mixed part-songs. Repeatable to a maximum of 48 credits, including original course.

MUS 272.course_description: Preparation and performance of major band works. Open to all students with band experience. Repeatable to a maximum of 48 credits, including original course.

MUS 273.course_description: The study of orchestral technique through practical application and public performance of diverse repertoire for string orchestra. Repeatable to a maximum of 48 credits, including original course.

MUS 274.course_description: Performance and interpretation of contemporary jazz in a large ensemble situation. Repeatable to a maximum of 48 credits, including original course.

MUS 275.course_description: Supervised performances in small ensemble groups in jazz idioms stressing repertoire, improvisation, and performance of written arrangements and compositions. One public performance per quarter required. Repeatable to a maximum of 48 credits, including original course.

MUS 276.course_description: Includes private accompanying instruction and weekly performance seminars. Accompanying assignments include duos, chamber ensembles and large performance ensembles. Sight-reading skills, interpretation and accompanying techniques are emphasized. Repeatable for credit.

MUS 278.course_description: Preparation of opera scenes or a major music production to include a public performance each quarter. Repeatable for credit.

MUS 280.course_description: Music literature studies from an analytical and performance viewpoint from early to classic music, culminating in a public performance each quarter. Repeatable to a maximum of 48 credits, including original course.

MUS 281.course_description: Rehearsal, coaching, and study of the performance of works for small ensembles, culminating in a concert performance. Open to piano, string, wind, brass and percussion performers. Repeatable to a maximum of 48 credits, including original course.

MUS 282.course_description: Classical guitar students participate in duos, trios, quartets and pieces written for guitar orchestra. Repeatable to a maximum of 48 credits, including original course.

MUS 283.course_description: Repeatable to a maximum of 48 credits, including original course.

MUS 284.course_description: Preparation and performance of vocal works by major jazz composers. Open to all University students having the ability to sing in mixed chorus. Repeatable to a maximum of 48 credits, including original course.

MUS 285.course_description: Practical application for singing, acting and movement to performance-related work from American musical theatre through solo, duet and group performance. Repeatable to a maximum of 6 cr.

MUS 300.course_description: An individualized course of study not available through or replacing existing curriculum, to be arranged between one matriculating student and sponsoring faculty member. All academic policies and registration deadlines apply. Directed Independent Study courses cannot substitute for General University Requirements and are not eligible for tuition waiver.

MUS 301.course_description: This course is designed to investigate the relationships of music and sound with concepts of environmental and cultural sustainability. We will explore these concepts in local and global contexts through literary research, class discussions and lectures, fieldwork and sonic mapping, and sonic archive creation. This course is open to all students, regardless of major.

MUS 302.course_description: This course investigates the relationships between music, culture, and social justice, especially as they exist within North American contexts. Students will gain a deeper understanding of intersections between music, culture, and social justice across various contexts and identities, such as gender, race, ability, environment, war, citizenship, and public health. We will explore these concepts through class lectures and discussions, individual and collaborative research, audiovisual analysis, and service project design.

MUS 303.course_description: This course is designed to develop skills in deep listening, improvisation, spontaneous composition, and sensory experience. Students will engage in these practices through a variety of interactive music and sound-based activities at weekly rehearsals and one performance. This ensemble is open to all students, regardless of major, and does not require an audition. Repeatable to a maximum of 4 credits, including original course.

MUS 305.course_description: An investigation of specific musical styles and practices of selected Pacific Rim cultures, including Pacific Islands, West Coast Native Americans, South America, Indonesia, China and Japan. Includes class participation in actual musical situations from these areas.

MUS 311.course_description: Repeatable to a maximum of 66 credits, including original course.

MUS 321.course_description: The development of aural competence in and visual familiarity with the sounds and symbols of atonal, freely tonal and highly chromatic tonal systems; completion of extended tertian harmony. Exercises and drill in prepared and sight reading, dictation, error detection, accuracy of rhythm and intonation. S/U grading.

MUS 322.course_description: Formal and stylistic analysis of works from the major historical periods up to 1900.

MUS 323.course_description: The development of aural competence in and visual familiarity with the sounds and symbols of atonal, freely tonal and highly chromatic tonal systems; completion of extended tertian harmony. Exercises and drill in prepared and sight reading, dictation, error detection, accuracy of rhythm and intonation. S/U grading.

MUS 324A.course_description: Counterpoint in species and free style. Composition and analysis of pieces in two and three parts.

MUS 324B.course_description: Counterpoint in species and free style. Composition and analysis of pieces in two and three parts.

MUS 325.course_description: The development of aural competence in and visual familiarity with the sounds and symbols of atonal, freely tonal and highly chromatic tonal systems; completion of extended tertian harmony. Exercises and drill in prepared and sight reading, dictation, error detection, accuracy of rhythm and intonation. S/U grading.

MUS 326.course_description: Orchestration with special reference to the needs of the instrumental conductor and composer. Repeatable for credit.

MUS 331.course_description: Intermediate-level projects in melody, counterpoint, harmony, instrumentation, texture, rhythm, and notation; participation in weekly composition seminars. Repeatable for credit under advisement.

MUS 334.course_description: Study of basic chord changes, scales and patterns with improvisation based on these principles. Analysis of transcribed solos and study of jazz repertoire.

MUS 335.course_description: Study of altered chords, scales and patterns with improvisation based on the principles. Analysis of transcribed solos, study of jazz repertoire and ear training.

MUS 336.course_description: Study of bitonal chords, atonality and patterns with improvisation based on these principles. Analysis of transcribed solos, study of jazz repertoire and ear training.

MUS 338.course_description: Practical and theoretical foundation for playing Jazz piano. Participants develop the physical skills required to play chord lead sheets and walk bass lines, as well as the keyboard as a means of understanding, both visually and aurally, Jazz and commercial music harmony.

MUS 341.course_description: Main styles, forms, terminology and composers up to 1600. Individual research projects.

MUS 342.course_description: Main styles, forms, terminology and composers from 1600 to 1830. Individual research projects.

MUS 343.course_description: Main styles, forms, terminology and composers from 1830-present. Individual research projects.

MUS 345.course_description: This course will introduce students to the study of music history and culture from local, national, and global perspectives. Three weeks will be dedicated, each, to the studies of Western European art music, global musicultures, and popular musics. The first partial week of the term will serve as an introduction to musicology and the final week will be dedicated to comprehensive review and preparation for the next series course. As this is a writing-intensive course, students will also learn how to write about music through scaffolded lessons and assessments in each unit.

MUS 346.course_description: This course is the second in the musicology sequence, which is dedicated to a topical exploration of music history and culture through lecture, activity, and discussion-based frameworks. Students will engage in five units that each feature case studies on various genres of music, including Western European art music, global musicultures, and popular musics. Building upon knowledge from MUS 345, class sessions and assessments will relate to common topics of study in the field of musicology. As this is a writing-intensive course, students will also learn how to write about music through scaffolded lessons and assessments in each unit.

MUS 347.course_description: This course is the third in the musicology sequence, which is dedicated to a topical exploration of music history and culture through lecture, activity, and discussion-based frameworks. Students will engage in five units that each feature case studies on various genres of music, including Western European art music, global musicultures, and popular musics. Building upon our first set of case studies in MUS 346, class sessions and assessments will relate to five new topics of study in the field of musicology. As this is a writing-intensive course, students will also learn how to write about music through scaffolded lessons and assessments in each unit.

MUS 351.course_description: Basic conducting techniques, score reading and interpretive analysis.

MUS 352.course_description: Instrumental techniques, score reading, interpretive analysis and rehearsal techniques.

MUS 353.course_description: Choral techniques, score reading, interpretive analysis and rehearsal techniques.

MUS 354A.course_description: Hands-on practical experience in developing advanced conducting skills. Ensemble conducting experience.

MUS 354B.course_description: Hands-on practical experience in developing advanced conducting skills. Ensemble conducting experience.

MUS 361.course_description: For elementary teachers, not music majors. The skills of singing, reading, writing, playing and hearing music; techniques and materials used in the elementary grades.

MUS 362.course_description: Instructional techniques, resources, curriculum design, and methodology for teaching students in non-performance based general music classes. Emphasis on P-6th Grades.

MUS 363A.course_description: This course is designed to engage future music educators in the wealth of historic and contemporary choral music written by composers outside the Western European canon.

MUS 363B.course_description: This course is designed to engage future music educators in the wealth of group singing traditions from around the world and the ways these traditions may be brought into U.S. choral classrooms.

MUS 364.course_description: Instruction in elementary-level string instrumental repertoire, teaching strategies, rehearsal techniques, curriculum design and implementation.  Peer-teaching and micro-teaching assignments in conjunction with Instrumental Pedagogy Lab classes and public school programs.

MUS 365.course_description: The teaching of string classes with particular emphasis on instruction beyond the beginning levels. Areas of focus include teaching strategies for reinforcing fundamental skills, introducing intermediate and advanced skills, repertoire, rehearsal techniques, and curricular design and implementation.

MUS 366A.course_description: Familiarization and application of the phonetic structures of the major languages of singing and the use of the International Phonetic Alphabet as a basic tool for pronunciation.

MUS 366B.course_description: Familiarization and application of the phonetic structures of the major languages of singing and the use of the International Phonetic Alphabet as a basic tool for pronunciation.

MUS 366C.course_description: Familiarization and application of the phonetic structures of the major languages of singing and the use of the International Phonetic Alphabet as a basic tool for pronunciation.

MUS 367.course_description: Diatonic harmony applied to the fretboard.  Hands-on application of scales and chords as well as basic arranging chord-melody for the guitarist.

MUS 371.course_description: The Advanced Treble Chorale (ATC) is an auditioned select ensemble of skilled singers using a combination of rote learning and music literacy skills to prepare assigned repertoire. Repeatable to a maximum of 48 credits, including original course.

MUS 372.course_description: The Western Washington University Symphonic Winds is comprised of outstanding instrumentalists from the Department of Music and throughout the WWU community. The ensemble studies and performs a diverse body of repertoire, ranging from standard wind band literature to contemporary works for winds and percussion. Participation is open to all WWU students regardless of area of study by means of auditions held at the beginning of the fall quarter. Repeatable to a maximum of 48 credits, including original course.

MUS 398.course_description: This arts education course provides future teachers with a foundation in the elements and principles of Visual Art, Dance, Music and Theatre and their applicability to the elementary classroom. (Also offered as ART 398, DNC 398 and THTR 398).

MUS 399.course_description: A public recital approved by the student's applied instructor and/or recital committee. Students should check their area policies for more information and specific requirements and procedures. S/U grading.

MUS 400.course_description: An individualized course of study not available through or replacing existing curriculum, to be arranged between one matriculating student and sponsoring faculty member. All academic policies and registration deadlines apply. Directed Independent Study courses cannot substitute for General University Requirements and are not eligible for tuition waiver.

MUS 411.course_description: Repeatable to a maximum of 66 credits, including original course.

MUS 412.course_description: Repeatable to a maximum of 66 credits, including original course.

MUS 413.course_description: Repeatable to a maximum of 66 credits, including original course.
