MUS 416.course_description: Repeatable to a maximum of 66 credits, including original course.

MUS 418.course_description: Applied individual instruction. Jazz and commercial music styles will be explored, and the functional role of the improviser in an ensemble setting will be addressed. Repeatable to a maximum of 66 credits, including original course.

MUS 422.course_description: Formal and stylistic analysis of representative 20th-century works.

MUS 424.course_description: Post-tonal counterpoint in species and free styles. Composition and analysis of contemporary works.

MUS 431.course_description: Advanced projects in melody, counterpoint, harmony, instrumentation, texture, rhythm, and notation; participation in weekly composition seminars. Repeatable for credit under advisement.

MUS 432.course_description: Instruction in the use of computer software and analog synthesizers for creation of electroacoustic music. Discussion of music, arts technology, and aesthetics. Group instruction and studio time. Repeatable to a maximum of 6 credits, including original course.

MUS 434.course_description: Writing and arranging for small jazz ensembles. Analysis of small jazz ensemble styles.

MUS 435.course_description: Writing and arranging for a variety of instrumental combinations. Analysis of jazz ensemble styles.

MUS 436.course_description: Writing and arranging for large jazz ensemble. Analysis of large jazz ensemble styles.

MUS 441.course_description: Reading and interpreting early, contemporary or other extant systems.

MUS 442.course_description: This course is designed to investigate the historical and sociocultural elements of music. Students are expected to engage in weekly readings and listening assignments, seminar-style discussion, and research. The student, in consultation with the instructor, will select a course-related topic for individual research. Ongoing results of this work are shared with other members of the seminar. Seminar topics vary quarterly. Repeatable to a maximum of 16 credits under different topics, including original course.

MUS 443A.course_name: History of Musical Genres: Choral Music
MUS 443A.course_description: Development and literature of important musical genres from their origin to the present.

MUS 443B.course_name: History of Musical Genres: Solo Song
MUS 443B.course_description: Development and literature of important musical genres from their origin to the present.

MUS 443C.course_description: Development and literature of important musical genres from their origin to the present.

MUS 443D.course_name: History of Musical Genres: Keyboard Music
MUS 443D.course_description: Development and literature of important musical genres from their origin to the present.

MUS 443E.course_name: History of Musical Genres: Chamber Music
MUS 443E.course_description: Development and literature of important musical genres from their origin to the present.

MUS 443F.course_name: History of Musical Genres: Symphonic Music
MUS 443F.course_description: Development and literature of important musical genres from their origin to the present.

MUS 443G.course_description: Development and literature of important musical genres from their origin to the present.

MUS 443H.course_name: History of Musical Genres: Symphonic Music in the 20th Century
MUS 443H.course_description: Development and literature of important musical genres from their origin to the present.

MUS 443I.course_name: History of Musical Genres: Opera I
MUS 443I.course_description: Development and literature of important musical genres from their origin to the present.

MUS 443J.course_name: History of Musical Genres: Opera II
MUS 443J.course_description: Development and literature of important musical genres from their origin to the present.

MUS 444.course_description: History and literature of musicians’ responses to works of Shakespeare - music for stage and film, orchestral music, opera and song settings.

MUS 451.course_description: Advanced conducting techniques to include direction of student ensembles under faculty supervision.

MUS 455.course_description: Offered summers only. Repeatable for credit.

MUS 456.course_description: Offered summers only. Repeatable for credit.

MUS 460.course_description: This course is designed to introduce processes associated with the development of comprehensive literacy (reading, writing, speaking, and listening) within the P-12 music classroom. The course considers and includes two approaches to the pursuit of teaching toward literacy: 1) the cross-over, combination, and correlation between literacy standards and music standards, and 2) the onset of guiding students toward literacy in the academic area of music, i.e., the symbolic systems and “codes” related to musical ideas, meaning, and communication.

MUS 461.course_name: Advanced Techniques in General Music Education
MUS 461.course_description: Advanced teaching techniques for instructing secondary level students in non-performance based classrooms. In depth curriculum, methods, assessment strategies, long-term planning. Laboratory experience is included.

MUS 463.course_description: Instruction in middle and high school choral repertoire, teaching strategies, rehearsal techniques, classroom management, curriculum design. Peer-teaching and micro-teaching assignments in public schools.

MUS 465.course_description: Instruction in middle and high school instrumental rehearsal techniques, repertoire selection, classroom management systems, short and long term planning, and curriculum design. Peer-teaching and on-site observation within public school secondary instrumental classes.

MUS 466.course_description: A study of the basic concepts involved in instrument or voice pedagogy through a survey of the most important modern teaching methods. Repeatable for credit.

MUS 466A.course_description: Provides an introduction to the principles of piano teaching at the beginner to intermediate/early advanced levels. The course includes basic information on how to teach and develop the basics of piano playing.

MUS 466B.course_description: A study of modern voice teaching methods including the physics and physiology of voice production, psychology of singing, and vocal health. Anatomic and physiologic underpinnings of respiration, phonation, articulation, registration, and hearing are explored in depth.

MUS 466C.course_description: The historical and international perspective of piano teaching.  Included is discussion of national schools of piano playing, the relationship of technological changes in piano construction to piano technique, piano pedagogy and composition styles.

MUS 466D.course_description: The study and application of modern voice teaching methods including voice classification, diagnostics and remediation, selection of repertoire, historical and comparative pedagogy, and strategies for effective teaching.

MUS 466E.course_description: For aspiring professional musicians, this course explores varied practical skill sets that go beyond technical mastery of an instrument and are often drawn upon by successful artists and pedagogues of today. Required for brass, woodwind, string, and percussion applied areas, but recommended for any performance major.

MUS 467.course_description: A stylistic and historical survey of literature for piano. Repeatable to a maximum of 6 credits, including original course.

MUS 468A.course_description: A survey of guitar literature and history from Renaissance to present.

MUS 468B.course_description: A survey of guitar literature and history from Renaissance to present.

MUS 469.course_description: Observation, assisting and intense field experience in music classroom environments. Repeatable for credit.

MUS 471.course_description: Selected group experience, vocal ability, reading skill, musicianship and interest in serious choral music considered for membership. Repeatable to a maximum of 48 credits, including original course.

MUS 472.course_description: Repeatable to a maximum of 48 credits, including original course.

MUS 473.course_description: Repeatable to a maximum of 48 credits, including original course.

MUS 474.course_description: Advanced performance and interpretation of contemporary jazz in an ensemble situation; recent developments in the idiom; performance of student compositions and arrangements. Repeatable to a maximum of 48 credits, including original course.

MUS 475.course_description: Supervised small ensemble playing in jazz idioms stressing repertoire, improvisation and performance of written arrangements and compositions. One public performance per quarter required. Repeatable to a maximum of 48 credits, including original course.

MUS 476.course_description: Advanced instruction in accompanying skills. Repeatable for credit.

MUS 478.course_description: Preparation of opera scenes or a major musical production to include a public performance each quarter. Repeatable for credit.

MUS 480.course_description: Music literature studies from an analytical and performance viewpoint from early to classic music, culminating in a public performance each quarter. Repeatable to a maximum of 48 credits, including original course.

MUS 481.course_description: Open to piano, string, wind, brass and percussion performers. Repeatable to a maximum of 48 credits, including original course.

MUS 483.course_description: Advanced chamber choral ensemble. Audition required. Repeatable to a maximum of 48 credits, including original course.

MUS 484.course_description: Preparation and performance of vocal works by major jazz composers. Open to all University students having the ability to sing in mixed chorus. Repeatable to a maximum of 48 credits, including original course.

MUS 485.course_description: Performance of 20th-century music literature. Repeatable to a maximum of 48 credits, including original course.

MUS 486.course_description: Rehearsal and performance of chamber orchestra literature. Repeatable to a maximum of 48 credits, including original course.

MUS 498.course_description: A full-length, public recital featuring the student's original compositions and approved by the student's recital committee. S/U grading.

MUS 499.course_description: A full-length, public recital approved by the student’s Recital Committee. S/U grading.

MUS 500.course_description: An individualized course of study not available through or replacing existing curriculum, to be arranged between one matriculating student and sponsoring faculty member. All academic policies and registration deadlines apply.

MUS 501.course_description: Advanced work in conducting band and orchestra music; baton technique, interpretation, score preparation and rehearsal techniques. Repeatable for credit.

MUS 502.course_description: Successful techniques in developing and conducting choral groups, score analysis of outstanding choral works; laboratory experience in conducting. Repeatable for credit.

MUS 503.course_name: Introduction to Graduate Study of Music
MUS 503.course_description: Sources and availability of music, recordings and literature about music throughout its entire history. Techniques of research bibliography and formal writing about music. Students are expected to prepare and defend a formal written project.

MUS 504.course_description: This course focuses on musical analysis through a rhetorical or performative lens, with emphasis on how the structural organization of music practically informs and guides the act of performance.

MUS 507.course_description: This course is designed to introduce broad pedagogical practices in the teaching of music in K-12th grade settings. Through discussion, responses, readings, and presentations, students will explore the career realities of full-time public-school music teaching.

MUS 511.course_description: In addition to regularly scheduled private lessons, students are expected to participate in organ or piano class performances and to hold a church organist position throughout their residence for the degree. Repeatable to a maximum of 60 credits, including original course.

MUS 512.course_description: In addition to regularly scheduled private lessons, a public performance is expected each quarter. Repeatable to a maximum of 60 credits, including original course.

MUS 513.course_description: In addition to regularly scheduled private lessons, a public performance of a significant work is expected. The performance will be approved and evaluated by a faculty committee. Repeatable to a maximum of 60 credits, including original course.

MUS 514.course_name: Individual Instruction: Advanced Winds and Percussion
MUS 514.course_description: In addition to regularly scheduled private lessons, a public performance of a significant work is expected. The performance will be approved and evaluated by a faculty committee. Repeatable to a maximum of 60 credits, including original course.

MUS 515.course_description: In addition to regularly scheduled private lessons, attendance and performance at master class is expected. In addition, a public performance is expected each quarter. Repeatable to a maximum of 60 credits, including original course.

MUS 516.course_description: Students in Advanced Vocal Coaching will explore a range of detailed issues relating to musical and textual interpretation, character, diction, performance practice, and other matters that may be pertinent to preparation for performance at a professional level. Repeatable to a maximum of 6 credits, including original course.

MUS 518.course_description: Individual instruction in jazz performance styles and techniques. Repeatable to a maximum of 12 credits, including original course.

MUS 519.course_description: Individual instruction in conducting techniques and repertoire.

MUS 525.course_name: Brass and Percussion Techniques and Materials
MUS 525.course_description: Pedagogical and fundamental performance problems for all brass and percussion instruments; appropriate literature for beginning through advanced levels; performance problems encountered within the school band and orchestra settings.

MUS 531.course_description: Orchestration with special reference to the needs of the instrumental conductor and composer.

MUS 532.course_description: Analysis of works by various composers who have generated the major trends of 20th-century music.

MUS 533.course_name: Analytical Techniques: 19th-Century Musical Styles and Practices
MUS 533.course_description: Analysis of works by various composers who generated the major trends of 19th-century music.

MUS 534.course_description: Composition, rehearsal and public performance of original works. Repeatable for credit.

MUS 538.course_description: Reading, interpreting and transcribing music from early notational systems.

MUS 539.course_description: An in-depth look at a particular musical genre. Sample topics: opera, solo song, choral music, the concerto, symphonic music. Course may be repeated once for credit, with a different topic.

MUS 541.course_description: An in-depth study of a particular segment of music chosen from the Medieval and Renaissance periods with historical perspective, analysis of representative works, and bibliography and research techniques appropriate to the subject. Repeatable once for credit.

MUS 542.course_description: An in-depth study of a particular segment of music chosen from the Baroque and Classical periods with historical perspective, analysis of representative works, and bibliography and research techniques appropriate to the subject. Repeatable once for credit.

MUS 543.course_description: An in-depth study of a particular segment of music chosen from the Romantic and Contemporary periods with historical perspective, analysis of representative works, and bibliography and research techniques appropriate to the subject. Repeatable once for credit.

MUS 550.course_description: This course is designed to investigate the historical and sociocultural elements of music. Students are expected to engage in weekly readings and listening assignments, seminar-style discussion, and research. The student, in consultation with the instructor, will select a course-related topic for individual research. Ongoing results of this work are shared with other members of the seminar. Seminar topics vary quarterly. Repeatable with different topics to a maximum of 24 credits, including original course.

MUS 551.course_description: This course will introduce students to the discipline, foundations, and current directions of musicology, including the relationships between its sub-disciplines and its applicability to their lives and careers as musicians. We will explore these concepts through reading, writing, discussion, and various other musicological methodologies. Students will also engage in individual research projects, in consultation with the instructor, and share the ongoing and final results of this research with other members of the seminar.

MUS 552.course_description: This course is designed to investigate relationships between music, gender, and sexuality in the context of a musicological seminar. We will explore these concepts through various methodologies, including reading, writing, discussion, and musicking. Students will also engage in individual research projects, in consultation with the instructor, and share the ongoing and final results of this research with other members of the seminar.

MUS 555.course_description: Course not applicable to MMus degree. Offered summers only. Repeatable for credit.

MUS 556.course_description: Course not applicable to MMus degree. Offered summers only. Repeatable for credit.

MUS 560.course_description: This course is designed to introduce processes associated with the development of comprehensive literacy (reading, writing, speaking, and listening) within the music education classroom, P-12th grades. The course considers and includes two approaches to the pursuit of teaching toward literacy: 1) the cross-over, combination, and correlation between literacy standards and music standards, and 2) the onset of guiding students toward literacy in the academic area of music, i.e., the symbolic systems and “codes” related to musical ideas, meaning, and communication.

MUS 561.course_name: Advanced Techniques in General Music Education
MUS 561.course_description: Advanced teaching techniques for instructing secondary level students in non-performance based classrooms. In depth curriculum, methods, assessment strategies, long-term planning.

MUS 562.course_description: Instructional techniques, resources, curriculum design, and methodology for teaching students in non-performance based general music classes. Emphasis on P-6th Grades.

MUS 563A.course_description: This course is designed to engage future music educators in the wealth of historic and contemporary choral music written by composers outside the Western European canon.

MUS 563B.course_description: This course is designed to engage future music educators in the wealth of group singing traditions from around the world and the ways these traditions may be brought into US choral classrooms.

MUS 565.course_description: The teaching of heterogeneous string classes with particular emphasis on classes beyond the beginning levels. Areas of focus include teaching strategies for reinforcing fundamental skills, introducing intermediate and advanced skills, repertoire, rehearsal techniques, and curricular design and implementation.

MUS 566.course_description: Principles of piano teaching at the beginner through intermediate/early advanced levels; this will include in-depth discussion on teaching rhythm, sound production, hand/body position, pedaling, technique, sight reading, memorizing, musicianship, artistry, as well as psychology, child, teenager, adult, ADHD, and other special circumstances, and developmental and learning theories as related to currently available piano pedagogy materials. Repeatable up to 6 credits including original course.

MUS 568.course_description: The historical and international perspective of piano teaching. This will include discussions of national schools of piano playing, the relationship of technological changes in piano construction to piano technique, piano pedagogy and composition styles. Repeatable up to 6 credits including original course.

MUS 571.course_description: Rehearsal and public performance of representative choral works. Repeatable to a maximum of 12 cr.

MUS 572.course_description: Rehearsal and public performance of works for wind ensemble. Repeatable to a maximum of 12 cr.

MUS 573.course_description: Rehearsal and public performance of works for symphony orchestra. Repeatable to a maximum of 12 cr.

MUS 574.course_description: Advanced performance and interpretation of contemporary jazz in an ensemble situation; recent developments in the idiom; performance of student compositions and arrangements. Repeatable to a maximum of 12 cr.

MUS 575.course_description: Supervised small ensemble playing in jazz idioms stressing repertoire, improvisation and performance of written arrangements and compositions. One public performance per quarter required. Repeatable to a maximum of 12 cr.

MUS 576.course_description: Graduate-level instruction in accompanying skills. Pianists will accompany singers and instrumentalists under the supervision and regular coaching of the instructor. Repeatable for credit.

MUS 578.course_description: Preparation of opera scenes or a major musical production to include a public performance each quarter. Repeatable to a maximum of 12 cr.

MUS 580.course_description: Editing, coaching and performance practice of early music (before 1800). Involves preparation and participation in public performance. (Only 6 credits applicable towards MMus degree). Repeatable up to 6 credits.

MUS 581.course_description: Rehearsal and public performance of representative works of chamber music. Open to piano, string, wind, brass and percussion performers. Repeatable to a maximum of 12 cr.

MUS 583.course_description: Rehearsal and public performance of chamber vocal works. Repeatable to a maximum of 12 cr.

MUS 585.course_description: Rehearsal and performance of 20th-century music literature. Repeatable to a maximum of 12 cr.

MUS 586.course_description: Rehearsal and performance of chamber orchestra literature. Repeatable to a maximum of 6 cr.

MUS 690.course_description: Students in the composition concentration of the MMus degree program may meet the thesis requirement by submitting a major original composition; students in the performance concentration may meet the thesis requirement by presenting a full-length public recital; students in the music education concentration selecting the conducting practicum for their thesis requirement will carry out a practical and/or creative conducting project, field study or investigation, or rehearsal/conducting series culminating in a public performance. Repeatable to a maximum of 6 credits, including original course. S/U grading.

NURS 301.course_name: Information Literacy to Support Academic Discourse
NURS 301.course_description: Focuses on developing the ability to utilize technologies to access and evaluate the credibility of information, consider the strength of varied perspectives, and develop skills of academic discourse necessary for a reasoned analysis of current issues in health care and health care professions.

NURS 305.course_description: Explores the principal themes and issues relating to social justice and health disparities. Examines how oppression, racism and privilege shape patient care. Provides opportunities to support social justice in healthcare using increased self-awareness, theories of justice, and research findings to promote equitable patient care.

NURS 307.course_description: This is a course that emphasizes strategies and ongoing practice in critical reading, writing and thinking skills that enhance student success in developing clear, informed, analytic and persuasive academic papers. Students may take one credit per quarter, repeatable up to 5 credits maximum, including original course. May be taken concurrently with any core RN to BSN course.

NURS 401.course_description: Throughout the 5 credits of this course, students will establish a professional nursing presence through self-assessment and identification of academic, professional and personal goals.  Students will examine select issues within professional nursing practice.  Each quarter, course objectives increase in depth and complexity.

NURS 402.course_description: Utilizes the elements of the research process and analytic skills necessary to evaluate, translate and apply current systematic inquiry to inform nursing practice and promote optimal clinical outcomes.

NURS 403.course_name: Translational Research for Evidence-Based Practice-Practice Experience
NURS 403.course_description: Application of NURS 402 principles. This course requires 30-hours of practice experience with a community mentor. The targeted goal of this practice experience is completing a project proposing an evidence-based practice change.

NURS 412.course_description: Examines health care policy, finance and regulatory environments that directly and indirectly influence the health care system. Utilizes a systems-leadership approach in advocacy for patients, families, communities and healthcare professionals to promote social justice and equity in our system of care.

NURS 422.course_name: Organizational Change for Quality and Safety in Healthcare
NURS 422.course_description: Examines and applies theories of organizational behavior, systems thinking, and leadership to quality improvement strategies that minimize errors and optimize positive clinical outcomes.

NURS 423.course_name: Organizational Change for Quality and Safety in Healthcare Practice Experience
NURS 423.course_description: Application of NURS 422 principles. Participation in selected patient safety and quality improvement initiatives provide opportunity to apply and evaluate the relevance of theoretical concepts to real-world health care challenges. This course requires 30-hours of practice experience with a community mentor. The targeted goal of this practice experience is completing a project proposing a blueprint for implementation of a practice change idea to include organizational assessment for readiness for change, quality assurance measures, and a plan for sustainability of the change

NURS 432.course_description: Community-Based Care for Vulnerable Populations emphasizes population-focused healthcare including the assessment and exploration of factors that influence health and well-being of communities. The course integrates and applies concepts of social justice, health promotion, and disease and injury prevention in a variety of settings and populations.  This course is taken in conjunction with the practice experience course, NURS 433, allowing the student to apply these concepts, for the improvement of healthcare services to vulnerable populations in the community context.

NURS 433.course_name: Community-Based Care for Vulnerable Populations Practice Experience
NURS 433.course_description: Community-Based Care Clinical Practice experience of 30 hours taken in conjunction with NURS 432 course. Students establish community partnerships and apply theoretical foundations. Washington State RN license required. S/U grading.

NURS 442.course_description: Integrates knowledge, skills and attitudes necessary to promote community based patient/family centered health care coordination through effective use of appropriate technologies, interdisciplinary communication, teamwork and collaboration.

NURS 443.course_description: Interdisciplinary Care Coordination Practice Experience of 30 hours taken in conjunction with NURS 442 course. Students establish community partnerships and apply theoretical foundations. Washington State RN license required. S/U grading.

NURS 452.course_description: Examines major problems and policy issues in global health from multiple perspectives. Focuses on understanding the historical, political, social, cultural, environmental and economic determinants of adverse health conditions in developing countries. Provides a knowledge base for healthcare professionals to promote social justice by improving global health disparities.

NURS 510.course_name: Health Systems Assessment for Health Equity
NURS 510.course_description: In this course, students critically reflect on basic worldviews, biases, beliefs, and assumptions to increase decision-making and grow in awareness of a complex world. Building on this awareness, students assess individual and communities’ unmet health and social needs in the context of their lives and the structural factors that shape health conditions.

NURS 511.course_name: Health Systems Assessment for Health Equity Practice Experience
NURS 511.course_description: This course is the first of three required foundations Practice Experience courses (NURS 511, 521, and 531) to ground students in the curriculum’s conceptual model of the determinants of health and population health equity. In this course, students apply NURS 510 principles and are required to complete 30 hours of practice experience with a community preceptor. The targeted goal of this course is to explore implementation science leadership at the community/population level by accessing and evaluating population data through a community needs assessment (WAC 246-840-531, 2(a)). The three foundations Practice Experience courses enable students to participate in an aspect of an organizational or population quality assurance project.

NURS 512.course_description: In this course, students develop nursing scholarship skills within a framework of promoting equity in healthcare, incorporating reflective practice, social justice, and health equity with palliative approaches. Students explore implementation science, applying evidence-based practices with a strong emphasis on health equity, ethical leadership in scholarly activities, and adherence to ethical guidelines in research. Additionally, students explore using quality improvement principles with an equity perspective to prepare them to contribute to a culture of equity and patient safety by evaluating disparities and designing evidence-based interventions.

NURS 520.course_description: In this course, students examine the beliefs and values in systems of power that shape nursing practice and education, such as the political, social, environmental, geographic, and economic drivers of health and health equity. Students explore the impact of payment models, regulatory bodies, and political influences on the delivery of healthcare and education and the nurse leader and educator roles. Participatory models of power sharing are introduced.

NURS 521.course_name: Systems of Power in Healthcare Practice Experience
NURS 521.course_description: This course is the second of three required foundations Practice Experience courses (NURS 511, 521, and 531) to ground students in the curriculum’s conceptual model of the determinants of health and population health equity. In this course, students apply NURS 520 principles and are required to complete 30 hours of practice experience with a community preceptor. The targeted goal of this practice experience is to explore implementation science leadership and investigate population interventions (WAC 246-840-531, 2(a)) by identifying the systems of power (e.g., socio-political, regulatory) that impact the delivery of health or educational services in an organization and the nurse leader and educator roles. The three foundations Practice Experience courses enable students to participate in an aspect of an organizational or population quality assurance project.

NURS 522.course_description: In this course, students develop a working knowledge of healthcare information systems to describe the potential benefits of these technologies for improving patient care and health outcomes while identifying potential concerns regarding data justice. Students examine information technologies’ impacts on individuals’ healthcare experiences and information acquisition. Students also explore the implications of emerging technologies interfacing with information systems for individuals, particularly from marginalized communities.

NURS 530.course_description: In this course, students examine interprofessional population management strategies using the tools of evidence-based practice (EBP), quality improvement (QI), and research to address health and social needs, including environmental health and palliative care, of the communities served. Students analyze nurses’ unique roles and contributions to interprofessional partnerships.

NURS 531.course_name: Population Management for Health Equity Practice Experience
NURS 531.course_description: This course is the third of three required foundations Practice Experience courses (NURS 511, 521, and 531) to ground students in the curriculum’s conceptual model of the determinants of health and population health equity. In this course, students apply NURS 530 principles and are required to complete 30 hours of practice experience with a community preceptor. The targeted goal of this course is to investigate population interventions for an organizational or population quality assurance project (WAC 246-840-531, 2(a)), and to connect their population intervention investigation to implementation science leadership. Students identify feasible strategies to accommodate social barriers through care transitions and address communities’ health and social needs.

NURS 532.course_description: In this course, nurse educator students enhance their teaching skills, including critical self-reflection to improve teaching practices, applying teaching and learning theories, understanding learner needs, creating inclusive learning environments and instructional design principles, and assessing teaching effectiveness. Students develop and present a health education module or unit of instruction to apply their knowledge and evaluate its quality and effectiveness.

NURS 534.course_description: In this course, students navigate the intersection of art and science in supervising and guiding individuals, primarily focusing on governance and leadership theories. Students have a comprehensive grasp of how these realms impact a nurse leader’s capacity to promote health equity and nurture a culture characterized by transparency, accountability, adaptability, ethical decision-making, diversity, and active stakeholder involvement.

NURS 540.course_name: Partnerships for Health Equity, Sustainability, and Advocacy
NURS 540.course_description: This course examines emerging system-level interventions, including inter-professional partnerships, coalition building, and policy advocacy to provide nurse leaders and educators with sustainability and health equity strategies for future generations.

NURS 542.course_description: In this course, students gain essential online teaching and learning skills, including proficiency in using educational technologies and learning management systems, applying effective online teaching strategies, and designing online education modules that incorporate inclusive design principles and educational theories. Students develop and present an online health education module or unit of instruction to apply their knowledge and evaluate its quality and effectiveness.

NURS 543.course_description: In this Nurse Educator Practice Experience, students synthesize existing knowledge and skills to enhance the quality of nursing and healthcare delivery. This course requires 30 hours of practice experience with a nurse educator preceptor. Throughout the practice experience, students teach patients, populations, student nurses, or nursing students, guided by a nurse educator preceptor, demonstrating competence in curriculum design, assessment, evaluation, facilitating learning, learner development and socialization, inclusive design, and functioning as change agents within the realm of nursing education. Additionally, students develop proficiency in the core competencies outlined in the NLN Core Competencies for Nurse Educators.

NURS 544.course_description: In this course, students develop essential skills in systems thinking and adaptive complex strategies and explore tools and techniques to navigate complexity, uncertainty, and unexpected disruptions. Students articulate their role and responsibility in promoting organizational responsiveness to practice person-, family-, and community-centered care and leading initiatives promoting equity, diversity, and inclusiveness in care delivery and business operations. Students analyze the ethical implications of systems thinking and adaptive complex strategies and examine emerging trends in these areas, including applications in fields such as artificial intelligence in nursing practice and its associated challenges.

NURS 545.course_description: In this Nursing Leadership Practice Experience, students synthesize existing knowledge and skills to enhance the quality of nursing and healthcare delivery. This course requires 30 hours of practice experience with a nurse leader preceptor. Throughout the practice experience, students actively participate with a nurse leader preceptor in leadership and change projects, engage in research activities, or access client or population data for quality assurance and improvement projects. Additionally, students assess the leadership styles of key leaders within the organization, consider their influence on the organization’s culture and effectiveness, and evaluate the organization’s governance structure, policies, and decision-making processes and how they align with governance theories. Students communicate their analyses through informative presentations to nursing leader preceptors, demonstrating their ability to synthesize and apply knowledge to real-world healthcare leadership.

NURS 550.course_name: Holistic Health Assessment, Physiology & Pharmacology Simulation Design
NURS 550.course_description: In this course, students examine the integration of advanced nursing care concepts, including holistic health assessment, pathophysiology, and pharmacologic intervention throughout the lifespan through an ecological health lens. Students develop and implement a healthcare simulation integrating the course concepts using the International Nursing Association for Clinical Simulation and Learning Healthcare Simulation Standards of Best Practice (TM).

NURS 551.course_description: Capstone I: Nurse Educator Project is the first of two capstone courses for students to apply knowledge and skills that empower graduate-level nurse educators to address complex healthcare challenges through evidence-based solutions. This course requires 90 hours of practice experience with a nurse educator preceptor. Students collaborate with stakeholders to identify learning needs, opportunities for improvement, and innovative strategies. The project involves systematically searching for evidence, critically appraising it, and synthesizing findings into recommendations seeking innovative solutions in the education context. Additionally, students develop proficiency in the NLN Core Competencies for Nurse Educators. Students complete the capstone project in Capstone II.

NURS 555.course_description: Capstone I: Nursing Leadership Project is the first of two capstone courses, which are culminating courses designed as an application of leadership knowledge and skills that empower graduate-level nurse leaders to address complex healthcare challenges through evidence-based solutions. This course requires 90 hours of practice experience with a nurse leader preceptor. Through this course, students undertake a comprehensive project, from identifying an issue in healthcare to conducting a systematic search for evidence, critically appraising the evidence, and finally, synthesizing the findings into a recommendation. Students complete the capstone project in Capstone II.

NURS 556.course_name: Implementing Effective Change: Principles of Implementation Science
NURS 556.course_description: In this course, students explore the interdisciplinary field of implementation science, which systematically integrates evidence-based practices into real-world contexts to enhance outcomes. Students examine the theoretical foundations of implementation, analyzing the behavioral, organizational, and sociopolitical factors critical for adopting and sustaining new initiatives.

NURS 560.course_name: Curriculum Design, Program Evaluation, and Quality Enhancement
NURS 560.course_description: In this course, students explore forces influencing nursing curricula, including accreditation and licensure requirements, specialty competencies, program evaluation, and quality improvement principles. Students reflect on how learning and insights in the MSN curriculum inform professional development in preparation for entering the nursing education profession.

NURS 561.course_description: Capstone II: Nurse Educator Project is the second of the two capstone courses designed to apply leadership and education knowledge and skills in empowering graduate-level nurse educators to address complex healthcare challenges with evidence-based solutions. This course requires 90 hours of practice experience with a nurse educator preceptor. Students build upon their work from Capstone I by completing the capstone project, which includes conducting a comprehensive Fit and Feasibility Assessment from an EBP model, identifying key stakeholders and their influence and impact on project success, and recommending evidence-based implementation strategies. Students will present or disseminate the educational product, considering the readiness of the practice setting and demonstrating the ability to communicate with and engage stakeholders. Additionally, students develop proficiency in the NLN Core Competencies for Nurse Educators.

NURS 565.course_description: Capstone II: Nursing Leadership Project is the second of the two capstone courses designed to apply leadership knowledge and skills in empowering graduate-level nurse leaders to address complex healthcare challenges with evidence-based solutions. This course requires 90 hours of practice experience with a nurse leader preceptor. Students build upon their work from Capstone I by completing the capstone project, which includes conducting a comprehensive Fit and Feasibility Assessment from an EBP model, identifying key stakeholders and their influence and impact on project success, and recommending evidence-based implementation strategies that encompass resource allocation, timelines, and risk avoidance/mitigation. Students will create a compelling and informative presentation on recommendations and present it to the leadership team.

NURS 566.course_description: In this course, students develop knowledge and skills to understand an organization’s financial processes. It enables them to apply economic principles, conduct cost-benefit analyses, and create business models to set measurable priorities and objectives, fostering a culture of financial responsibility and equity.

NURS 570.course_description: In this course, students add practice experience hours to complete project work at an approved practice site as an extension/enhancement of other MSN program coursework. The independent practice experience course requires program approval to enroll. All work is conducted under the supervision and evaluation of program faculty. Repeatable to a maximum of 8 credits and 6 times, including original course.

OPS 360.course_description: Examines the concepts for designing, planning and improving manufacturing and service organizations. Topics include enterprise resource planning, facility layout, forecasting, queuing models, inventory management, lean manufacturing, total quality control, and project management.

OPS 367.course_description: Concepts and techniques for designing, planning and controlling service operations. Topics include service site location, service facilities design, managing capacity and demand in service operations, work force scheduling, the queuing phenomenon, and the impact of new technology on service operations.

OPS 400.course_description: An individualized course of study not available through or replacing existing curriculum, to be arranged between one matriculating student and sponsoring faculty member. All academic policies and registration deadlines apply. Directed Independent Study courses cannot substitute for General University Requirements and are not eligible for tuition waiver.

OPS 417.course_description: Concepts and techniques for designing, planning and controlling service operations. Topics include service site location, service facilities design, managing capacity and demand in service operations, work force scheduling, the queuing phenomenon, and the impact of new technology on service operations.

OPS 455.course_name: Environmental, Social and Governance Strategies for Operations and Supply Chain Management
OPS 455.course_description: This course covers the important environmental, social and governance issues that impact operations and supply chain management. These issues are central to the effective management of an organization and are imperative for the effective and efficient supply chain.

OPS 460.course_description: Examines principles and cases in the design and analysis of lean manufacturing systems. Topics include principles of lean thinking, seven wastes, kaizen practices, current and future state value stream mapping, continuous flow, cellular manufacturing, Heijunka, standard work, and visual management.

OPS 461.course_description: Examines the organization, planning, and controlling of projects and provides practical knowledge on managing project scope, schedule and resources. Topics include project life cycle, work breakdown structure and Gantt charts, network diagrams, scheduling techniques, and resource allocation decisions. Concepts are applied through team projects and tutorials using project management software.

OPS 462.course_description: Covers the development of optimization and simulation models using Microsoft Excel for the solution of business problems.   Topics include advanced spreadsheet use; linear, integer, and non-linear programming; and the simulation of stochastic systems.  Applications in operations, finance, and marketing are reviewed.

OPS 463.course_description: Examines the principles and techniques for planning and managing resource usage across the business enterprise. Topics include business process integration, inventory management, master scheduling, and material and capacity planning. Concepts are applied through the use of current enterprise resource planning software.

OPS 464.course_name: Manufacturing and Supply Chain Management Practicum
OPS 464.course_description: Manufacturing or supply chain management-related employment, research or special project experience. Emphasis on applying manufacturing and supply chain management principles in an academically guided setting. Minimum requirements include a written proposal, a work log, and a comprehensive final written report. Repeatable to a maximum of 8 credits.

OPS 465.course_description: Examines the principles and techniques for managing and improving quality in an organization. Topics include incoming material control, statistical process control, and process improvement.

OPS 466.course_description: Examines the principles, techniques, and practices for the design and management of integrated supply chain operations. Investigates supply chain strategy, distribution, facility location decisions, purchasing, and information systems for managing supply chain activities.

OPS 467.course_description: This course will cover a variety of logistics-related issues pertaining to the design and operation of supply chains, including appropriate modeling tools for their analysis. Emphasis will be on the application and development of mathematical modeling techniques for the analysis of issues such as: multi-stage network design, vehicle routing and scheduling, cycle and safety inventories, and multi-echelon inventory control.  Other related topics include supply chain information technology and visualizing supply chain data and metrics.

OPS 468.course_description: This is a capstone course, enabling students to apply their learning from the operations management program coursework. The course reviews supply chain principles and techniques and examines issues in managing global supply chain strategies and operations. Topics include global supply chain strategy decisions, key performance indicators, inventory models, network design, global facility location decisions, transportation & logistics, risk management, and sales & operations planning.

OPS 469.course_name: Seminar in Manufacturing and Supply Chain Management
OPS 469.course_description: Operations management theory and concepts applied to current manufacturing and supply chain problems.

PHIL 112.course_name: Introduction to Philosophy: Ethics and the Good Life
PHIL 112.course_description: Philosophy is the attempt to answer, through rational reflection, the most fundamental questions. In this introductory course, we will explore questions of ethics and morality. Questions addressed may include, among others: What makes an action right or wrong? How can we think productively about controversial issues like abortion, euthanasia, animal rights, immigration, etc.? Do cultural differences mean there is no objective truth about morality? What makes for a good or meaningful life? This course will equip you to think through such issues for yourself.

PHIL 113.course_name: Introduction to Philosophy: Reason and Religion
PHIL 113.course_description: Philosophy is the attempt to answer, through rational reflection, the most fundamental questions. In this introductory course, we will explore questions about religion and religious faith. Questions addressed may include, among others: How should we reason about whether there is a God? Who or what is a God, anyway? Could we have good evidence that a miracle happened? Might there be life after death? Does faith conflict with reason? Can it be rational to act on faith? This course will equip you to think through such issues for yourself.

PHIL 114.course_name: Introduction to Philosophy: Knowledge and Reality
PHIL 114.course_description: Philosophy is the attempt to answer, through rational reflection, the most fundamental questions. In this introductory course we will explore issues involving the nature of the world around us and our ability to know what it is really like. Questions addressed may include, among others: Is the physical world all there is? Do we have free will? How might we come to know about such things? For that matter, how might we come to know anything at all? This course will equip you to think through such issues for yourself.

PHIL 115.course_name: Introduction to Philosophy: Ethics and the Environment
PHIL 115.course_description: Philosophy is the attempt to answer, through rational reflection, the most fundamental questions. In this introductory course, we will explore ethical questions about the environment and our relationship to it. Questions addressed may include, among others: Is it morally right to eat animals? What should we do, if anything, about species and ecosystems that are endangered? Does the natural world have inherent value? Should we engage in climate activism? What do we owe, if anything, to the people who will live on Earth hundreds of years from now? This course will equip you to think through such issues for yourself.

PHIL 120.course_description: Critical thinking skills – the ability to ask helpful questions, evaluate complicated arguments, consume information wisely, and disagree productively – are essential to living a thoughtful and fulfilling life. At the heart of these skills is the ability to reason well, no matter what questions we’re wrestling with. In this introductory course, we will read and analyze examples of reasoning in action, with the goal of figuring out what reasoning is, how it works, and how we can do it better.

PHIL 201.course_description: Our ability to reason in accordance with mathematically precise principles of logic can be a powerful tool to help us think carefully. In this course, we will develop our ability by creating a symbolic language and formal proof system, and we will use that system to assess arguments. This course will be useful for everyone who cares about thinking carefully in a systematic and rigorous way.

PHIL 202.course_description: This course extends the focus of PHIL 201 to include a more powerful system of natural deduction involving quantifiers, predicates, relations, and identity.

PHIL 300.course_description: An individualized course of study not available through or replacing existing curriculum, to be arranged between one matriculating student and sponsoring faculty member. All academic policies and registration deadlines apply. Directed Independent Study courses cannot substitute for General University Requirements and are not eligible for tuition waiver.

PHIL 310.course_description: This course addresses the nature and possibility of knowledge and related states like reasonable belief. Questions addressed may include, among others: What would it take to really know something, instead of merely thinking you know it? Can we ever get real knowledge? If so, then how? If we can’t get knowledge, then can we at least come to form rational or reasonable beliefs? And what would those things be?

PHIL 320.course_description: This course addresses questions about the nature of morality, including a survey of historical and contemporary explanations of what makes an action right or wrong. Other questions addressed may include, among others: What is it to be a virtuous person? What role should self-interest play in the good life? And when is a wrongdoer blameworthy for what they have done?

PHIL 330.course_description: A systematic study of the fundamental categories of reality, such as existence, substance, property, identity, space, time, change, event, causality, necessity, essence, free will and mind. The philosophical issues in which these categories play a part also will be discussed.

PHIL 335.course_description: Philosophy of religion and philosophical theology at an advanced level. Topics may include arguments for and against the existence of God, the attributes of God, religious pluralism, religion and science, religion and ethics, miracles, and the epistemology of religious belief.

PHIL 340.course_description: An examination of the basic methods and concepts of the sciences through the study of such topics as explanation, confirmation, causality, probability, laws of nature, theories, revolution, reduction and realism.

PHIL 350.course_description: The nature of the state, and of the institutions and practices of which it is comprised; the basis and scope of political obligation, the proper role of political activity; considerations of concepts of sovereignty, legitimacy, limits of state power, representation, social justice, oppression and the like.

PHIL 355.course_name: Aesthetics and the Philosophy of Art
PHIL 355.course_description: Examination of the concept of art and related concepts, and also of aesthetic evaluation and interpretation as they apply to nature and to human artifacts.

PHIL 360.course_description: Concepts and principles involved in analysis and appraisal of social institutions with attention to freedom, rights, justice, and the relation between laws and morality.

PHIL 363.course_name: History of Philosophy: Classical Chinese Philosophy
PHIL 363.course_description: This course is an introduction to the philosophical texts and topics of the “classical” period of Chinese philosophy, from the time of Kongzi (Confucius) through the unification of China in the 3rd century BCE, including Confucian, Mohist, Daoist, and Legalist thinkers. Topics may include, among others: the role of ritual in human life, whether human nature is good or bad, how one becomes a moral person, and the proper role and function of government.

PHIL 364.course_name: History of Philosophy: Ancient Greek Philosophy
PHIL 364.course_description: A survey of early Greek philosophy from the pre-Socratic period to the Hellenistic age. Potential topics include early Greek theories of knowledge, material change, and the good life.

PHIL 366.course_description: Great philosophical thinkers in the rationalist tradition, their problems and their methods: Descartes, Spinoza, Leibniz, et al.

PHIL 367.course_description: Great philosophical thinkers in the empiricist tradition, their problems, and their methods: Locke, Berkeley, Hume, et al.

PHIL 368.course_name: History of Philosophy: Kant and Post-Kantian Philosophy
PHIL 368.course_description: Kant and post-Kantian philosophers, their problems, and their methods: Kant, Nietzshe, Schopenhauer, et al.

PHIL 370.course_description: An examination of selected philosophical thinkers and/or topics from the history of philosophy. Repeatable with different topics up to 9 credits including original course.

PHIL 400.course_description: An individualized course of study not available through or replacing existing curriculum, to be arranged between one matriculating student and sponsoring faculty member. All academic policies and registration deadlines apply. Directed Independent Study courses cannot substitute for General University Requirements and are not eligible for tuition waiver.

PHIL 403.course_description: An examination of the nature of language through the study of such topics as truth, reference, meaning, use, convention, language’s differences from other forms of communication and representation, and language’s relations to thought and reality. The relevance of theories on these topics to selected philosophical issues also will be discussed.

PHIL 410.course_description: An intensive examination of selected topics and methods in epistemology.

PHIL 417.course_description: Examination of a special topic, a particular philosophical issue or the writings of a specific philosopher. Repeatable for credit, but not as a substitute for PHIL 403 or 425.

PHIL 420.course_description: An intensive examination of selected topics and methods in ethical theory.

PHIL 425.course_description: A study of the mind through the examination of such topics as the mind-body problem, intentionality, consciousness, ‘qualia,’ introspection and knowledge of other minds. Philosophical theories on these topics - such as dualism, behaviorism, type physicalism, functionalism and eliminativism.

PHIL 430.course_description: An intensive examination of selected topics and methods in metaphysics.

PA 101.course_description: Through lecture and physical practice, students will gain an understanding of the quantity and quality of exercise essential for developing and maintaining cardiorespiratory fitness, muscular fitness, and flexibility for healthy adults. S/U grading. Kinesiology majors only. Also offered as PE 101 for non-Kinesiology majors.

PA 104.course_description: Through lecture and physical participation, students will learn and practice yoga correctly and safely while enhancing health and well-being. S/U grading. Kinesiology majors only. Also offered as PE 104 for non-Kinesiology majors.

PA 106.course_description: Students will learn and demonstrate intermediate skills through safe Yoga practice including: flexibility, balance strength, mental focus, concentration, meditation, relaxation, breathing techniques, and vibrant health. S/U grading. Also offered as PE 106 for non-Kinesiology majors.

PA 107.course_description: A physical movement class designed to help the non-swimmer to novice develop pool safety skills; learn basic water skills, including floating on front and back; treading water; holding breath underwater and to learn basic crawl stroke; basic elementary backstroke; and flutter kick. S/U grading. Kinesiology majors only. Also offered as PE 107 for non-Kinesiology majors.

PA 108.course_description: Through lecture and physical participation, students will learn correct lifting and spotting technique, the basic muscle groups and weight training principles, and understand types of potential injuries and injury prevention. S/U grading. Kinesiology majors only. Also offered as PE 108 for non-Kinesiology majors.

PA 109.course_description: A physical movement class designed to educate the non-yogi to athlete to understand how to condition for yoga based movement; learn how to work with Clubbells in Yoga asana; learn the signature Clubbell Yoga class format of Awaken, Condition, Practice and Flow; learn how to integrate High Intensity Interval Training timing protocols into a yoga based conditioning class; learn how to differentiate breathing techniques for yoga based movement training. Strong emphasis on preparing students to understand movement patterns, categories of poses and yoga sport specific exercises for eventual Clubbell Yoga intensive course. S/U grading. Kinesiology majors only. Also offered as PE 109 for non-Kinesiology majors.

PA 110.course_description: A physical movement class designed to introduce three types of gentler yoga – Gentle Flow, Yin, and Restorative. This practice focuses on a slower pace to develop a deeper mind-body – breath connection, relieve stress, while increasing strength and flexibility. S/U grading. Also offered as PE 110.

PA 111.course_description: A physical movement class designed to stretch, strengthen, and balance the body with focus on postural symmetry, breath control, abdominal strength, and muscular flexibility utilizing methods from the Pilates program. S/U grading. Kinesiology majors only. Also offered as PE 111 for non-Kinesiology majors.

PA 112.course_description: A physical movement class designed to stretch, strengthen, and balance the body with focus on posture, breath control, abdominal strength, and muscular flexibility utilizing methods from the Pilates program. Intermediate Pilates utilizes the use of props and weights to further develop strength and flexibility while building on the movements established in Beginning Pilates. S/U grading. Also offered as PE 112.

PA 118.course_description: To build upon the principles of Beginning Weight Training (PE 108/PA 108), by adding new concepts, techniques, modalities, and to teach more in-depth neurological and physiological adaptations, and how they are applied to resistance training. Students will design a periodized training program identifying specific training phases. S/U grading. Kinesiology majors only. Also offered as PE 118 for non-Kinesiology majors.

PA 119.course_description: An introductory course designed to teach students the proper techniques of indoor climbing. This class will specifically cover safety considerations, terminology, top rope belay, how to identify a safe climbing pathway and execute the route. Climbing builds strength, muscle, endurance, while strengthening cognitive skills. S/U grading. Kinesiology majors only. Also offered as PE 119 for non-Kinesiology majors.

PA 125.course_description: An interval dance-fitness class that combines Latin and International rhythms with easy to follow steps that focus on cardiovascular benefits and total body toning. S/U grading. Kinesiology majors only. Also offered as PE 125 for non-Kinesiology majors.

PA 132.course_description: Introduction and practice of the basic skills of both singles and doubles court positioning and strategy, game playing rules, scoring and etiquette. Students will work toward proficiency in basic badminton strokes (forehand, backhand, overhead clear, forehand smash, and short serve). S/U grading. Kinesiology majors only. Also offered as PE 132 for non-Kinesiology majors.

PA 134.course_description: Introduction and practice of the basic skills of both singles and doubles court positioning and strategy, game playing rules, scoring and etiquette. Students will work toward proficiency in basic pickleball strokes (forehand, backhand, lob, drop-shot, dink, deep serve, and short serve). S/U grading. Kinesiology majors only. Also offered as PE 134 for non-Kinesiology majors.

PA 139.course_description: Introduction and practice of the basic shots (forehand, backhand, ceiling, back-wall, corner, and kill), rules, scoring, and court etiquette for singles, cut-throat, and doubles court positioning and playing strategy. S/U grading. Also offered as PE 139 for non-Kinesiology majors.

PA 144.course_description: Introduction, practice and demonstration of the basic soccer fundamentals (passing, controls, dribbling, heading, covering, shooting, tackling/jockeying); offensive and defensive concepts; game play, including goalkeeping; and knowledge of the rules of the game. S/U grading. Kinesiology majors only. Also offered as PE 144 for non-Kinesiology majors.

PA 145.course_description: Introduction and practice of the basic individual and game playing skills, including serving, passing, spiking, setting, blocking, digging and floor skills. Students will be able to demonstrate mastery of the basic team patterns and understand the rules of play both in a game and in written form. S/U grading. Kinesiology majors only. Also offered as PE 145 for non-Kinesiology majors.

PA 149.course_description: Introduction and practice of the basic throwing, catching, offense and defensive skills. Students will gain an understanding of the ‘spirit of the game,’ and knowledge of rules and strategies (stacking, flow, cutting, forcing, and defensive set-up). S/U grading. Kinesiology majors only. Also offered as PE 149 for non-Kinesiology majors.

PA 152.course_description: A physical movement class designed to demonstrate punches, kicks, blocks and evasive maneuvers through a well-rounded workout. Improve strength, balance, and endurance while increasing mental awareness with focus on cardiovascular conditioning. S/U grading. Kinesiology majors only. Also offered as PE 152 for non-Kinesiology majors.

PA 153.course_description: By embracing the gentle movements, philosophy, techniques, and mechanisms of Tai Chi Ch’uan, students will be learning the self-defense applications of the art, while strengthening their body’s auto-immune functions for health, healing, and longevity. Also offered as PE 153 for non-Kinesiology majors.

PA 155.course_description: Students will learn and demonstrate intermediate skills based on the practice of the Push Hands or Tui Shou exercise. It is the next step in developing the mind/body connection. Tui Shou is based upon the applications of the T’ai Chi movements and helps to internalize the physical abilities of spontaneously reading and responding to another's energy in order to direct and ultimately control it. S/U Grading. Also offered as PE 155 for non-Kinesiology majors.

PA 167.course_description: An introductory course designed to teach students the fundamentals of mountain biking. This class will include understanding of bike parts and safety considerations to make before starting a ride, proper body position, braking and cornering techniques, trail riding etiquette, basic maintenance, and common trailside repairs. First class session will meet for 1 hour on campus. This mandatory class session will include safety lecture and cover all the logistical matters regarding the class. Class sessions will mostly be held at Galbraith Mountain, the local trail network that is accessible for riders of all skill levels. S\U grading. Also offered as PE 167

PA 168.course_description: The course consists of four systems to develop well-rounded martial arts practitioners. These systems are Escrima, Muay Thai, Jiu-Jitsu, and Defensive Tactics. They seamlessly train students to defend themselves with an impact or edged weapon extending beyond their reach, fight standing up or on the ground, or choose restraint techniques to control an attacker when the threat level is low and extreme force is not warranted. S/U grading. Kinesiology majors only. Also offered as PE 168 for non-Kinesiology majors.

PA 169.course_description: Introduction and practice of personal, physical and mental self-defense skills with significant focus on the use of posture and demeanor to de-escalate potential risk. S/U grading. Kinesiology majors only. Also offered as PE 169 for non-Kinesiology majors.

PA 173.course_description: Swimming for Fitness PE class is designed for intermediate to advanced swimmers looking to enhance their swimming skills, cardiovascular endurance, and overall fitness. Participants will engage in a variety of structured swim workouts, stroke refinement, and conditioning exercises. The course will also cover competitive swimming techniques, open water readiness, and personalized goal setting to help students achieve their fitness objectives. S/U grading. Also offered as PE 173.

PA 177.course_description: Course provides an introduction to the basic skills of Kayak Touring. Including boat handling, rescues, navigation, weather, safety tactics, and tide forecasting and trip planning. Instructional emphasis on the water paddling skills. S/U grading. Kinesiology majors only. Also offered as PE 177 for non-Kinesiology majors.

PE 101.course_description: Through lecture and physical practice, students will gain an understanding of the quantity and quality of exercise essential for developing and maintaining cardiorespiratory fitness, muscular fitness, and flexibility for healthy adults. S/U grading. Also offered as PA 101.

PE 104.course_description: Through lecture and physical participation, students will learn and practice yoga correctly and safely while enhancing health and well-being. S/U grading. Also offered as PA 104.

S/U grading. Also offered as PA 106 for Kinesiology majors only.

PE 112.course_description: A physical movement class designed to stretch, strengthen, and balance the body with focus on posture, breath control, abdominal strength, and muscular flexibility utilizing methods from the Pilates program. Intermediate Pilates utilizes the use of props and weights to further develop strength and flexibility while building on the movements established in Beginning Pilates. S/U grading. Also offered as PA 112.

PE 115.course_description: Personal health and wellness with emphasis on creating positive habits and mindset, physical fitness routine, stress management, nutrition and psychological well-being. S/U grading.

PE 118.course_description: To build upon the principles of Beginning Weight Training (PE 108/PA 108), by adding new concepts, techniques, modalities, and to teach more in-depth neurological and physiological adaptations, and how they are applied to resistance training. Students will design a periodized training program identifying specific training phases. Also offered as PA 118.

PE 119.course_description: An introductory course designed to teach students the proper techniques of indoor climbing. This class will specifically cover safety considerations, terminology, top rope belay, how to identify a safe climbing pathway and execute the route. Climbing builds strength, muscle, endurance, while strengthening cognitive skills. Also offered as PA 119.

PE 125.course_description: An interval dance-fitness class that combines Latin and International rhythms with easy to follow steps that focus on cardiovascular benefits and total body toning. S/U grading. Also offered as PA 125.

Students will work toward proficiency in basic badminton strokes (forehand, backhand, overhead clear, forehand smash, and short serve). S/U grading. Also offered as PA 132.

Students will work toward proficiency in basic pickleball strokes (forehand, backhand, lob, drop-shot, dink, deep serve, and short serve). S/U grading. Also offered as PA 134.

PE 136.course_description: Introduction and practice of the basic strokes (volley, serve, forehand, and backhand), rules, scoring, and court etiquette for singles and doubles tennis court positioning and playing strategy. S/U grading.

PE 139.course_description: Introduction and practice of the basic shots (forehand, backhand, ceiling, back-wall, corner, and kill), rules, scoring, and court etiquette for singles, cut-throat, and doubles court positioning and playing strategy. S/U grading. Also offered as PA 139 for Kinesiology majors only.

PE 144.course_description: Introduction, practice and demonstration of the basic soccer fundamentals (passing, controls, dribbling, heading, covering, shooting, tackling/jockeying); offensive and defensive concepts; game play, including goalkeeping; and knowledge of the rules of the game. S/U grading. Also offered as PA 144.

PE 145.course_description: Introduction and practice of the basic individual and game playing skills, including serving, passing, spiking, setting, blocking, digging and floor skills. Students will be able to demonstrate mastery of the basic team patterns and understand the rules of play both in a game and in written form. S/U grading. Also offered as PA 145.

Students will gain an understanding of the 'spirit of the game,' and knowledge of rules and strategies (stacking, flow, cutting, forcing, and defensive set-up). S/U grading. Also offered as PA 149.

Tui Shou is based upon the applications of the T’ai Chi movements and helps to internalize the physical abilities of spontaneously reading and responding to another's energy in order to direct and ultimately control it. S/U Grading. Also offered as PA 155 for Kinesiology majors only.

PE 167.course_description: An introductory course designed to teach students the fundamentals of mountain biking. This class will include understanding of bike parts and safety considerations to make before starting a ride, proper body position, braking and cornering techniques, trail riding etiquette, basic maintenance, and common trailside repairs. First class session will meet for 1 hour on campus. This mandatory class session will include safety lecture and cover all the logistical matters regarding the class. Class sessions will mostly be held at Galbraith Mountain, the local trail network that is accessible for riders of all skill levels. S/U grading. Also offered as PA 167.

PE 168.course_description: The course consists of four systems to develop well-rounded martial arts practitioners. These systems are Escrima, Muay Thai, Jiu-Jitsu, and Defensive Tactics. They seamlessly train students to defend themselves with an impact or edged weapon extending beyond their reach, fight standing up or on the ground, or choose restraint techniques to control an attacker when the threat level is low and extreme force is not warranted. S/U grading. Also offered as PA 168.

PE 169.course_description: Introduction and practice of personal, physical and mental self-defense skills with significant focus on the use of posture and demeanor to de-escalate potential risk. S/U grading. Also offered as PA 169.

PE 170.course_description: The purpose of the course is to teach students the basics of safe and effective sailing for life long health and enjoyment. Students will learn how to prepare for sailing and safely perform basic sailing skills. S/U grading.

PE 171.course_description: Introduction to collegiate style sailboat racing, including: strategy, boat handling and tactics. Students will receive lectures, demonstrations and use on the water drills to develop the skills and concepts involved in racing. Emphasis on practical application, with racing on the water occurring as often as safe and practical. S/U grading.

PE 173.course_description: Swimming for Fitness PE class is designed for intermediate to advanced swimmers looking to enhance their swimming skills, cardiovascular endurance, and overall fitness. Participants will engage in a variety of structured swim workouts, stroke refinement, and conditioning exercises. The course will also cover competitive swimming techniques, open water readiness, and personalized goal setting to help students achieve their fitness objectives. S/U grading. Also offered as PA 173.

PE 175.course_description: The purpose of the course is to teach students the basics of safe and effective windsurfing for life-long health and enjoyment. Students will learn how to prepare for windsurfing and safely perform basic windsurfing skills. S/U grading.

PE 177.course_description: Course provides an introduction to the basic skills of Kayak Touring. Including boat handling, rescues, navigation, weather, safety tactics, and tide forecasting and trip planning. Instructional emphasis on the water paddling skills. S/U grading. Also offered as PA 177.

PE 179.course_description: Course provides intermediate skills through the use of multiple designs of boats. Techniques for control and efficiency are examined as students learn to sail more complex and challenging boats. With more sophisticated boats and rig adjustments a more sophisticated understanding of the hydro and aerodynamic principles can be gained. S/U grading.

PE 180.course_description: This course is designed to take students on the Salish Sea in kayaks, making a passage from Guemes Island to Sinclair Island where they will experience an overnight camp with “leave no trace” practice. Students will demonstrate boat handling, planning, and safety skills learned in Basic Kayak Touring (PE 177).

PE 181.course_description: This course is designed for the Varsity Athletes.  Each student is required to attend regularly scheduled practices, individual meetings, team meetings, conditioning, games/events, and team activities. Repeatable up to 10 credits.  S/U grading.

PE 183.course_description: This course is designed for the Varsity Athletes.  Each student is required to attend regularly scheduled practices, individual meetings, team meetings, conditioning, games/events, and team activities. Repeatable up to 10 credits.  S/U grading.

PE 185.course_description: This course is designed for the Varsity Athletes.  Each student is required to attend regularly scheduled practices, individual meetings, team meetings, conditioning, games/events, and team activities. Repeatable up to 10 credits.  S/U grading.

PE 189.course_description: This course is designed for the Varsity Athletes.  Each student is required to attend regularly scheduled practices, individual meetings, team meetings, conditioning, games/events, and team activities. Repeatable up to 10 credits.  S/U grading.

PE 190.course_description: This course is designed for the Varsity Athletes.  Each student is required to attend regularly scheduled practices, individual meetings, team meetings, conditioning, games/events, and team activities. Repeatable up to 10 credits.  S/U grading.

PE 192.course_description: This course is designed for the Varsity Athletes.  Each student is required to attend regularly scheduled practices, individual meetings, team meetings, conditioning, games/events, and team activities. Repeatable up to 10 credits.  S/U grading.

PE 193.course_description: This course is designed for the Varsity Athletes.  Each student is required to attend regularly scheduled practices, individual meetings, team meetings, conditioning, games/events, and team activities. Repeatable up to 10 credits.  S/U grading.
