SPAN 103.course_description: Introduction to language and cultures in the Spanish-speaking world. This course builds upon material learned in SPAN 102.

SPAN 104.course_description: Designed for students with two years of high school Spanish or equivalent to prepare them for the intermediate level through review and development of basic structure and vocabulary. Also for students needing a review of the first year. Offered fall only.

SPAN 195.course_name: Introduction to Language and Cultures in the Spanish-Speaking World
SPAN 195.course_description: An introduction to language and cultures in the Spanish-speaking world. S/U grading

SPAN 201.course_description: Review of fundamentals: understanding, speaking, reading and writing.

SPAN 202.course_description: Review of fundamentals: understanding, speaking, reading and writing.

SPAN 203.course_description: Review of fundamentals: understanding, speaking, reading and writing.

SPAN 300.course_description: An individualized course of study not available through or replacing existing curriculum, to be arranged between one matriculating student and sponsoring faculty member. All academic policies and registration deadlines apply. Directed Independent Study courses cannot substitute for General University Requirements and are not eligible for tuition waiver.

SPAN 301.course_description: Language development, including written composition, vocabulary building, analysis of grammatical problems and discussion of selected Spanish texts.

SPAN 302.course_description: Language development, including written composition, vocabulary building, analysis of grammatical problems and discussion of selected Spanish texts.

SPAN 305.course_description: Development of speaking skills in communicative situations. S/U grading.

SPAN 314.course_description: SPAN 314 is a linguistics course on Spanish phonetics - the sounds of Spanish. The course is designed to give students the opportunity to improve their production of the sounds of Spanish, describe the sound inventory of Spanish, and become familiar with the phonetic characteristics of the different varieties of Spanish in the world.

SPAN 333.course_description: Provides students with the practical and cultural knowledge necessary for work in the Spanish-speaking world. Emphasis on professional customs and practice, with considerable vocabulary exposure.

SPAN 334.course_description: Development of vocabulary, communicative skills, research skills, and cultural knowledge relevant to the academic and professional fields of healthcare professions.

SPAN 340.course_description: Selected works of major Hispanic authors, with emphasis on reading improvement and methods of textual interpretation.

SPAN 351.course_name: Survey of the Literature of Spain
SPAN 351.course_description: Historical survey of ten centuries of Spanish (Peninsular) literature.

SPAN 352.course_name: Survey of the Literature of Latin America
SPAN 352.course_description: Historical survey of Latin American literature from the pre-Hispanic period until the present.

SPAN 400.course_description: An individualized course of study not available through or replacing existing curriculum, to be arranged between one matriculating student and sponsoring faculty member. All academic policies and registration deadlines apply. Directed Independent Study courses cannot substitute for General University Requirements and are not eligible for tuition waiver.

SPAN 401.course_description: Review of key grammar topics and special focus on essay writing at the advanced level.

SPAN 404.course_description: This course explores all core areas of Spanish language & linguistics: phonology (sound system), morphology (word formation), semantics (meaning), syntax (phrase formation), and language variation across the Spanish-speaking world. Students will gain a comprehensive understanding of the structure and usage of Spanish.

SPAN 425.course_description: Practicum in teaching Spanish. Repeatable to a maximum of 4 credits, including original course. S/U grading.

SPAN 430.course_description: Selected films and readings. Emphasis on film as a medium through which to achieve understanding of chosen topics in various cultures of the Spanish-speaking world. Repeatable up to 10 credits under different topics, including original course.

SPAN 440.course_description: Study of major areas in Hispanic linguistics. Topics may include history of the Spanish language, lexicology, phonology, morphology, syntax, dialectology or sociolinguistics. Repeatable with different topics to a maximum of 10 credits, including original course.

SPAN 450.course_description: Major authors and movements. Repeatable with different topics up to 10 credits, including original course.

SPAN 500.course_description: An individualized course of study not available through or replacing existing curriculum, to be arranged between one matriculating student and sponsoring faculty member. All academic policies and registration deadlines apply.

SPED 300.course_description: An individualized course of study not available through or replacing existing curriculum, to be arranged between one matriculating student and sponsoring faculty member. All academic policies and registration deadlines apply. Directed Independent Study courses cannot substitute for General University Requirements and are not eligible for tuition waiver.

SPED 301.course_name: Educational Psychology I: Development and Individual Differences
SPED 301.course_description: Principles of human development and individual differences as they relate to both academic and non-academic functioning. Emphasis on implications for P-12 classrooms.

SPED 302.course_name: Educational Psychology II: Motivation, Learning and Assessment
SPED 302.course_description: Principles of human motivation and learning and their implications for P-12 classrooms; basic statistical and applied concepts used in assessment of student performance.

SPED 303.course_description: Principles of human development, learning, and motivation as they relate to both academic and non-academic functioning. Emphasis on implications for P-12 classrooms.

SPED 305.course_name: Introduction to Special Education and Typical/Atypical Development
SPED 305.course_description: This course is an introduction to characteristics, categories of exceptionality, and typical/atypical child development. The course includes examination of provisions of special education and related services. It includes federal and Washington state legislation pertinent to special education from preschool through high school. The course includes content necessary for general and special educators.

SPED 310.course_description: Issues of culture and social justice as they impact education, schools, and teaching. Includes a service learning component.

SPED 350.course_name: Principles of Assessment and Data Based Decision Making
SPED 350.course_description: Introduction to multi-tiered systems of support and the application of curriculum-based evaluation principles of assessment to various tiers in reading, math, written language and content areas. Includes the selection and administration of universal screening tools and interpretation of progress monitoring assessment data as well as problem solving processes. Designed as part of a residency or year-long internship program.

SPED 351.course_description: Introduction to the science of reading for K-12 students in inclusive classrooms: Emphasis on emergent literacy, instructional methods, and assessment in an MTSS framework.

SPED 360.course_description: An introduction to characteristics and categories of exceptionality, and the rules and regulations concerning provision of special education and related services.  Includes federal and Washington state legislation pertinent to special education from preschool through high school.  A minimum of 15 hours of practicum experience required during the quarter.

SPED 363.course_description: Introduction to the characteristics and needs of secondary students with special needs; pertinent federal and state laws; curricular and behavior management adaptations in the regular classroom; assessment of learning problems; instructional techniques; behavior management strategies.

SPED 364.course_description: Introduction to impact of disability and English language acquisition on access to the general education curriculum.  Research-based practices in instructional planning to provide access to all elementary students.

SPED 400.course_description: An individualized course of study not available through or replacing existing curriculum, to be arranged between one matriculating student and sponsoring faculty member. All academic policies and registration deadlines apply. Directed Independent Study courses cannot substitute for General University Requirements and are not eligible for tuition waiver.

SPED 410.course_description: Course provides an overview of classroom management, positive behavior intervention support, and strategies for responding to challenging behavior.  Includes instruction in lesson design, with an emphasis on effectively using direct instruction and applying universal design for learning principles.

SPED 420.course_description: Research-based recommended practices in the design, delivery and evaluation of instruction for diverse learners.

SPED 430.course_description: Legal issues and inclusive practices for diverse populations. A collaborative, problem-solving approach to best practices, with an emphasis on school-based services for students with academic, behavioral, and linguistic needs.

SPED 440.course_description: Practicum experience in school setting designed to provide opportunities to demonstrate effective teaching and behavior management practices.

SPED 441.course_description: Systematic study of teaching; observation; analysis and development of teaching skills and strategies; individual projects. Repeatable to a maximum of 10 credits. S/U grading.

SCED 511.course_description: Assisting with the teaching of an on-campus science methods course for pre-service elementary school teachers. S/U grading.

SCED 512.course_description: Planning and implementing a series of not less than three in-service workshops in elementary school science. Repeatable for elective credit. S/U grading.

SCED 513.course_description: Examination of science curricula for grades K-12 with major emphasis on the elementary grades as a basis for selection of a science curriculum and teacher’s guide for use in local school systems.

SCED 514.course_description: Repeatable to a maximum of 3 cr.

SCED 515.course_description: A seminar addressing the development of a variety of formative and summative assessment techniques and exploring psychometric properties of science items and tests for practicing science teachers.

SCED 517L.course_name: Implementing and Supporting Science Professional Learning Communities
SCED 517L.course_description: This-year long seminar course will provide teachers and principals opportunities for ongoing learning and reflection on the challenges they face in supporting and sustaining effective professional learning communities.

SCED 580.course_name: Special Problems in Science Teaching in the Elementary School
SCED 580.course_description: Problems related to science instruction and curriculum. Repeatable to a maximum of 10 cr.

SCED 582.course_name: Special Topics in the Physical Sciences for Elementary School Teachers
SCED 582.course_description: In-depth study of topics in the physical sciences most appropriate for instruction in the elementary school. Repeatable with instructor and/or graduate advisor permission to a maximum of 8 cr.

SCED 583.course_name: Special Topics in the Biological Sciences for Elementary School Teachers
SCED 583.course_description: In-depth study of topics in the biological sciences most appropriate for instruction in elementary school. Repeatable with instructor and/or graduate advisor permission to a maximum of 8 cr.

SCED 584.course_name: Special Topics in the Earth Sciences for Elementary School Teachers
SCED 584.course_description: In-depth study of topics in earth sciences most appropriate for instruction in the elementary school. Repeatable with instructor and/or graduate advisor permission to a maximum of 8 cr.

SCED 584A.course_description: In-depth study of topics in earth sciences most appropriate for instruction in the elementary school. Repeatable with instructor and/or graduate advisor permission to a maximum of 8 cr.

SCED 590.course_name: Special Problems in Science Teaching in the Junior and Senior High School
SCED 590.course_description: Problems related to science instruction and curriculum. Repeatable with no maximum.

SCED 590S.course_name: Special Problems in Science Teaching in the Junior and Senior High School
SCED 590S.course_description: Problems related to science instruction and curriculum. Repeatable with no maximum.

SCED 592.course_name: Special Topics in the Physical Sciences
SCED 592.course_description: Content topics in chemistry and physics of special interest to secondary teachers. Repeatable with instructor and/or graduate advisor permission to a maximum of 8 cr.

SCED 593.course_name: Special Topics in the Biological Sciences
SCED 593.course_description: Content topics in biology of special interest to the secondary teacher. Repeatable with instructor and/or graduate advisor permission to a maximum of 8 cr.

SCED 594.course_name: Special Topics in the Earth Sciences
SCED 594.course_description: Content topics in geology and related fields of special interest to secondary teachers. Repeatable with instructor and/or graduate advisor permission to a maximum of 8 cr.

SCED 598.course_description: Research in fields of biology, chemistry, earth science, general science, physical science, physics or education for non-thesis option.

SCED 690A.course_description: Restricted to thesis-related research. Repeatable to a maximum of 12 cr.

SCED 690B.course_description: Field project under the direction of a faculty committee. A portion of the field project normally requires work off campus. Repeatable to a maximum of 12 cr. S/U grading.

SEC 300.course_description: An individualized course of study not available through or replacing existing curriculum, to be arranged between one matriculating student and sponsoring faculty member. All academic policies and registration deadlines apply. Directed Independent Study courses cannot substitute for General University Requirements and are not eligible for tuition waiver.

SEC 303.course_description: Study of adolescents in educational and community settings. Application of current theories of adolescent development in secondary classrooms and community contexts. Engage with the wide range of issues that affect the developing adolescent, including language, culture, identity, inequity, racism, media, family, and community factors. Develop skills to collaborate with families and community agencies to support student learning. Includes service-learning component.

SEC 310.course_description: Issues of culture and social justice as they impact education, schools, and teaching. Includes a service-learning component.

SEC 400.course_description: An individualized course of study not available through or replacing existing curriculum, to be arranged between one matriculating student and sponsoring faculty member. All academic policies and registration deadlines apply. Directed Independent Study courses cannot substitute for General University Requirements and are not eligible for tuition waiver.

SEC 410.course_description: Focus on ideas for communicating effectively in schools/classrooms. Oral, visual, and listening communication skills will be examined as part of the teaching/learning process.

SEC 411.course_description: This course examines the central concepts, basic premises and historical underpinnings that frame contemporary ideas of education and teachings practice.

SEC 425.course_name: Developmental Reading, Writing and Learning in Secondary Schools
SEC 425.course_description: Developmental reading, writing and learning skills and strategies specific to content area instruction in the secondary school. Includes techniques for assessing texts, students’ literacy levels; designing appropriate instruction; evolution of literacy definitions, academic language, and the integration of reading and writing with current K-12 Content Standards for instruction and assessment. May include field experience.

SEC 426.course_name: Social Studies for the Secondary School
SEC 426.course_description: Social studies methods, resources, curriculum, objectives, planning. For secondary certification.

SEC 430.course_name: Secondary School Methods I - Instructional Strategies, Daily Planning, and Standards
SEC 430.course_description: An exploration of secondary curricula, lesson planning, instructional strategies and their relationship to assessment and classroom management. Introduces methods to infuse multicultural perspective into instruction and use of multicultural educational resources.

SEC 431.course_name: Secondary School Methods II-Assessment and Long Term Planning
SEC 431.course_description: Develop professional practices that align long-range planning with assessment strategies.  Develop unit plans and collect evidence of student learning through formative and summative assessment.  Articulate that planning and assessment are linked to: classroom and time management; differentiating instruction; problem-based learning and culminating projects; and, community contexts.  Discuss field experiences.

SEC 432.course_name: Secondary School Methods III - Management, Motivation and Discipline
SEC 432.course_description: Study of theories of behavior management, motivation, and disciplinary approaches.  Exploration of family and community contexts and their implications for student behavior.

SEC 433.course_description: Opportunities to collaborate, co-teach, deepen understanding of school culture, and actively facilitate student learning through peer, instructor, and self-evaluations. S/U grading.

SEC 434.course_description: Introduction to the pedagogy of service learning. Addresses the definition, rationale, service-learning techniques, and assessment. Students articulate their own proposed service-learning curriculum. A 2-credit option for the course includes field-based practicum working with a school that is implementing a service-learning program. S/U grading.

SEC 435.course_description: Assigned placement in middle or high school with opportunities to collaborate, co-teach, deepen understanding of school culture, build relationships with students, and actively facilitate student learning. S/U grading.

SEC 436.course_description: Assigned placement in middle or high school with opportunities to collaborate, co-teach, deepen understanding of school culture, build relationships with students, and actively facilitate student learning. S/U grading.

SEC 450.course_description: Designed to give students an overview of middle school curriculum and instruction. Examines various forms of curricula currently used in middle schools, developmental issues concerning middle school students and appropriate instructional strategies. Provides an opportunity to closely examine issues through on-site visits to middle schools in the area.

SEC 451.course_name: Curriculum and Instruction in Middle Schools
SEC 451.course_description: Interdisciplinary middle school curricula; team planning strategies; thematic unit and lesson development; instructional and skill building strategies.

SEC 452.course_description: In-school observation with a focus on the needs of early adolescents; assisting teachers in their classrooms. Reflective journal writing and individual inquiry projects required. S/U grading.

SEC 464.course_description: Preparation for teaching in a multicultural society. Participants will learn how to design a curriculum that reflects diversity and an instructional methodology that promotes the learning of diverse students.

SEC 495.course_description: Supervised teaching experience to develop and demonstrate teaching competence at the junior high/middle school or senior high school level. Interact with diverse students and utilize planning and teaching strategies which attend to needs of diverse populations. S/U including IP grade.

SEC 500.course_description: An individualized course of study not available through or replacing existing curriculum, to be arranged between one matriculating student and sponsoring faculty member. All academic policies and registration deadlines apply.

SEC 501.course_name: Introduction to Educational Research Inquiry for Secondary Teachers
SEC 501.course_description: History, paradigms, and theories of action research in school settings. Examining and interpreting information about student performance; designing and planning school-based inquiry to improve professional teaching practice. May include community service.

SEC 510.course_description: Methods and means of becoming a more effective communicator. Examination and practice of oral, visual and listening communication skills as part of the teaching/learning process. Review of current research in the area of teaching communication practice.

SEC 512.course_description: Examines the central concepts, basic premises and underlying assumptions of controversial issues in contemporary educational practice.

SEC 513.course_name: Seminar in Education, Culture, and Equity
SEC 513.course_description: This seminar examines the larger cultural issues affecting education within social, political and social justice frameworks.

SEC 514.course_name: Teaching and Learning in Secondary Schools I
SEC 514.course_description: This course provides Master in Teaching candidates field experiences in a secondary school setting to intentionally observe, practice, co-teach, reflect, and receive feedback on teaching and learning. This is a companion course to SEC 532. S/U grading.

SEC 515.course_name: Teaching and Learning in Secondary Schools II
SEC 515.course_description: This course continues Master in Teaching candidates’ field experiences in a secondary school setting to intentionally observe, practice, co-teach, reflect, and receive feedback on teaching and learning. This course focuses on assessment and classroom management. This is a companion course to SEC 533. S/U grading.

SEC 524.course_name: Seminar in Secondary School Language Arts Curriculum
SEC 524.course_description: Planning and developing curriculum in language, literature and composition. Advanced study in specialized curriculum design and materials.

SEC 525.course_name: Content Reading, Writing and Communication in Secondary Schools
SEC 525.course_description: Techniques for integrating state and national standards in reading, writing and communication into the various subject areas taught in secondary schools. Strategies for assessing, teaching, and supporting students of diverse skill levels in literacy and with special needs through the context of content-area courses. May include a supervised field experience.

SEC 531.course_description: Advanced study of adolescents in educational settings. Application of the biopsychosocial theories of development of the adolescent to secondary classroom teaching and learning. Define and examine multicultural issues and their effect on the developing adolescent. Communicate and interact with parents and community agencies to support student learning. Includes community service learning component.

SEC 532.course_name: Curriculum and Instruction in Secondary Schools
SEC 532.course_description: Planning and development of curriculum. Advanced study of curriculum design, instructional strategies, unit planning and lesson design. Emphasis on current studies and trends. Introduces methods to infuse multicultural perspective into instruction and the use of multicultural educational resources. Independent research.

SEC 533.course_name: Assessment and Professional Development in Secondary Schools
SEC 533.course_description: Design effective lessons, study a variety of assessment strategies. Create curricula and assessments that address and support the many aspects of diversity. Student portfolio review, certification requirements, legal rights and responsibilities of the profession.

SEC 534.course_name: Management, Motivation and Discipline in the Secondary Schools
SEC 534.course_description: Theories of adolescent development, including issues of diversity as a basis for creating effective learning environments. Emphasis on classroom models of management, creating an individual management plan, and the importance of student motivation.

SEC 550.course_name: Culture, Language, and Equity in Schooling
SEC 550.course_description: This course takes up issues of culture and social justice as they impact schools and teaching. Students will examine their own cultural and linguistic identity - particularly in the context of histories of schooling - and understand how beliefs and perspectives influence teaching. We will explore theory and research on bilingual and biliteracy acquisition and development drawn from critical, sociocultural, cognitive, and sociolinguistic traditions that inform current practice. Finally, we explore foundational concepts in language acquisition for multilingual students, and the historical, legal, theoretical and policy contexts of culturally and linguistically diverse (CLD) students.

SEC 551.course_name: Effective Teaching and Learning in Multilingual Classrooms
SEC 551.course_description: This course introduces students to teaching and learning in multilingual classrooms, including implementing translanguaging strategies, and with a focus on cultural competence. Students will create unit and lesson plans, and engage in backwards planning to inform instruction. Students will use formative assessment to improve teaching and learning. They will develop oral and written presentation skills.

SEC 552.course_description: The focus of this course will be general considerations for assessment, grading, and summative, portfolio, and performance assessment. Additionally, uses and abuses of standardized testing will be addressed as well as school- and district-wide uses of assessment data. This course builds on foundational concepts in both Secondary Education and Multilingual Education, as well as work with planning and implementing instruction. The heart of the course and embedded throughout are considerations for cultural competence and for teaching, learning, and assessment in dual language and multilingual classrooms, including translanguaging strategies.

SEC 555.course_name: Middle School Curriculum Designs and Instructional Strategies
SEC 555.course_description: Current trends in middle-level education; includes a review of developing curriculum ideas endorsed by the National Middle School Association. Physical, social and emotional growth of early adolescents; instructional strategies for middle-level schools; requires topical or action research project.

SEC 580.course_description: Historical and philosophical perspectives on school curriculum as these relate to modern curricula.

SEC 582.course_name: Analysis of Research in Secondary Education
SEC 582.course_description: Examination and analysis of research related to contemporary issues in secondary education.

SEC 590.course_name: Seminar in Analyzing Teaching and Supervision
SEC 590.course_description: Advanced studies in the principles of supervision; utilization of instructional resources and the evaluation and improvement of teaching.

SEC 595.course_description: Supervised teaching experience to develop and demonstrate teaching competence at the middle or senior high school level. Interact with diverse students and utilize planning and teaching strategies which attend to needs of diverse populations. S/U including IP grade.

SEC 598.course_description: Supervised teaching performance. Participants develop plans and procedures designed for the improvement of instruction and submit a plan to the course instructor and appropriate public school authority for classroom implementation and evaluation. Repeatable to a maximum of 12 cr. S/U grading.

SEC 639.course_description: Studies of current topics in Secondary Education.

SEC 690.course_description: Research study under the direction of a faculty committee. S/U grading.

SEC 691.course_description: Graduate research under the direction of a program advisor/committee. S/U grading.

SEC 692.course_description: Graduate research pertaining to the professional practice of teaching at the middle or high school level.  Implementation of a field-based research project under the supervision of a faculty advisor. Work with a critical friends peer-mentoring group to organize and analyze data obtained during field-based research. S/U grading.

SEC 693.course_description: Graduate research pertaining to the professional practice of teaching at the middle or high school level. Compilation of data obtained during field-based research project under the supervision of a faculty advisor. Work with a critical friends peer-mentoring group and faculty advisor to compile the capstone paper. Present research to peers and faculty. S/U grading.

SMNR 101.course_name: Seminar in the Liberal Arts and Sciences for First-Year Students
SMNR 101.course_description: An introductory seminar offering an exploration of academic content and essential questions within the liberal arts and sciences tradition. Includes embedded instruction in academic skills and use of campus resources pertinent to exploration of the FIG cluster theme. Concludes in a formal paper or academic presentation. FIG seminars are linked to FIG clusters or GUR strands. Repeatable under different topics.

SMNR 185.course_description: Want to thrive during your time at WWU and lead a meaningful life you love after college but don’t really know where to begin? Do you want to learn by diving into a wide variety of experiences & activities at WWU to get connected & clearer about what lights you up? And would you enjoy learning from more experienced students at WWU about how they’ve decided what to study & engage in at WWU? Take this course to hone your design thinking skills to create a college experience that works for you.

SMNR 190.course_description: Examination of some social and political systems that impact first-year first-generation students’ academic success. Topics include mentorship training, community building, service-learning accessibility, and cultural capital applications. As a cohort, students will learn ways to respond to institutional effectiveness as they build on their academic strengths.

SMNR 191.course_description: Exploration of community building through on-campus partnerships that are grounded in the common interest of supporting others through their higher educational academic journey. As a cohort students will partake in the planning and organization of on-campus events that celebrates their cultural wealth. Students will adopt ways of thinking analytically to inform their lived experiences as they create common bonds using a cohort model in theory and practice.

SMNR 192.course_description: Investigation of community organizations that are designed to support the lives of vulnerable populations are necessary when seeking positive social justice changes. This seminar course offers students on-hands experiences with Accessibility Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion (ADEI) practices, through volunteer work with off-campus partners, such as nonprofit organizations in Whatcom County. Students will first meet with on-campus partners and partake in training to build their knowledge on ADEI principles prior to turning their knowledge into best practices.

SMNR 201.course_description: Seminar designed to support first year students in: exploring timely academic questions, experiencing a sense of community and connection with a small group of student through community-engaged, active learning, and building relationships with faculty and the community that support your success and thriving at WWU. Repeatable to a maximum of 9 credits under different topics, including original course.

SMNR 385.course_description: Courses on happiness and leading meaningful lives are taking off at universities nationwide. And for good reason. In times of so much uncertainty, isolation and information overload, we need new ways of navigating life outside of traditional approaches to planning for the future. In this course, we will explore content and practice skills that help you live life on purpose and design your life in ways that create a deep sense of meaning and fulfillment especially in times of transition (like graduation or your first years at college). Learn to stop going through the motions of life and stop playing by everyone else's rules and start creating the life you want even when you're not sure what that is or what step to take next. Find your way through the overwhelming array of choices with ease. And learn research-based practices for noticing and reducing stress so it stops driving your life. Together, we will practice experiencing joy, connection, and satisfaction no matter what your life looks like in the moment. This course will be highly experiential and provide opportunities for you to immediately apply course principles to your life.

SOC 221.course_description: Processes determining population growth - fertility, mortality and migration - and their influence on economic development in the more and less-developed countries of the world; population policies in various countries and their implications for population growth and future development.

SOC 234.course_description: This course investigates a range of sociological issues by focusing on a specific topic over the course of one term. Topics may be offered A) based on unique areas of faculty expertise and/or B) in order to address emerging social issues in a timely fashion that are not covered by courses in the current catalog. Students’ learning will include exposure to theoretical perspectives in the discipline, discussion of various methodological approaches to social inquiry, and the opportunity to apply key concepts. Repeatable with different topics to a maximum of 10 credits, including original course. May be taken only once for GUR credit.

SOC 251.course_description: A broad overview of concepts, issues and research findings in the sociological study of deviant behavior; how deviance is defined, reacted to and punished in American society. Emphasis on contemporary theoretical perspectives, along with current issues in deviance.

SOC 255.course_description: A survey of basic concepts, problems and issues in the sociological study of social organizations applied to the criminal justice system.

SOC 260.course_description: Introduction to the study of family as a social institution in society. Overview of social theories on the family and methodological underpinnings of the field of family study. Emphasis on the family as agent of stratification in society, changing roles of men and women in the context of the American family, contemporary issues relating to family social policy today, and the interplay between family and society across time and cultures.

SOC 268.course_description: Introduction to major concepts, issues and research findings regarding the relationship between gender and social structures. Aspects of society examined include education, work, family, law, government and the media. Discussion includes interrelationship between gender, race, class and age. Focus on the U.S., with some cross-national material.

SOC 269.course_description: Introduces students to the sociology of race and ethnic relations in the United States. Surveys racial and ethnic minority groups and provides a historical context for their relative positions in the United States by considering the dynamics of the political and economic climate, racial/ethnic attitudes, interminority relations, and social policy.

SOC 271.course_description: This course will explore sociological approaches to immigration. We will think about why people immigrate, where they go, and the consequences of immigration for both the home and host society. This will help students understand current events.

SOC 300.course_description: An individualized course of study not available through or replacing existing curriculum, to be arranged between one matriculating student and sponsoring faculty member. All academic policies and registration deadlines apply. Directed Independent Study courses cannot substitute for General University Requirements and are not eligible for tuition waiver.

SOC 302.course_description: The emergence of sociology: sociology as response to the Industrial Revolution and as an attempt to develop a scientific understanding of social organization, behavior and change; the development of social thought; Comte, Spencer, Marx, Durkheim and Weber.

SOC 304.course_description: An applied statistics course that introduces students to two important aspects of statistics: (1) graphical and numerical procedures for describing and summarizing data; and (2) quantitative analysis of data to make decisions and predictions and draw inferences. This course also involves the use of computers for statistical analysis and introduces students to the most common statistics used by sociologists.

SOC 306.course_description: Focuses on applying research methods used by sociologists. Examines the principles of research design, the nature of empirical observations, sampling and measurement techniques, and applied narrative and statistical analysis. Engages students in the steps of the research process and examines effective social science writing techniques.

SOC 320.course_name: Computer Applications for Social Science Data
SOC 320.course_description: Designed to integrate fundamental statistical knowledge with direct computer applications for the organization and analysis of data sets encountered in social science research. Training in the use of library statistical routines (e.g., SPSS) central to research in the social sciences is emphasized.

SOC 321.course_description: Systematic introduction to the study of human populations. Designed for students interested in the subject regardless of their major discipline. Examines social, economic and biological factors associated with fertility, mortality and migrations.

SOC 322.course_description: This course examines how groups of people across time and space have enslaved their fellow citizens, neighbors, and families. There is a focus on historical abolitionist movements, as well as contemporary forms of slavery including sex trafficking, bonded labor, and forced marriage. Students will be asked to apply a sociological perspective to these practices to question who is responsible for maintaining them operationally, culturally, and financially.

SOC 326.course_description: This course examines contemporary family life in the United States. We will focus throughout the course on the “diverging destinies” of children and families — a divergence that has occurred as inequality has risen in the U.S. over the past half century. Students who successfully complete the course will achieve an understanding of the historical and contemporary conditions of family life based by studying research that uses the best available sources of data. Students will also read and evaluate social science research in order to understand the forces shaping behavior in contemporary families. The course examines topics such as childbearing, child well-being, cohabitation, single parenthood, marriage, divorce, remarriage, aging, family policy, gendered roles in families, and transnational families. We  consider the causes of change in these family behaviors as well as variation in family patterns across race and ethnicity, class, sexuality, and age. Finally, we will learn about and apply the tools and methods of family demography. These tools will improve our ability to think critically and to be appropriately skeptical when we make statements about causality.

SOC 330.course_description: Examines the relationship between the self and society, including topics such as the nature of the self, the development of self-concept, the social construction of emotions and their impact on sense of self, and the social organization of identity. Emphasizes the theoretical perspective of symbolic interaction and its relationship to qualitative research.

SOC 332.course_description: A social psychological examination of liking, loving and relating. Emphasis on dyadic relationships such as marriage, friendship and parent-child relationships. Topics include socialization into romance and love, historical linkages between industrialization and the ‘feminization’ of love, sociological perspectives on liking and loving, and research methods used in the study of dyadic relationships.

SOC 333.course_description: Basic theories, methods and concepts in the field of social gerontology highlighting demographic trends in aging locally, nationally, and globally, the effects of population aging in developing and developed countries, individual accommodations to the aging process in different societies, the social construction of old age across cultures, and social policy in relation to the stratification of the aged and an increasingly elderly population from a comparative perspective.

SOC 334.course_description: This course provides an overview of various aspects of contemporary Chinese society since the establishment of the People’s Republic of China in 1949. Students will gain basic literacy in the historical, social, cultural, and political domains within contemporary China. In particular, the course will focus on on-going social changes in Reform-era China (1978 - present) related to the party-state regime, civil society, population growth and urbanization, environmental issues, family, kinship, marriage, sexuality, and related topics.

SOC 338.course_description: Human sexuality, with an emphasis on Western cultures and the United States in particular, is studied from a scientific perspective. Emphasis on both description and explanation of patterns and diversity in sexuality. While focusing on the social dimensions of sexuality, the historical, biological and psychological aspects of sexuality are integrated into a comprehensive overview.

SOC 339.course_description: Examines women’s sexuality in contemporary U.S. culture. Focuses on the social construction of women’s stigmatized sexualities and real-world consequences in various arenas. Topics include intersecting identities, sexual mores, mainstream media portrayals, pornography, sexual harassment, violence, sex work, and sexual health. Contains some explicit material. Also offered as WGSS 339.

SOC 340.course_description: Introduction to major theoretical perspectives and research on public and private organizations, such as corporations, schools and health-care facilities. Formal and informal structures, the relationship between organizations and their environments, leadership, decision-making and labor markets.

SOC 341.course_description: This class will explore sociological understandings of social movements, starting with the collective behavior theories of the 1950s and continuing to contemporary, constructivist understandings. Over the course of the class, students will learn how sociologists understand collective action undertaken to bring about social change, examine various theories and models, explore some of the history of social movements in our country, and simulate social movement participation.

SOC 342.course_description: Explores the sociological perspective on religion. Focuses on religion’s persistent relevance to societies and to smaller groups and the effects of secularization. Assesses the social patterns of religious participation, by race, class, immigrant status, age, gender. Investigates the connections between religion and other social institutions such as the economic, educational and political systems.

SOC 345.course_description: This course provides students with broad knowledge about the conditions of contemporary family life in the United States and the sociological forces shaping families. The course emphasizes exposure to original research in family sociology. We will consider the diversity of families, placing a strong emphasis on differences across lines of social class, gender, immigrant status, race and ethnicity, and sexuality. The course incorporates a historical perspective and pays attention to the way that intersectional identities and structural inequalities together define family experiences. The course will draw on research using a wide range of sociological methods, and the specific focus may change across terms and instructors.

SOC 347.course_description: Applies a sociological perspective to gain a better understanding of the consequences of development policies on gender relations in the global South. Critically evaluates how development theory and practice address poverty, health, education, environment, population, domestic-unpaid and paid work. Examines the relationship between women from developed and developing countries in the context of globalization.

SPED 443.course_description: Typical sequences and patterns of development and interrelationships across all areas from prenatal to age eight, and implications of developmental delays and disabilities.

SPED 444.course_name: Assessment and Intervention in Early Childhood Special Education
SPED 444.course_description: Issues and resources related to developmental assessment, intervention, and monitoring of infants, toddlers, and preschoolers with delays and/or disabilities.  Emphasizes family-centered services, cross-cultural competence, activity-based strategies and teaming.

SPED 446.course_description: This course focuses on mentoring students with complex needs in a Transition Program age range. This course builds upon concepts presented in SPED 474 Students With Complex Needs. Topics include vocational education, daily living skills, community-based education, developing leisure and recreation skills, communication skills, motor and medical needs, and assistive technology appropriate for persons with complex needs. The course emphasizes the transition of students with significant needs into post-secondary environments. This course requires a field experience where students will be a peer mentor to students in local school district transition program. This is a flipped classroom. Class time is dedicated to peer mentor activities and readings and assignments are completed independently outside class time. Repeatable to a maximum of 4 credits, including original course.

SPED 450.course_name: Curriculum-Based Evaluation and Norm Referenced Assessment
SPED 450.course_description: This course provides students focusing upon general and special education with information regarding a variety of assessment processes and practices, including the CBE process and norm-reference assessments. Assessments common in elementary and special education classrooms will be explored. Course content will include information regarding assessment skills, descriptive statistics and measurement, types of assessment instruments, data literacy, and issues pertaining to the assessment of students with disabilities and/or from diverse ethnic and linguistic backgrounds. Additionally, students will gain experience administering, scoring, interpreting the results of a variety of norm-referenced test instruments, and report writing.

SPED 451.course_description: This course provides a foundational framework regarding disability laws, eligibility, referral, and legal guidelines regarding development of the IEP. This course also describes professional interactions and the process of developing services across a variety of school-based teams. Student will gain experience writing both 504 plans and IEPs.

SPED 452.course_description: This course teaches the basic principles of behavior analysis, including behavior assessment, planning for crisis intervention, and positive behavior supports. This course includes a practicum component and a program assessment.

SPED 453.course_description: How to create meaningful and legally compliant individual education plans (IEPs) for P-12 students with disabilities in collaboration with families. Includes a focus is on effective communication, problem solving, and cultural competence skills necessary for sustaining collaborative relationships with other professionals, paraeducators, family members and community agencies. Part of a residency/year-long internship program.

SPED 454.course_description: Math instruction and intervention in an inclusive, multi-tiered system of support. Includes the application of curriculum-based evaluation principles for data-based decision making, developing an understanding of emergent numeracy, computation, problem solving, algebra and functional applications of measurement, time and money. Part of a residency or yearlong internship program.

SPED 455.course_name: Behavioral Assessment and Intervention in Inclusive Systems
SPED 455.course_description: Introduction to the practical application of functional behavior assessment, positive behavior supports, and applied behavior analysis for students with behavioral needs. Includes interventions and crisis management strategies and prevention. Part of a residency/yearlong internship program.

SPED 456.course_name: Assessment and Intervention in Written Expression
SPED 456.course_description: Written expression instruction and intervention in an inclusive, multi-tiered system of support. Includes the application of curriculum-based evaluation principles for data-based decision making, developing an understanding of emergent writing skills, syntax and sentence skills, text structure and strategy instruction for written expression. Part of a residency or yearlong internship program.

SPED 457.course_name: Students with Disabilities in Inclusive Classrooms
SPED 457.course_description: Classrooms that successfully include students with disabilities are designed to address the individual needs of all students, whether they have disabilities or not, and to welcome diversity. This class provides an introduction to the characteristics of students with special needs and addresses pertinent federal and state laws and legislation regarding students with disabilities, the rights and responsibilities of educators in providing a free, appropriate public education for all students, curricular and behavior management adaptations and techniques appropriate for inclusive settings.

SPED 460.course_description: This class prepares candidates to create classroom environments that support the success of all learners. Universal and targeted strategies for building and maintaining safe and affirming classrooms are covered.

SPED 462.course_name: Teaching for Learning, Motivation, and Achievement in a Diverse Society
SPED 462.course_description: The class focuses on teaching to improve the attention, memory, motivation, mindset and self-monitoring in a diverse classroom.  Focus of the course is on the application of strategy instruction, academic vocabulary instruction, study skills instruction, assistive technology and current best practice in designing and delivering powerful interventions for learning in an inclusionary setting. Additional emphasis is placed on understanding the impact of a teacher’s mindset, beliefs and dispositions, especially in relation to culture, disability, and ethnicity, on potential student learning outcomes.

SPED 463.course_name: Curriculum-Based Evaluation: Data-Based Assessment for Effective Decision Making
SPED 463.course_description: Curriculum-based assessment procedures, summative and formative evaluation and progress monitoring. Course emphasizes research-based methods that support effective evaluation within the context of the Response to Intervention framework in both general and special education settings. Specific focus is on the implementation of assessment and evaluation procedures, development of IEP goals and objectives, and instructional intervention plans in the areas of math, reading, and written expression. This course includes field experiences in which these assessment and evaluation procedures are practiced.

SPED 464.course_description: This course will provide a foundational framework regarding disability law, specifically Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act of 1974, the Americans with Disabilities Act, and the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act.  Eligibility, referral, and legal guidelines regarding development of the IEP will be investigated. Federal and Washington State regulations regarding provision of special education services will be covered.

SPED 465.course_name: Assessment for Special Education and General Education Teachers
SPED 465.course_description: This course will provide students with information regarding a variety of assessment processes and practices. Course content will include information regarding assessment skills, descriptive statistics and measurement, types of assessment instruments, data literacy, and issues pertaining to the assessment of students with disabilities and/or from diverse ethnic and linguistic backgrounds. Additionally, students will gain experience administering, scoring, interpreting the results of a variety of norm-referenced test instruments, and report writing. Additionally, assessment materials with be interpreted and used to create behavioral objectives and actionable IEP goals.

SPED 466.course_description: Referral and assessment for special education eligibility, norm-referenced and teacher-developed assessments, legal and procedural issues in IEP development, and strategies for assessing students from culturally and linguistically diverse backgrounds.

SPED 467.course_description: Curriculum-based procedures and formative evaluation. Determining present levels of educational performance, developing associated goals and objectives and monitoring progress. Guidelines for implementation of comprehensive Response to Intervention (RtI) procedures.

SPED 468.course_name: Effective Collaboration with Families, Professionals and Community
SPED 468.course_description: Provides students with knowledge and skills for developing and sustaining effective collaborative partnerships with other professionals, paraeducators, family members, and community members.  Focus is on effective communication, problem solving, and cultural competence skills necessary for sustaining collaborative relationships within a diverse society.

SPED 469.course_name: Professional Collaboration: Working with Families, Colleagues, and Community to Promote Student Success
SPED 469.course_description: Provides candidates with knowledge and skills for developing and sustaining effective collaborative partnerships with other professionals, paraeducators, family members, and community members. Focus is on effective communication, problem solving, and cultural competencies for sustaining collaborative relationships within a diverse society. A major component of this course is the effective collaboration necessary for legally compliant and meaningful individualized education plans (IEP) for P-12 students with disabilities. Includes IEP writing and practice.

SPED 470.course_description: This course is designed to present information on the problem of violent and/or aggressive youth in school.  The class will stress an educative approach by focusing on what educators can do to prevent, respond to and follow up on acts of violence. S/U grading.

SPED 471.course_name: Interventions for Learning and Achievement in a Diverse Classroom
SPED 471.course_description: The class focuses on the attention, motivation and self-monitoring skills of students in a diverse classroom. Primary content of the course is on teaching the task-related skills and strategies needed for students to learn efficiently and effectively. Includes a focus on strategy instruction, academic vocabulary and current best practice in designing and delivering interventions for learning. An emphasis is placed on understanding the interaction between one’s mindset, beliefs and dispositions, especially in relation to culture, disability, and ethnicity, on potential student learning outcomes.

SPED 472.course_description: Assessment and intervention for students with intensive behavioral needs including functional behavior assessment, positive behavior supports, crisis management, and applied behavior analysis.

SPED 473.course_description: Exploration of characteristics, identification and special needs of students who are at risk for academic and/or social failure in school due to chemical dependence issues, bilingualism, poverty, dysfunctional family situations or other factors that may interfere with a student’s ability to succeed. Analyzes strategies that combine the skills of special and regular education teachers.

SPED 474.course_description: History, philosophy, characteristics and services for students with low incidence disabilities. Empirically-based design of instruction and monitoring of functional curricula for people who need some level of continual support.

SPED 475.course_description: Seminar in Autism will focus on educational and therapeutic interventions for clients with autism. There is a lab component to this course which requires hands-on intervention with clients with autism

SPED 476.course_description: This practicum course will provide students with an opportunity to observe and familiarize themselves with numerous school and community based placement options for individuals with disabilities. Practicum will include preschool through postsecondary transition experiences with students exhibiting a variety of disabilities. S/U grading.

SPED 478.course_name: Mentoring Equity and Justice for Individuals with Complex Needs
SPED 478.course_description: This course focuses on addressing and mentoring change in systems that have marginalized individuals with complex needs. The course emphasizes a collaborative approach by mentoring community individuals in public school transition programs to integrate and self-advocate in the community and in post-secondary educational settings. Given the premise that ALL individuals can learn, and a desire to see learning progress beyond the public education setting, we will emphasize the need for systemic changes in post-secondary educational systems to remove barriers to inclusion of individuals with complex needs. This course requires field experience in mentoring individuals in the community and on WWU campus.

SPED 479.course_name: Developmental and Remedial Reading Instruction for Inclusive Settings
SPED 479.course_description: Reading theories, assessment, instruction, and modifications are addressed for teachers of reading. Course includes methods for teaching emergent literacy and for fluent reading, especially comprehension. Instructional methods, curricula, and materials; accommodating for individual differences are addressed.

SPED 480.course_description: Practicum experience in school/community settings. Designed to provide opportunities for students to develop, implement, and monitor literacy intervention programs for individuals or small groups of students. Repeatable to a maximum of 3 credits and 3 times, including original course.

SPED 481.course_name: Practicum VI - Individual/Group Intervention, Written Expression
SPED 481.course_description: Practicum experience in school/community settings. Designed to provide opportunities for students to develop, implement, and monitor instructional intervention programs in literacy for small and large groups.

SPED 482.course_description: Practicum experience in school/community settings. Designed to provide opportunities for students to develop, implement, and monitor instructional intervention programs in Math for small and large groups.

SPED 483.course_name: Reading Instruction for Students with Special Needs
SPED 483.course_description: Basic reading instruction for K-12 students in inclusive classrooms; emergent literacy, instructional methods, curriculum and materials; accommodating for individual differences.

SPED 484.course_description: Written expression decision-making and instruction strategies within the context of Response to Intervention. Aligning instructional strategies to student need through the application of problem-solving, progress monitoring and decision making. Focus on topics such as emergent writing skills, mechanics, sentence fluency, and the writing process.

SPED 485.course_description: Designing and teaching mathematics for an inclusive classroom. Course emphasizes pedagogy and methods that support decision-making within the context of an Multi-Tiered System of Supports (MTSS) and Universal Design for Learning (UDL) frameworks. Specific focus is on data-based decision making; design and implementation of research based instructional strategies; and interventions based on student data.

SPED 486.course_name: Case Study Applications in Special Education
SPED 486.course_description: Uses the case study method to present situations frequently encountered in special education settings, in review of special education course content and application in preparation for student teaching internships.

SPED 487.course_description: Designing and teaching written expression for a diverse classroom. Course emphasizes pedagogy and methods that support decision-making within the context of a Response to Intervention framework in both general and special education. Focus is on the application and alignment of assessment, strategies and interventions to student needs through problem-solving, progress monitoring and decision making. Additional topics include emergent writing skills, mechanics, sentence fluency, and the writing process. This course is linked to a field experience for application of concepts in real-world settings as part of a senior project.

SPED 488.course_description: Designing and teaching mathematics for a diverse classroom. Course emphasizes pedagogy and methods that support decision-making within the context of an Multi-Tiered System of Supports (MTSS) and Universal Design for Learning (UDL) frameworks. Focus is on the alignment of and connections between assessment data, instructional practices, and progress monitoring. Specific focus is on data-based decision making; design and implementation of research based instructional strategies; and interventions based on student data. Additional topics include emergent numeracy, computation, problem solving, algebra and functional applications of measurement, time and money.

SPED 489.course_description: Practicum experience in school/community settings. Designed to provide opportunities for students to develop, implement, and monitor instructional interventions. Candidates will have experiences with large and small groups and with individuals with and without disabilities.

SPED 490.course_description: Diagnosis of students, lesson preparation, videotaped peer teaching, analysis of teaching, lesson redesign.

SPED 494.course_description: Supervised general education teaching experience to develop and demonstrate teaching competence at the primary and/or intermediate grade levels. S/U including IP grade.

SPED 496.course_description: Supervised teaching experience to develop and demonstrate teaching competence for exceptional children. Repeatable to 24 credits. S/U including IP grade.

SPED 498.course_description: Supervised teaching experience to develop and demonstrate teaching competence for children and youth with disabilities. S/U including IP grade.

SPED 499.course_description: Supervised teaching experience to develop and demonstrate teaching competence for exceptional children. S/U including IP grade.

SPED 500.course_description: An individualized course of study not available through or replacing existing curriculum, to be arranged between one matriculating student and sponsoring faculty member. All academic policies and registration deadlines apply.

SPED 501.course_description: Introduction to the concepts and procedures of contemporary research within special education. Reviewing, analyzing and interpreting research literature applicable to special education. Planning research with exceptional populations including defining research problems, developing relevant hypotheses, and selecting appropriate research designs (including quantitative and qualitative approaches).

SPED 503.course_description: Systematic analysis, design, development and evaluation of instructional systems and practices for diverse learners. Application of instructional design principles and supporting technologies in P-12 and transitional settings, within decision making frameworks and Response to Intervention.

SPED 510.course_description: Rules, regulations, and related funding categories within special education. Includes specialized instruction and evaluation procedures for use in general education settings.

SPED 518.course_name: Current Issues in Education: Special Education
SPED 518.course_description: Examination and discussion of current issues in special education. Repeatable to a maximum of 10 cr.

SPED 542.course_description: Current issues and best practices in early childhood program design and implementation. Emphasis on family-centered, play-based interagency models that serve children of all abilities. Applied research focus.

SPED 543.course_name: Assessment of Young Children (Birth to 8 Years)
SPED 543.course_description: Issues and resources for accurate and appropriate assessment of young children. Current best practices in instructionally relevant assessment, monitoring child progress and evaluating overall program success. Alternative strategies for assessing the very young child, family needs and special populations. Emphasis on critical  evaluation of instruments, psychometric adequacy and technical aspects of test development.

SPED 544.course_description: Curriculum development and adaptation for infants, toddlers and preschool children. Includes available resources, best practices with the developmentally young and play-based curricula. Focus on model program curricular approaches, the use of daily routines and parent-child interaction as a context and content for curriculum, and peer-mediated learning strategies. Emphasis on efficacy research and the impact of various curricular models.

SPED 560.course_name: Literacy Instruction for Students with Special Needs
SPED 560.course_description: Advanced study of literacy instruction for K-12 students in inclusive classrooms; emphasis on supportive learning environments including computers, adaptive equipment, peer-mediated learning strategies, and accommodation for individual differences; includes theories of literacy acquisition, research-based instructional methods, curriculum and material, related disabilities, and assessment and evaluation.

SPED 562.course_description: Information processing and learning theory as it applies to students with mild disabilities. Discusses assessment and evaluation of cognitive strategies and their application to academic and social skill development.

SPED 563.course_name: Curriculum and Methods in Special Education
SPED 563.course_description: Analysis and application of curricular design, research-based instructional models, and assistive technology with discussions of universal design and legal mandates.

SPED 564.course_description: Applied behavior analysis for children with learning and behavioral problems. Emphasis on functional assessment, single-subject research design and the teaching of social skills.

SPED 565.course_name: Communication and Collaboration in Special Education
SPED 565.course_description: The collaborating teacher’s role in providing special education services to children in integrated settings. Emphasizes instructional and communication skills needed to achieve that role.

SPED 567.course_description: Intensive study of legal, intervention and ethical issues in special education.  Repeatable to a maximum of 6 credits.

SPED 568.course_description: Advanced evaluation and decision-making processes.  Focus on curriculum-based procedures, formative evaluation, and educational decision making.  Emphasis on generating present levels of educational performance and associated goals and objectives.

SPED 570.course_description: This course is designed to present information on the problem of violent and/or aggressive youth in school.  The class will stress an educative approach by focusing on what educators can do to prevent, respond to and follow up on acts of violence. S/U grading.

SPED 590.course_name: Seminar in Demonstration Teaching and Supervision
SPED 590.course_description: Advanced studies in the principles of supervision; utilization of instructional resources and the evaluation and improvement of teaching.

SPED 598.course_description: Full-time residency placement in a special education environment in the public schools. Repeatable to a maximum of 16 cr.

SPED 599.course_description: Full-time teaching placement in a special education environment for ME. certification students. Not applicable to graduate plans of study. Repeatable to 24 credits. S/U grading.

SPED 690.course_description: Research study under the direction of a faculty committee. Repeatable to a maximum of 9 cr. S/U grading.

SPED 691.course_description: Graduate research under the direction of a program advisor/committee. Repeatable to a maximum of 6 credits. S/U grading.

SUST 116.course_description: This course reviews emerging issues in global sustainability studies and introduces students to writing and problem solving skills. Emphases are in multidisciplinary approaches that address complex social, environmental, and economic interrelationships in sustainable development, through exploration of the UN Sustainable Development Goals (UNSDGs). Emphases are in multidisciplinary approaches that address complex social, environmental, and economic interrelationships in sustainable development. Also offered as UEPP 116

SUST 408.course_description: Now, more than ever, we need leaders for sustainability. This course is designed for students who are curious about and eager to lead for a more sustainable and just world. This course will explore what kind of leadership is required to address sustainability and climate change. Together, we will examine how historical notions of leadership might offer lessons, and how we may need to think and act differently. Through the use of articles, case studies, personal reflection, and collaborative inquiry, you will learn key competencies for leading for sustainability. Also offered as LDST 408.

SUST 471.course_description: Introduction to campus sustainability planning as applied to the WWU campus community. Project-based learning and research involving stakeholders across campus. Selected research topics relative to Western’s master planning process pursuit of sustainability. A studio course emphasizing the application of sustainability principles in campus planning, development, and operations. Repeatable to a maximum of 9 credits, including original course. Also offered as UEPP 471.

SUST 495.course_description: This practicum emphasizes applied knowledge and skill development, field experiences, and classroom teaching. Format may include workshops as well as instructor-guided and student self-directed practical exercises both in and out of the classroom. Repeatable with different topics to a maximum of 10 credits and 3 times, including original course. S/U grading.

TEOP 301.course_description: Practicum experience in school setting designed to provide opportunities to demonstrate effective teaching and behavior management practices.

TEOP 302.course_description: Practicum experience in a school setting designed to provide opportunities to demonstrate effective teaching and behavior management practices.

TEOP 303.course_description: Practical application of responsive teaching practices and instructional design principles in inclusive classrooms. Part of a residency program.

TEOP 304.course_description: Practical application of systematic and explicit literacy instruction in a classroom setting. Part of a residency program in Inclusive Education.

TEOP 401.course_name: Practicum 3 – Interventions in Math and Literacy
TEOP 401.course_description: Practicum experience in a school setting designed to provide opportunities to demonstrate effective teaching and behavior management practices.

TEOP 402.course_description: Practicum experience in school setting designed to provide opportunities to demonstrate effective teaching and behavior management practices.

TEOP 403.course_description: Practicum experience in school setting designed to provide opportunities to demonstrate effective teaching and behavior management practices.

TEOP 494.course_description: Supervised teaching experience to develop and demonstrate teaching competence at the primary and/or intermediate grades in general education and in special education. Repeatable to 32 credits. Admission Fall quarter only. S/U including IP grade.

TESL 340.course_name: Strategies for Working with English Language Learners
TESL 340.course_description: Introduction to teaching and learning strategies for supporting and instructing English language learners. Includes fundamentals of curriculum design, lesson planning, assessment, and material evaluation and selection.

TESL 350.course_name: Tutoring and Supporting English Language Learners
TESL 350.course_description: Supervised practicum supporting English Language Learners through tutoring and program support. Repeatable to a maximum of 4 credits, including original course. S/U grading.

TESL 400.course_description: An individualized course of study not available through or replacing existing curriculum, to be arranged between one matriculating student and sponsoring faculty member. All academic policies and registration deadlines apply. Directed Independent Study courses cannot substitute for General University Requirements and are not eligible for tuition waiver.

TESL 411.course_name: Linguistics and Second Language Acquisition for TESOL
TESL 411.course_description: Principles of linguistics (phonetics, phonology, morphology, syntax, semantics, and pragmatics) and second language acquisition with an emphasis on understanding and supporting the language development of English language learners in teaching and learning contexts.

TESL 441.course_name: Instructional Theories and Methods for TESOL
TESL 441.course_description: Exploration of theories and methods of the instruction of English language learners in a variety of contexts, with special emphasis on supporting English language learners in community-based contexts. Includes opportunities to evaluate and demonstrate principles of teaching and supporting reading, writing, speaking, and listening.

TESL 443.course_name: Trends in Instructional Theories and Methods for TESOL
TESL 443.course_description: Investigation, examination, and analysis of specific topics and trends of English language teaching and supporting English language learners. This course is available as a professional/continuing education course for English language teaching professionals. Repeatable to a maximum of 12 credits with different topics, including original course.

TESL 450.course_description: Investigation of specific career and professional opportunities for English language support professionals. Includes opportunities for professional identity development and investigation of trends in the field of TESOL.

TESL 451.course_description: Supervised practicum in supporting English language learners in community-based settings. Includes analysis of strategies for supporting English language learners in applied contexts. Repeatable up to 6 credits with different topics, including original course.

THTR 101.course_name: Introduction to the Art of the Theatre
THTR 101.course_description: An introduction to the nature of the theatre, to plays and the way they work, and to the arts of the theatre and the activities of those who perform them.

THTR 111.course_description: Foundations in Design Communication will introduce theatre design concepts, principles of design composition, and techniques of design representation through drawing, painting, graphic analysis, and model making. In addition to the studio format of the class, students will learn about theatre design through an analysis of an important work of visual culture. Students will analyze important works of world painting and use the deep compositional structure of these works to generate their own designs.

THTR 160.course_description: Fundamentals of acting with emphasis on basic techniques and tools used by the actor. Includes improvisation; resume writing; auditioning; and vocal, physical and emotional awareness.

THTR 168.course_name: Introduction to Film: Acting and Production
THTR 168.course_description: Introduction to rudimentary acting and production techniques, including professional conduct, script analysis and audition process.

THTR 184.course_description: This week-long intensive workshop focuses on writing for the stage – character creation, conflict and structure- resulting in the production of a working script and a staged reading. S/U grading.

THTR 201.course_description: Training eye and ear to appreciate the work of the filmmaker. Analysis of the basic conventions of technique with an emphasis on critical exposition.

THTR 202.course_description: Exploring the development, structure, conventions, aesthetics, historical and cultural facets that comprise a specific genre in film.  Examples include Film Noir, Western, Horror, etc.

THTR 210.course_description: Introduction to theatre design concepts and principles, art techniques and theatre design critical language. Exploration of art media, drawing, painting and design presentation in relation to theatre design through dramatic analysis and design expression.

THTR 212.course_description: Basic theory of planning, drafting, construction and rigging for stagecraft and lighting technology.

THTR 213.course_description: Practice of basic theory in stagecraft and theatre technology. 12 hours of lab required.

THTR 215.course_name: Theatrical Stage Makeup & Hair Styling Techniques
THTR 215.course_description: Theory and practice of applying makeup for the stage with emphasis on character development, facial anatomy and aging. This course focuses on the fundamental hair and makeup skills most commonly needed for professional and academic theatre practitioners for realized production application

THTR 216.course_description: Introduction to costume technology, design and color theory, play analysis, costume history, and drawing/rendering techniques. 8 hours of lab work required.

THTR 218.course_description: An introductory course  focusing on costume figure drawing as a means of conveying costuming ideas through traditional and digital methods.

THTR 228.course_description: A course that analyzes play scripts and the dramatists behind the writing. Also an introduction to dramaturgical research and the technology required to start a career as an emerging theatrical collaborator.
