THTR 255.course_description: Serve as a member of the production crew for a departmental production in the areas of costumes, scenery, lighting, sound, stage management, and general backstage crew. Repeatable to a maximum of 6 credits and 3 times, including original course. S/U grading.

UEPP 440.course_name: Public and Stakeholder Engagement in Energy, Climate, and Environmental Policymaking
UEPP 440.course_description: We examine different types of civic engagement in public policymaking about energy, climate, and environment through the lens of deliberative democracy. Students will learn to think critically and creatively about how the public, business, and organized interest groups can be effectively involved in policymaking. Also offered as ENRG 440.

UEPP 442.course_name: Regional Environmental and Economic  Resource Modeling
UEPP 442.course_description: Spatial resource assessment and planning models, including quality of life, shift-share, input-output and linear programming under resource constraints, and demographic projections. Also offered as ENVS 442.

UEPP 443.course_description: Major intellectual traditions related to urban political economy. Emphasis on questions of social justice, everyday practices, and urban social movements and resistance.

UEPP 451.course_description: Explores history, policy, conflicts, and current events around natural resources, with a particular emphasis on public lands and resource agencies.

UEPP 454.course_description: This course is an introduction to policy analysis as applied to contemporary environmental issues. Topics include competing approaches to evaluating public policy, methods for the assessment of environmental policy alternatives, ethics and policy analysis, and the utilization of policy analysis in decision-making.

UEPP 457.course_description: Course considers several fact patterns involving disputes over natural resources and environmental issues. Students will study and, in some cases, research the facts and will be assigned roles to represent during dispute resolution sessions. Students have the opportunity to practice a range of dispute resolution techniques which may include negotiation, mediation, and other dispute resolution techniques.

UEPP 461.course_description: Land use planning is an attempt to reconcile the conflict between individual property rights and collective environmental goals. This course examines the American legal system’s role in framing and resolving this dilemma. It provides an understanding of the legal framework that creates our unique ‘bottom up’ land use regulatory system. It also examines the practical and philosophical implications of federal constitutional restrictions on local government land use authority, including ‘takings’ and housing discrimination cases.

UEPP 462.course_description: Survey of the philosophy, methods, critical thinking, and analytical techniques used in public planning. Synthesis of the theories drawn from several disciplines and applied to planning. Emphasis on the application of explanatory concepts in planning decision-making.

UEPP 463.course_name: Native American Planning and Natural Resources Policy
UEPP 463.course_description: Survey of political and jurisdictional considerations, treaty rights, and social and environmental conditions facing tribal communities in their pursuit of self-governance and sustainability. Historic federal Indian policy, court rulings and the consideration of off-reservation treaty rights in regional planning. Approaches to intergovernmental cooperation for sustainable natural resources management. Offered alternate years.

UEPP 464.course_description: Survey of diverse roles of professional planners in the public and private sector, including multiple levels of government, non-governmental organizations, and specialized private consulting firms; examination of interaction between these professional planning organizations with broader governmental structures; investigation of their involvement with political, social, economic, and environmental issues. Includes regular field trips.

UEPP 470.course_name: Planning Studio I: Urban Design Methods
UEPP 470.course_description: Processes in community goal making, analytic techniques and methods of site planning and urban design.

UEPP 471.course_description: Introduction to campus sustainability planning as applied to the WWU campus community. Project-based learning and research involving stakeholders across campus. Selected research topics relative to Western’s master planning process pursuit of sustainability. A studio course emphasizing the application of sustainability principles in campus planning, development, and operations. Repeatable to a maximum of 9 credits, including original course. Also offered as SUST 471.

UEPP 472.course_description: HELP2024-25 Western Washington University Catalog Print-Friendly Page (opens a new window)Facebook this Page (opens a new window)Tweet this Page (opens a new window)Add to Portfolio (opens a new window)UEPP 472 - Planning Studio II: Plan Development Analysis and synthesis of significant socioeconomic biophysical and cultural resources used in planning; preparation of a land-use or other plan for a selected region.

UEPP 473.course_description: This is a methods and applications course in land use planning, engaging students in plan implementation. The course will focus on innovative land use regulations but will also include work with capital improvements and market-based strategies. New land use regulations will be designed to enable and facilitate the implementation of projects from Studio I. Students will examine the costs of direct public investment required to implement their plans, and the possibility of employing incentive-based strategies or public-private partnerships.

UEPP 474.course_description: Synthesis and application of principles, practices and policies in sustainable development and the design of projects, processes, and products using a systems approach to promote social, economic, and environmental sustainability. Students apply sustainable design techniques to local regional and international community problems.

UEPP 475.course_description: This course introduces students to concepts of community development in the context of urban change in the United States. It explores community development goals, organizations, strategies, tools, and planning processes. The theory and practice of urban development, neighborhood change, and community organizing will be discussed, with a particular focus on affordable housing and industrial facility siting. Social, economic, and environmental justice considerations and community empowerment is emphasized in this course.

UEPP 493.course_description: Environmental Impact Assessment requires a range of professional qualifications and involves a wide spectrum of disciplines and methodologies. This interdisciplinary capstone course involves class preparation of an impact assessment of a local project, summarizing physical, biological and social aspects of a study area. Review of pertinent laws and EIS documents. Also offered as ESCI 493 and ENVS 493.

UEPP 495.course_description: Experience in teaching a lecture or laboratory course in urban and environmental planning and policy. Repeatable to a maximum of 4 credits, including original course. S/U grading.

UEPP 498A.course_description: A special project carried out under the supervision of a faculty adviser and documented in thesis form according to guidelines supplied by the college. May reflect a single study topic or be part of a major investigation which may take the form of fieldwork, or laboratory, library or community research. Repeatable to a maximum of 15 credits, including original course.

UEPP 498B.course_description: Supervised work experience relevant to urban and environmental planning and policy and appropriate to the student’s program. The one- to three-month experience is documented by a written report prepared according to guidelines supplied by the college. Repeatable to a maximum of 15 credits, including original course. S/U grading.

UEPP 498C.course_description: A special project carried out under supervision of a faculty adviser and documented in non-thesis form suitable to the project. May take the form of some environmental or community activity having either a physical or programmatic result. Repeatable to a maximum of 15 credits, including original course.

UEPP 498D.course_description: While enrolled as a major in the College of the Environment, a student who has undertaken a college-level foreign language study may study for one quarter in a country utilizing that language. International study must be approved in advance and carried out under the supervision of the student’s adviser, must follow the international study guidelines for the student’s major, and relate to the student’s course of study at the College of the Environment. The result of the study must be reported in written, taped, filmed or graphically portrayed form. Repeatable to a maximum of 15 credits, including original course. S/U grading.

UEPP 499.course_description: Student-faculty interaction on topics of general interest. Repeatable to maximum 10 credits, including original course. S/U grading.

UEPP 499A.course_description: Student-faculty interaction on topics of general interest. Repeatable to maximum 10 credits, including original course. Letter grading.

UEPP 500.course_description: An individualized course of study not available through or replacing existing curriculum, to be arranged between one matriculating student and sponsoring faculty member. All academic policies and registration deadlines apply.

UEPP 501.course_name: Histories and Practices of Planning and Environmental Sustainability
UEPP 501.course_description: The course explores root causes of planning and sustainability conflicts – political, cultural, economic, and spatial. Solution-oriented, we focus on key areas where physical planning, programs, and policies can make a difference to the future of cities and regions. How can we help address these formidable challenges and leave a legacy of environmental quality for future generations? A main feature of the course consists of linking critical reflections of dominant discourses with progressive frameworks for transformative, just, and equitable solutions. The course focuses on big ideas, key debates, and broad types of policies and tools.

UEPP 502.course_name: Applied Methods and Ethics in Planning and Environmental Sustainability
UEPP 502.course_description: The course covers methods and ethics in urban planning and environmental sustainability research and practice. The course covers three core areas: methods in planning and sustainability; action research; professional and ethical principles for community engagement.

UEPP 503.course_description: The focus of this course will be on the theory and practice of communicating academic research plans and project deliverables and results in written documents and public presentations.

UEPP 529.course_description: This course introduces students to the discipline of urban design by first briefly tracing some of the main influences, traditions, and fundamentals that shaped it. We then explore ways of seeing urban spaces, the role of the observer, elements of urban design, relations of power in urban form, lived spaces, and “other” spaces. The course also includes an introduction to methods in urban design, primarily in terms of site analysis and urban ethnographic methods. The course structure consists of lectures, readings, discussion, and applied exercises. Readings are posted weekly prior to class. You are expected to complete your reading assignments prior to class. Class time is dedicated to lectures, discussion, in-class exercises, and critique.

UEPP 539.course_description: This course provides students with applied and hands-on experience in urban design. The course adopts a studio format. Students in this course will apply principles and methods to investigate a project site, analyze its components, identify needs and assets, develop socio-spatial programs, and propose forms, uses, and activities that meet needs and aspirations of current and future users. Students will work in teams during part of the research and produce independently individual urban design solutions, scenarios, and projects. The course encourages utopian thinking and the development of “ideal” urban design solutions that are informed by political, economic, cultural, and spatial realities and desires.

UEPP 543.course_name: Social Justice and the City - Advanced Seminar in Urban Studies
UEPP 543.course_description: Advanced seminar covering major intellectual traditions related to urban political economy. Emphasis on questions of social justice, everyday practices, and urban social movements and resistance.

UEPP 549.course_description: This course explores the social and technological changes underway to transition from a fossil-fuel based energy system to a low-carbon system. We study the technology involved with existing and evolving electricity, transportation, food, and building energy systems and then interrogate the social, economic, and political structures that substantiate the existing system or promote change to a low carbon future. Also offered as ENRG 549.

UEPP 551.course_description: The course addresses history, politics, conflicts, and current events around natural resources, with a particular emphasis on public lands.

UEPP 559.course_description: The goal of this course is to explore policymaking and policy implementation in the context of energy technologies. Using case studies we will reveal the multidimensionality and tensions implicit in policy debates. We will assemble a toolbox that enables us to innovate, assess, and promote policy options. Focus will be placed on policy solutions such as common pool resource management, community-based social marketing, civic dialogue, and analytic-deliberation. Also offered as ENRG 559.

UEPP 562.course_description: This course provides a critical overview of urban planning theories. While urban planning draws on many disciplines: urban and regional studies, sociology, political science, geography, and more, this course focuses on the following main questions: What is the relationship between urban planning, the state, and political economy? How does urban planning affect urbanization processes, patterns, and everyday life? How does urban planning as a discipline and practice intersect with the notions of public good, public/private property, democracy, and economic development? What assumptions, historical and social context shaped different utopian conceptualizations of the city?

UEPP 563.course_name: Native American Planning and Natural Resources Management
UEPP 563.course_description: Survey of political and jurisdictional considerations, treaty rights, and social and environmental conditions and conflicts facing tribal communities in their pursuit of self-governance. Consideration of the effects of historic federal Indian policy, court rulings and off-reservation treaty rights in regional planning. Evaluation of effective approaches toward encouraging intergovernmental cooperation in sustainable natural resources management.

UEPP 570.course_name: Planning Studio I: Urban Design Methods
UEPP 570.course_description: This course is a comprehensive studio that applies previous classroom training in urban analysis. Students engage with the planning process through an exploration of planning methods, community engagement, and critical analysis. Various types of plans will be explored along with the processes that take place in their development. The course provides a broad overview of each topic in order for students to gain exposure to these planning techniques and develop effective strategies for inclusive methods that document the voice of communities and amplifies the voice of underrepresented communities in particular. Students will apply the skills and concepts gained through the course to the year-long Urban Transitions Studio (UTS) planning project. There will be an emphasis on participatory methods and urban design research methods.

UEPP 572.course_description: Planning Studio Analysis and synthesis of significant socioeconomic; biophysical and cultural resources used in planning; preparation of a comprehensive land-use or other topical plan for a selected region or urban community.

UEPP 573.course_description: This is a methods and applications course in land use planning, engaging students in plan implementation. The course focuses on innovative land use techniques and regulations but will also include work with capital improvements and market-based strategies. New approaches to land use regulations will be designed to enable and facilitate the implementation of projects from Studio II. Students will examine the costs of direct public investment required to implement their plans, and the possibility of employing incentive-based strategies or public-private partnerships.

UEPP 574.course_description: Synthesis and application of principles, practices and policies in sustainable development and the design of projects, processes, and products using a systems approach to promote social, economic, and environmental sustainability. Students apply sustainable design techniques to local regional and international community problems.

UEPP 575.course_description: This course introduces students to concepts of community development in the context of urban change in the United States. It explores community development goals, organizations, strategies, tools, and planning processes. The theory and practice of urban development, neighborhood change, and community organizing will be discussed, with a particular focus on affordable housing and industrial facility siting. Social, economic, and environmental justice considerations and community empowerment is emphasized in this course.

UEPP 590.course_description: Current trends and issues in urban and environmental planning and policy. Repeatable to a maximum of 3 credits, including original course. Also offered as ENVS 590.

UEPP 593.course_description: Preparation of an objective assessment description of a real natural area including the search for public documentation, evaluation of coverage and specific new analyses. Coordinating role in task group data assembly and editorial review of draft project summaries. Experience directly related to professional responsibilities in the environmental field. Review of assessment utilization in the EIS format and of significant legislation. Also offered as ENVS 593.

UEPP 595.course_description: Experience in teaching a lecture or laboratory course in urban and environmental planning and policy. Repeatable to a maximum of 10 credits, including original course. S/U grading.

UEPP 598.course_description: Individualized research experience in the field, not including research related to thesis or field project. Repeatable to a maximum of 15 credits, including original course.

UEPP 599.course_description: Student-faculty interaction and selected topics across the spectrum of urban studies and planning. Repeatable to maximum 10 credits, including original course. S/U grading.

UEPP 599A.course_description: Selected topics across the spectrum of urban and environmental planning (e.g., urban studies, urban sustainability, planning theory, social justice, etc.) Repeatable to maximum 10 credits, including original course. Letter grading.

UEPP 690.course_description: Thesis research in urban and environmental planning and policy under faculty direction. Repeatable up to 12 credits, including original course. S/U grading.

UEPP 691.course_description: Development of an application of knowledge in practical context. This may take the form or an environmental program in the student’s area of graduate work, such as preparation of curriculum or other educational materials; policy analysis or implementation; planning or design portfolio, or other project. Repeatable to a maximum of 12 credits, including original course. S/U grading.

SOCP 301.course_description: This course is designed to help students understand how to apply the sociology degree to employment in a helping profession. This is the first course in a three-course sequence and will focus on providing students with the information and resources needed to be successful in the program. Topics include, but are not limited to, sociological writing and reading instruction, study skills, professionalization in the workplace training, and an exploration of sociology in different career fields.

SOCP 303.course_name: Statistics for Nonprofit Management and Social Work
SOCP 303.course_description: Understanding statistics is necessary if you are to be a critical consumer of information, both for yourself and your client. Data analysis is used in everything from deciding whether someone can receive a loan to the kind of sentence one may receive when convicted of a crime. This course provides an understanding of basic statistics that is essential for social workers to be effective evidence-based practitioners and researchers. It provides the tools necessary to use data and knowledge to inform what you do – whether that is a high-level policy or the focus of an intervention with a single service user.

SOCP 305.course_description: A survey course designed to give students an introductory look at research and program evaluation. This course will use a practical approach to assess how various methods are used in different environments and for what purpose. Sample topics include evaluation vs research, quantitative methods to evaluate programs - such as survey design, qualitative methods for program evaluation - such as interviews and focus groups. Students will gain a greater understanding of how to gather meaningful data that can be used to enhance programs and apply for grants.

SOCP 307.course_description: This course is designed to provide students with an overview of the theoretical frameworks central to the study of sociology and give them the skills and experience needed to apply those theories to complex social problems and organizational structures through programmatic and policy intervention development. Students will develop a robust sociological theory toolkit that they can leverage to critically analyze and address needs in their professional careers.

SOCP 350.course_name: Patterns of Domestic Violence and Abuse
SOCP 350.course_description: This course examines forms of family violence such as child abuse and neglect, spousal and partner abuse, and elder abuse. The course will examine the history of legalized violence and abuse within families and social changes to better intervene and protect people experiencing violence and abuse. Course topics include theories of abuse, outcomes of abuse, and social and cultural forces that shape people’s experiences of violence and abuse. A major part of this course will look at the social and legal implications, interventions, and preventions.

SOCP 352.course_description: A survey of different religions and analysis of associated practices, customs, beliefs, and rituals in the context of broader social issues and problems. This course examines the costs and benefits of religion in society and how religion is used to confine and liberate people.

SOCP 354.course_description: This course focuses on an examination of the relationship between disability and forms of social and societal inequality. The course considers the social construction of disability, historical and cross-cultural contexts of disability, the roles and responses of institutions and organizations, and how disability intersects with intersections of identity to produce disparate experiences, outcomes, and opportunities for individuals and communities.

SOCP 356.course_description: Through a sociological lens, students will delve into the historical foundations and contemporary manifestations of racial hierarchies, examining how they intersect with issues of power and privilege across various spheres of life including education, employment, healthcare, housing, and the criminal justice system. The course places a strong emphasis on the role of social institutions and policies in perpetuating or challenging racial disparities and encourages students to consider the implications of social justice initiatives and policy reforms.

SOCP 358.course_description: Aging and dying are universal, but how individuals and societies respond to these processes varies drastically and is shaped by social, cultural, historical and structural factors. This course will introduce you to sociological theories, concepts, and empirical findings in the study of aging, dying, bereavement and grief. Specific topics covered include aging and life course, the biology and medical management of aging, end-of-life ethical issues, facing mortality, moving through grief, cross-cultural and ancestral approaches to the transition to death, and more.

SOCP 360.course_description: This course provides a foundation for understanding drugs and society. The course covers an overview of sociological perspectives of drug use and behavior, historical and current drug use trends, examines drug use in individuals and communities, considers societal responses including prohibition, treatment, criminalization, and prevention at local, organizational, institutional, and policy levels. Students will critically engage key controversial debates confronting U.S. citizens and policymakers.

SOCP 362.course_description: Gender and sexuality are organizing principles of society. This course will explore how gender and sexuality are constructed and how these constructions differ across cultures. Much of the course will be framed around how these constructions are used to maintain power through social structures, institutions, and interactions. This course will also examine how race, age, ethnicity, culture, disability, and nation status impact our understanding of gender and sexuality.

SOCP 364.course_description: This course focuses on the social determinants of heath. The course will address how health disparities are defined and measured with a focus on how social inequalities impact who gets sick and who gets care. This course will take a global comparative approach to not just look at health disparities and inequalities in the US, but around the world. Students will be introduced to how health policy is created and reformed and what this looks like around the world. The sociology of health and illness is an extensive area of study. Because of this, the readings incorporate foundational texts and contemporary readings that look at our understanding of health and illness before and after the presence of COVID-19.

SOCP 366.course_description: This course focuses on the multi-dimensional interplay between familial structures and broader societal systems. The course will consider family structures and dynamics across cultural and historical contexts, explore how these dynamics intersect with social institutions such as education, economy, healthcare, and social services, and critically examine how family structures contribute to the reproduction or transformation of norms and inequalities.

SOCP 368.course_description: This course explores various aspects of immigration and migration, examining the causes, processes, and impacts of migration on individuals, societies, and global communities. Through a sociological lens, students will delve into theories of migration, historical and contemporary migration patterns, policy impacts, and integration challenges. Drawing on existing theories and empirical studies, this course will address why people migrate, how citizens respond to migration, how federal and local governments regulate migration and social membership, and how local communities manage the settlement of newcomers. The goal of this course is to foster a comprehensive understanding of migration phenomena, encourage critical thinking about complex migration issues, and develop empathy and cultural sensitivity towards migrants. Within the global context, special attention will be paid to US immigration patterns, policies, and current issues.

SOCP 370.course_description: This course introduces students to the sociological study of homelessness and housing. The course will cover the historical foundations of homelessness in the United States. Building on this, the course will introduce students to the primary research and intervention paradigms in homelessness and housing. The course will utilize a community case study design to introduce students to the work of addressing homelessness and housing crises in the communities they intend to work in.

SOCP 372.course_description: The formulation of law is a social process. The sociology of law is the study of how legality enters political, economic, and cultural practices, who has power to influence legislation, and who benefits. This class focuses on the intricate relationship between legal systems and societal structures and how everyday life creates and incorporates legal meanings and practices. The course will examine how law both shapes and is shaped by social norms and will consider how legal frameworks and systems impact and shape the opportunities and trajectories of individuals and communities. Individual and organizational processes are governed by laws and laws are used for domination and for social change. This course will cover the basics of what the sociology of law is, what laws are and how they operate, the influence of sociology in the creation and study of the legal system, punishment, jurisprudence, and the future of the sociology of law.

SOCP 374.course_description: This course focuses on the sociological study of stratification, inequality, and poverty in Urban and Rural contexts. The course will first introduce students to the foundations of sociological stratification and inequality theories and research paradigms. Then, the course will turn to spatial considerations of these topics in both rural and urban contexts with an opportunity for application in real world settings.

SOCP 376.course_description: This course focuses on the conceptual category of youth. Questions that will be addressed include: How has the category of youth changed and remained the same overtime? How is youth defined across different cultures and communities? What drives the definition of youth? How is youth experience defined and refined by identity? How does family include childhood and youth development in positive and negative ways? When and how do social institutions like education and work influence youth? How do youth respond to social inequalities and issues of justice? The goal of this course is for students to reflect on their experience as a young person and assess how society includes and excludes youth, which youth are included or excluded, and why these systems of youth inclusion and exclusions might exist. Furthermore, students will be asked to assess how these concepts apply to the work they hope to do in the future.

SOCP 401.course_description: The goal of this course is to provide students with valuable exposure and concrete experience in a professional field related to sociology while building robust partnerships with local and global agencies. Students will have the opportunity to apply the knowledge they have gained in their sociology course work and to practice using sociological frameworks and methods in applied professional settings. Students will learn how to frame their internship experience as part of their broader education portfolio and to leverage that portfolio in their pursuit of post-graduation plans. Repeatable to a maximum of 15 credits, including original course.

SOCP 403.course_description: Professional Development 2 is designed for sociology majors aspiring to pursue careers in social work or other helping professions. This course aims to equip students with the necessary skills and knowledge to engage effectively with community partners as emerging professionals. This second course in the professional development sequence will focus on preparing students to engage with community partners as professionals and will include resume development, internship opportunity exploration and application, and interview skills training.

SOCP 405.course_description: This is the third class in the sequence of professional development courses to assist you in college and beyond. In the first course, you should have explored the resources needed to be successful in college (e.g., reading instruction, study skills, professionalization in the workplace, and an exploration of sociology). In the second course, you should have been exposed to engagement with community partners as professionals (e.g, working with community partners, resume development, internship opportunity exploration, and interview skills training). The third course focuses on preparing you for their post-graduation pathways. Content will include resume tailoring, graduate school and job application materials, online profile development, reference requests, advanced interviewing training, and find positions (paid and internships) they are interested in applying to, and professional career development.

WGSS 211.course_name: Introduction to Women, Gender, and Sexuality Studies
WGSS 211.course_description: Introduction to the issues, questions, conceptual frameworks, and methods basic to women, gender, and sexuality studies.

WGSS 212.course_description: This course is meant to introduce students to feminist thought. Through engagement with primary theoretical texts, students will become familiar with the core theorists and central arguments of feminist theory. At the end of the course, students will be knowledgeable on the various ways that the term feminism has and continues to be used in social, political, artistic, and economic contexts.

WGSS 213.course_name: Introduction to Sexuality and Queer Studies
WGSS 213.course_description: This course introduces students to the interdisciplinary field of Sexuality Studies with a focus on the insights of the field of Queer Studies. Students will draw upon intellectual approaches to sexuality ranging from the arts and humanities to the social and natural sciences. Course addresses different permutations of the desires, identities, and practices that constitute sexuality in the US, the Arab Middle East, and Filipino/a diaspora.

WGSS 300.course_description: An individualized course of study not available through or replacing existing curriculum, to be arranged between one matriculating student and sponsoring faculty member. All academic policies and registration deadlines apply. Directed Independent Study courses cannot substitute for General University Requirements and are not eligible for tuition waiver.

WGSS 310.course_description: Examines how race, ethnicity, and indigeneity shape and inform local and global understandings of sex, gender, and sexuality. Students will address intersectional and de-colonial feminist and gender studies and question how settler colonialism and racism impact possibilities and strategies for gender justice.

WGSS 314.course_description: Examines transnational feminism and examines the strategies women develop to resist global patriarchal structures, how definitions of gender and sexuality are reproduced, negotiated, and deployed, and forms of organization and mobilization in the context of globalization and transnational flows.

WGSS 317.course_description: The purpose of this class is to explore what women have done during times of war and how war has affected their lives, focused on recent and ongoing conflicts across the globe, especially those in which the United States plays a role.

WGSS 320.course_name: Topics in Women, Gender, and Sexuality Studies
WGSS 320.course_description: Focus on special topics in women, gender, and sexuality studies. Readings and/or topic area to be determined by instructor. Repeatable up to 15 credits with different topics, including original course. May be taken only once for GUR credit.

WGSS 331.course_description: This course will examine gender theory, with varying emphases, including but not limited to feminist, queer, trans, intersectional and critical race theory. Repeatable with different topics up to 10 credits including original course. Also offered as ENG 331.

WGSS 335.course_description: From the alternate kinship models of superheroes and other protagonists to the marginalization of comics’ visual and narrative production as “less than” art, to the courting of outsider audiences in the formation of various counterpublics, comics have always been queer. In this course, we will closely read, respond to, and analyze a wide range of texts in order to gain some understanding of how comics are situated in historical, cultural, social, and political contexts. Students will exercise and refine textual and cultural analysis skills by examining how an author utilizes context, form, visual cues, language, and other elements of sequential art.

WGSS 339.course_description: Examines women’s sexuality in contemporary U.S. culture. Focuses on the social construction of women’s stigmatized sexualities and real-world consequences in various arenas. Topics include intersecting identities, sexual mores, mainstream media portrayals, pornography, sexual harassment, violence, sex work, and sexual health. Contains some explicit material. Also offered as SOC 339.

WGSS 344.course_description: This course examines how constructions of gender, sexuality and age shape possibilities to imagine queer and transgender childhoods and lives.

WGSS 348.course_description: Although men’s experiences and perspectives have long dominated academic inquiry, their work has been mistakenly assumed to be universal for humanity rather than analyzed as having gender-specific particularities. This course provides a feminist and queer perspective on men, masculinity, and manliness in the United States from the colonial era to today.

WGSS 350.course_description: This course examines feminist and queer methodologies in the social sciences and humanities.

WGSS 356.course_description: This course surveys how historians approach the topic of gender and how the discipline of Gender Studies has altered the way professionals study history. Rather than focusing on a particular region or era, this course examines how notions of femininity, masculinity, and the relationships between the two have changed and endured across different temporal and spatial contexts. Students will learn about the development of gender as a category of historical analysis, the growth of interdisciplinary approaches to gender in and out of academe, and current approaches to both gendering history and historicizing gender.  Also offered as HIST 356.

WGSS 358.course_name: Women of Color in the U.S.
WGSS 358.course_description: This course addresses the experiences and struggles of women of color in the United States both historically and today. In order to understand people in their own terms, we will read primary documents and secondary sources authored exclusively by women of color. Our overall goal is to better acquaint ourselves with the histories of women of color in order to better apprehend where they have been and where they are going, with a special emphasis on how they have been marginalized in the disciplines of History and Gender Studies. Also offered as HIST 358.

WGSS 363.course_description: Over the term we will examine the historical contexts that inform food injustice and food insecurity. This course centers Indigenous and people of color led feminist informed movements for food and land sovereignty.

WGSS 365.course_description: This course considers how popular culture provides us with the scripts to create and practice femininities, masculinities, and sexualities, and how these practices are infused with race and class. We will examine the ways in which popular culture, broadly defined, helps to shape our cultural ideas about intersectional gender differences.

WGSS 367.course_description: This class explores the fields of Disability Studies and Feminist Studies to see what each can bring to the other.

WGSS 372.course_description: This course critically explores how gender is considered through media. By investigating media texts, audiences, producers, and technologies, students will learn to identify the ways in which media may uphold the status quo and also be harnessed to resist the status quo.

WGSS 400.course_description: An individualized course of study not available through or replacing existing curriculum, to be arranged between one matriculating student and sponsoring faculty member. All academic policies and registration deadlines apply. Directed Independent Study courses cannot substitute for General University Requirements and are not eligible for tuition waiver.

WGSS 410.course_description: Under supervision of a WGSS faculty member and/or in the context of a seminar of interdisciplinary readings, students will work in a community or activist setting.

WGSS 411.course_description: Research based writing or field project under direction of faculty advisor.

WGSS 450.course_name: Capstone Seminar in Women, Gender, and Sexuality Studies
WGSS 450.course_description: Capstone seminar in Women, Gender, and Sexuality Studies. Involves reading and research in original sources on topics of central importance to women, gender, and sexuality. Repeatable with different topics to a maximum of 10 credits, including original course.

WGSS 453.course_description: Explores women’s economic, religious, political and familial roles through topics such as development and globalization, violence, and women’s movements. Student contributions to course topics emphasized through individual papers and group panel work. Also offered as ANTH 453.

THTR 256.course_description: Practical experience in rehearsal and performance for a departmental production. Must be cast in a departmental production to receive credit. Repeatable to a maximum of 6 credits and 6 times, including the original course. S/U grading.

THTR 260.course_description: Exploration of the theory of the physical, vocal, intellectual and emotional instrument of the individual actor in relation to character demands of a scene or play through the studio approach. Students demonstrate their knowledge of theory in both written and oral forms.

THTR 261.course_name: Voice Studio I: Voice and Breath
THTR 261.course_description: The fundamentals of Voice and Speech for Actors with an emphasis on developing resonance, finding vocal variety, and communicating with clarity and efficiency. Includes work with dramatic and poetic text.

THTR 263.course_description: An actor’s introduction to the history, vocabulary and basic techniques of several styles of theatrical movement and dance. Topics may include ballet, modern, jazz, tap, hip-hop, mask, combat and period styles. The actor will also explore character development through movement and dance. Repeatable to a maximum of 6 cr.

THTR 264.course_description: An introduction to Jerzy Grotowski’s approach to acting, resulting in scene work based on emotional need discovered through movement.

THTR 266.course_description: A performance-based course providing the fundamentals of singing for actors and dancers with an emphasis on vocal technique, coordination, musicality, and expression. Musical Theatre repertoire will be prepared, explored, and coached in class.

THTR 300.course_description: An individualized course of study not available through or replacing existing curriculum, to be arranged between one matriculating student and sponsoring faculty member. All academic policies and registration deadlines apply. Directed Independent Study courses cannot substitute for General University Requirements and are not eligible for tuition waiver.

THTR 301.course_description: Theory, critical language, play analysis and engineering of sound design for the stage. Repeatable to a maximum of 6 credits, including original course.

THTR 309.course_description: This course introduces students to the social, historical and artistic forces behind period styles.

THTR 310.course_description: A survey of traditional scene painting with emphasis on color, technique, materials, tools and formulas.

THTR 311.course_description: Investigates how stage designers create a visual world for works of drama, music and dance.

THTR 312.course_description: This course introduces students to digital media drawing techniques using industry standard software.

THTR 313.course_description: Technical and artistic study of light and color as they affect other theatre arts and contribute to artistic design; laboratory work in production.

THTR 314.course_description: An in-depth study of the stage manager’s role and responsibilities before, during and after production. Assignment to one major production.

THTR 315.course_description: An advanced study of the history, technique and application of theatrical make-up. Repeatable up to 6 credits, including original course.

THTR 316.course_description: Theory, critical language, play analysis and studio experience for design and rendering of costumes for the stage.

THTR 318.course_description: Design, construction and manipulation of puppets with focus on the history of puppets and puppet making.

THTR 319.course_description: History, design and construction of hats for the theatre.

THTR 320.course_description: Practical working knowledge of drafting and design software.

THTR 321.course_description: This course introduces concepts and methods of digital design composition appropriate for theater designers, engineers, artists and students of any field that work with physical and digital models.

THTR 322.course_description: Beginning and intermediate skill-building in classic improvisation techniques, focusing on the ability to play and lead improvisation games and activities effectively.

THTR 323.course_name: Adobe Creative Suite for Entertainment Design
THTR 323.course_description: Software and digital media create much of the visual content in contemporary entertainment design. This course is intended to introduce students to the software that creates digital images and time-based media content. Course content will include technical information about the digital tools and commands available, detailed instruction in Photoshop and After Effects for content creation, and discuss the workflow for design industries.

THTR 324.course_description: This course will introduce projection and media design for live performance and entertainment design. The course will cover content creation, media software, and projection systems.

THTR 326.course_description: A course in advanced AutoCad which will teach students a professional working knowledge of the advanced commands, drawing management, and file structures.

THTR 328.course_description: Dramaturgy for the theatre discipline: including review and critique, technical writing and methods of production research.

THTR 330.course_description: A teaching assistant position designed to provide theatre students with experience and guidance in assisting an instructor in a particular theatre course. Repeatable up to a maximum of 6 credits and 6 times, including original course.

THTR 350.course_description: Exploration of the history, philosophy, literature and techniques for creating theatre for young audiences.

THTR 351.course_description: Instructional methods in theatre arts, design, analysis and practical application of theatre arts techniques and pedagogy through observation, seminar and practicum in the theatre department.

THTR 353.course_description: An intensive and comprehensive involvement in the study and practice of creating and performing theatre for youth. The first part of the course is dedicated to building the show as an ensemble and the second part of the course is comprised of touring the show to area elementary schools.

THTR 354.course_description: Participants prepare all aspects of a touring production and accompanying educational support materials offered to elementary or secondary schools in Washington. This is a two-quarter commitment. Repeatable once for a maximum of 6 credits.

THTR 355.course_description: Practical experience as an assistant designer or other assistant technical role on a departmental production in the areas of costumes/makeup, scenery, lighting, sound, and stage management. Repeatable to a maximum of 10 credits and 5 times, including original course.

THTR 356.course_description: Practical experience in rehearsal and performance for a departmental production. Must be cast in a departmental production to receive credit. Repeatable to a maximum of 10 credits and 10 times, including original course. S/U grading.

THTR 360.course_description: Continuation of skills and refinement of techniques presented in earlier acting studios, but with a strong emphasis on the use of the body and physical characterization. Scene work of several periods and styles is required.

THTR 361.course_name: Voice Studio II: Speech and Language
THTR 361.course_description: Continued refinement of skills and techniques presented in Voice Studio I, but with strong emphasis on diction and clarity of speech. Includes work with dialects and challenging dramatic text.

THTR 362.course_description: Preparation course for students selected to compete in the Kennedy Center’s American College Theatre Festival’s Irene Ryans acting competition and URTA graduate school auditions. Repeatable up to a maximum of three credits, including original course.

THTR 363.course_description: Sequence of exercises and drills challenging improvement in resonation, breath support, articulation, relaxation, placement and vocal work ranging from good stage speech (mid-Atlantic) to dialect.

THTR 364.course_description: An introductory exploration of the Suzuki and Viewpoints actors training movement systems intended to build an actor’s awareness of their body, especially the center. The method uses exercises that are inspired by Greek theater as well as martial arts and requires great amounts of energy and concentration allowing greater awareness of natural expressiveness in order to commit more fully to the physical and emotional requirements of acting.

THTR 366.course_description: Practical application of singing and acting to performance-related work from American musical theatre through solo, duet and group exploration.

THTR 368.course_description: An exploration and application of techniques and approaches for actors reflected currently in the film and television industry.

THTR 370.course_description: Theory and practice of stage direction including selection of play, casting and blocking. Production of a scene for public performance is required.

THTR 371.course_description: Individualized practicum in directing for the stage. Repeatable up to 6 credits.

THTR 380.course_description: Development of theatre to the Renaissance.

THTR 381.course_description: Development of theatre from the Renaissance to the beginning of realism.

THTR 382.course_description: Development of theatre from the beginnings of realism to contemporary theatre.

THTR 383.course_description: Evolution of costume from ancient Greece through present-day fashion with reference to theatrical production.

THTR 384.course_description: Beginning exercise in dramatic writing, with emphasis on primary forms and conventions.

THTR 385.course_name: Topics in Intermediate Costume Technology and Construction
THTR 385.course_description: Course focuses on varied costume technology and construction methods. Repeatable to a maximum of 9 credits, including original course.

THTR 398.course_description: This arts education course provides future teachers with a foundation in the elements and principles of Visual Art, Dance, Music and Theatre and their applicability to the elementary classroom. (Also offered as ART 398, MUS 398 and DNC 398).

THTR 400.course_description: An individualized course of study not available through or replacing existing curriculum, to be arranged between one matriculating student and sponsoring faculty member. All academic policies and registration deadlines apply. Directed Independent Study courses cannot substitute for General University Requirements and are not eligible for tuition waiver.

THTR 411.course_description: Contemporary stage design practice and theory with an emphasis on artistic interpretation of dramatic literature and music as a visual design.

THTR 412.course_description: Technical analysis of scripts, special effects, computers and properties. Laboratory work on productions.

THTR 413.course_description: Concepts and techniques of drafting and computer-assisted drafting, text work sheets, and application programs related to lighting design.

THTR 414.course_description: Examination of advanced skills and approaches to stage management in the theatre. This includes running rehearsals, managing productions and meetings, Actors Equity Association rules and guidelines, and exercises in clear communication, leadership, and organization.

THTR 416.course_description: Exploration and execution of complete designs of costumes for the modern theatre with emphasis on the development of the design concept and interpretation.

THTR 420.course_name: Advanced Theatre Design and Portfolio Development
THTR 420.course_description: Exploration and project execution of complete design paper project including all supporting technical and research materials leading to a final presentation of designer portfolio.

THTR 428.course_description: The in-depth exploration of an individual playwright or group of playwrights, or performance genre such as devising, opera, theatre and community, or theatre for social change. Courses will be taught as seminar only and/or combination seminar plus lab. Credits vary from three to four dependent on course offered. Repeatable with different topics up to 8 credits, including original course.

THTR 450.course_description: Advanced techniques in youth theatre. Each student selects and prepares a script for performance for and/or by youth.

THTR 452.course_description: Exploration of techniques and curriculum for use in secondary theatre classrooms. Creation of lesson plans and projects aimed specifically for theatre students.  This course has a required academic Service-Learning component.

THTR 455.course_description: Practical experience as a designer or other lead technical role on a departmental production in the areas of costumes/makeup, scenery, lighting, sound, and stage management. Repeatable to a maximum of 10 credits and 2 times, including original course.

THTR 460.course_name: Acting Studio III: Audition Technique and Professional Preparation
THTR 460.course_description: Continued refinement of skills and techniques introduced in previous studios, with special emphasis on auditioning and professional preparation.

THTR 461.course_description: Continued refinement of skills and techniques presented in Voice Studio II, with a strong emphasis on the robust use of text and language as exemplified in the plays of Shakespeare, and other plays with heightened text.

THTR 462.course_description: Students study specific advanced acting techniques and styles and apply them directly through production performance. Repeatable with different topics up to a maximum of 10 credits.

THTR 463.course_description: Preparation of several contrasting monologues and development of specific performance skills to best demonstrate the varied talents of the individual actor in an audition format. S/U grading.

THTR 464.course_description: An advanced exploration of the Suzuki, Viewpoints, and Grotowski actor training movement systems.

THTR 465.course_description: Offered only summer quarter. Contact director of theatre for details. Repeatable once.

THTR 470.course_description: Producing and directing a one-act play for public performance; special emphasis on working with the actor.

THTR 471.course_description: Individualized practicum in directing for the stage. Repeatable up to 6 credits.

THTR 480.course_description: Students devise an original work for the main stage theatre season through phases of research, creation, and development.  All students write, design, and perform the piece.

THTR 485.course_description: Opportunity for disciplined expression in writing for stage, film, television or other media. May be repeated under separate topics to a maximum of 12 credits.

THTR 495.course_description: Qualified third- and fourth-year students may apply to apprentice with theatre companies, performing arts agencies or producing organizations. Repeatable to a maximum of 24 cr. S/U grading.

THTR 496.course_description: Capstone research or reflective thesis demonstrating deep knowledge of an area within the student’s declared theatre concentration. Topics are arranged in conjunction with and approval from student’s departmental advisor.

UEPP 110.course_name: Ecogastronomy: The Science and Sustainability of Food
UEPP 110.course_description: This course is an introduction to the science and sustainability of “good” food as it is produced and consumed in various social, cultural, economic, political, and physical science settings. Over the course of the quarter, we will consider gastronomic sciences that focus on taste and sensory awareness, as well as clean and just food production.

UEPP 111.course_description: This course is a discussion section to the art and appreciation of “good” food to accompany UEPP 110: An Introduction to the Science and Sustainability of Food. The class will include discussion of the regional geography of agriculture and consumption patterns, Slow Food as a social movement, gastronomic sciences that focus on taste and sensory awareness, clean and just food production and the co-optation of “sustainable” and “organic” agriculture.

UEPP 116.course_description: This course reviews emerging issues in global sustainability studies and introduces students to writing and problem solving skills. Emphases are in multidisciplinary approaches that address complex social, environmental, and economic interrelationships in sustainable development, through exploration of the UN Sustainable Development Goals (UNSDGs). Emphases are in multidisciplinary approaches that address complex social, environmental, and economic interrelationships in sustainable development. Also offered as SUST 116.

UEPP 170.course_description: A survey of professions and research fields working to develop urban and environmental planning and policy solutions to contemporary local and global problems.

UEPP 202.course_description: A basic overview of environmental issues in the United States and globally. An emphasis will be placed on environmental and human sustainability in a social science context.

UEPP 261.course_description: This course will address the principles and practices in urban development and public planning in the United States as well as the concepts of planning as a community process and professional activity. Students will also touch on evolution of planning ideas in response to changing social, economic, and environmental conditions within the American political framework, survey of the specialized fields in planning practice, and emphasizing the emerging field of environmental planning.

UEPP 270.course_description: A survey of environmental, social, economic, and political issues facing urban populations in North America and around the world.

UEPP 300.course_description: An individualized course of study not available through or replacing existing curriculum, to be arranged between one matriculating student and sponsoring faculty member. All academic policies and registration deadlines apply. Directed Independent Study courses cannot substitute for General University Requirements and are not eligible for tuition waiver.

UEPP 302.course_description: This course aims to help students develop their research and public communication skills for an evolving information atmosphere and politics.

UEPP 314.course_name: Food security, policy, and practica: Special topics
UEPP 314.course_description: Food security programs need to deliver nutrient-dense, culturally-appropriate, environmentally-sound, and cost-effective foods. This course provides a critical link from food policies, including the FDA Food Safety Modernization Act, to sustainable food practices. Practica illustrate issues in food processing to deliver safe and nutritious products, on different geographic scales. Topics vary, but the special case of cheese is highlighted, as it is a key component of USDA commodity distribution programs. It also is the nexus of many debates in food safety, food waste, and climate change.

UEPP 322.course_name: Quantitative Methods for Planning and Policy
UEPP 322.course_description: An introduction to Geographic Information Systems (GIS) technology and quantitative analysis software tools introducing planning students to spatial and quantitative data analysis and presentation skills.

UEPP 343.course_description: Geographic focus upon the development, functions, and problems of the modern city with emphasis on American patterns.

UEPP 350.course_description: This course will allow students to understand the history of energy policy and regulation within the US, with a focus on the interplay among energy science/technology, social justice, and policy. A specific focus will be placed on energy issues as they pertain to the Pacific Northwest. Also offered as ENRG 350.

UEPP 355.course_description: Environmental law and policy provide tools to prevent and address environmental harm. Explore, analyze, and critique policy tools and processes relating to air and water quality, hazardous wastes, and species protection.

UEPP 356.course_description: This course introduces students to sustainable housing innovations through a critical investigation of housing policy, housing design, land use and building regulations, and overarching logics of human settlement. We will explore housing innovations that present effective solutions to these issues, historically and today, while seeking creative modes in transforming discriminatory logics.

UEPP 359.course_name: Business and Sustainability Principles and Practice
UEPP 359.course_description: This course will provide both a survey and applications of principles and practices in business using environmental ethics, resources conservation, and sustainability frameworks. Also offered as MGMT 359.

UEPP 360.course_name: Plan Graphics and Site Design:  Methods in Urban Design
UEPP 360.course_description: Introduction to the application of graphic design technology to plan design using computer aided design, publication layout, image presentation, and video editing software.

UEPP 368.course_description: Field methods course examining great cities. Concepts and themes in human geography and urban planning provide a framework for the analysis of the human environments and the forces and efforts that shape them. Course is repeatable to a maximum of 12 credits, including original course; course may only be taken once for each destination. Also offered as ENVS 368.

UEPP 369.course_description: Settler Cities represent settler futures, settler ideals, and settler fantasies while attempting to erase Indigenous presence and Indigenous futures. Many North American cities were built upon Indigenous villages, actively removing Indigenous peoples to create settler spaces. As this class will demonstrate, the ongoing project of settler urbanization has not been successful, highlighting the resurgence of Indigenous communities across Turtle Island and the geopolitical extents of the North American settler-state. The course provides a cross-border assessment of Settler Cities between Canada and the United States demonstrating the pervasive systems of settler colonialism and the shared project of Indigenous Futures. Also offered as C/AM 369.

UEPP 370.course_description: Survey of the origins, development, and significance of the planning movement in the United States and the profession that emerged from it. The seminal innovators, practices, and achievements in American planning.

UEPP 373.course_description: Locational and network analysis and modeling of local, regional, and national systems. Also, investigation of alternatives to traditional transportation modes.

UEPP 374.course_description: This course examines the basic tools used to regulate the development and redevelopment of land. The operation and limits of tools such as zoning, subdivision plats, variances, and growth management will be discussed. Examples, which will be reviewed and critiqued, will be drawn from local and state governments. Participants will write various technical documents and interact with planning professionals responsible for writing and implementing land use regulations.

UEPP 375.course_name: Indigenous Placemaking: Decolonizing Space and Place
UEPP 375.course_description: Spatial Knowledge encompasses the production of knowledge through land-based practices. Through the course we will investigate the impacts of colonization on spatial practices and the current dominance of settler-colonialism on Indigenous communities and the continuity of Indigenous knowledge systems. We will explore both spatial knowledge across multiple scales of the Land from macro, meso and micro to the rural - urban divide. Also offered as C/AM 375.

UEPP 400.course_description: An individualized course of study not available through or replacing existing curriculum, to be arranged between one matriculating student and sponsoring faculty member. All academic policies and registration deadlines apply. Directed Independent Study courses cannot substitute for General University Requirements and are not eligible for tuition waiver.

UEPP 410.course_description: Ecological concepts and principles applied to design and management of sustainable food production systems. Consideration given to food and farm politics and economics, as well as the experience of place and policies for relocalization. Includes case studies and laboratory/field experience in sustainable agriculture horticulture and strategies for resilience. Also offered as ENVS 410.

UEPP 411.course_description: Field and project work in agroecology and sustainable agriculture in the context of planning for food security. Integration of ecological principles within socio-cultural-economic systems. Focus on resource cycling and integrated nutrient systems. Combination of field experience, hands-on pratica, case studies and research. Required field trips.

UEPP 415.course_name: Planning Studio: Food Security and Resilient Communities
UEPP 415.course_description: Sustainability planning for food security and community resilience. Project-based learning and research in community vulnerabilities and racialized food distribution structures. Consideration of gender, class, caste in current and future planning. Individual, household, regional, national, international scales considered. Repeatable to a maximum of 9 credits, including original course.

UEPP 429.course_name: Introduction to Urban Design Principles and Methods
UEPP 429.course_description: Introduction to fundamentals of urban design; emphasis on social and spatial aspects of the built environment.

UEPP 439.course_description: Urban design studio; application of principles and methods of urban design in a professional project setting; addresses historical and political dimensions of urban space; emphasis on social justice and equity through socio-spatial practices; includes implementation strategies and techniques.
